NAVITROL USER INSTRUCTIONS - Navitec Systems Oy CONFIDENTIAL

NAVITROL USER INSTRUCTIONS

User Instructions

Updated 20.06.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
NavitrolNavitrol navigation software for positioning
Navigation computerThe computer system running Navitrol.
Navithor ToolsA tool to create the environment model from the teaching data.
NavitrolUpdaterSW tool to install & update Navitrol and parameter overrides
AGV controlThe software controlling the operation of the AGV including dead reckoning positioning. Communicates with Navitrol.
SupervisorOn-board PLC controlling some components of the AGV. Communicates with Navitrol.
RSSILaser scanner signal strength value
IPCIndustrial PC

Overview

Introduction

Navitrol is a positioning and navigation software for AGVs designed by Navitec Systems. While positioning and navigation are the main features, Navitrol is capable of large variety of AGV control tasks, such as:

  • Target and Obstacle detection
  • Pickup and drop-off functionalities
  • Sensor fusion

AGV executing a navigation and load-handling task

The positioning feature provides the position of an AGV in map coordinates. The positioning is based on dead reckoning data combined with laser scanner corrections. The laser scanner corrections are based on matching received 2D measurements to the taught environment. It is possible to use Navitrol for positioning only applications. In these applications Navitrol is typically used for position correction source by control software running on separate hardware.

In the case when Navitrol is being used to control the AGV directly, the Navigation computer is connected directly to the motor controllers and Navitrol controls the output of the motors or commands are sent to other controlling hardware through the Ethernet Supervisor Interface. The navigation feature provides control references for an AGV to drive along predefined routes combining position control with the positioning.

Navitrol requires an environment model for positioning. This model is created by first teaching the environment by driving the AGV manually around the production area and then using Windows-based Tools software to generate environment and routes. In addition a CAD model of the environment can be used for correcting scaling and misalignment issues.

Navitrol is a Linux software run on an IPC installed on the AGV capable of communicating with various sensors and control devices (See Supported Devices).

Requirements

  • Navitrol software runs on Linux Debian operating system.

    • Supported Debian versions are Buster (10) and Bullseye (11). Recommended version for new installations is Bullseye (11)
    • See Linux Image installation

  • IPC must fulfill the Hardware Requirements

  • Navitrol software needs a license to be run. See Licensing for detailed information.

Setup

Quick start

  1. Install and power up the IPC Linux Image installation
  2. Set up the IPC Software for Navitrol
  3. Install or update Navitrol
  4. Configure scanners and setup odometry source for the navigation IPC
  5. Initial Navitrol run
  6. Initial calibration (AGV calibration + teaching the environment)

Set up the IPC Software for Navitrol

Navitrol is run on Linux. Commands are given using a SSH terminal connection over Ethernet. Linux has a Samba file server for transferring files.

Passwords

There are two user accounts that are already set up.

User levelUser namePassword
rootrootnavitrol
usernavitecnavitrol

SSH Terminal Connection

The SSH connection is used for giving commands to Linux. A recommended program for taking connection is Putty.

Putty can be downloaded from: chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty

Set up the IP address to the Host name field and press open to make a connection.

Putty configuration

IPC Network connections

The default IP address of the Navigation computer is 10.10.6.100. If the IP address needs to be changed the modification is done in the location /etc/network/interfaces. Network configurations are explained more detail in:

  • Debian 11 Bullseye Installation - Network configuration
  • Debian 10 Buster Installation - Ethernet configurations

After changing the network configuration a reboot is needed.

Transferring Files

The onboard Linux of the Navigation computer runs as a samba server for transferring files between your Windows computer and the IPC.

The connection can be made using Windows explorer.

Setting the address in Windows explorer

After making the connection the user name and password is asked. Enter the user name navitec and password navitrol.

The simplest way to access Samba network drive is to type \\IPC_IP\\navitec\ to Windows Explorer address line, and then type in credentials. As described above. This can however fail in different ways: Windows may fail to connect at all, or the authentication fails because of Windows trying to force specific domain or username. In all those cases it is worth trying to map the network share as a drive. Mapping can be done with File Explorer or with command prompt.

Other option is to use WinSCP to transfer files: https://winscp.net/eng/index.php

Map network drive
  • Right click "This PC" in File Explorer
  • Select "Map network drive..."
  • Add path \\IPC_IP\\navitec\ to Folder, and check "Connect using different credentials"
    • Don't use windows credentials, instead insert username and password matching Navitrol IPC configuration.
Mount with command line
net use DRIVE: \\\\IPC_IP\\navitec /user:USERNAME PASSWORD

Example:

 net use K: \\\\192.168.1.100\\navitec /user:navitec navitrol

Install or Update Navitrol

Since version 6.28.00 Navitrol software is distributed as Debian installation package. There are two alternative ways to handle software installation. User can either use NavitrolUpdater or directly use Debian Package Manager to handle the installation. Use of NavitrolUpdater is the preferred way when updating several AGV's at a time.

NOTE: If you are installing Navitrol the first time, installation is done from command line

Command line

The package name is Navitrol_version_architecture.deb, for example Navitrol_6.28-0_amd64.deb.

Installation:

  1. Copy the installation package to the Navigation computer using SCP or samba

  2. Open SSH connection to Navigation computer

  3. Gain root privileges using 'su -' command.

  4. Install package with dpkg -i Navitrol_6.28-0_amd64.deb command on linux terminal

  5. Navitrol is now installed to run at startup, but it still needs a licence and the parameter file params.txt

    1. Contact Navitec support for the license and base params.txt file

NavitrolUpdater

  1. Choose what do you want to update, any combination can be selected

    • If Navitrol, check "Update Navitrol" and click "Browse" to select used Navitrol installation package (*.deb)

    • If parameters, check "Update params.txt"

    • If override parameters, check "Update params_override.txt"

    • If environment file, check "Upload Environment file"

  2. Choose the files for each checked option with by pressing "Browse" button for each file

  3. Choose the AGVs that you want to update

    • You can add AGVs to list

    • Only the AGVs that where "Update" is checked are updated

  4. Hit the "Update Selected Navitrol Clients"

NavitrolUpdater - Trouble shooting

Updater does not accept the correct password

Reason: The linux system on the IPC does not allow direct login as super user.

Solution: Enable direct login as super user

  1. Open terminal in the IPC running Navitrol.

  2. Login as super user using "su -" command and navitrol as password

  3. Open sshd_config file using nano /etc/ssh/sshd_config command

  4. Add new line to the file: PermitRootLogin yes (the place of the line does not matter)

  5. Save file with ctrl+s and close it with ctrl+x

  6. Restart the ssh process with /etc/init.d/ssh restart command

Configure scanners and setup odometry source for the navigation IPC

The default IPC that Navitrol is run on is:
VBOX-3121-i3, i3-6300U @ 2.3 GHz, 2 core, 4 threads, 4 GB RAM memory

In order to run Navitrol, the IPC needs to be set up. Minimum setup to use Navitrol for localization:

  • Configure scanners and the IPC ports for the scanners
  • Odometry source for the IPC
    • Enable and configure communication interface(s), see Configure odometry source
    • Connect to communication interface(s) used

Communication interfaces at the back of the IPC

Communication interface on the front of the IPC

Power cable wiring for the IPC

CAN and RS422 serial interface ports

Configure Scanners

Most scanners communicate over Ethernet, but for example the SICK S300 scanners require RS422 serial interface with a communication rate of 500 kbaud. For this communication a standard serial port is replaced with a dual RS422 card. The card is from Diamond Systems, therefore the mark DS below the port, see the figure below. The detailed scanner configuration instructions for each scanner can be found here: Scanner configurations

R2000 UHD LiDAR scanner

Configure odometry source

The most common way to provide odometry data is either through CAN bus or Ethernet supervisor interface. Other options currently are EtherCAT and serial.

In most machine types odometry source is selected automatically, and related communication interface enabled automatically as well. When using specific machine types, such as machine_type_id 44xxxx, odometry source must be defined using parameter odometry_source. More detailed information on odometry source selection and configuration can be found from Odometry Source, that document describing also the parameters used to enable other communication interfaces.

Further instructions for setting up and using different communication interfaces:

  • CAN CAN communication
  • Ethernet interface Ethernet Supervisor Interface
  • EtherCAT interface EtherCAT communication
  • Serial bus, with Roboteq motor controllers only Roboteq Controller Configuration

Check also the list of supported devices or ask additional information from Navitrol support. List of supported devices: Supported Devices

Initial Navitrol run

To run Navitrol on the IPC, the following prerequisites have to be done:

  • IPC installed with Debian Buster (10) or Debian Bullsey (11)
  • Navitrol software package (.deb) installed under /home/navitec folder

After this the initial Navitrol parameters are needed. The initial parameter file is provided by Navitec support.

Parameters

Parameters affecting the operation of Navitrol are in the file params.txt in the /home/Navitec folder. It is a text file which can be edited with any editor which can output a plain text file. Parameters that are not listed in params.txt file are used in Navitrol with their default value

A line in the parameter file may be either a comment line or a parameter line. A comment line starts with # and a parameter line with the parameter type indicator F (Float), S (String), I (Integer) or U (Unsigned Integer).

In addition to the parameter type a parameter line consists of the name of the parameter and the current value. Then there is an optional comment about the parameter. A comma is required between each obligatory item of a parameter definition.

Navitrol reads in the parameter file when it starts. If not being able to parse the parameter file Navitrol does not start but writes about the problem on the terminal. A typical error in the parameter file could be a value outside the minimum and maximum limits. If the real parameter value needs to be set outside the minimum or maximum then the limits must be changed accordingly.

General Parameters
NameTypeDefault valueDescription
machine_type_idInt0ID of the machine type. Provided by Navitec Systems, check Machine types
machine_type_keyUint0Verification key corresponding to the machine type ID. Provided by Navitec systems
dim_frontFloat1.0Dimension of the AGV in meters from the navigation point to the front outer dimension. Beams falling inside the perimeter of the vehicle are skipped. Has to be positive
dim_rearFloat-1.0Dimension of the AGV in meters from the navigation point to the rear outer dimension. Beams falling inside the perimeter of the vehicle are skipped. Has to be negative
dim_leftFloat1.0Dimension of the AGV in meters from the navigation point to the left outer dimension. Beams falling inside the perimeter of the vehicle are skipped. Has to be positive
dim_rightFloat-1.0Dimension of the AGV in meters from the navigation point to the right outer dimension. Beams falling inside the perimeter of the vehicle are skipped. Has to be negative
supervisor_eth_enabledInt0Determines if Navitrol should be expecting messages through the Supervisor or AGV controller interface. 1 for enabled, 0 for disabled.
supervisor_eth_ipString192.168.2.141Supervisor IP address. Needed if Supervisor works as a server
supervisor_eth_portInt5015Supervisor communication server side port
supervisor_eth_serverInt0Defines whether Supervisor is server or client, 0 - client, 1 - server
supervisor_eth_endiannessInt0Defines Supervisor data endianness, 0 - little endian, 1 - big endian
veh_inte_error_message_modeInt20 to not send errors/warnings to PLC/agv controller, 1 to send active errors, 2 to send active errors and warnings
veh_inte_heartbeat_intervalInt0How often to send active errors/warnings to PLC/agv controller in ms
loc_xy_max_corrFloat0.0015Maximum single localization correction for X and Y in meters
loc_h_max_corrFloat0.1500Maximum single localization correction for heading in degrees.
odo_max_interval_msInt60Maximum odometry receive interval in milliseconds. Navitrol gives ERROR_DEADREC_HIGH_DT if time from last odometry update is highen than this parameter
General Position Control System parameters
NameTypeDefault valueDescription
control_interval_usInt30000AGV position control and vehicle interface control interval.
control_interval_error_ratioFloat1.1Defines how much measured control interval can deviate from target (e.g. 1.1 means 10%)
control_interval_max_stdev_usInt1000Defines how much measured control interval standard deviation can be in us
fleet_control_typeInt10 - No fleet control, 1 - Navitec Systems fleet control, 2 - External fleet control, 3 - VD(M)A fleet control
fleet_control_portInt6007TCP port number used for communication with the fleet control server.
machine_idInt1Machine ID number reported to fleet control and other systems

Example format of parameter set from params.txt (with Schwarzmueller Omni drive AGV):

# Parameters specific to each vehicle type
I,machine_type_id,                                            180007 # Id of vehicle type
U,machine_type_key,                                       2381850774 # Verification key of machine type id
F,dim_front,                                                2.300000 # min 0.010000, max 100.000000
F,dim_rear,                                                -1.510000 # min -100.000000, max -0.010000
F,dim_left,                                                 0.870000 # min 0.010000, max 100.000000
F,dim_right,                                               -0.870000 # min -100.000000, max -0.010000
S,supervisor_eth_ip,                                    172.16.12.49 # Supervisor IP address
I,supervisor_eth_server,                                           1 #

More detailed parameters can be found in documents specifying the specific feature in the software. For example, parameters related to actuators can be found in the document Actuator Control.

Navitrol test run

After you have the initial parameters to params.txt under /home/navitec, you can run Navitrol with Linux terminal command (as root user):

./Navitrol

After a successful test run (Navitrol starts running on terminal), proceed to the Initial calibration Guide.

Troubleshooting

Most Common issues

Navitrol does not run with command ./Navitrol

  • Check that you have installed Navitrol to /home/navitec: 
dpkg -s navitrol
  • Check that you have working parameters that Navitrol can parse. Navitec Support will provide you the parameters

Cannot change parameters from params.txt

params.txt file might need permissions for reading and writing. The permissions can be added with linux command:

cd /home/navitec
chmod +rw params.txt

Advanced Troubleshooting

Logging Functions

Navitrol provides a list of commands that can be used in order to write specific log messages to files and/or view them in real time. Amount of log lines and the threads of interest can be also specified manually. Loggings functionalities are explained on their own document Logging

Navitrol Licensing

Updated 11.06.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
FingerprintingA method for uniquely identifying the target where application runs.
Device-locked licenseDevice-locked licensing uses target fingerprinting and locks the license to the target.
Floating licenseFloating license is not locked to any specific target/HW. When a licensed software is started it leases a license from the License Server and frees the license when it shuts down. With Floating license the number of simultaneously running instances is limited by the license.
Lease durationA time that a Floating license lease is valid without renewal.
License ServerNavitec Systems application that manages creation and updates of all licenses.
Server sync intervalThe interval for server syncs by a licensed software when using online (Floating license) licensing model.
Trusted Platform Module (TPM)TPM is an international standard for a secure crypto-processor, and it is designed to provide hardware-based, security-related functions.

Overview

Navitrol supports two different licensing methods, Legacy license and Regular license. Legacy licensing model has been used from the early days of Navitrol. It does however have multiple practical limitations, and therefore new licensing method, Regular licensing, has been introduced.

Regular licensing is the recommended future-proof solution. Existing Legacy licenses are still supported, but all new (or future) licensed features are not supported by Legacy licensing method.

Current license details

Detailed information about Navitrol license for a connected Navitrol can be seen in Monitor by selecting "Help-About" from menu.

All this information is also logged in the beginning of each text log file (startlog.txt and log.txt). Examples of logged data are shown in the following chapters.

NOTE: Hardware and license details are different in each case, as they depend on the hardware, licensing model and licensed options in use. Therefore, any license details shown in this document are just examples of one specific case.

Licensing method selection

Licensing method (Regular vs. Legacy) used is selected at run-time by Navitrol. Regular licensing is prioritized, and it is used if license file LicenseDetails.json exists on the system. See Regular license below for details. If there is no LicenseDetails.json file, Navitrol switches to Legacy licensing method for backward compatibility. It is only the existence of this file that matters. If license file exists, but has invalid data or format, then Navitrol still sticks to Regular licensing and raises a related error.

In the beginning of each text log file there is some information about run-time system and licensing method used. The section that shows license information is referred here as a license section.

In case of Regular licensing being used, text logs starts with:

Mon May 27 10:36:26 2024

Navitrol 6.53.02 99083666 2024-05-27T07:31:25+00:00 for machine type 440001
Debian GNU/Linux 11 (bullseye)
RT Kernel 5.10.0-23-rt-amd64

Board SMB-2600 by Sintrones Technology Corp.
BIOS by American Megatrends Inc.
CPU Intel(R) Celeron(R) 2980U @ 1.60GHz
CPU 2 cores, clock 1596.38 MHz
TotalMem 7869 MiB, TotalSwap 3905 MiB, TotalStorage 52.56 GiB

REGULAR licensing used (LibVer 3.21.2) - Activation mode DeviceLocked
Normal Fingerprint
LicenseKey 0744E5-925FE1-40BCAB-0D53DE-1207EB-614120

In case of Legacy licensing being used, license section starts with:

LEGACY licensing used
License id,key 4091113304772258577,13541695821371515033

License models

Regular licensing supports different licensing models. The currently available ones are

  • Offline Device-locked license
  • Floating license

Legacy licensing supports only Offline Device-locked licenses.

Backward and forward compatibility

Navitrol can use any license created for older SW version, assuring full backward compatibility.

Regular licensing provides full forward compatibility as well. Legacy licensing on the other hand has limitations with forward compatibility. It is not guaranteed that license created for a specific Navitrol version would be usable with older Navitrol versions.

Basic license

A basic license is simply a license to run Navitrol without additional licensed options.

License with options

A license with options is a license to run Navitrol with predefined additional licensed options. A license in this case includes information about all enabled licensed options/features.

In Legacy licensing all licensed features are enabled by specific parameters.

Regular licensing uses the same parameters and mechanisms for old license options, but licensed option can also be tied to something else than parameter values (like kinematic type of the machine).

All enabled license options are logged into beginning of the text log files in license section:

LEGACY licensing used
License id,key 9439414948331747385,14605972011522150860
Valid license with options in use
License for option "Dynamic Mapping Server" in use
License for option "Route Driver" in use
License for option "Precision Positioning" in use
License for option "Target Detection" in use
License for option "External Localization" in use
License for option "Obstacle Avoidance" in use
License for option "Warehouse Racking" in use
License for option "3D Object detection" in use

Regular license

Regular licensing has several benefits over Legacy licensing from user point of view, like:

  • More license models - supports currently Offline Device-locked license and Floating license. More options available later.
  • All current and future license options/features are supported.
  • Full forward and backward compatibility for licenses created for other SW version.
  • License validation time is quite deterministic, typically instant. Time may vary with Online licensing models (Floating license).
  • Possibility for time limited trial licenses.
  • Possibility for more tailored licensing models and fingerprinting methods in the future.

Activation mode

License models in Regular license concept are called activation modes. The two Regular license activation modes at the moment are:

  • DeviceLocked - Uses Offline Device-locked license. Device-locked license uses target fingerprinting and locks the license to the target.
  • Floating - Floating license is not locked to any specific target/HW. When a licensed software is started it leases a license from the License Server. The License Server allocates a license for that instance (or target) if there is a free license available. Licensed software needs to renew the lease periodically, and finally free the license when it shuts down. This method limits the number of instances that can run at the same time. All licensed software instances need an Internet connection for communicating with the License Server at run time.

Files

Files related to the use of a Regular license are described in the table below.

FileContent and scopeOffline
activation		Online
activation
License file
LicenseDetails.json		Provides information to Navitrol for license activation and validation.
Required for all licensing models. Format and content shown below.		XX
Offline activation request file
LicenseOfflineRequest.gz		Created by Navitrol on user request.
Content used by License Server for offline activation.		X-
Offline activation response file
LicenseOfflineResponse.dat		Created by the License Server when making offline activation on the server side.
Navitrol uses this file as input for offline activation at target.		X-

NOTE: All of these files are automatically generated and should never be modified manually. Regular licensing has cross-checks for all the relevant information built-in. If information in these files is modified, license activation or validation fails.

License file LicenseDetails.json

A license file in a target system is mandatory for Regular licensing to work. License file is required for all licensing models. This JSON formatted file provides information for license activation and validation, most important ones being the LicenseKey and ActivationMode.

Mandatory license file information from Navitrol point of view include:

  • Product Shall be NavigationSoftware. Anything else results in license file rejection as license is not meant to be used with Navitrol.
  • LicenseKey Created by the License Server. License key is used for license activation and validation.
  • ActivationMode Activation mode to be used by Navitrol (shall be one of the predefined values: DeviceLocked, Floating).

An example license file content having mandatory information only is shown below.

  {
    "LicenseKey": "3A432A-E840E3-42F7AB-A35E2E-6D0317-F69792",
    "ActivationMode" : "DeviceLocked",
    "Product": "NavigationSoftware"
  }

A license file may contain additional information as well. Optional license file information includes:

  • FileGenerationDate - License generation date is typically included, but not regarded as mandatory information by Navitrol.
  • Custom fingerprinting - License can be defined by the License Server to use a specific custom fingerprinting method. In such a case, details are defined in a license file.

How to set up a Regular license

Steps to set up a Regular license are:

  • Order a license from Navitec Systems. Process starts with creating the license in the License Server. Basic information needed in this phase are:
    • License options that shall be included in the license, including machine kinematics.
    • Target system - Navitrol running on a bare HW, a Virtual machine or a Container. NOTE: Navitec Systems may limit the target options available. Trying to activate license in a VM/Container if that is not allowed, results in an error.
    • Other things to decide at this phase are
      • Fingerprinting method - Valid for Node-Locked licenses only.
      • Validity
        • Time - By default a license is perpetual, like in Legacy licensing. There is a possibility to define a limited Validity time.
        • SW versions - By default a license is not version limited. License can be limited up to a specific SW release version only.
      • Possible trial license and trial period
      • + more
  • When detailed license information is known, license can be created in the License Server.
  • License Server provides the license file LicenseDetails.json.
  • License file LicenseDetails.json is copied to target system sub-folder ./license (/home/navitec/license).
  • After that license needs to be activated and validated. Steps required for activation depend on a license activation mode used. See License activation and License validation below for details.

License activation

Unlike in the Legacy licensing method, each license must be activated before being valid. License activation always involves the License Server which keeps track of created and activated licenses.

Prerequisite is the license file LicenseDetails.json existing in target system sub-folder ./license (/home/navitec/license).

Activating Offline Device-locked license

Offline Device-locked license activation is clearly separated from validation. Creating offline request file and offline activation are done only on user request using commands shown below. Running these commands requires root privileges.

Steps are:

  1. Generate offline request file LicenseOfflineRequest.gz file on sub-folder ./license by issuing the command 

    root@navitec:~$ ./Navitrol licreq

    On successful command one should see on the console:

    Packed license request files to: "./license/LicenseOfflineRequest.gz"
DeviceLocked license request file creation SUCCESSFUL

  2. Provide the LicenseOfflineRequest.gz file generated in target HW for license generation.

  3. Offline response file LicenseOfflineResponse.dat is generated on the License Server using offline request file as input.

  4. Offline response file is transferred/copied to Navitrol ./license folder.

  5. Activate license in Navitrol by issuing command 

    root@navitec:~$ ./Navitrol licact

    This command uses the license file and the offline response file as input. On successful activation one should see on the console:

    DeviceLocked license activation SUCCESSFUL

Activating Floating license

Floating license activation (license leasing) is performed automatically at each startup. After successful activation/lease, Navitrol periodically validates and renews the license.

License deactivation

Floating licenses are automatically deactivated by Navitrol at each exit/shut-down, which frees the leased license for someone else to lease. If Navitrol for any reason fails to do that (like communication not working), license re-activation or leasing is not possible until lease time is over. When lease time expires without client sync to server, license lease will be freed by the License Server. Server sync interval is defined in the license by the License Server.

Other than Floating licenses are never deactivated by Navitrol.

License validation

Successful license activation already means that license itself is valid at that time. At run-time Navitrol periodically validates the license and in case of Floating license renews the license. License validation may fail at any time for example if some license option is used without having such an option included in the license. Floating license validation may fail also if connection to License Server is lost for too long time.

There are more possibilities why validation can fail, like license expiry in case of time limited license.

Validity - time

By default licenses are created perpetual, i.e. for unlimited time. If a license has a limited Validity time, that is checked by Navitrol at run-time. Navitrol logs validity information and expiration time in text log, and optionally raises a warning WARNING_LICENSE_EXPIRATION when a time limited license is about to expire soon. This warning period is defined with a parameter license_warning_period_days. Warning can be disabled by setting this parameter to 0.

Validity - SW version

If a license has SW release version limitation, that is checked by Navitrol at start-up. Navitrol uses two digit version number (MAJOR.MINOR) to check this, which means that hotfixes are always allowed even if SW version limitation is defined.

System time

System time being wrong or being tampered with, may result in license activation or validation to fail.

Navitrol checks and monitors also system time on target to

  • be close enough the network time (Online).
  • not being tampered with, like time moved backwards.

Time is allowed to move backwards only a limited amount to allow time changes related to day-time saving. If substantially larger time adjustments are detected, this is indicated as an error when activating or validating the license.

Trial license

Trial licenses can be created for testing purposes.

NOTE: Navitrol requires that each Trial license is time limited. If a Validity time is not defined (unlimited) in a Trial license, Navitrol raises an error ERROR_LICENSE_CONTENT.

Parameter summary

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
license_server_addrString""License Server URL used for Floating license - ask for correct setting from Navitec Systems support
license_warning_period_daysInt0Defines pre-warning time for time limited license expiry
ads_enabledInt0Enables ADS feature - see note below
ads_server_ipString0IP adress for remote ADS Server - see note below
ads_server_netidString0NetID for remote ADS server - see note below

NOTE: ads_* parameters are relevant from licensing point of view only if Navitrol is run in Beckhoff IPC. Contact Navitec support for detailed information.

Legacy license

Legacy licensing method is supported for now for backwards compatibility. Missing license will result in immediate ERROR_NO_LICENSE_CODE, so there is no more option to drive without a license.

Legacy licensing has some practical limitations and short-comings from user point of view, like:

  • Limited license models - supports only Offline Device-locked license.
  • Limited amount of license options/features supported. Any recently created or future license options are not supported.
  • Limited forward compatibility for licenses created for other SW version.
  • License validation time can be rather long - in the worst case validation can take minutes.
  • No trial licenses.

How to set up a Legacy license

Steps to set up a Legacy license are:

  • After Navitrol has run once successfully, a license.txt file is generated in folder /home/navitec.
  • When ordering a license, one needs to define all the license options shall be included in the license.
  • Provide the license.txt file generated in target HW for license generation.
  • License is generated by the License Server and license is provided as a licensekey.txt file.
  • File licensekey.txt is copied to Navitrol run folder (/home/navitec).
  • License is validated each time Navitrol is restarted.

Troubleshooting

Logging and console output

All details related to logging and console output are subject to change. The basic principles will not however change.

Text log license section

Licensing method, license options enabled, and other relevant license information are logged in the license section beginning of each text log file.

Invalid license

REGULAR licensing used - License model DeviceLocked
Normal Fingerprint
LicenseKey 3A432A-E830E3-42FFAB-A35E2E-6D0317-F69792
License validation error: The release version is not allowed.
No valid license or license not validated

Valid license without options and limitations

REGULAR licensing used - License model Floating
LicenseKey 258487-493DB4-4E0797-0896F5-4BA43D-988381
License is not time limited
License is not limited by SW version
Valid license with no options in use

Valid license with options and limitations

REGULAR licensing used - License model Floating
LicenseKey 258487-493DB4-4E0797-0896F5-4BA43D-988381
License Expiry 2024.10.30
License is limited to SW version 6.58
Valid license with options in use
License for option "WarehouseRacking" in use
License for option "DrivingDiffSteer" in use

Logging prefix

License related logging in text logs has a prefix "LIC:", making search for license related log lines easier.

0.7046 [-1:6]  LIC: License file read OK (status 1), KEY "3A432A-E830E3-42FFAB-A35E2E-6D0317-F69792"
0.7050 [-1:2]  LIC: SetProductData - Success
0.7056 [-1:2]  LIC: SetProductId - Success
0.7061 [-1:2]  LIC: SetLicenseKey - Success
0.7061 [-1:2]  LIC: SetReleaseVersion - Success
0.7340 [-1:2]  LIC: IsLicenseGenuine - The release version is not allowed.
0.7340 [-1:6]  LIC: License is not valid or not activated

This prefix is not used on console commands, like ./Navitrol licact. 

0.1363 [-9:2]  SetProductData - Success
0.1369 [-9:2]  SetProductId - Success
0.1376 [-9:2]  SetLicenseKey - Success
0.1376 [-9:2]  SetReleaseVersion - Success

License method

License method used is logged in license section of text logs:

In case of Regular licensing being used this license section starts with:

REGULAR licensing used (LibVer 3.21.2) - Activation mode DeviceLocked
Normal Fingerprint
LicenseKey 0744E5-925FE1-40BCAB-0D53DE-1207EB-614120

In case of Legacy licensing being used this license section starts with:

LEGACY licensing used
License id,key 4091113304772258577,13541695821371515033

Enabled license options

All enabled license options are logged in license section of text log files. All options are logged in same style, regardless whether they are tied to parameters or something else:

LEGACY licensing used
License id,key 9439414948331747385,14605972011522150860
Valid license with options in use
License for option "Dynamic Mapping Server" in use
License for option "Route Driver" in use
License for option "Precision Positioning" in use
License for option "Target Detection" in use
License for option "External Localization" in use
License for option "Obstacle Avoidance" in use
License for option "Warehouse Racking" in use
License for option "3D Object detection" in use

Obsolete license options

License may contain obsolete options. Those are logged as shown below, telling also which option should be used instead.

LEGACY licensing used
License id,key 9439414948331747385,14605972011522150860
Valid license with options in use
License for obsolete option "Line Following" defined - license for option "External Localization" is expected instead
License for obsolete option "External Localization - Docking" defined - license for option "External Localization" is expected instead

Missing license options

Logging/console output for missing license options based on parameters looks like

1.4530 [-1:1]  LIC: Required License Option missing for StandAlone  parameter: I,route_driver_enabled

There is same kind of output for options not based on parameters

0.7627 [-1:1]  LIC: Required License Option missing for DrivingDiffSteer

Errors and Warnings

351 WARNING_LICENSE_EXPIRATION

Time limited license is about to expire soon. Time period is defined with parameter license_warning_period_days. Warning can be disabled by setting this parameter to 0.

106 ERROR_NO_LICENSE_CODE

No valid license or license not yet activated.

217 ERROR_LICENSE_OPTION_MISSING

License doesn't include permission to use a feature that has been activated.

228 ERROR_LICENSE_FILE

License file invalid - missing or conflicting data in license file. Typical reason is:

  • License file is manually manipulated.

229 ERROR_LICENSE_CONTENT

License file information conflicts with the license content or license content is inconsistent. Possible reasons are:

  • License file is manually manipulated.
  • Trial license defined without validity.

Odometry Source

Updated 15.03.2024

Overview

Introduction

Very fundamental functionality for Navitrol in all installations is positioning. Positioning is in most situations based on odometry data combined with other sensor data.

The interface for providing the odometry data is called odometry source. This same interface is assumed to be the primary control interface as well. It is quite typical that several Navitrol communication interfaces, such as CAN and Ethernet supervisor, are used at the same time. In all cases, one of the interfaces is selected to be the odometry source.

Setup

Configuring odometry source

With most machine types (parameter machine_type_id) odometry source is selected automatically, and then related communication interface is also enabled automatically. Corresponding parameter values (odometry_source and specific "bus_enabled" parameter for corresponding interface) are in those cases ignored. Additional communication interfaces can be enabled as needed using parameters (see table below).

When using some specific machine types, such as machine_type_id 44xxxx (meaning 440000 - 449999), the odometry source must be explicitly defined using parameter odometry_source. Also in this case corresponding primary communication interface is enabled automatically. Any additional communication interfaces used must be enabled using corresponding parameters.

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
odometry_sourceInt0Odometry source (primary control interface)
0 = Undefined
1 = CAN
2 = Supervisor Ethernet
3 = EtherCAT
4 = Serial

Effective only for machine_type_id 44xxxx.
can_enabledInt00 - CAN interface not enabled
1 - CAN interface enabled

Effective only if odometry source is not CAN
supervisor_eth_enabledInt00 - Supervisor Ethernet interface not enabled
1 - Supervisor Ethernet interface enabled

Effective only if odometry source is not Supervisor Ethernet
ethercat_enabledInt00 - EtherCAT interface not enabled
1 - EtherCAT interface enabled

Effective only if odometry source is not EtherCAT

NOTE: There is no specific parameter to enable serial interface. Serial interface is always enabled automatically for any device using serial communication.

Machine types and odometry source

As already mentioned, with most machine types the odometry source is selected automatically. Machine type to use is always defined by Navitec Systems, and set in parameter machine_type_id.

The following table shows odometry source for different machines types.

Machine Type IdOdometry source
10009Serial
10012CAN
10013 -10014Serial
10016CAN
10017 - 10021Ethernet Supervisor
10022CAN
10024 - 10025Ethernet Supervisor
2xxxxEthernet Supervisor - Positioning only
30001Proprietary
31001Ethernet Supervisor
5xxxx - 7xxxxEthernet Supervisor - Positioning only
90001Ethernet Supervisor - Positioning only
90002 - 90003Ethernet Supervisor
11xxxx -13xxxxCAN
14xxxx - 15xxxxEthernet Supervisor - Positioning only
150001 is the recommended generic positioning only machine type
160001 - 160003Serial
160004CAN
17xxxx - 18xxxxCAN
190001Serial
190002 - 190004Ethernet Supervisor
20xxxx - 26xxxxCAN
27xxxxEthernet Supervisor
28xxxx - 29xxxxCAN
31xxxxEthernet Supervisor
32xxxx - 40xxxxCAN
41xxxxEtherCAT
42xxxxCAN
43xxxxProprietary
44xxxxConfigured using parameter odometry_source
45xxxxCAN

Troubleshooting

There are very few things that can go wrong with odometry source configuration, especially as it is in most cases automatically selected.

ERRORS AND WARNINGS

ERROR_ODOMETRY_SOURCE

Description:

  • This error indicates that the odometry source is not defined preventing Navitrol from positioning.

Possible error reason:

  • Parameter odometry_source has not been properly defined.

How to recover:

  • If you are using one of the 44xxxx machine types, check that odometry source is defined using parameter odometry_source.
  • If you are not using one of the 44xxxx machine types, contact Navitec Systems support.

ERROR_VEH_INTE_NOT_READY

Description:

  • This error indicates that Navitrol's primary vehicle interface is not operational preventing operation.

Possible error reasons:

  • Odometry source improperly defined.
  • Communication interface for odometry source not properly configured.
  • Communication interface for odometry source not properly connected.
  • Communication interface bus for odometry source not operational.

How to recover:

  • If you are using one of the 44xxxx machine types, check that right odometry source is defined using parameter odometry_source.
  • Check that all communication related parameters are properly defined, and all connections are ok.
  • Check that selected communication bus is operational.

Initial Calibration Guide

Updated 26.01.2024

Introduction

Navitrol determines the position of the vehicle based on its two main data sources: odometry and scanner data. The odometry is used for the dead reckoning calculation which the scanner data then validate and correct. If these do not comply with the reality, the AGV might lose its position and/or drive very poorly. Thus, the calibration process is one of the most fundamental steps in the commissioning of an AGV and it is only possible to achieve good results if it is done properly.

The procedure can be divided into several steps as it ranges from adjusting scanner positions to tuning the control gains of advanced position control features. To achieve the best results, it is recommended to follow the order given in this document. Furthermore, since Navitrol supports several different kinematic types (see section 2.1), some sections might be redundant for the vehicle of interest. Therefore, sections relevant to only some kinematic types are marked by their abbreviations.

Machine Types

Navitrol supports a variety of different kinematic types. In this document, the following ones are covered:

  • Differential drive (D)
  • Mecanum drive (M)
  • Omni drive (O)
  • Steer drive (S)
  • Differential sub-unit for Steer (DS) and Omni (DO)

In addition to this, there are different communication alternatives and other options that can be tailored for the specific vehicle and since the control process varies a lot between the different combinations, it is important that Navitrol knows how to distinguish between them. This is defined by the so-called machine type ID and the associated machine type key in the Navitrol parameter file params.txt:

ParameterDescription
I,machine_type_idID of the machine type.
U,machine_type_keyVerification key corresponding to the machine type ID.

The values for these parameters are provided by Navitec Systems.

Vehicle Coordinate System

Each vehicle has its own internal coordinate system with its origin in the so-called navigation point. The system orientation in relation to the vehicle frame is defined such that the x-axis points towards the front of the vehicle and the y-axis towards the vehicle's left side, see Figure 1.

Figure 1: Vehicle coordinate system.

Initial Configurations

Navitrol relies on measurements and configuration settings specified by the user when computing the dead reckoning and position corrections using scanner data. It is important that these are set precisely as even small offsets can cause large deviations in the position calculation and if the reader has access to the CAD model it is recommended to start from this. All coordinates are given in relation to the vehicles internal coordinate system.

At this stage of the calibration process, it is recommended to keep the vehicle off the ground to minimize the risk of any accident.

Deactivate Features Disturbing The Calibration

Some features of Navitrol should be disabled during the calibration process as they otherwise have a negative impact on the result:

  • Disable sensor fusion by setting I,sf_use_sensor_fusion to zero.

  • Disable the automatic odometry correction by setting the following parameter to zero:

    • F,odo_err_est_alpha

Control Interval

The control interval specifies at what rate Navitrol should expect to receive the control messages. If Navitrol has a direct connection to the motor controller, then this would be the message time interval between Navitrol and the motor controller itself. However, if Navitrol is connected to the motor controllers via a PLC/PC, then the control interval is defined between Navitrol and PLC/PC instead.

Set the specified interval and error ratios with the following parameters:

ParameterDescription
I,control_interval_usControl message interval in microseconds.
F,control_interval_error_ratioDefines how much the measured control interval can deviate from target (e.g. 1.1 means 10%).
I,control_interval_max_stdev_usDefines how much the measured control interval standard deviation can be in microseconds.

Vehicle Frame Dimensions

Scanner points hitting objects within the vehicle frame needs to be filtered out to avoid their negative impact on the localization properties. If the dimensions are set properly, one will see that Navitrol Monitor renders these points as gray:

ParameterDescription
F,dim_frontdistance from the navigation point to the front of the vehicle along the x-axis.
F,dim_reardistance from the navigation point to the rear of the vehicle along the x-axis.
F,dim_leftdistance from the navigation point to the left side of the vehicle along the y-axis.
F,dim_rightdistance from the navigation point to the left side of the vehicle along the y-axis.

Localization Scanners

Navitrol supports up to two separate localization scanners and their orientations and positions are defined by the following parameters in params.txt:

ParameterDescription
F,scan_rear_xrear scanner x-coordinate.
F,scan_rear_yrear scanner y-coordinate.
F,scan_front_xfront scanner x-coordinate.
F,scan_front_yfront scanner y-coordinate.
I,scan_rear_upside_down1 if rear scanner is mounted upside down.
I,scan_front_upside_down1 if front scanner is mounted upside down.
F,scan_rear_sen_angangular offset between the coordinate system of the rear scanner and the coordinate system of the vehicle.
F,scan_front_sen_angangular offset between the coordinate system of the front scanner and the coordinate system of the vehicle.

NOTE! Depending on how many scanners that are used for localization or target detection, some of these parameters might be redundant. Navitrol Monitor can be used to visually estimate whether the values are roughly correct, for example by placing the vehicle next to straight wall and verifying that the scanner views are matching.

Vehicle Wheel Positions and Configurations

The dead reckoning calculation uses the wheel positions and the encoder information to determine how the vehicle is moving. Depending on the kinematic type, different information is required. If not mentioned specifically, distance parameters should also include the sign according to the vehicle's coordinate system.

Differential drive

For the differential drive, the wheel positions are specified by a single parameter as they are symmetrical around the navigation point:

ParameterDescription
F,wheel_trackabsolute distance between the driving wheels along the y-axis.

Mecanum drive

In addition to the wheel_track parameter, mecanum vehicles also require information about the distance to the driving wheels along the x-axis:

ParameterDescription
F,wheel_trackabsolute distance between the driving wheels along the y-axis.
F,wheel_distabsolute distance between the driving wheels along the x-axis.

Omni drive

Since Navitrol supports up to six individual omni wheels, most of the omni specific parameters are defined as arrays with index i = 0,1,...,5. These indices may be defined arbitrary by the user but should start from zero and remain consistent between the parameters.

ParameterDescription
F,wheel_x[i]x-coordinate of the wheel with index i.
F,wheel_y[i]y-coordinate of the wheel with index i.
F,wheel_y_off[i]wheel offset from turning axle of the wheel with index i (y in vehicle coordinates when straight).

The dead reckoning is computed based on encoder data from two individual wheels. The wheels that are used for this are specified in the Navitrol parameter file with the parameter I,omni_deadrec_ref_axle[i]. A general guideline is that the selected wheels should not be lined up parallel to either the x-axis or the y-axis and that the greater the distance between them the better. An example of this can bee seen in Figure 2.

Figure 2: Example of which combination of wheels that together are viable for dead reckoning. The wheels with the same color make a viable pair.

I,mot_ctrl_omni_speed_control_used[i] should be set to determine which wheels are used for speed control and finally I,maintain_omni_kinematics should be set to 1 if the motor controller is not able to handle rapid large changes in the reference value, otherwise it should be 0.

Steer drive

Steer driven vehicles require two parameters to specify the wheel configuration:

ParameterDescription
F,wheel_distdistance from the navigation point to the center point of the driving wheel along the x-axis.
F,wheel_off_centerdistance from the navigation point to the center point of the driving wheel along the y-axis.

Differential Sub-unit

ParameterDescription
Omni
F,wheel_x[i]x-coordinate of the sub-unit center point with sub-unit index i.
F,wheel_y[i]y-coordinate of the sub-unit center point with sub-unit index i.
Steer
F,wheel_distDistance between navigation point and sub-unit center point.
Common for both Omni and Steer
F,sub_diff_wheel_trackDistance between the centers of the wheels in differential steer-drive wheel unit.

w = sub_diff_wheel_track parameter.

Wheel Control source

The wheel control source depends on the motor controllers and interface being used (for example CAN, Ethercat or Ethernet Supervisor). Configure the parameters based on what control source/communication interface is utilized. The different wheel control source parameters can be found from the following documents:

  • CAN and EtherCat wheel control source configurations : Motor controllers common
  • Ethernet Supervisor wheel control source configurations : Communication specification between Navitrol and Ethernet supervisor

Steer Encoders (O, S, DO, DS)

Two of the kinematic types, omni drive and steer drive (+ differential sub-units), rely on an absolute encoder to determine the orientation of their wheels. Due to variations among the different models, Navitrol requires the user to define the specifications in params.txt. Among other things, this includes defining the resolution of the encoder.

Omni drive

The parameters that should be defined/calibrated if Navitrol receives the raw data directly from the encode are:

ParameterDescription
U,omni_steer_enc_pulses_overflow[i]should be set to the decimal value of the total resolution. This means that if the total resolution is given by e.g. 25 bits, then the parameter should be set to 33.554.431.
U,omni_steer_enc_pulses_per_rev[i]should be set to the amount of pulses per wheel revolution of the encoder. A possible gear ratio must be considered.
U,omni_steer_enc_zero[i]should be set to the pulse count that corresponds to the zero angle (wheel facing forward).
This needs to be calibrated after the mounting of the encoder.
I,omni_enc_steer_node_id[i]is the CANOpen id of the steer encoder.
I,can_steer_enc_modelshould be set to either
0 = generic (no config)
1 = Leine&Linde (RSA608)
2 = Sick (AHS/AHM36)

The only parameter that must be tuned manually is omni_steer_enc_zero since the rest of the parameters are not dependent on the mounting. At this stage, estimate the zero level by physically setting the steer wheel as straight as possible and read the pulse count from terminal with the command: .\\Navitroldumpl0 "CanAbsEncoderParseRxMsgRPDO1node" or .\\Navitroldumpl0 "CanAbsEncoderParseRxMsgRPDO2 node" depending on the encoder model.

If EtherCAT is used as a control interface, check the encoder parameters and command for tuning encoder zero from Ethercat encoder document.

When Navitrol is not receiving raw encoder data directly from absolute encoder, then it is possible to calibrate the zero angle by adjusting the angular offset with the parameter F,omni_steer_ang_offset_deg[i] [deg].

Steer drive:

The parameters that should be defined/calibrated if Navitrol receives the raw data directly from the encode are:

ParameterDescription
U,steer_enc_pulses_overflowshould be set to the decimal value of the total resolution. This means that if the total resolution is given by e.g. 25 bits, then the parameter should be set to 33.554.431.
I,steer_enc_pulses_per_revshould be set to the amount of pulses per wheel revolution of the encoder. An possible gear ratio must be considered.
I,can_steer_enc_zeroshould be set to the pulse count that corresponds to angle 0 (wheel facing forward). This needs to be calibrated after the mounting of the encoder.
I,can_enc_steer_node_idIs the CANOpen id of the steer encoder.
I,can_steer_enc_modelShould be set to either
0 = generic (no config)
1 = Leine&Linde (RSA608)
2 = Sick (AHS/AHM36)

The only parameter that must be tuned manually is can_steer_enc_zero since the rest of the parameters are not dependent on the mounting. At this stage, estimate the zero level by physically setting the steer wheel as straight as possible and read the pulse count from terminal with the command: .\Navitroldumpl0 "CanAbsEncoderParseRxMsgRPDO1node" or .\Navitroldumpl0 "CanAbsEncoderParseRxMsgRPDO2 node" depending on the encoder model.

When Navitrol is not receiving raw encoder data directly from a CAN absolute encoder, then it is possible to calibrate the zero angle by adjusting the angular offset with the parameter F,mot_ctrl_steer_ang_offset_deg [deg].

Odometry Scale

Since Navitrol often receives odometry information expressed in angular velocities or in encoder pulses, it is necessary to convert these values internally to something that might be used for the dead reckoning calculations. How this conversion is done depends on the source of the odometry.

Velocity Calculated from Encoder Pulses

If the odometry is read from an incremental encoder or through the Supervisor interface, the conversion rate from a single pulse to meters needs to be defined. The scaling factor is defined by:

\( odometry\ scale = \frac{\pi\ \ *(\ Wheel\ diameter\ \lbrack m\rbrack)}{(Pulses\ per\ revolution)\ *(Gear\ ratio)} \)

It is set by the Navitrol parameter F,mot_ctrl_drive_dist_scale for all kinematic types except for differential drive which uses F,mot_ctrl_left_dist_scale and F,mot_ctrl_right_dist_scale for the left and right wheel respectively.

Velocity Calculated from Motor RPM

If the odometry is calculated from an RPM value stated by the motor controller, then the scaling factor is defined by:

\( odometry\ scale = \frac{\pi\ \ *(\ Wheel\ diameter\ \lbrack m\rbrack)}{60 *(Gear\ ratio)} \)

It is set by the Navitrol parameter mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_s.

Wheel Spinning and Steering Direction

Depending on how the mechanical parts have been mounted it might be necessary to invert the input and/or output speed such that the sign of the calculated velocity is correct. The verification is commonly done using the keyboard control of Navitrol Monitor.

The Navitrol parameters that regulate the sign of the input and output depends on the machine type of the vehicle, although the idea is the same:

  • If the wheels physically spin in the opposite direction of the reference, then the output should be inverted.

  • If the wheel spinning direction in Navitrol monitor is incorrect, then the input should be inverted (see Figure 3).

Figure 3: The wheel spinning direction is visualized by the wheel arrows in Navitrol Monitor. Green corresponds to forward/positive while red corresponds to reverse/negative.

Additionally, for machine types with steering wheels, one should also verify the steering direction of the wheels.

Differential drive

  • I,mot_ctrl_left_inv_out = 1 to invert output for the left motor.

  • I,mot_ctrl_right_inv_out = 1 to invert output for the right motor.

  • Change the sign of F,mot_ctrl_left_dist_scale to invert the input.

  • Change the sign of F,mot_ctrl_right_dist_scale to invert the input.

Mecanum drive

  • I,mot_ctrl_mecanum_inv_output[i] = 1 to invert output for the motor.

  • I,mot_ctrl_mecanum_inv_input[i] = 1 to invert input for the motor.

Omni drive

  • I,mot_ctrl_omni_speed_inv_output[i] = 1 to invert the output for the drive motor.

  • I,mot_ctrl_omni_speed_inv_input[i] = 1 to invert the input for the drive motor.

  • I,mot_ctrl_omni_steer_inv_output[i] = 1 to invert the output for the steer motor.

  • I,mot_ctrl_omni_steer_inv_input[i] = 1 to invert the input for the steer motor.

Steer drive

  • I,mot_ctrl_wheel_v_inv_out = 1 to invert the output for the drive motor.

  • I,mot_ctrl_steer_v_inv_out = 1 to invert the output for the steer motor.

  • I,mot_ctrl_steer_v_inv_in = 1 to invert the input for the steer motor.

Differential Sub-units

Do not use Omni or Steer inversion parameters with differential sub-units.

Navitrol Monitor shows normally the main kinematic wheels (Omni or Steer), but the sub-unit wheels can be shown from the following setting:

Show sub-unit wheels on Navitrol Monitor.

Easy way to check omni sub-units driving directions is to first enable only one sub-unit by setting the omni_steer_nbr parameter to 1 and check that both right and left spins to correct directions in real and in Navitrol Monitor. Then increasing the omni_steer_nbr by one and checking the next sub-unit and so on until all sub-units are correct.

Showing Omni wheel 0 index as normal wheel (left figure) and as sub-unit (right figure). Wheels spinning forward.

Showing Omni wheels 0 and 1 indices as normal wheels (left figure) and as sub-units (right figure). Wheels spinning forward.

i = index of the wheel. For Steer drive, i is always 0. For Omni Drive, i is the omni wheel index.

  • I,mot_ctrl_diffunit_left_inv_output[i], = 1 to invert output for the left motor.

  • I,mot_ctrl_diffunit_right_inv_output[i], = 1 to invert output for the right motor.

  • I,mot_ctrl_diffunit_left_inv_input[i], = 1 to invert input for the left motor.

  • I,mot_ctrl_diffunit_right_inv_input[i], = 1 to invert input for the right motor.

After all differential sub-units have been configured, open Motor controller test form from NavitrolMonitor. From the test form it is possible to give reference angle and speed for each individual sub-unit. Test that all the sub-units are turning correctly and spinning in the right direction.

Velocity and Steering Controller Calibration

Sections marked with PID only refer to a case where Navitrol directly controls the output of the motor and are not necessary if Navitrol is just reporting target velocity. From this point forwards it is necessary to have the vehicle on the ground such that it can freely drive around.

Calibrate Wheel Velocity Control (PID only)

Even though the parameters that define the properties of the wheel velocity control vary between the different kinematic types, the process for tuning them is the same:

  • Set the initial values for the wheel velocity control parameters to zero.

  • Give a drive command either forward or reverse from Navitrol Monitor to generate a reference step.

  • Increase the proportional gain stepwise while monitoring how the measured velocity is reaching the target velocity in the control chart for the relevant kinematic type. Repeat until the measured speed starts to oscillate.

  • Increase the derivative gain until the overshoot of the measured speed is controlled to less than 5% of the target.

  • Repeat the two former steps until the fastest rise time with less than 10% overshoot is reached.

Differential drive (D, DS)

The proportional gain is adjusted by Navitrol parameters F,mot_ctrl_left_p and F,mot_ctrl_right_p while the derivative gain is adjusted by F,mot_ctrl_left_d and F,mot_ctrl_right_d. The control chart relevant for this part of the calibration can be found in Navitrol Monitor under Navitrol Monitor Charts Differential Drive Motors Drive Motor Speed Control.

Mecanum drive

For mecanum drives, the wheels are indexed by i = 0,...,3 where 0 = FL, 1 = FR, 2 = RL and 3 = RR. The Navitrol parameters for the proportional and derivative gains are F,mot_ctrl_mecanum_p[i] and F,mot_ctrl_mecanum_d[i] respectively. The control chart relevant for this part of the calibration can be found in Navitrol Monitor under Navitrol Monitor Charts Mecanum Drive Motors Speed Control).

Omni drive (O, DO)

The Navitrol parameters for the proportional and derivative gains are F, mot_ctrl_omni_speed_p[i] and F, mot_ctrl_omni_speed_d[i] respectively. The control chart relevant for this part of the calibration can be found in Navitrol Monitor under Navitrol Monitor Charts Omni Drive Motors PD Control**.**

Steer drive

The Navitrol parameters for the proportional and derivative gains for the forward direction are F,mot_ctrl_wheel_v_p and F,mot_ctrl_wheel_v_d respectively. The corresponding parameters for the reverse direction are F,mot_ctrl_wheel_v_rev_p and F,mot_ctrl_wheel_v_rev_d, which often may be set to the same values as the forward gains. The control chart relevant for this part of the calibration can be found in Navitrol Monitor under Navitrol Monitor Charts Steer Drive Motors Drive Motor Speed Control (steer).

Calibrate Wheel Steer Control (PID only, O, S, DO, DS)

Just as for the wheel velocity controller, the parameters that needs to be configured for the wheel steer controller differ between the kinematic types although the process of calibrating them is the same. The control gains are tuned in a similar manner as previously, however now there is also an integral part to take into consideration:

  • Set the initial values for the wheel steer control parameters to zero.

  • Give a drive reference with curvature from Navitrol Monitor to generate a steering reference value.

  • Increase the proportional gain stepwise while monitoring how the measured angle is reaching the target angle in the control chart for the relevant kinematic type. Repeat until the measured angle shows stable oscillations.

  • Increase the derivative gain in small steps until the system does no longer oscillate.

  • Repeat the two former steps until the system is responsive enough without having oscillations.

  • Adjust the integral gain to minimize the static error while keeping the overshoot and oscillations low.

Omni drive

The Navitrol parameters for the proportional, derivative and integral gains are F,mot_ctrl_omni_steer_p[i], F,mot_ctrl_omni_steer_d[i] and F,mot_ctrl_omni_steer_i[i] respectively. The control chart relevant for this part of the calibration can be found in Navitrol Monitor under Navitrol Monitor Charts Steer Drive Motors Steering.

It is important to set the target steer angle to a reasonable and safe value during the calibration that is well within the steering limits. This is enabled by the parameter I,omni_steer_limit_enable[i] = 1 and defined by F,omni_steer_limit_CCW_angle_deg[i] in the counter clockwise direction and F,omni_steer_limit_CW_angle_deg[i] in the clockwise direction.

Steer drive

The Navitrol parameters for the proportional, derivative and integral gains are F,mot_ctrl_steer_ang_p, F,mot_ctrl_steer_ang_d and F,mot_ctrl_steer_ang_i respectively. The control chart relevant for this part of the calibration can be found in Navitrol Monitor under Navitrol Monitor Charts Steer Drive Motors Steering.

It is important to set the target steer angle to a reasonable and safe value during the calibration that is well within the steering limits by adjusting F, mot_ctrl_max_steer_ang_deg and F,mot_ctrl_min_steer_ang_deg.

Odometry Calibration

A good odometry calibration is necessary to achieve good performance while driving autonomously as it is the foundation behind the dead reckoning calculations.

Steer Encoders (O, S, DO, DS)

After the initial estimation of the steer encoder zero level has been done it is important to verify the performance and if it does not fulfill the requirements, one should continue to calibrate it until it does. The procedure can be divided into the following steps:

  • Put the AGV on the ground, aligned with a reference line, and manually drive it straight for at least 10 meters using the Navitrol Monitor keyboard control. It is important that the wheels are at the zero position when starting the drive.

  • Measure the physical distance and angle deviation from the straight line.

  • If the distance deviation is larger than 5 centimeters and/or the heading deviation is larger than 1 degree, estimate which wheel is causing the offset and change the zero level values correspondingly. Repeat the previous steps.

Additionally, for omni drive vehicles, when the deviation during straight driving falls within the tolerances, one should verify that the by Navitrol perceived driving is straight as well:

  • Initialize the AGVs position such that it is aligned with the grid in the main window of Navitrol Monitor and make sure that there is no environment around it to avoid scanner corrections during the calibration process. The heading should be zero.

  • Give a reference straight forward.

  • If the drive path visualized by Monitor deviates from a straight physical path, abort the Monitor connection and use the playback function (bottom slider) to analyze the wheel orientation. If the wheel orientation is not close to zero it is possible to adjust the measured angles with the parameter F,omni_steer_ang_offset_deg[i].

Odometry Scale

Assuming that the scanner positions and angles are adequately configured at this point, one can utilize Navitrol Monitor to fine tune the odometry scale. The procedure can be broken down to the following steps:

  • In Navitrol Monitor, initialize the vehicle position far from any predefined environment such that there will be no match between the scanner points and the defined map. It is preferable to align the vehicle frame with the grid network in Navitrol Monitor.

  • In Navitrol Monitor, select the option to freeze the data.

  • Give a drive reference straight forward using the keyboard control of Navitrol Monitor. Keep driving for around ten meters or more if possible.

  • If the odometry is correct and the scanner angle is properly defined, then there should be no offset between the frozen scanner data and the live data. If there is a lengthwise offset, measure this using the Navitrol Monitor measurement tool and calculate the ratio between the driven distance and the measured offset.

  • Adjust the odometry scale parameter according to the calculated ratio.

  • Repeat the procedure until the lengthwise offset has been eliminated.

Wheel Positions

At the point when the odometry scale and possible steer encoders (O, S) have been properly tuned, the vehicle should be able to drive straight and correctly estimate the driven distance. However, to make precise and accurate turns it is important to also calibrate the positions of the wheels carefully. This is done by the following steps:

  • In Navitrol Monitor, initialize the vehicle position far from any predefined environment such that there will be no matching environment. It is preferable to align the vehicle frame with the grid network in Navitrol Monitor.

  • In Navitrol Monitor, select the option to freeze the data.

  • Make a turn in slow speed with a small turn radius. If the mechanical construction of the vehicle allows for pivoting, then that is preferred.

  • Compare the frozen scanner points with the live view. If there is an angular offset, adjust the wheel position parameters accordingly.

If the frozen scanner points deviate from the live view, it means that the dead reckoning estimation is not correct. Since the odometry scale has already been calibrated, as well as the steer encoders, the most probable cause for this is the wheel placement. For example, if the estimated pivoting angle is less than the actual pivoting angle for a differential driven vehicle, it is likely that the length of the differential axle has been overestimated.

Scanner Calibration

Before performing the Navitrol scanner calibration, it is vital for the navigation that the height and seen angle of laser scanners are first mechanically adjusted to be as level as possible in relation to the ground.

Scanner Positions and Angles

Automatic Scanner Calibration

If the AGV is using two laser scanners for localization it is of high importance that these are well-aligned with each other. If this is not done correctly, the environment that is used for navigation can be seen differently depending on the orientation of the vehicle and on which laser scanner sees the environment.

Navithor Tools implements a feature that automates this process by matching recorded measurements to each other. It is accessed from the top bar under Tools --> Calibrate Scanners and requires a teach file with clearly seen environment to work. Preferably, the teach file should cover the AGV driving the path of a figure 8 three times in slow speed.

Manual Fine Tuning of Scanner Angles

After the localization scanners have been aligned with each other they will still need to be aligned with the vehicle frame. This is important also for systems with a single scanner used for localization. If this is not done carefully there will be discrepancies between measured odometry and scanner data which in turn will have a negative impact on the performance of the vehicle, causing false position corrections. This discrepancy usually shows up as large lateral corrections and a good performance is only achieved after these have been reduced to fulfill the defined requirements.

The lateral corrections should be monitored under Navitrol Monitor --> Charts --> Odometry Correction --> Position Correction Averages while the AGV is driving on a straight route. The target is to reach a lateral correction within [-0.1, 0.1] [cm/m]. If the average correction is not within the acceptable limits, manual tuning of the scanner angles is required. This can be broken down into the following steps:

  • Disable the rear scanner by setting I,scan_rear_front_selection = 2 and I,scan_rear_front_localization_selection = 2.

  • Reload the parameter file from Navitrol Monitor under Navitrol -> Reload Parameter file.

  • Record a teach file where only one scanner is activated and create a new project with clearly defined environment and a straight route of 3-10 meters, longer is better. Make sure that one of the lanes is set to reverse.

  • Raise the average position correction gain by increasing F,odo_err_est_alpha from 0.002 to 0.006.

  • Create a drive order between the two endpoints of the route and set the AGV driving back and forth in an endless loop.

  • Adjust the defined scanner angle with the parameter F,scan_front_sen_angle until the lateral corrections are within the acceptable range. Start by both increasing and lowering it by 1 degree to determine which direction it should be adjusted in before tuning it more accurately. NOTE! If the lateral correction chart displays large jumps during the calibration process it is likely that the environment is not good enough and should be redefined.

  • When the front scanner has been well aligned with the odometry the final calibration step is to activate and adjust the angle of the rear scanner accordingly. E.g. if scan_front_sen_ang was decreased from 90 to 89, one must also adjust scan_rear_sen_ang from -90 to -91.

  • Finally, set odo_err_est_alpha, scan_rear_front_selection and scan_rear_front_localization_selection back to their original values and analyse the corrections once again. If the scanners are not matching each other, start by adjusting scan_rear_sen_ang. The scanner points should match each other on both sides of the vehicle.

NOTE! Matching the scanner views to each other is the most vital part of the scanner calibration process. Once the front scanner is calibrated according to the procedure and it is time to calibrate the rear scanner, pay more attention to matching the scanner views than the correction charts.

Odometry to Scanner Delay

If there is delay between the incoming odometry data and the incoming scanner measurements, the delay needs to be specified for Navitrol so that it can be taken into consideration. The delay can be measured by performing the following steps:

  • Connect to Navitrol with Navitrol Monitor.

  • Drive the vehicle manually towards and away from a wall that is perpendicular to the vehicles heading.

  • Monitor the possible delay from Navitrol Monitor -> Charts -> Odometry Correction -> Scan Delay Calibration (check the affecting parameters from the table below)

  • Calculate the time difference between the moment when Navitrol has received input of the vehicle moving from the scanner measurements (green graph for front scanner and red graph for rear scanner) to the moment when Navitrol has received odometry stating that there is movement. Set the parameter

      F, scan_delay [ms]

accordingly (negative if scanner is slower than odometry).

Scan Delay Calibration parameters

These parameters can be adjusted to change the threshold for drawing the scanner measurements in the Scan Delay Calibration chart in Navitrol Monitor. The default values should be usually sufficient

ParameterDefaultDescription
F,calib_scan_delay_min_dist0.2Minimum beam distance to environment to activate scanner delay calculation. [m]
F,calib_scan_delay_max_dist5.0Maximum beam distance to environment to activate scanner delay calculation. [m]
I,calib_scan_delay_n_dist_beams31Maximum/ideal number of beams considered when calculating the average distance to the wall.
I,calib_scan_delay_min_ok_beams20Minimum number of beams that have to be valid.
F,calib_scan_delay_dev_limit0.05Maximum deviation of the distance measured by a single beam from the average measured distance. Beams not fulfilling this are not used for the scanner delay calibration. [m]
F,scan_delay0.0Delay of scanner measurement [ms] relative to odometry measurements.

Position Controller Calibration

After the odometry and scanner positions are calibrated accurately, it is vital to make sure that also the position controller works properly. It calculates reference values for speed and steering and is responsible for keeping the vehicle on track while driving.

Define Limitations

For the position controller to be able to give reasonable reference values that the vehicle can follow, it is possible to enforce limitations on velocity, turning rate and steer rate etc.:

ParameterDescription
F,mot_ctrl_max_wheel_v_fwMax drive wheel velocity when driving forwards [m/s].
F,mot_ctrl_max_wheel_v_bwMax drive wheel velocity when driving in reverse [m/s].
F,mot_ctrl_max_wheel_accMax acceleration [m/s^2].
F,mot_ctrl_max_wheel_decMax deceleration [m/s^2].
F,max_turn_rate_deg_p_sMaximum turning rate of the vehicle [deg/s]. Limit is applied to the speed of the planned trajectory.
F,mot_ctrl_max_steer_rate_deg_p_sMaximum turning rate of the steering wheels [deg/s]. Limit is applied to the speed of the planned trajectory (O, S).
F,mot_ctrl_max_steer_rate_scaleScale factor for mot_ctrl_max_steer_rate_deg_p_s used during driving to limit the reference steering angle change (S).
F,sub_diff_max_turn_wheel_speedMaximum diffunit turning speed [m/s] for each wheel (DS, DO).

Output and Feedback Delay

When Navitrol sets a velocity or RPM target, there is always some amount of delay until this results in physical movement of the motor. In practice, it is important to minimize this delay as it worsens the performance of the system and makes it unresponsive in certain situations. However, Navitrol does implement a way to minimize the effect for small delays of this kind by predicting the upcoming control sequence. The delay can be visually estimated based on the speed control chart in Navitrol Monitor:

  • Give the vehicle a manual drive command using Navitrol Monitor keyboard control.

  • Monitor the results from Navitrol Monitor Charts Speed Control Final Speed Control.

  • Calculate the time difference between the moment Navitrol sets a target velocity (orange graph) to the moment Navitrol receives odometry measurements indicating movement, see Figure 5.

  • Change the Navitrol parameter I,pc_predict_ms to the calculated value.

Figure 4: Feedback delay in Navitrol Monitor is calculated by subtracting the corresponding timestamps, in this case 42998.6183 s -- 42998.4700 s = 0.1483 s = 148.3 [ms].

The drive performance with the estimated value should be evaluated on a pre-defined route:

  • Let the vehicle drive in a loop in automatic mode along a route with at least two defined curves of 90 degrees, see Figure 5.

  • Monitor the point where the vehicle begins the turn in relation to its trajectory.

  • Adjust the delay time. If the vehicle starts turning too late it often means that the delay time has been underestimated and vice versa.

Figure 5: Example route for fine tuning the output and feedback delay. The straight path should be long enough for the vehicle to stabilize between the turns.

Distance and Heading Control Gains

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
pc_pid_heading_pFloat4.0Position control heading gain
pc_pid_dist_pFloat4.0Position control distance gain
