The part of the position controller that is responsible for keeping the vehicle on the route while driving can be split into two main parts: distance control and heading control. The purpose of the distance control is to minimize the distance between the navigation point of the vehicle and the route while the heading control works to align the vehicle's frame heading with the route tangent. The influence of each term might be adjusted by the corresponding gain parameters, as the optimal values heavily depend on the vehicle model itself.

The idea is to reach a highly accurate and responsive control while still minimizing the oscillations and overshoot. Often, oscillation is caused by either an inaccurate delay estimation (pc_predict_ms) or non-optimal position control gains. In general, oscillation decreases as the heading gain is increased but the higher the gain, the more important it is that the delay parameter is accurate and the delay consistent. If there are large delays in the steer controller, increasing the heading gain may have the oppositeeffect.

Large distance gains might give a more responsive system, but they might also introduce overshoot and oscillation. Additionally, they require an accurate positioning since noise in the localization always will propagate to the position control. Thus, it is often viable to not set the distance gain too high.

Oscillations are more prone to appear as the driving speed increases. To deal with this, Navitrol implements a way to define the position control gains in speed dependent sets according to Figure 6. If the speed settings are not implemented, then only the first set of control gains are necessary.

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
pc_pid_speed_setting[]Float0.0Change PID settings after the speed is higher than given here (0.0 == disabled)
pc_pid_speed_dist_p[]Float0.0Position control distance gain for different speed values
pc_pid_speed_heading_p[]Float0.0Position control heading gain for different speed values

Figure 6: Visualization of how the position control gains relate to the speed settings. The names of the speed settings and control gains reflect the corresponding Navitrol parameters.

The process of calibrating the position control may be divided into the following steps:

  • Starting at the lowest speed setting, set both control gains to low values. 1 is a good starting point for both.

  • Let the vehicle drive in a loop on route with two turns of 270 degrees, see Figure 7.

  • Monitor how well the vehicle is following the route and how responsive it is to distance and heading offsets.

  • Adjust the control gains to increase the performance of the system according to the guidelines mentioned previously, starting with the distance gain.

  • Increase the speed and introduce a new speed setting when it is evident that the previously defined control gains cannot work properly anymore.

  • Repeat until the full speed range of the vehicle has been covered. For high speeds it might be necessary to adapt the route layout.

Figure 7: Route for tuning position control gains.

Distance and Heading Control Gains for loaded AGV

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
pc_pid_heading_p_loadedFloat0.0PosCont head gain for loaded AGV (0.0 == use non-loaded value)
pc_pid_dist_p_loadedFloat0.0PosCont dist gain for loaded AGV (0.0 == use non-loaded value)
pc_pid_speed_setting_loaded[]Float0.0Change PID settings for loaded AGV after the speed is higher than given here (0.0 == disabled)
pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded[]Float0.0PosCont head gains for loaded AGV for different speed values (0.0 == disabled)
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded[]Float0.0PosCont dist gains for loaded AGV for different speed values (0.0 == disabled)

In many applications, the vehicle is meant to transport resources between different points along the route. For heavy and/or large resources it is common that the kinematic properties of the vehicle change noticeably between the loaded and unloaded state. To reduce the effect of this, Navitrol implements a way to adapt the control gains based on the current load state of the vehicle. It works together with its corresponding speed settings as seen in Figure 8.

Figure 8: Visualization of how the position control gains relate to the speed settings for a loaded vehicle. The names of the speed settings and control gains reflect the corresponding Navitrol parameters.

Distance and Heading Control Gains based on load weight

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
pc_pid_load_weight_kg[]Float0.0Change PosContPID settings for loaded AGV when load weight is higher than given here (0.0 == disabled).
pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded1[]Float0.0PosContPID settings using two dim gain array (0.0 == disabled).
See the Speed/Load array below how these parameters are used.
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded1[]Float0.0PosContPID settings using two dim gain array (0.0 == disabled)
pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded2[]Float0.0PosContPID settings using two dim gain array (0.0 == disabled)
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded2[]Float0.0PosContPID settings using two dim gain array (0.0 == disabled)
pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded3[]Float0.0PosContPID settings using two dim gain array (0.0 == disabled)
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded3[]Float0.0PosContPID settings using two dim gain array (0.0 == disabled)

Note that Navitrol needs to get the load weight through some interface to be able to define what weight gain should be used. This information is not provided through every interface, so ask Navitec if your setup is able to use this.

If all of these gain parameters that are listed in this Chapter are enabled, the correlation between speed and load weights would look like this table below.

Priority of the gains:

  1. Use the weight gains: if pc_pid_load_weight[0] > 0.0.
  2. Use the loaded speed gains: if pc_pid_speed_setting_loaded[i], pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded[i] and pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded[i] are all > 0.0.
  3. Use the standard loaded gains: if pc_pid_dist_p_loaded and pc_pid_heading_p_loaded are > 0.0.
  4. Use non-loaded speed gains: if pc_pid_speed_setting[i], pc_pid_speed_dist_p[i] and pc_pid_speed_heading_p[i] are all > 0.0.
  5. Use non-loaded basic gain values pc_pid_heading_p and pc_pid_dist_p.
Speed/LoadNot loaded< weight0< weight1< weight2> weight2
< speed0pc_pid_heading_p
pc_pid_dist_p		pc_pid_heading_p_loaded
pc_pid_dist_p_loaded		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded1[0]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded1[0]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded2[0]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded2[0]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded3[0]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded3[0]
< speed1pc_pid_speed_heading_p[0]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p[0]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded[0]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded[0]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded1[1]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded1[1]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded2[1]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded2[1]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded3[1]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded3[1]
< speed2pc_pid_speed_heading_p[1]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p[1]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded[1]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded[1]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded1[2]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded1[2]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded2[2]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded2[2]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded3[2]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded3[2]
> speed2pc_pid_speed_heading_p[2]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p[2]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded[2]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded[2]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded1[3]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded1[3]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded2[3]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded2[3]		pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded3[3]
pc_pid_speed_dist_p_loaded3[3]

Example set of parameters:

F,pc_pid_load_weight_kg[0], 350 		# weight parameter array size ==3     =>  gives 4 ranges
F,pc_pid_load_weight_kg[1], 700 	    # Weight0 < Weight1 < Weight2
F,pc_pid_load_weight_kg[2], 900

F,pc_pid_speed_setting_loaded[0], 0.5	# speed parameter array size ==3     =>  gives 4 ranges
F,pc_pid_speed_setting_loaded[1], 1.0	# speed0 < speed1 < speed2 (when AGV is loaded)
F,pc_pid_speed_setting_loaded[2], 1.5

F,pc_pid_speed_setting[0], 0.8	        # speed parameter array size ==3     =>  gives 4 ranges
F,pc_pid_speed_setting[1], 1.2	        # speed0 < speed1 < speed2 (when AGV is not loaded)
F,pc_pid_speed_setting[2], 1.7

F,pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded1[0], 4.1
F,pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded1[1], 6.6
F,pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded1[2], 3.2
F,pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded1[3], 10.5

F,pid_speed_dist_p_loaded1[0], 4.3
F,pid_speed_dist_p_loaded1[1], 3.0
F,pid_speed_dist_p_loaded1[2], 7.5
F,pid_speed_dist_p_loaded1[3], 10.0

F,pc_pid_speed_heading_p_loaded2[0], 5.5

Stopping Accuracy

Accurate stopping is a requirement for most applications and Navitrol implements different methods to facilitate this, such as crawl mode, stop offsets and distance-based control gains:

  • Let the vehicle drive in a loop on a route with two stop points and a 90 degree turn in-between, see Figure 9. The speed of the route should be low, just as it would be in a real application.

  • Monitor where the vehicle stops in relation to the route. If there is an offset, first try to modify the crawl mode parameters:

ParameterDescription
F,slow_down_crawl_distHow far from the stopping point that the crawl mode is activated.
F,min_slow_down_speedSpeed while in crawl mode.
  • For systematic and constant stopping deviations there is a possibility to define a stopping offset:
ParameterDescription
F,pc_stop_distance_offsetStopping distance offset from last point (positive if stops too early)

Figure 9: Route for tuning stopping accuracy.

Steer drive and differential drive

Furthermore, Navitrol includes an accurate stopping feature that dynamically adjusts the position controller gains when arriving at a stop point. It can be activated by setting the parameter F,pc_end_gain_dist [m] to a value larger than zero and then adjusting the different gains/gain limits specified by the parameters:

  • F,pc_end_gain1 -- Used in the dynamic calculation of the proportional gains for position control of both heading and distance.

  • F,pc_end_max_gain -- Maximum proportional gain for position control of both heading and distance.

  • F,pc_end_min_gain -- Minimum proportional gain for position control of distance.

The effect of the parameter pc_end_gain1 is illustrated in Figure 10 and one can see how an increased parameter value increases the heading gain but reduces the distance gain.

Figure 10: Illustration of how the pc_end_gain1 parameter affects the heading and distance position control gains.

Pivoting

If the mechanical construction of the vehicle allows for pivoting, where the vehicle is turning around its navigation point without any translational movement, then also this should be configured:

  • Set the required target accuracy in degrees to the Navitrol parameter F,pivot_target_head_diff_deg. Setting it too low can result in issues as the position controller is not able to fulfill it.

  • Let the vehicle drive in a loop on a route with two pivot points, see Figure 11.

  • Monitor the pivoting speed and adjust it if necessary by changing the Navitrol parameter F,pivot_speed.

  • Monitor the angular stopping accuracy. Navitrol decreases the speed reference when reaching the end of the pivot and these quantities can be adjusted by the parameters

ParameterDescription
F,pivot_crawl_speedDrive point velocity during pivot when close to target.
F,pivot_crawl_head_diff_degSlow driving angular distance during pivot [deg].
F,pivot_dec_head_degAngular difference from stop target before decelerating from pivot speed to slowdown speed during pivot [deg].

Figure 11: Route for tuning pivoting.

Parameter reconfiguration

Updated 19.07.2024

Overview

Sometimes parameters used by Navitrol for some specific purpose need to be changed when Navitrol software is updated. There are numerous possible reasons for this, some examples being

  • Unifying parameter usage
  • Replacing some previously used machine types with new ones

At start-up, Navitrol checks any need for such parameter configuration. If reconfiguration is needed, error ERROR_PARAMETER_RECONFIGURE_NEEDED is raised, and parameter reconfiguration is required before Navitrol can be run again. This error may be triggered by an issue in any of the parameter files used by Navitrol.

Navitrol provides command line utility to check for needed parameter changes. This utility lists all the changes needed to console and stores the same information to a log file .\params_backup\params_reconfigure_log.txt. This utility is even able to fix the parameter files automatically in many cases, if given a permission to do so.

Important note: Parameter changes needed may be related to basic driving. If that is the case, it is recommended to verify updated parameters and all driving directions having AGV lifted off the ground.

Reconfiguration policy

Parameter reconfiguration rules are called reconfiguration policies. Each Navitrol version may include any number of reconfiguration policies, and each policy has different rules for changing parameters.

Navitrol 6.54 has one reconfiguration defined policy, RoboteqDistScale.

How to use

Preconditions

  • Minimum software version requirements
    • Navitrol 6.54.00

Basics

If error ERROR_PARAMETER_RECONFIGURE_NEEDED is raised, parameters need to be reconfigured.

Issue cmd

./Navitrol paramsreconfigure

Navitrol examines all available parameter files and reports whether

  • No reconfiguration is needed.
  • Manual reconfiguration is needed; this may be necessary for different reasons, Navitrol listing the issues why automatic reconfiguration is not possible.
  • Automatic reconfiguration is possible; parameter changes are listed and then user given the possibility to either allow or deny the writing of the updated information to parameter file.

Reconfiguration rules may be different to main parameter file params.txt and override files (params_override.txt, params_zone*.txt).

NOTE: Navitrol updating the parameter file means that any manually added user comments and parameter regrouping is lost. That is why user is always given the option to make the suggested parameter changes manually.

Reconfiguration policies

Reconfiguration policy RoboteqDistScale

This reconfiguration policy checks parameters used for scaling speed as reported by Roboteq motor controllers. Parameter mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_s should be used for that purpose, but some old machine types have used distance scaling parameters instead. Starting from Navitrol software version 6.54, mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_s is used for all machine types.

Machine types affected and parameters involved are listed in a table below.

Machine type idKinematic typeScaling parameter(s)
SW version 6.52 and older		Scaling parameter
SW version 6.54 and later		Inversion parameter(s)
10012Omnimot_ctrl_drive_dist_scalemot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_smot_ctrl_omni_speed_inv_input[]
mot_ctrl_omni_speed_inv_output[]
10016Diffmot_ctrl_left_dist_scale
mot_ctrl_right_dist_scale		mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_smot_ctrl_left_inv_in
mot_ctrl_right_inv_in
mot_ctrl_left_inv_out
mot_ctrl_right_inv_out
230003Diffmot_ctrl_left_dist_scale
mot_ctrl_right_dist_scale		mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_smot_ctrl_left_inv_in
mot_ctrl_right_inv_in
mot_ctrl_left_inv_out
mot_ctrl_right_inv_out
340001Diffmot_ctrl_left_dist_scale
mot_ctrl_right_dist_scale		mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_smot_ctrl_left_inv_in
mot_ctrl_right_inv_in
mot_ctrl_left_inv_out
mot_ctrl_right_inv_out
340002Mecanummot_ctrl_drive_dist_scalemot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_smot_ctrl_mecanum_inv_input[]
mot_ctrl_mecanum_inv_output[]
340004Mecanummot_ctrl_drive_dist_scalemot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_smot_ctrl_mecanum_inv_input[]
mot_ctrl_mecanum_inv_output[]

Parameter mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_s has been mistakenly obligatory parameter for many machine types that have not used it all. If parameter file contains both old style dist_scale parameters and mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_s, automatic reconfiguration is not possible. In such a case reconfiguration suggests manual configuration, and reports what prevents automatic configuration:

ISSUE: Both mot_ctrl_left_dist_scale/mot_ctrl_right_dist_scale and mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_s defined

If one knows that dist_scale parameters have right values, it is possible to overcome this issue by simply removing mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_s from parameter file.

NOTE: Inversion parameters are modified by this policy only for "main" parameter file params.txt. As Navitrol version 6.52 supported only open loop control with Roboteq motor controllers, output inversion parameters are never modified.

Parameter backup files

Whenever any of the current parameter files is modified by reconfiguration, backup file is stored to folder ./params_backup. File name of each such a backup file:

  • starts with original file name
  • includes reconfigure to indicate that backup was created by reconfiguration
  • includes date and time

Backup files are named like:

  • params_reconfigure_backup_2024.04.16_10.50.27.txt
  • params_override_reconfigure_backup_2024.04.16_11.48.37.txt
  • params_zone0_reconfigure_backup_2024.04.16_14.21.30.txt

Console output and logging

Console output and information stored to log by command ./Navitrol paramsreconfigure are almost identical. Some additional information is stored to log file, including Navitrol software version used, date and time.

The following shows an example of logged data for all three possible cases as mentioned above; no reconfiguration needed, manual reconfiguration needed and automatic reconfiguration possible.

#####################################################################################
Parameter reconfiguration
Date: 2024.04.16_10.30.48
SWVer 6.54.00
#####################################################################################

Check for reconfiguration need for file params.txt, machine type 10016 using policy RoboteqDistScale
Parameter reconfiguration not required for params.txt

Check for reconfiguration need for file params_override.txt, machine type 10016 using policy RoboteqDistScale
Parameter reconfiguration not required for params_override.txt


#####################################################################################
Parameter reconfiguration
Date: 2024.04.16_10.35.27
SWVer 6.54.00
#####################################################################################

Check for reconfiguration need for file params.txt, machine type 10016 using policy RoboteqDistScale
Manual parameter reconfiguration needed for params.txt
ISSUE: Both mot_ctrl_left_dist_scale/mot_ctrl_right_dist_scale and mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_s defined
Actions:
1. Add/change mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_s to right value in parameter file (check value of mot_ctrl_left_dist_scale/mot_ctrl_right_dist_scale)
2. Add/change in/out inversion parameters to parameter file if old dist_scale used was negative
3. Remove parameters mot_ctrl_left_dist_scale and mot_ctrl_right_dist_scale


#####################################################################################
Parameter reconfiguration
Date: 2024.04.16_10.48.25
SWVer 6.54.00
#####################################################################################

Check for reconfiguration need for file params.txt, machine type 10016 using policy RoboteqDistScale
Parameter reconfiguration needed for params.txt - configuring changes
Add:        F,mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_s, 0.001440
Add/Change: I,mot_ctrl_left_inv_in, 1
Add/Change: I,mot_ctrl_right_inv_in, 0
Remove:     F,mot_ctrl_left_dist_scale, -0.001440
Remove:     F,mot_ctrl_right_dist_scale, -0.001440
Changes are not stored to file params.txt

Check for reconfiguration need for file params_override.txt, machine type 10016 using policy RoboteqDistScale
Parameter reconfiguration needed for params_override.txt - configuring changes
Add:        F,mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_s, 0.011100
Remove:     F,mot_ctrl_left_dist_scale, -0.011100
Remove:     F,mot_ctrl_right_dist_scale, 0.011100
Storing changes to file params_override.txt

NOTE: Stored override parameter files might not include all parameters listed in this output. If the value matches with basic parameters, then values are not stored in override file.

Navitrol parameters

Updated 19.09.2024

This document lists all Navitrol parameters. Some of the listed parameters are applicable only for specific machine types.

AGV Identification and dimensions

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
machine_type_idint0Id of vehicle type
machine_type_keyuint0Verification key of machine type id
dim_frontfloat1.3AGV lengthwise dimension from navigation point to the front end. Positive value.
dim_rearfloat-0.51AGV lengthwise dimension from navigation point to the rear end. Negative value.
dim_leftfloat0.27AGV dimension from navigation point to the left side. Positive value.
dim_rightfloat-0.27AGV dimension from navigation point to the right side. Negative value.
machine_idint1Machine ID number reported to fleet control and other systems.
wheel_distfloat0.5Lengthwise offset of steering wheel from navigation point, positive is toward the front of the machine.
wheel_off_centerfloat0.0Sideways offset of steering wheel from navigation point, positive is to the left.
wheel_trackfloat0.248Distance between the centers of the differential drive wheels.
reported_machine_typeint0Override machine type reported to fleet control. 0 = no override
wheel_xfloat[]0.0Longitudinal position of wheel relative to vehicle navigation point. Positive towards front. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.
wheel_yfloat[]0.0Lateral position of wheel relative to vehicle center point. Positive to the left. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.
wheel_y_offfloat[]0.0Wheel offset from its turning axle, lateral distance when wheel is straight. Positive to the left. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.

AGV Interfaces

Scanners

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
scanner_sends_every_nth_measint[]1Scanner sends only every nth meas - not Navigation SW controllable, valid for specific scanners only
scanner_meas_modelint[]-1Measurement scanner model. Same as scanner_model_front
scanner_meas_addrstring[]1.1.1.1:5001.1.1.1:500
scanner_meas_use_nth_measint[]1Use only every nth measurement beam from each scan.
scanner_meas_upside_downint[]0Mounting orientation: 0 = normal, 1 = upside down
scanner_meas_dang_factorfloat[]-1.0Scanner angular resolution (dAng) scaling, -1 to disable, >0 scaling factor for dAng (reasonable values 0.995...1.005)
scanner_meas_xfloat[]0.0Scanner lengthwise mounting position relative to navigation point. Positive is towards the front of the machine.
scanner_meas_yfloat[]0.0Scanner lateral mounting position relative to navigation point. Positive is left from the machine center line.

scanner_meas_beam_max_ang_degfloat[]360.0Scanner beam min&max angles define the range of valid scanner measurement beams for each scanner with 0 deg being the first measurement beam

scanner_meas_safety_zone_dirint[]0Which direction should the slowdown and stops happen on safety zone triggers. 0 = none, 1 = backward only, 2 = forward only, 3 = both directions
scanner_model_frontint0Front scanner model: 0 = Sick Ethernet, 1 = Sick S300, 2 = Omron OS32C, 3 = P+F R2000 UHD 4 = obsolete, 5 = Leuze RSL400, 6 = Hokuyo UAM-05LP, 7 = Keyence SZ-V 32N, 8 = Sick uScan, 9 = Sick S300 TCP/IP, 10 = Reserved, 11 = Quanergy M1, 12 = Hokuyo SCIP, 15 = DDS, 16 = Leuze RSL200

scan_rear_front_localization_selectionint3Defines which scanners are used for localization: 0 = no scanners, 1 = rear scanner only, 2 = front scanner only, 3 = both rear and front scanners
scanner_to_moveint0Scanner to move: 0 = disable, 1 = rear scanner, 2 = front scanner
front_scanner_serial_portstring/dev/ttyS0Insert serial port name here. E.g. ttyRX0 if using external serial card and ttyS0 if using Debian Jessie

rear_scanner_ipstringRear scanner IP

rear_scanner_portint44818Rear scanner port: Sick 2111, PEF 80, Omron 44818, Velodyne 2368, Hokuyo 10940, Leuze 9999, Keyence 8800, QuanergyM1 4141

scan_front_sen_angfloat90.0Front scanner mounting angle relative to machine frame. Scanner's X-axis is towards the right side of the scanner. Therefore a scanner that points towards the front of the machine has a mouting angle of -90 degrees.

Ethernet supervisor

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
supervisor_safety_scanner_enabledint0Enables supervisor safety scanner.
supervisor_speedlimit_clear_on_standbyint1When state is changed to STANDBY: 0 = Do not clear speed limit, 1 = Clear speed limit
supervisor_ctrl_max_nbr_invalid_feedbackint1Maximum number of consecutive invalid feedback messages from Supervisor.
veh_inte_heartbeat_intervalint0Defines how often the error message is sent to supervisor [ms]. 0 = Periodic sending disabled.
veh_inte_error_message_typeint0Defines which error message will be sent: 0 = basic (201), 1 = with error levels (202)
veh_inte_error_message_modeint2Defines if active errors, warnings or both are sent in supervisor error message: 0 = Do not send the error message, 1 = Send only errors, 2 = send errors and warnings.
veh_inte_error_message_send_only_on_requestint10 = send errors/warnings if active errors change, 1 = send active errors only on request (or periodically, if veh_inte_heartbeat_interval > 0).
veh_inte_error_message_send_only_active_errorsint10 = send errors/warnings if they have been active and not sent yet, 1 = send only active errors/warnings.
veh_inte_env_read_rply_msgint1Defines if environment read message (1108) will be sent every time environment is loaded: 0 = disabled, 1 = enabled.
veh_inte_sym_point_rply_msgint1Defines if symbolic point data message (3103) will be sent every time when segment file is loaded: 0 = disabled, 1 = enabled.
veh_inte_send_drive_ready_msgint0Defines if drive ready message (3129) will be sent every time AGV finishes a drive order: 0 = disabled, 1 = enabled.
veh_inte_target_symbolic_point_info_interval_msint0Defines the time interval [ms] for sending target symbolic point information message (6103). 0 = disabled.
supervisor_ctrl_speed_scale_infloat1.0Speed scale for supervisor controlled machine types. Incoming speed measurements are multiplied by this value.
supervisor_ctrl_speed_scale_outfloat1.0Speed scale for supervisor controlled machine types. Outgoing speed references are divided by this value.

eth_set_speed_ref_prior_to_driveint0Enables setting speed reference before driving. Can be useful e.g. to give direction of movement to safety system.

supervisor_eth_odometry_receive_timeout_msint250Defines a communication alive time limit for supervisor communication when odometry is received from supervisor. If no messages are received within the defined time, Navitrol tries to reconnect to socket.
supervisor_eth_receive_timeout_msint5000Defines a communication alive time limit for supervisor communication. If no messages are received within the defined time, Navitrol tries to reconnect to socket.

supervisor_eth2_enabledint0Enables secondary Supervisor interface.
agv_supervisor_custom_errors_maxint0Maximum number of supervisor errors/warnings sent to fleet control.
eth_ctrl_msgnum_validateint1When enabled Navitrol will validate that the message numbers in received supervisor control messages increase by one between each message: 0 = disabled, 1 = Enabled
veh_inte_cums_overflowuint0xFFFFFFFFUDefines the encoder overflow value when using differential drive odometry.
veh_inte_manual_ang_velfloat0.785Maximum angular velocity [rad/s] for manual control from supervisor.
supervisor_remote_ctrl_speed_scale_pctfloat50.0Speed scale 10-100% from maximum wheel speed. Applied when remote control status section is used in the Ethernet supervisor interface.
agv_plc_ipstring192.168.1.158IP address of the onboard PLC.
use_supervisor_standard_commsint00 = use custom messages, 1 = use standard supervisor messages
use_supervisor_standard_drive_ctrl_sectionint00 = Using custom manual (e-15 key) feature, 1 = Use standard drive control section
supervisor_can_enabledint0Enables CAN based supervisor interface.
supervisor_can_nodeid_arrint[]0CAN node ID of supervisor PLC. 0 = disabled
supervisor_can_nodeid_mode_arrint[]0Mode for node ID at corresponding index: 0 = slave - Navigation SW transmits RPDOs, 1 = master - Navigation SW transmits TPDOs.
supervisor_can_rx_timeout_msint0Timeout of PDOs received by Navigation SW.
supervisor_can_tx_interval_msint0Tranmsission interval of PDOs transmitted by Navigation SW.
supervisor_can_tx1_typeid_arrint[]0Type ID of message transmitted by Navigation SW to CAN bus on PDO 1.
supervisor_can_tx2_typeid_arrint[]0Type ID of message transmitted by Navigation SW to CAN bus on PDO 2.

supervisor_can_rx1_typeid_arrint[]0Type ID of message received by Navigation SW from CAN bus on PDO 1.
supervisor_can_rx2_typeid_arrint[]0Type ID of message received by Navigation SW from CAN bus on PDO 2.
supervisor_can_rx3_typeid_arrint[]0Type ID of message received by Navigation SW from CAN bus on PDO 3.
supervisor_can_rx4_typeid_arrint[]0Type ID of message received by Navigation SW from CAN bus on PDO 4.

Motor controller

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
mot_ctrl_watchdog_msint200Motor control hardware watchdog timeout [ms].
mot_ctrl_drive_angle_diag_time_msint200Maximum time [ms] steer angle is detected to be controlled in the wrong direction. Value 0 disables diagnostics.
mot_ctrl_drive_dir_diag_time_msint250Maximum time [ms] motor is detected to run in wrong direction. Value 0 disables diagnostics.
mot_ctrl_serial_portstring/dev/ttyS2Serial port for first Roboteq controller (steer/diff).
mot_ctrl_serial_port2string/dev/ttyS2Serial port for second Roboteq controller (mecanum).
mot_ctrl_left_inv_inint-1Input inversion for the left wheel of diff drive: -1 = copies value of mot_ctrl_left_inv_out, 0 = disabled, 1 = enabled
mot_ctrl_right_inv_inint-1Input inversion for the right wheel of diff drive: -1 = copies value of mot_ctrl_right_inv_out, 0 = disabled, 1 = enabled
mot_ctrl_left_inv_outint0Output inversion for the left wheel of diff drive: 0 = disabled, 1 = enabled
mot_ctrl_right_inv_outint0Output inversion for the right wheel of diff drive: 0 = disabled, 1 = enabled
mot_ctrl_steer_v_inv_outint0Enables inversion of steering motor output.
mot_ctrl_steer_v_inv_inint0Enables inversion of steer angle input.
mot_ctrl_wheel_v_inv_inint-1Input inversion for the driving wheel of steer drive: -1 = copies value of mot_ctrl_wheel_v_inv_out, 0 = disabled, 1 = enabled
mot_ctrl_wheel_v_inv_outint0Output inversion for the driving wheel of steer drive: 0 = disabled, 1 = enabled
mot_ctrl_drive_min_outputint0Minimum output (absolute value) sent to the motor controller (cutoff point). Not used for steer drive.
mot_ctrl_drive_max_outputint1000Maximum output (absolute value) sent to the motor controller (cutoff point). Not used for steer drive.
mot_ctrl_drive_max_stall_output_pctfloat40.0Percentage of maximum output sent to the motor controller when AGV is at stall (AGV not moving with non-zero reference).
mot_ctrl_max_output_current_percentint100Maximum output current (percent) sent to the motor controller.
mot_ctrl_enable_ctrl_token_switchingint0Enables Ctrl token switching.
mot_ctrl_left_dist_scalefloat-0.000001Convert encoder pulses of the left wheel to driven distance [m] (differential drive).
mot_ctrl_right_dist_scalefloat-0.000001Convert encoder pulses of the right wheel to driven distance [m] (differential drive).
mot_ctrl_drive_dist_scalefloat-0.000001Convert encoder pulses of the drive wheels to driven distance [m] (steer, mecanum, omni).
mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_sfloat0.0001Convert measured RPM of the wheel's motor to the velocity of the wheel [m/s].
mot_ctrl_steer_ang_offset_degfloat0.0Offset to correct error in AGV's steering angle [deg].
mot_ctrl_steer_ang_scalefloat1.0Multiplier to correct error in AGV's steering angle scale.
mot_ctrl_turn_rate_in_scalefloat1.0
mot_ctrl_turn_rate_out_scalefloat1.0
mot_ctrl_speed_in_long_scalefloat1.0
mot_ctrl_speed_out_long_scalefloat1.0
mot_ctrl_speed_in_lat_scalefloat1.0
mot_ctrl_speed_out_lat_scalefloat1.0
mot_ctrl_max_wheel_v_fwfloat0.8Default maximum drive wheel velocity when driving forwards [m/s]
mot_ctrl_max_wheel_v_bwfloat0.8Default maximum drive wheel velocity when driving in reverse [m/s]
mot_ctrl_max_wheel_accfloat0.5Default maximum drive wheel acceleration [m/s^2]. The reference speed is ramped up based on this value.
mot_ctrl_max_wheel_decfloat0.5Default maximum drive wheel deceleration [m/s^2]. The reference speed is ramped down based on this value.
mot_ctrl_output_lowpass_alphafloat1.0Applies filter to steer and velocity outputs. Default value for no filtering
mot_ctrl_max_steer_rate_deg_p_sfloat30.0Maximum wheel steering rate [deg/s]. Limits the speed of the planned trajectory.
mot_ctrl_max_steer_rate_scalefloat3.0Scale factor for mot_ctrl_max_steer_rate_deg_p_s used during driving to limit the reference steering angle change.
mot_ctrl_max_steer_ang_degfloat90.0Maximum angle limit for the steer wheel.
mot_ctrl_min_steer_ang_degfloat-90.0Minimum angle limit for the steer wheel.
mot_ctrl_max_wheel_dec_ramped_fast_stopfloat0.0Maximum wheel deceleration during ramped fast stop. Only used if larger than mot_ctrl_max_wheel_dec
mot_ctrl_forced_velocity_ramping_enabledint0Enabels that the speed reference is forced to always follow acc and dec ramps.
mot_ctrl_max_wheel_v_fw_arrfloat[]0.8Default maximum drive wheel velocity when driving forwards [m/s] that can be selected to replace the default limit.
mot_ctrl_max_wheel_v_bw_arrfloat[]0.8Default maximum drive wheel velocity when driving in reverse [m/s] that can be selected to replace the default limit.
mot_ctrl_max_wheel_acc_arrfloat[]0.5Default maximum drive wheel acceleration [m/s^2] that can be selected to replace the default limit. The reference speed is ramped up based on this value.
mot_ctrl_max_wheel_dec_arrfloat[]0.5Default maximum drive wheel deceleration [m/s^2] that can be selected to replace the default limit. The reference speed is ramped down based on this value.
mot_ctrl_max_steer_rate_deg_p_s_arrfloat[]30.0Maximum wheel steering rate [deg/s] that can be selected to replace the default limit. Limits the speed of the planned trajectory.
mot_ctrl_steer_ang_pfloat1.0Proportional gain for steering motor control.
mot_ctrl_steer_ang_dfloat1.0Derivative gain for steering motor control.
mot_ctrl_steer_ang_ifloat1.0Integral gain for steering motor control.
mot_ctrl_steer_ang_deadband_degfloat0.25Steering angle deadband.
mot_ctrl_wheel_v_pfloat1.0Proportional gain for driving motor in forward direction.
mot_ctrl_wheel_v_dfloat1.0Derivative gain for driving motor in forward direction.
mot_ctrl_wheel_v_ifloat1.0
mot_ctrl_wheel_v_rev_pfloat1.0Proportional gain for driving motor in backward direction.
mot_ctrl_wheel_v_rev_dfloat1.0Derivative gain for driving motor in backward direction.
mot_ctrl_diffunit_left_inv_inputint[]0Enables input inversion for diffunit left wheel.
mot_ctrl_diffunit_right_inv_inputint[]0Enables input inversion for diffunit right wheel.
mot_ctrl_diffunit_left_inv_outputint[]0Enables output inversion for diffunit left wheel.
mot_ctrl_diffunit_right_inv_outputint[]0Enables output inversion for diffunit right wheel.
mot_ctrl_left_pfloat1.0Proportional gain for controlling left motor speed. Valid only for motor controllers that do not have internal PID.
mot_ctrl_left_dfloat1.0Derivative gain for controlling left motor speed. Valid only for motor controllers that do not have internal PID.
mot_ctrl_right_pfloat1.0Proportional gain for controlling right motor speed. Valid only for motor controllers that do not have internal PID.
mot_ctrl_right_dfloat1.0Derivative gain for controlling right motor speed. Valid only for motor controllers that do not have internal PID.
mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq1_channel1_wheelint0Maps channel of roboteq controller to wheel index. Indexes are 0 = FL (Forward Left), 1 = FR (Forward Right), 2 = RL (Rear Left), 3 = RR (Rear Right). For example, mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq1_channel1_wheel, 0 would mean that channel 1 of motor controller with node id defined in can_roboteq_nodeid[0] would be wheel 0 = FL.
mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq1_channel2_wheelint1Maps channel of roboteq controller to wheel index. Indexes are 0 = FL (Forward Left), 1 = FR (Forward Right), 2 = RL (Rear Left), 3 = RR (Rear Right). For example, mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq1_channel2_wheel, 1 would mean that channel 2 of motor controller with node id defined in can_roboteq_nodeid[0] would be wheel 1 = FR.
mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq2_channel1_wheelint2Maps channel of roboteq controller to wheel index. Indexes are 0 = FL (Forward Left), 1 = FR (Forward Right), 2 = RL (Rear Left), 3 = RR (Rear Right). For example, mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq2_channel1_wheel, 2 would mean that channel 1 of motor controller with node id defined in can_roboteq_nodeid[1] would be wheel 2 = RL.
mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq2_channel2_wheelint3Maps channel of roboteq controller to wheel index. Indexes are 0 = FL (Forward Left), 1 = FR (Forward Right), 2 = RL (Rear Left), 3 = RR (Rear Right). For example, mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq2_channel2_wheel, 3 would mean that channel 2 of motor controller with node id defined in can_roboteq_nodeid[1] would be wheel 3 = RR.
mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq3_channel1_wheelint2Maps channel of roboteq controller to wheel index. Indexes are 0 = FL (Forward Left), 1 = FR (Forward Right), 2 = RL (Rear Left), 3 = RR (Rear Right).
mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq4_channel1_wheelint3Maps channel of roboteq controller to wheel index. Indexes are 0 = FL (Forward Left), 1 = FR (Forward Right), 2 = RL (Rear Left), 3 = RR (Rear Right).
mot_ctrl_mecanum_nodeidint[]0CANopen NodeId. 0 = not defined, Indexes are 0 = FF (Forward Left), 1 = FR (Forward Right), 2 = RL (Rear Left), 3 = RR (Rear Right).
mot_ctrl_mecanum_inv_outputint[]0Enables output inversion for mecanum AGV. Indexes are 0 = FL, 1 = FR, 2 = RL, 3 = RR.
mot_ctrl_mecanum_inv_inputint[]0Enables input inversion for mecanum AGV. Indexes are 0 = FL, 1 = FR, 2 = RL, 3 = RR.
mot_ctrl_mecanum_pfloat[]1.0Proportional gain for motor speed. Used for motor controllers without internal PID controller. Indexes are 0 = FL, 1 = FR, 2 = RL, 3 = RR.
mot_ctrl_mecanum_dfloat[]1.0Derivative gain for motor speed. Used for motor controllers without internal PID controller. Indexes are 0 = FL, 1 = FR, 2 = RL, 3 = RR.
mot_ctrl_nanotec_p_gainint60000Nanotec motor controller proportional gain.
mot_ctrl_nanotec_i_gainint500Nanotec motor controller integral gain.
mot_ctrl_steer_min_outputfloat5.0Minimum output sent to the steering motor. Not used if array parameters (mot_ctrl_steer_min_output_arr[] mot_ctrl_steer_max_output_arr[]) defined.
mot_ctrl_steer_min_output_arrfloat[]1.0Minimum output sent to the steering motor. If set, non-array parameters (mot_ctrl_steer_min_output, mot_ctrl_steer_max_output) are not used.
mot_ctrl_steer_max_outputfloat999.0Maximum output sent to the steering motor. Not used if array parameters (mot_ctrl_steer_min_output_arr[] mot_ctrl_steer_max_output_arr[]) defined.
mot_ctrl_steer_max_output_arrfloat[]4999.0Maximum output sent to the steering motor. If set, non-array parameters (mot_ctrl_steer_min_output, mot_ctrl_steer_max_output) are not used.
mot_ctrl_wheel_v_minfloat0.0005Vehicle is thought to be standing still when measured wheel speed is below this value [m/s].
mot_ctrl_wheel_v_out_dead_bandfloat20.0
mot_ctrl_steer_ang_out_dead_bandfloat20.0Steering motor deadband.
mot_ctrl_steer_ang_stopped_deadband_degfloat2.0Steering angle deadband when AGV is stopped.
mot_ctrl_steer_ang_meas_min_limit_degfloat-120.0Minimum limit for measured steering angle. Used for unit conversion.
mot_ctrl_steer_ang_meas_max_limit_degfloat120.0Maximum limit for measured steering angle. Used for unit conversion.
mot_ctrl_steer_ang_target_min_limit_degfloat-90.0Minimum limit for target steering angle. Used for unit conversion.
mot_ctrl_steer_ang_target_max_limit_degfloat90.0Maximum limit for target steering angle. Used for unit conversion.
mot_ctrl_steer_driving_min_outputfloat0.0Minimum output sent to the driving motor. Applicable only for steer AGV.
mot_ctrl_steer_driving_max_outputfloat9999.0Maximum output sent to the driving motor. Applicable only for steer AGV.
mot_ctrl_v_deadbandfloat0.05Wheel speed deadband.
mot_ctrl_calib_v0float0.5Motor controller calibration speed 0.
mot_ctrl_calib_v1float0.1Motor controller calibration speed 1.
mot_ctrl_odo_from_speedint1
mot_ctrl_odo_steer_type_irobint00 = rear odo, front steer, 1 = bicycle model
mot_ctrl_steer_angle_hard_limit_degfloat90.0Steer drive AGV hard angle limit. 0.0 to disable.
mot_ctrl_steer_torque_mNmint0Torque set to the steering motor controller.
mot_ctrl_drive_torque_mNmint0Torque set to the driving motor controller.
mot_ctrl_reset_errors_timerint500After the defined time [ms] Navigation SW tries automatically reset motor control faults. Value 0 = fault reset disabled
mot_ctrl_curtis_reboot_controller_timer_msint5000After the defined time [ms] Navigation SW tries to reboot Curtis motor controller in order to clear faults. Value 0 = controller reboot disabled
mot_ctrl_curtis_max_number_reboot_controllerint2Maximum number of attemts to reboot the motor controller in order to clear faults.
mot_ctrl_odometry_from_rpmint1Source of odometry: 0 = encoder, 1 = rpm
filt_gain_raw_speed_inputfloat0.0Smoothing raw speed input from motor controller.
mot_ctrl_disable_main_contactor_msint0Disable main contactor to save energy after standing still for the defined time. 0 = disable this feature.
mot_ctrl_disable_delay_msint1000Motor controller disabling delay [ms] after activating brakes: -1 = never disable, 0 = no delay
mot_ctrl_startup_delay_main_contactor_msint0Time given for main contactor to stabilize before enabling drive. 0 = no delay, 500 = recommended for Schwarzmueller.
mot_ctrl_startup_delay_drive_enable_msint0Time given for driveEnable to take hold before releasing brakes. 0 = no delay, 100 = recommended for Schwarzmueller.
mot_ctrl_startup_delay_brake_release_msint0Time given for brakes to fully open before giving rpm out. 0 = no delay, 200 = recommended for Schwarzmueller, 100..300 = recommended for Curtis.
mot_ctrl_omni_steer_angle_hard_limit_deg_posfloat[]0.0Sets an error if the control or sensor value exceeds this value. The CAN control output is cut at this positive limit. Value 0.0 for no limit. Only used for omnis with CAN interface.
mot_ctrl_omni_steer_angle_hard_limit_deg_negfloat[]0.0Sets error if the control or sensor value goes below this value. The CAN control output is cut at this negative limit. Value 0.0 for no limit. Only used for omnis with CAN interface.
mot_ctrl_steer_typeint[]1Type of the motor controller for steering: 1 = Schwarzmueller, 2 = Engel
mot_ctrl_omni_speed_inv_inputint[]0Inversion of speed input if the sensor gives negative speed when the wheel is rotated forwards. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.
mot_ctrl_omni_speed_inv_outputint[]0Inversion of speed output if a positive reference gives a negative speed. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.
mot_ctrl_omni_speed_pfloat[]1.0Speed control proportional gain for each wheel. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.
mot_ctrl_omni_speed_dfloat[]1.0Speed control derivative gain for each wheel. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.
mot_ctrl_omni_steer_inv_inputint[]0Inversion of steer angle input if the sensor value increases clockwise. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.
mot_ctrl_omni_steer_inv_outputint[]0Inversion of steer motor output if a positive reference gives a clockwise wheel turning. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.
mot_ctrl_omni_steer_pfloat[]1.0Steer control proportional gain for each wheel. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.
mot_ctrl_omni_steer_dfloat[]1.0Steer control derivative gain for each wheel. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.
mot_ctrl_omni_steer_ifloat[]1.0Steer control integral gain for each wheel. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.
mot_ctrl_omni_speed_control_usedint[]01 indicates wheels with speed control. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.
mot_ctrl_engel_p_gainfloat0.2Engel motor controller proportinal gain.
mot_ctrl_engel_i_time_msfloat4.0Engel motor controller integration time [ms].
mot_ctrl_engel_home_offsetint0Engel motor controller homing offset.
mot_ctrl_engel_estop_enabledint1Engel emergency stop activation. Emergency stop activation comes from digital input 8 (BU-RD wire). DI8 should be powered in normal mode.
mot_ctrl_micontrol_estop_check_enabledint1Activates MiControl E-STOP check. Emergency stop activation comes from digital input 6 and 7 (STO-A and STO-B).
mot_ctrl_simulated_drive_controller_type_arrint[]MOTOR_CONTROLLER_TYPE_SIMULATEDType of the simulated drive motor controller: -1 - Single channel simulated motor controller
mot_ctrl_drive_controller_type_arrint[]MOTOR_CONTROLLER_TYPE_NOT_DEFINEDType of the drive motor controller: 0 - none, 1 - Schwarzmueller (not implemented), 2 - Engel (not implemented) 3 - Nanotec, 4 - Kinco, 5 - Roboteq single channel, 6 - Roboteq dual channel 1, 7 - Roboteq dual channel 2
mot_ctrl_drive_can_nodeid_arrint[]0Motor controller CAN node id for drive motor controller. 0 = this parameter not used
mot_ctrl_drive_inv_input_arrint[]0Invert drive motor controller input. 0 = no inversion, 1 = invert input
mot_ctrl_drive_inv_output_arrint[]0Invert drive motor controller output. 0 = no inversion, 1 = invert output,
mot_ctrl_drive_min_output_arrint[]-1Minimum output sent to the drive motor controller (cutoff point). -1 = this parameter not used
mot_ctrl_drive_max_output_arrint[]-1Maximum output sent to the drive motor controller (cutoff point). -1 = this parameter not used
mot_ctrl_drive_max_stall_output_pct_arrfloat[]0.0Percentage of maximum output sent to the drive motor controller when AGV is at stall (AGV not moving with non-zero reference). 0.0 = this parameter not used.
mot_ctrl_drive_dist_scale_arrfloat[]0.0Distance scale for drive motor controller. 0.0 = this parameter not used.
mot_ctrl_drive_rpm_to_m_per_s_arrfloat[]0.0Value used to convert drive motor controller rpm to m/s. 0.0 = this parameter not used.
mot_ctrl_drive_torque_mNm_arrint[]-1Torque value (milli Newton meter) send to drive motor controller. -1 = this parameter not used
mot_ctrl_drive_p_arrfloat[]0.0P value of the drive motor controller. 0.0 = this parameter not used.
mot_ctrl_drive_i_arrfloat[]0.0I value of the drive motor controller. 0.0 = this parameter not used.
mot_ctrl_drive_d_arrfloat[]0.0D value of the drive motor controller. 0.0 = this parameter not used.
mot_ctrl_drive_estop_enabled_arrint[]-1Emergency stop activation for drive motor controller, -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = estop not used, 1 = estop used
mot_ctrl_drive_disable_delay_ms_arrint[]-1Drive motor controller disabling delay after activating brakes in ms, -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = no delay, 300 = recommended for Schwarzmueller
mot_ctrl_drive_startup_delay_main_contactor_ms_arrint[]-1Time given in ms for drive motor controller main contactor to stabilize before enabling drive. -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = no delay, 500 = recommended for Schwarzmueller.
mot_ctrl_drive_startup_delay_drive_enable_ms_arrint[]-1Time given in ms for driveEnable to take hold before releasing brakes on drive motor controller. -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = no delay, 100 = recommended for Schwarzmueller.
mot_ctrl_drive_startup_delay_brake_release_ms_arrint[]-1Time given in ms for brakes to fully open before giving rpm out to drive motor controller. -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = no delay, 200 = recommended for Schwarzmueller, 100..300 = recommended for Curtis
mot_ctrl_drive_reset_errors_timer_ms_arrint[]-1After the defined time (ms) Navigation SW tries automatically reset drive motor controller faults. -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = fault reset disabled
mot_ctrl_drive_disable_main_contactor_ms_arrint[]-1Disable drive motor controller main contactor to save energy after standing still for the defined time (ms), -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = disable this feature
mot_ctrl_drive_encoder_pulses_per_rev_arruint[]0Encoder resolution (pulses per revolution) used to calculate RPM if drive motor controller does not provide that. 0 = this parameter not used
mot_ctrl_drive_pfloat0.0P value of the drive motor controller. 0.0 = this parameter not used.
mot_ctrl_drive_ifloat0.0I value of the drive motor controller. 0.0 = this parameter not used.
mot_ctrl_drive_dfloat0.0D value of the drive motor controller. 0.0 = this parameter not used.
mot_ctrl_drive_estop_enabledint-1Emergency stop activation for drive motor controller, -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = estop not used, 1 = estop used
mot_ctrl_drive_disable_delay_msint-1Drive motor controller disabling delay after activating brakes in ms, -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = no delay, 300 = recommended for Schwarzmueller
mot_ctrl_drive_startup_delay_main_contactor_msint-1Time given in ms for drive motor controller main contactor to stabilize before enabling drive. -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = no delay, 500 = recommended for Schwarzmueller.
mot_ctrl_drive_startup_delay_drive_enable_msint-1Time given in ms for driveEnable to take hold before releasing brakes on drive motor controller. -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = no delay, 100 = recommended for Schwarzmueller.
mot_ctrl_drive_startup_delay_brake_release_msint-1Time given in ms for brakes to fully open before giving rpm out to drive motor controller. -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = no delay, 200 = recommended for Schwarzmueller, 100..300 = recommended for Curtis
mot_ctrl_drive_reset_errors_timer_msint-1After the defined time (ms) Navigation SW tries automatically reset drive motor controller faults. -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = fault reset disabled
mot_ctrl_drive_disable_main_contactor_msint-1Disable drive motor controller main contactor to save energy after standing still for the defined time (ms), -1 = this parameter not used, 0 = disable this feature
mot_ctrl_drive_encoder_pulses_per_revuint0Encoder resolution (pulses per revolution) used to calculate RPM if drive motor controller does not provide that.
mot_ctrl_simulated_steer_controller_type_arrint[]MOTOR_CONTROLLER_TYPE_SIMULATEDType of the simulated motor controller for steering: -1 - Single channel simulated motor controller
mot_ctrl_steer_controller_type_arrint[]MOTOR_CONTROLLER_TYPE_NOT_DEFINEDType of the motor controller for steering: Same values as mot_ctrl_drive_controller_type_arr
mot_ctrl_steer_can_nodeid_arrint[]0Motor controller CAN node id for steer motor. 0 = this parameter not used

mot_ctrl_steer_inv_output_arrint[]0Invert steer motor controller output. 0 = no inversion, 1 = invert output

Roboteq

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
roboteq_check_echoint10 = do not check command echo, 1 = check command echo, 2 = old obsolete value (behaves as 1).
roboteq_channel1_rightint1Defines which motor is controlled by channel one of the motor controller: 0 = left, 1 = right
roboteq_brake_output1int-1Digital out number for first brake, -1 if disabled.
roboteq_brake_output2int-1Digital out number for second brake, -1 if disabled.
roboteq_angle_sensor_typeint1Roboteq motor controller's angle sensor type: 0 = Hall, Sine Cosine and Resolver sensors, 1 = encoders
roboteq_angle_sensor_type_arrint[]-1Override values for roboteq_angle_sensor_type when CAN interface is used and sensor type is not the same for all controllers.
roboteq_channel1_steerint11 = channel one of Motor controller is right steering, 0 = driving.

Nanotec

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
nanotec_emergency_stop_IO_enabledint0Nanotec internal emergency stop activation. Emergency stop activation comes from digital inputs 1 and 2.

Syntron

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
syntron_profiled_accelerationuint327408Syntron motor controller acceleration slope [pulses/s^2]
syntron_profiled_decelerationuint327679Syntron motor controller deceleration slope [pulses/s^2]
syntron_max_accelerationuint3537456Syntron motor controller maximum acceleration [pulses/s^2]
syntron_max_decelerationuint3537648Syntron motor controller maximum deceleration [pulses/s^2]
syntron_max_torqueuint43513Syntron motor controller maximum torque [mNm].

Quicktron

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
quicktron_nodeidint00 = not defined, >0 Node ID for quicktron can Card. In default setup the node ID is 1.
quicktron_zero_encodersint00 = no zeroing, 1 = Reset angle data to 0, needed only for calibration.

Dunker

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_cmduint117DriveCommand used: 116 (x74) Speed mode, 117 (x75) Sub Speed mode
dunker_mot_ctrl_start_delay_msuint100Start delay [ms]. Must be > t1 + t2 (Brake_Management_OffDelay1 + Brake_Management_OffDelay2).
dunker_mot_ctrl_cooldown_time_msuint200Cooldown time [ms] before reactivating drive.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_values_overrideint0Enables Dunkermotoren OD parameter values written using Navigation SW parameters in params.txt.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_vel_kpuint[]100VEL_Kp - P-gain of the speed/position PID-controller.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_svel_kpuint[]600SVEL_Kp - P-gain of the SVEL-PI-controller.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_svel_kiuint[]60SVEL_Ki - I-gain of the SVEL-PI-controller.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_curr_kpuint[]20CURR_Kp - P-gain of the PI-current-controller.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_curr_kiuint[]10CURR_Ki - I-gain of the PI-current-controller.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_vel_kvffuint[]1000VEL_Kvff - defines the velocity feed-forward control.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_motor_typeuint[]1MOTOR_Type: 0 = Brush type motor (DC), 1 = Brushless motor (BLDC).
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_motor_polnuint[]8MOTOR_PolN - number of poles in motor.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_motor_polarityuint[]2MOTOR_Polarity - change sign/unit by setting corresponding bit for, PWM (Bit0), Hall sensor (Bit1), Encoder (Bit3), Abs Encoder (Bit4).
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_vel_feedbackuint[]2378VEL_Feedback - feedback source of the velocity and the positioning controller, 0 = Auto, 256 = AIN0, 274 = EMF feedback, 2378 = HALL, 2410 = Encoder, 2426 = Absolute Encoder.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_svel_feedbackuint[]2378SVEL_Feedback - source of the SVEL feedback, 0 = Auto, 274 = EMF feedback, 2378 = HALL, 2410 = Encoder, 2426 = Absolute Encoder.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_motor_enc_resolutionuint[]24MOTOR_ENC_Resolution - resolution [pulses per revolution] of the incremental encoder.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_motor_curr_limitmaxposuint[]50000CURR_LimitMaxPos - maximum current [mA] for the positive range.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_motor_curr_limitmaxneguint[]50000CURR_LimitMaxNeg - maximum current [mA] for the negative range.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_motor_curr_dynlimitmodeuint[]1CURR_DynLimitMode - activates and deactivates the dynamic limitation of the current: 0 = limitation deactivated, 1 = limitation activated
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_motor_curr_dynlimitpeakuint[]50000CURR_DynLimitPeak - Dynamic current limit I*t - Peak current [mA].
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_motor_curr_dynlimitcontuint[]16900CURR_DynLimitCont - Dynamic current limit I*t - Continuous current [mA].
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_motor_curr_dynlimittimeuint[]2000CURR_DynLimitTime - maximum time [ms] for the peak current.
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_velocity_acc_delta_vuint[]3000Velocity Acceleration - Delta v [rpm]
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_velocity_dec_delta_vuint[]3000Velocity Deceleration - Delta v [rpm]
dunker_mot_ctrl_drive_pid_vel_kaffuint[]150VEL_Kaff - PID-Controller Acceleration Feed Forward [mA].

CAN Configuration

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
can_steer_drive_steering_nodeidint30Node ID for steer drive steering controller.
can_steer_drive_driving_nodeidint31Node ID for steer drive driving controller.
can_diffunit_left_nodeidint[]0CANOpen Node ID for diffunit left motor controllers.
can_diffunit_right_nodeidint[]0CANOpen Node ID for diffunit right motor controllers.
can_diff_drive_left_nodeidint30Node ID for diff drive left motor controller.
can_diff_drive_right_nodeidint31Node ID for diff drive right motor controller.
can_sick_mls_event_timer_msint10Can sick mls event timer for TPDO1.
can_sick_mls_calibrate_offsetint[]0Trigger offset calibration - see SICK MLS manual for instructions.
can_sick_mls_factory_resetint[]0Factory reset the can sick mls sensor - see SICK MLS manual for instructions.
can_enabledint0Enables CAN communication.
can_nmt_masterint1Enables Navigation SW to work as CANOpen NMT master on primary CAN.
can_syncint1Navigation SW (Primary CAN) role for CANOpen SYNC messages: 0 = None, 1 = SYNC producer, 2 = SYNC consumer
can_sync_rx_modeint1Select sync receive PDOs: 0 = Legacy (all predefined), 1 = True CANOpen SYNC PDOs only. Ignored if can_sync=0 or no CANOpen SYNC PDOs exist.
can_send_nmt_start_alwaysint0Defines when Navigation SW (Primary CAN) sends CIA301_NMT_CMD_START: 0 = Only on state change, 1 = Periodically every 1 second.
can_chint0Primary CAN channel number. Assumes device names like can0, can1,...
can_devicestringPrimary CAN device name; overrides can_ch if defined.
can_bitrate_kint250Primary CAN bus bitrate [Kbit/s]: 125, 250, 500 or 1000
can_min_tx_interval_usint0Primary CAN minimum transmit interval: 0 = not defined, >0 = Mininimu interval [us].
can_primary_any_idint0Primary CAN valid PDO id's that can be registered: 0 = Only valid PDO id's can be registered, 1 = Any id can be registered.
can_sdo_interval_msint100Primary CAN SDO message interval [ms] used by Navigation software.
can_sdo_timeout_msint500Primary CAN SDO message response timeout [ms] used by Navigation software.
can_sdo_write_from_fileint0Enables SDO writes from file sdo_write.txt for primary CAN.
can_heartbeat_producer_enableint0Enables Navigation software to be Heartbeat producer for primary CAN.
can_pdo_timeout_redefineint0CAN PDO timeouts/intervals: 0 = Using fixed defaults , 1 = Redefines based on parameters (control_interval_us, control_interval_error_ratio).
can_nodeguard_guard_time_msint200Nodeguarding guard time [ms]: 0 = Nodeguard disabled
can_reconnect_timer_msint200CAN reconnect delay [ms] after fatal issue has been detected.
can_comms_restart_timer_msint00 = disabled
can_bypass_failed_sdo_timer_secsint0After this time [s] CAN will be forced to OPERATIONAL state(with ERROR), even if all SDO writes are not successful. 0 = disabled
can_reset_flush_allint0
can_error_logging_interval_msint5000The interval [ms] for logging CAN not rxed
can2_chint-1Secondary CAN channel number: -1 = disabled. Assumes device names like can0, can1,...
can2_devicestringSecondary CAN device name; overrides can2_ch if defined.
can2_bitrate_kint250Secondary CAN bus bitrate [Kbit/s]: 125, 250, 500 or 1000.
can2_min_tx_interval_usint0Secondary CAN minimum transmit interval: 0 = not defined, >0 = Minimum interval [us]
can2_syncint0Enables Navigation software to send SYNC messages to secondary CAN (tied to primary CAN SYNC).
can2_send_nmt_startint0Enables Navigation software to send NMT start messages to secondary CAN (tied to primary CAN NMT start).
can_enable_tpdo_transmitint[]1Enables sending of each corresponding TPDO. All enabled by default, so these parameters can be used to disable sending of specific TPDOs.
can_use_drive_encodersint0Select whether external CAN drive encoders are used for a steer/diff AGV: 0 = not used, 1= external drive encoder(s) used.
external_navigation_controller_node_idint0External Navigation Controller Node ID: 0 = not defined, 1-127 = valid node ID.
navigation_software_node_idint0Navigation Software CANOpen Node ID: 0 = not defined, 1-127 = valid node ID.
can_steer_enc_modelint0Steering encoder model: 0 = generic (no config), 1 = Leine&Linde (RSA608), 2 = Sick (AHS/AHM36)
can_roboteq_nodeidint[]-1Roboteq controller CAN node ID.
can_roboteq_listen_nodeidint[]-1Roboteq controller CAN listen node ID.
can_roboteq_comms_modeint00 = miniCAN, 1 = CANOpen; common setting for all Roboteq controllers.
can_roboteq_drive_ctrl_indexint[]0Maps roboteq drive controller node ID to wheel index. For example, can_roboteq_drive_ctrl_index[0], 0 would mean that node ID defined can_roboteq_nodeid[0] would be drive wheel 0.
can_roboteq_steer_ctrl_indexint[]1Maps roboteq steer controller node ID to wheel index. For example, can_roboteq_steer_ctrl_index[0], 1 would mean that node ID defined can_roboteq_nodeid[1] would be steer wheel 0.
can_roboteq_right_ctrl_indexint[]0Maps roboteq right controller node ID to wheel index. For example, can_roboteq_right_ctrl_index[0], 0 would mean that node ID defined can_roboteq_nodeid[0] would be right wheel 0.
can_roboteq_left_ctrl_indexint[]1Maps roboteq left controller node ID to wheel index. For example, can_roboteq_left_ctrl_index[0], 1 would mean that node ID defined can_roboteq_nodeid[1] would be left wheel 0.
can_omni_steer_ctrl_nodeidint[]0Node ID for omni steering controller (array index = wheel number). 0 = not defined, 1-127 = valid node ID.
can_omni_drive_ctrl_nodeidint[]0Node ID for omni drive controller (array index = wheel number). 0 = not defined, 1-127 = valid node ID.
can_extbatt_if_node_idint0Can node ID for battery managment system: 0 = not defined, 1-127 = valid node ID.
can_extbatt_if_secondary_busint0Defines which CAN bus is used by BMS: 0 = Primary CAN Bus, 1 = Secondary CAN Bus
can_actuator_ctrl_node_idint[]0CAN node ID of the actuator: 0 = not defined, 1-127 = valid node ID.
can_actuator_ctrl_modelint[]0CAN actuator controller model: 0 = None, 1 = Schwarzmueller (reference). 2 = Curtis (reference/binary)
can_actuator_ctrl_torqueint[]0Motor control torque.
can_actuator_ctrl_rpm_to_m_per_sfloat[]1.0Motor control convert rpm to m/s. For Curtis, should be set between to actuator max speed / 32767.
can_actuator_ctrl_prop_valve_idxint[]0Proportional valve index. For Schwarzmueller - 1 (pin27) or 2 (pin16). For Curtis F2-T - 0 (pin 2) or 1 (pin 19).
can_actuator_ctrl_prop_valve_maxint[]200Proportional valve max output. For Curtis, should be set between 0-32767.
can_actuator_ctrl_prop_valve_minint[]0Proportional valve min output.

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
rls_absolute_serial_portstring/dev/ttyS3RS422 interfaced RLS absolute encoder serial port path
steer_enc_zeroint0Pulse encoder value corresponding to zero angle of steer wheel.

ethercat_enc_steer_modelint1Ethercat encoder model in steer drive: 1 = Generic (Sick AFS/AFM60)
steer_enc_pulses_per_revint1000Steering encoder pulses per full 360 degrees revolution (for steer/diff_steer AGVs).
steer_enc_pulses_overflowuint0xFFFFFFFUSteering encoder pulses overflow value. Maximum value + 1.
enc_zero_auto_update_enabledint1Enables automatic encoder zero offset redefiniton when using multi-turn encoder.
can_rls_sen_nodeidint[]-1RLS absolute encoder CAN node ID: 0 = not defined, 1-127 = valid node ID.
can_enc_actuator_node_idint[]0CAN node ID of the actuator's encoder: 0 = not defined, 1-127 = valid node ID.
can_enc_actuator_coefffloat[]1.0Coefficient to convert encoder pulses to correct unit (length/height [m], angle [rad]).
can_enc_actuator_calib_val_encint[]0Encoder value that matches actuator calibration value.
can_enc_actuator_calib_val_actfloat[]0Actuator value that matches encoder calibration value. Value in correct unit depending on the actuator type (length/height [m], angle [rad]).
can_enc_actuator_pulses_overflowuint[]0xFFFFFFFUMaximum encoder value.
can_enc_actuator_pulses_per_revint[]1000Encoder pulses per revolution.
can_enc_actuator_invuint[]0Inverse the value from encoder.
can_enc_actuator_modelint[]0Actuator's encoder model: 0 = generic (no config), 1 = Leine&Linde (RSA608), 2 = Sick (AHS/AHM36)

ethercat_enc_omni_model_arrint[]1Ethercat encoder model in omni drive (index - wheel number), 1 = Generic (Sick AFS/AFM60).
can_enc_drive_node_id_arrint[]0CAN node ID of drive controller encoder (array index = wheel number): 0 = not defined, 1-127 = valid node ID.
can_enc_drive_pulses_overflow_arruint[]0xFFFFFFFUMaximum encoder value.
can_enc_drive_pulses_per_rev_arruint[]1000Encoder pulses per revolution.
can_enc_drive_model_arrint[]0CAN drive controller encoder model:0 = generic (no config) 1 = Leine&Linde (RSA608), 2 = Sick (AHS/AHM36)
wheel_speed_measured_arrint[]01-wheel with separate speed encoder measurement as a substitute for the speed measurement from a speed controller. Indexes according to customer wheel numbering.

Extra sensors

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
uss_typeint00 = no Ultrasonic Sensors, 1 = Neobtoix USS CAN
uss_sensors_installeduint0Ultrasonic sensors installed in system as a bitmask. For example 3855 = 111100001111b means sensors 1-4 and 9-12 are installed in the system. Maximum number of sensors is 16.
uss_select_active_sensors_propertyint0Define which custom property is used as bitmap to activate sensors: 0 = all sensors active, 1-5 use custom attribute 1-5 protection zone, for example decimal 19 in binary 10011 means activate sensors 1, 2 and 5, others deactivated.
uss_activate_sensors_based_on_driving_dirint00 = use only custom properties to determine active scanners, 1 = activate sensors based on driving direction (naive approach, currently checks only sign of the velocity)
uss_sensor_facing_backwardsuint0Mark sensors that are facing backwards. Otherwise sensor is forwards. Bitmapped value, so for example value 240 = 11110000b means sensors 1-4 are forwards and 5-8 backwards.
uss_trigger_zonesint0Enables triggering of slow down/stopping zones from ultrasonic sensors.
uss_slow_speed_limitfloat0.2If speed is higher than this (fw or bw), use the distances for fast speed to trigger zones.
uss_sensor_zone1_dist_fastfloat[]0.70Trigger protection zone from ultrasonic sensors (fast speed), if reading of sensor is smaller than the defined parameter. Distance can be defined to each sensor individually.
uss_sensor_zone2_dist_fastfloat[]1.00Trigger warning zone 1 from ultrasonic sensors (fast speed), if reading of sensor is smaller than the defined parameter. Distance can be defined to each sensor individually.
uss_sensor_zone3_dist_fastfloat[]1.50Trigger warning zone 2 from ultrasonic sensors (fast speed), if reading of sensor is smaller than the defined parameter. Distance can be defined to each sensor individually.
uss_sensor_zone1_dist_slowfloat[]0.20Trigger protection zone from ultrasonic sensors (slow speed), if reading of sensor is smaller than the defined parameter. Distance can be defined to each sensor individually.
uss_sensor_zone2_dist_slowfloat[]0.40Trigger warning zone 1 from ultrasonic sensors (slow speed), if reading of sensor is smaller than the defined parameter. Distance can be defined to each sensor individually.
uss_sensor_zone3_dist_slowfloat[]1.50Trigger warning zone 2 from ultrasonic sensors (slow speed), if reading of sensor is smaller than the defined parameter. Distance can be defined to each sensor individually.
uss_set_active_sensors_only_on_changeint1Defines sending of active channels: 0 = default interval, 1 = if sensor setting changed.
uss_delay_to_ignore_dist_after_change_msint0Delay [ms] to ignore distance data for triggering zones after sending a command to change active sensors.
uss_enable_disabled_sensors_after_msuint0Delay [ms] to enable ultrasonic sensors disabled by the user. 0 = timer disabled.
rfid_check_enabledint0Enables RFID (aka. container type ID) verification.

simove_navigation_odometry_sourceint0Used odometry source: 0 = velocity, 1 = position
