Some non-CANopen devices however use such non-configurable settings (like message IDs) that they can't or shouldn't be connected to Navitrol Primary CAN bus. If there are non-CANopen devices sending messages with IDs conflicting with CANopen specification, then those devices need to be connected in a separate CAN bus. For that purpose Navitrol supports two simultaneous CAN buses, primary and secondary. Use of two buses makes it also possible to connect to CAN devices with different bitrates.

NOTE: There are also COTS products (CAN bridges) that make it possible to connect non-CANopen compliant devices or even devices with different bitrates to Navitrol Primary CAN bus. CAN-bridges support message ID translation/filtering that makes this possible.

Troubleshooting

CAN bus message logging

Navitrol logs always some amount of events related to CAN communication and CAN related issues. If one wishes to see all data sent to CAN bus and received from CAN bus, byte by byte, this can be accomplished by enabling can logging parameters.

Summary of received/not received objects is logged periodically whenever some of the expected CAN objects are missing. By setting parameter log_can_summary to 1, this summary is logged periodically even if there are no errors.

Examples of logged data are below. All these are subject to change when it comes to details. Key phrases, marked with double quotes in title (like "RX_RAW"), in the log will not change whenever it is possible to do so.

Obligatory receive objects never received i.e. "NotRxed"

0.4447 [08:1] CAN: PRI Node 30 Obj 19Eh NotRxed

0.4447 [08:1] CAN: PRI Node 30 Obj 29Eh NotRxed

0.4447 [08:1] CAN: PRI Node 31 Obj 19Fh NotRxed

0.4447 [08:1] CAN: PRI Node 31 Obj 29Fh NotRxed

NOTE: Available as shown here starting from Navitrol version 6.30.00

Navitrol versions 6.28 and older log only first missing object without node ID.

Received CAN messages, byte by byte: "RX_RAW" (params.log_can > 0)

234.3283 [08:6] CAN_INTE: RX_RAW PRI 2BCh dlc 8 00 00 00 00 00 00 04 00

234.3324 [23:6] CAN_INTE: RX_RAW SEC 1B2h dlc 8 00 00 00 00 00 00 03 DF

  • SEC -- PRIMARY/SECONDARY bus

  • 1B2h -- Message id in hex

  • dlc 8 -- Message length in bytes

  • 00 00 00 00 00 00 03 DF -- Message byte by byte

Transmitted CAN messages, byte by byte: "TX_RAW" (params.log_can > 0)

307.9164 [08:6] CAN_INTE: TX_RAW PRI 1B2h dlc 8 00 00 00 00 00 00 03 63

307.9165 [23:6] CAN_INTE: TX_RAW SEC 2BCh dlc 8 00 00 00 00 00 00 04 00

Log line interpretation is exactly same as before in case of RX message.

NOTE: you can pick both RX_RAW and TX_RAW, by using "X_RAW" as a key phrase.

"RX_SUM" (ERROR OR params.log_can_summary > 0)

53.4326 [08:6] CAN: RX_SUM

53.4326 [08:6] CAN: RX_SUM PRI node 50 Obj 232h XXX_IN1 rxed/req 0/1, age --- ms

53.4326 [08:6] CAN: RX_SUM PRI node 50 Obj 332h XXX _IN2 rxed/req 0/1, age --- ms

53.4326 [08:6] CAN: RX_SUM PRI node 50 Obj 432h XXX _IN3 rxed/req 1/1, age 732 ms

53.4326 [08:6] CAN: RX_SUM SEC node 60 Obj 23Ch BUS2_1 rxed/req 0/1, age --- ms

53.4326 [08:6] CAN: RX_SUM SEC node 60 Obj 33Ch BUS2_2 rxed/req 0/1, age --- ms

  • SEC -- PRIMARY/SECONDARY bus

  • 60 - node ID of the CAN device

  • 33Ch -- Message id in hex

  • rxed/req 0/1 -- Received at least once/required; if required message has not been received at all, then ERROR_CAN_ALL_NODES_NOT_OPER is generated (see troubleshooting section for more information)

  • --- -- Age of the message in ms (--- means that message has never been received)

CAN: "Summary of registered objects" (at startup)

At startup Navitrol logs also a summary of all registered objects, i.e. objects transmitted or parsed by Navitrol. If Navitrol has been running for a long time, this info is not yet available in standard log file, but can still be found in startlog.txt.

0.3924 [08:6] CAN: Summary of registered objects

0.3924 [08:6] CAN: Rx00: PRI node 50 COBid 0232h SYNC 1 TimeoutTime 50

0.3924 [08:6] CAN: Rx01: PRI node 50 COBid 0332h SYNC 1 TimeoutTime 50

0.3924 [08:6] CAN: Rx02: PRI node 50 COBid 0432h SYNC 1 TimeoutTime 50

0.3924 [08:6] CAN: Rx03: PRI node 50 COBid 0532h SYNC 1 TimeoutTime 50

0.3924 [08:6] CAN: Rx04: SEC node 60 COBid 023Ch SYNC 1 TimeoutTime 50

0.3924 [08:6] CAN: Rx05: SEC node 60 COBid 033Ch SYNC 1 TimeoutTime 50

0.3924 [08:6] CAN: Tx00: PRI node 50 COBid 01B2h SYNC 1 TxInterval 30 TxInterval min 10

0.3924 [08:6] CAN: Tx01: PRI node 50 COBid 02B2h SYNC 1 TxInterval 30 TxInterval min 10

0.3924 [08:6] CAN: Tx02: PRI node 50 COBid 03B2h SYNC 1 TxInterval 30 TxInterval min 10

0.3924 [08:6] CAN: Tx03: SEC node 60 COBid 01BCh SYNC 1 TxInterval 30 TxInterval min 10

0.3924 [08:6] CAN: Tx04: SEC node 60 COBid 02BCh SYNC 1 TxInterval 30 TxInterval min 10

  • Tx04 -- message type (Rx, Tx, Od)

  • SEC -- PRIMARY/SECONDARY bus

  • 60 -- node ID of the CAN device whose objects are registered -- typically used as a basis for message parsing and building.

  • 1B2h -- Message id in hex

  • SYNC 1 -- Tells whether message is a SYNC object or not. SYNC objects are used for synchronizing all operation in Navitrol.

  • TimeoutTime 50 -- Receive message timeout time. If receive interval exceeds this limit, error ERROR_CAN_RX_TIMEOUT is generated (see troubleshooting section for more information).

  • TxInterval 30 TxInterval min 10 -- Maximum and minimum transit intervals for each transmit object.

Troubleshooting CAN communication

Navitrol itself can detect some CAN related configuration issues, missing CAN nodes/objects and some major issues on the bus. It should be noted that Navitrol does have only limited capability to detect low level CAN bus related issues. Therefore truly comprehensive troubleshooting and analysis requires also other means, like use of a CAN analyzer.

CAN communication issue checklist

Typical problems are

  • Cabling related issues

    • Bus topology

    • Termination missing or incorrect

    • CAN_H/CAN_L "cross-connected"

    • Ground/shield connections

  • Sometimes it is assumed that powering through CAN interface is a standard feature (Navitrol IPC CAN connector does not have supply power)

  • CAN node missing or connected in a wrong way

  • One or more CAN nodes configured in wrong way (bitrate or node IDs in CANopen)

  • Mixing basic CAN and CANopen -- resulting in duplicate message IDs, maybe message IDs that conflict with CANopen basic mechanisms.

  • Damaged CAN interface

Additional things to verify:

  • Check that all devices are powered

  • Verify that CAN wiring & configuration rules have been followed.

  • Verify that configuration for CAN devices is ok

    • Same bitrate for all devices

    • Unique node ID (1...127) for all CANopen devices

    • Basic CAN message IDs do not conflict with CANopen ones

  • Each CANopen device should send bootup message at startup (0x700 + node ID)

  • CAN bus voltages

  • In Navitrol

    • Verify that Navitrol's CAN related parameters are set up correctly

    • Check for any CAN related ERROR active. See Error Descriptions for different CAN-errors

    • Verify that Navitrol is receiving CAN messages as expected: "RX_RAW" logging

    • Verify that Navitrol is receiving CAN messages from all configured nodes: "RX_SUM" logging

If any of the CAN devices on the bus is configured for wrong bitrate, then it typically messes all communication. In such a case it is often necessary to connect (or disconnect) CAN devices to the bus one by one and first find out which one of the devices causes the issues.

CAN Analyzer

Even if the communication seems to work kind of ok, it is possible that there are issues that result in collisions, delays and time jitter in communication. In case of unclear problems, it is often good policy to connect a CAN analyzer to the bus to check if there are detectable issues. For example errors in basic CAN device configuration (different bitrates, duplicated node IDs,..) often result in "Error frames" or other errors that can be detected using CAN analyzer SW. It is not that clear that all these errors are detected by Navitrol at all. See picture below.

Most useful windows for troubleshooting are "Bus Statistics" and "Output Window". Left hand pictures show contents in "normal" case without any issues. Bus Statistics details that should be checked are marked in picture. Right hand side on the other hand shows same windows in a case where physical bus has issues.

In some AGV's it is not that straightforward to physically connect to the bus. In those cases CAN hub (like Kvaser T-Cannector, see pic below) helps a lot.

SDO errors

SDO errors might occur if something was done incorrectly during the commissioning. If SDO Response message starts with 80 instead of 60 the SDO message has failed. The error reason is written to the last four data bytes and in that case the error can be googled.

SEND/RESPONSECOB ID (in hex 0x)dlcData bytes (in hex 0x)Description
SEND60182F 81 2F 00 00 00 00 00SDO Upload request:
Trying to set baud rate to 0 kbs
RESPONSE581880 81 2F 00 32 00 09 06Response not ok. Error code 0609 0032h: Value of parameter written too low.

Failed SDO message example

Appendix A

SDO write configuration

Navitrol supports writing OD parameters at startup time to any CANopen slave. Some of these write commands are "hard-coded" in Navitrol, but it is also possible to define any other SDO writes using ASCII-file sdo_write.txt, format explained below.

#--------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Sample file -- sdo_write.txt

#--------------------------------------------------------------------------

#

# Any data on a line after character '#' is ignored (regarded as comment)

#

# Mode, node ID, type, Idx.SubIdx, value

# - mode shall be

# * WRITE -- absolute write; value is written to OD as specified in file

# - Supported types are: I8 I16 I32 U8 U16 U32 F

# - Idx.SubIdx are both decimal or both hex (not mixed)

# - Integer values can be expressed in decimal or hex, prefix for hex values shall be 'x' or '0x'

# - spaces are ignored - can't have spaces separating items in single value though

#
# NODE 63
#

WRITE, 63,U8,0x4310.1,100 # VEL_Kp - PID-Position Controller - proportional gain

WRITE,63,I16,1500.09,x100

WRITE,63, I32, 0x49A0.20, x6400

WRITE, 40 , U16 , 1500.09 , x300

#
# NODE 22
#

WRITE, 22, I16, 1500.09, x100

#
# NODE 0x20 i.e. 32
#

WRITE,0x20, I16, 1500.09, x100

CAN Supervisor Interface

Updated 26.01.2024

Introduction

This document describes the interface between the Navitrol software and the AGV supervisor over CAN bus. Both programs are run on their dedicated computer units.

General CAN Network Definitions
Physical layerCAN ISO/DIS 11898
ID-format11-bit
Data length8 bytes
Byte orderLittle endian (Lowest byte first)

Message formats and definitions for PDOs between Navitrol and Supervisor are defined in following subsections.

Messages from the AGV supervisor to Navitrol

Following messages can be sent from AGV supervisor to Navitrol over CAN.

101 - Supervisor Status
Type ID101
TransmitterAGV Supervisor
ReceiverNavitrol
Length8
DataByte 0Bit 0: Status, 1 if OK, 0 otherwise.
If status is set to 1 Navitrol can drive the AGV
Bit 1: Estop. 1 when ESTOP active, 0 otherwise
Bit 2: DriveDisabled, automatic driving will not start if this bit is 1.
Bit 3-7: Reserved
Byte 1Bit 0: Safety Scanner Protection Zone
Bit 1: Safety Scanner Warning Zone 1
Bit 2: Safety Scanner Warning Zone 2
Bit 3-7: Reserved
Byte 2Binary input signals
Each bit indicates one binary input:
0 OFF/INACTIVE
1 ON/ACTIVE
Mapping and functionality of binary inputs are project specific.
Byte 3-7Reserved

102 - Command Message

See subsection Command And Result Protocol for more details about data members in this message.
Type ID102
TransmitterAGV Supervisor
ReceiverNavitrol
Length8
DataByte 0Command ID
Byte 1-7Command Data

Messages from Navitrol to the AGV supervisor

Navitrol can be configured to periodically send following messages over CAN.

201 - Navitrol Status
Type ID201
TransmitterNavitrol
ReceiverAGV supervisor
Length8
DataByte 0BIT 0: Error status
0 = no err
1 = error on
Bit 1: Position Initialization Status
0 = Failed
1 = Succeeded
Bit 2-7: Reserved
Byte 1Navitrol State

START_STATE = 1,
STANDBY_STATE = 2,
AUTO_STATE = 3,
FSTOP_STATE = 9,
LOAD_STATE = 14,
HOLD_STATE = 15,
MANUAL_STATE = 16,
PAUSE_STATE = 17
Byte 2Position confidence in percentage (0 - 100%)
Format: 8 bit unsigned char
Byte 3-4Speed mm/s
Format: 16 bit short
Byte 5Binary output signals
Each bit indicates one binary output:
0 OFF/INACTIVE
1 ON/ACTIVE
Mapping and functionality of binary outputs are project specific.
Byte 6-7Reserved

202 - Command Result

See subsection "Command And Result Protocol" for more details about data members in this message.
Type ID202
TransmitterNavitrol
ReceiverAGV supervisor
Length8
DataByte 0Last Received Command ID
Byte 1Response Status
Format: Unsigned Char
0 = Completed
1 = In progress
Byte 2-7Response Data

203 - Extended Status 1 - Virtual Tags
Type ID203
TransmitterNavitrol
ReceiverAGV supervisor
Length8
DataByte 0Bit 0: Virtual Tag in use
Bit 1-7: Reserved
Byte 1-2Virtual Tag 1
Byte 3-4Virtual Tag 2
Byte 5-7Reserved

204 - Extended Status 2 - Warning Zones
Type ID204
TransmitterNavitrol
ReceiverAGV supervisor
Length8
DataByte 0 -1Warning zone front value
Byte 2-3Warning zone rear value
Byte 4-7Reserved

Command And Result Protocol

Supervisor can send commands to Navitrol using Command PDO and Navitrol will communicate their result to Supervisor through Command Result PDO. Command PDO from Supervisor includes Command ID and relevant data. Command IDs for possible operations are defined in Table 1. On receiving new Command ID, Navitrol changes the Last Received Command ID in Command Result PDO. This PDO from Navitrol will include the result of last received command. If a command requires more than one update cycles before its result is available, response PDO will indicate an In Progress status for the command. In such cases, Supervisor should keep sending same command until the Result Status changes to Completed. When Response Status indicates completion of command execution, Response Data bytes will have results of the command as per definitions in Table 2. Navitrol reacts only to changes in Command ID from Supervisor. Therefore, it is essential that same action is not commanded consecutively. A special Clear command can be sent in between in such cases.

Supervisor can send commands defined in following table in Command PDO (ID - 102).

Command NameCommand ID (1 byte)Command Data (7 bytes)
Clear0Byte 0-6: 0
Pause Drive1Byte 0-6: Reserved
Resume Drive2Byte 0-6: Reserved
Release Hold3Byte 0: Next destination the AGV should drive to.
0 = Default,
1 = 1st Alternative Destination,
2 = 2nd Alternative Destination,
3 = 3rd Alternative destination
Byte 1-6: Reserved

Table 1. Command ID and command data description.

Following responses are sent by Navitrol in Command Result PDO (ID - 202).

Command NameCommand ID (1 byte)Response Data (6 bytes)
Clear0Byte 0-5: 0
Pause Drive1Byte 0: Pause Result
0 = accepted,
1 = bad input data,
2 = wrong state
Byte 1-5: Reserved
Resume Drive2Byte 0: Resume Result
0 = accepted,
1 = bad input data,
2 = wrong state
Byte 1-4: Destination ID: Symbolic Point ID of the resumed drive destination.
Byte 5: Reserved
Release Hold3Byte 0: Release Result
0 = accepted
1 = bad input data
2 = wrong state
3 = unreachable ID
4 = drive control disabled
Byte 1-4: Destination ID: Symbolic Point ID of the destination.
Byte 5: Reserved

Table 2. Responces to the commands.

Navitrol Parameters

Lister below are the parameter available for configuring supervisor CAN interface.

TypeNameDescription
Isupervisor_can_enabledSetting to 1 enable Supervisor CAN interface
Isupervisor_can_rx_timeout_msTimeout of PDOs received by Navigation SW
Isupervisor_can_tx_interval_msTransmission interval of PDOs transmitted by Navigation SW
Isupervisor_can_nodeid_arrCAN nodeid of supervisor PLC, 0 = disabled
Isupervisor_can_nodeid_mode_arrMode for node id at corresponding index; 0 = slave - Navigation SW transmits RPDOs, 1 = master - Navigation SW transmits TPDOs
Isupervisor_can_tx1_typeid_arrType id of message transmitted by Navigation SW to CAN bus on PDO 1
Isupervisor_can_tx2_typeid_arrType id of message transmitted by Navigation SW to CAN bus on PDO 2
Isupervisor_can_tx3_typeid_arrType id of message transmitted by Navigation SW to CAN bus on PDO 3
Isupervisor_can_tx4_typeid_arrType id of message transmitted by Navigation SW to CAN bus on PDO 4
Isupervisor_can_rx1_typeid_arrType id of message received by Navigation SW from CAN bus on PDO 1
Isupervisor_can_rx2_typeid_arrType id of message received by Navigation SW from CAN bus on PDO 2
Isupervisor_can_rx3_typeid_arrType id of message received by Navigation SW from CAN bus on PDO 3
Isupervisor_can_rx4_typeid_arrType id of message received by Navigation SW from CAN bus on PDO 4

Example configurations

In the following subsections some example configurations are presented along with comments about how the parameter value is interpreted.

Example Configuration 1

I, supervisor_can_enabled, 1 # CAN Supervisor interface is enabled

I, supervisor_can_nodeid_arr[0], 12 # Node ID 12 will be used for configurations at index 0

I, supervisor_can_nodeid_mode_arr[0], 0 # For node id (12), Navitrol will transmit RPDOs (node id + [0x200, 0x300, 0x400, 0x500])

I, supervisor_can_tx1_typeid_arr[0], 201 # Navitrol transmits message with Type ID 201 on PDO id (12 + 0x200)

I, supervisor_can_tx2_typeid_arr[0], 202 # Navitrol transmits message with Type ID 202 on PDO id (12 + 0x300)

I, supervisor_can_tx3_typeid_arr[0], 203 # Navitrol transmits message with Type ID 203 on PDO id (12 + 0x400)

I, supervisor_can_tx4_typeid_arr[0], 204 # Navitrol transmits message with Type ID 204 on PDO id (12 + 0x500)

I, supervisor_can_rx1_typeid_arr[0], 101 # Navitrol expects message with Type ID 101 on PDO id (12 + 0x180)

I, supervisor_can_rx2_typeid_arr[0], 102 # Navitrol expects message with Type ID 102 on PDO id (12 + 0x280)

Example Configuration 2

I, supervisor_can_enabled, 1 # CAN Supervisor interface is enabled

I, supervisor_can_nodeid_arr[0], 20 # Node ID 20 will be used for configurations at index 0

I, supervisor_can_nodeid_mode_arr[0], 1 # For node id (20), Navitrol will transmit TPDOs (node id + [0x180, 0x280, 0x380, 0x480])

I, supervisor_can_tx1_typeid_arr[0], 201 # Navitrol transmits message with Type ID 201 on PDO id (20 + 0x180)

I, supervisor_can_tx2_typeid_arr[0], 202 # Navitrol transmits message with Type ID 202 on PDO id (20 + 0x280)

I, supervisor_can_rx1_typeid_arr[0], 101 # Navitrol expects message with Type ID 101 on PDO id (20 + 0x200)

I, supervisor_can_rx2_typeid_arr[0], 102 # Navitrol expects message with Type ID 102 on PDO id (20 + 0x300)

Example Configuration 3

I, supervisor_can_enabled, 1 # CAN Supervisor interface is enabled

I, supervisor_can_nodeid_arr[0], 20 # Node ID 20 will be used for configurations at index 0

I, supervisor_can_nodeid_mode_arr[0], 1 # For node id (20), Navitrol will transmit TPDOs (node id + [0x180, 0x280, 0x380, 0x480])

I, supervisor_can_tx1_typeid_arr[0], 201 # Navitrol transmits message with Type ID 201 on PDO id (20 + 0x180)

I, supervisor_can_tx2_typeid_arr[0], 202 # Navitrol transmits message with Type ID 202 on PDO id (20 + 0x280)

I, supervisor_can_rx1_typeid_arr[0], 101 # Navitrol expects message with Type ID 101 on PDO id (20 + 0x200)

I, supervisor_can_rx2_typeid_arr[0], 102 # Navitrol expects message with Type ID 102 on PDO id (20 + 0x300)

I, supervisor_can_nodeid_arr[1], 21 # Node ID 21 will be used for configurations at index 1

I, supervisor_can_nodeid_mode_arr[1], 1 # For node id (21), Navitrol will transmit TPDOs (node id + [0x180, 0x280, 0x380, 0x480])

I, supervisor_can_tx1_typeid_arr[1], 203 # Navitrol transmits message with Type ID 203 on PDO id (21 + 0x180)

I, supervisor_can_tx2_typeid_arr[1], 204 # Navitrol transmits message with Type ID 204 on PDO id (21 + 0x280)

EtherCAT Communication

Updated 15.03.2024

Overview

Introduction

EtherCAT is one of the control interfaces supported by Navitrol. It can be used for controlling different devices e.g. motor controllers, encoders, etc.

EtherCAT is a high-performance, low-cost, easy to use Industrial Ethernet communication technology with flexible topology. It is used for real-time master-slave communication between controllers and field devices.

For the AGV system an IPC with Navitrol is the master of the bus and all the field devices (motor controllers, encoders e.g.) are slaves.

Requirements

  • Not all the EtherCAT devices are supported by Navitrol. Supported devices list should be consulted to check if some specific device is supported.
  • At least one of the Ethernet port of the IPC should be reserved for EtherCAT communication
  • EtherCAT interface is supported by the Navitrol starting from version 6.40.00

Limitations

  • At the moment, it is not possible to use CAN and EtherCAT together.
  • The feature is available only for position control systems.

Operational principles

EtherCAT bus topology

A Typical EtherCAT device has two or more communication ports. This allows to combine devices on a bus into different topologies.

EtherCAT provides great flexibility in terms of topologies. At least, these are supported:

  • Line
  • Tree
  • Star
  • Drop line
  • Ring

Also, a combination of different topologies (e.g. line + drop line) is supported, as it shown on the figure bellow.

Available topologies in EtherCAT.

From the reliability point of view it is recommended to use a ring topology since it allows cable redundancy. For instance, if some cable between two slaves is broken or cut, communication with all the devices would be still possible. Note that in such a case, two Ethernet ports of the master device will be used.

Cable redundancy in EtherCAT.

Cable selection

EtherCAT supports standard cables used for Ethernet connections. The following cable types are supported:

  • 100 BASE-TX (copper cable up to 100 m between 2 nodes). In practice, it is typically a standard patch-cord.
  • 100 BASE-FX (fiber optics).

Typically, EtherCAT devices are having RJ45 8p8c connector. However, some of the devices can have some alternative connectors (e.g. M12 or some proprietary connector. This should be noted when ordering cables for the EtherCAT bus.

Connection to the IPC

Standard IPC for Navitrol has two Ethernet ports (RJ45, 8p8c). Both of them can be used for EtherCAT communication.

Note that it is not recommended to connect EtherCAT bus through the switch (to bridge master and bus segment). It can cause issues and extra delays not only with EtherCAT communication, but also with Ethernet communication through this port. Therefore, it is recommended to connect EtherCAT devices directly to the IPC Ethernet port.

Addressing

In EtherCAT network, master automatically assign addresses. Therefore, there is no need for manual address configuration.

Navitrol (inside IPC) assign addresses the following rules:

  • Slave address starts from 1.
  • Slave address of a field device is done by physical position in the network
  • Slave address is auto-incremented.

Note: all slaves on the bus should have unique slave addresses.

In practice, it means that all EtherCAT slaves are addressed starting from master using the auto-increment procedure in ongoing direction. So the closest device on the bus to master will have address 1, the next device will have address 2 and so on.

Simple addressing example.

Advanced addressing

Addressing should be straight-forward in case if devices have only two Ethernet ports. In some cases, it might be hard to define ongoing direction where address will be auto-incremented. For instance, if several different topologies are mixed together.

In such a case, it can be done in two ways:

  1. Theoretical way.

    Every EtherCAT devices have up to 4 communication ports. Data in every device is processed in the following way: it is received from the previous device to the input port (port 0). After that, data for the device itself is inserted and the address is incremented. Then, if exists, data goes to the port 3 and all the devices connected to port 3 will be addresses. The same happens after that with the port 1 if exists. Finally, data goes to the output port and devices connected to it will be addressed.

    Advanced addressing example.

  2. Practical way

    This option will show position and the device type in the bus. The only limitation is that it will not distinguish two devices of the same type between each other.

    2.1 Power the devices and set up basic EtherCAT communication parameters.

    2.2 Connect EtherCAT bus to Navitrol and start Navitrol

    2.3 Wait for 20 seconds and take log

    2.4 Open the log and search "slave(s) found on the bus".

    It will list all the device types on the bus and print addresses.

Set up

The following steps should be done in process of commissioning:

  1. Physical connection

  2. Setting up the device

  3. Changing parameters

Physical connection

Wiring is the first step in establishing the EtherCAT bus. All devices are connected together with a standard Ethernet cables. Wiring is recommended to start from the IPC. Slave devices should be connected directly to those ports.

Additionally, make sure that devices on the bus are powered prior to the operation and wired according to the manufacturer's instructions.

Setting up the device

Some devices might require additional settings before start operating with Navitrol. For instance, motor controllers typically require some additional setting, such as PID controller tuning. For setting up such devices, refer to the device-specific document.

However, some of the devices are configured automatically by Navitrol when connected.

Basic setup of Navitrol

Parameter set depends on the project. Therefore, in this document, only generic parameters for establishing the communication will be described.

Depending on the topology, ethercat_mode parameter should be set. In case of ring topology when both ports of the IPC are utilized, master redundant mode should be selected. Additionally, ethercat_inte_redundant interface should be set in addition to ethercat_inte_primary. In other topologies (when only one port of the IPC is used), master single mode should be selected. Additionally, ethercat_inte_primary should be set.

The other parameters (e.g. slave addresses) can be found in the device-specific documents. For instance, kinematic type related parameters (specifying slave addresses of motor controllers) can be found in motor controller specific document (e.g. for Synapticon motor controller).

NameTypeDefaultInformation
ethercat_enabledInt0Enables EtherCAT communication
ethercat_modeInt0EtherCAT mode, 0 - Master single, 1 - Master redundant
ethercat_inte_primaryStringName of primary Ethernet interface used for EtherCAT communication
ethercat_inte_redundantStringName of redundant Ethernet interface used for EtherCAT communication
# Example parameters for ring topology

I,ethercat_enabled,                1 #
I,ethercat_mode,                   1 #
S,ethercat_inte_primary,        eth0 #
S,ethercat_inte_redundant,      eth1 #


# Example parameters for other topologies

I,ethercat_enabled,                1 #
I,ethercat_mode,                   0 #
S,ethercat_inte_primary,        eth0 #

Troubleshooting

Navitrol itself can detect most of the issues, such as:

  • some EtherCAT related configuration issues (e.g. parameter issue)
  • some device missing from the bus
  • a device is located on the wrong place on the bus.

It is advised in all the cases to check not only active errors, but also terminal. Typically, some important additional information is printed to the terminal in case of error.

Most common mistakes

EtherCAT start up fails

Typically, it can be explained by one of the following reasons:

  • Device is defined in parameter file but not connected to the bus
  • Device address defined in parameters is not correct. If some wrong device type is located in a position specified in the parameter file, it will also prevent EtherCAT from starting up
  • Device address is duplicated in the parameters.

In all the above-mentioned cases, it is recommended to open Linux terminal and check Navitrol prints from there. Bellow, there are the instructions on how to detect the problem and recover from it.

Device not connected to the bus

Active errors: ERROR_ETHERCAT_NO_COMMS, ERROR_ETHERCAT_HIGH_DT and ERROR_ETHERCAT_DEVICE_NOT_FOUND

Terminal error logging example:

EC: 1 Ethercat slave(s) not found. Registered slaves 2, devices on the bus 1. Not enough devices on the bus
EC: Slave 2 name SOMANET registered but not found on the bus

How to recover: Check if missing device is powered and connected to the bus

Incorrect device address

Active errors: ERROR_ETHERCAT_NO_COMMS, ERROR_ETHERCAT_HIGH_DT and ERROR_ETHERCAT_DEVICE_NOT_FOUND

Terminal error logging example:

EC: 1 Ethercat slave(s) not found. Registered slaves 2, devices on the bus 2.
EC: Slave 3 name SOMANET registered but not found on the bus

How to recover: Check parameters related to the EtherCAT address for mentioned device. Calculate its position on the bus (see "Addressing" chapter) and correct the parameter or position.

Wrong device at some address

Active errors: ERROR_ETHERCAT_NO_COMMS, ERROR_ETHERCAT_HIGH_DT and ERROR_ETHERCAT_DEVICE_NOT_FOUND

Terminal error logging example:

EC: CheckSlaves - slave 1 name mismatch, on the bus EK1100, registered SOMANET
EC: 1 Ethercat slave(s) not found. Registered slaves 2, devices on the bus 10.
EC: Slave 1 name SOMANET registered but not found on the bus

How to recover: Check parameters related to the EtherCAT address for mentioned devices. Calculate it's position on the bus (see "Addressing" chapter) and correct the parameter or position.

Slave address duplication

Active errors: ERROR_ETHERCAT_NO_COMMS, ERROR_ETHERCAT_HIGH_DT and ERROR_ETHERCAT_CONFIG

Terminal error logging example:

EC: Ethercat_RegisterSlaveInfo - attempt to double register slave address 1. Check parameters

How to recover: Check parameters related to the EtherCAT address. Several devices have the same address on the bus. Correct parameters.

Errors and warnings

Navitrol communication related errors are listed below, with additional troubleshooting information.

Note that ERROR_ETHERCAT_HIGH_DT and ERROR_ETHERCAT_NO_COMMS might be a cause of ERROR_ETHERCAT_CONFIG or ERROR_ETHERCAT_DEVICE_NOT_FOUND.

840 ERROR_ETHERCAT_NO_COMMS

Description: Navitrol has no connection to at least one EtherCAT slave (or no valid data has been received) for 100 ms.

Error level: Error

Error reason: Navitrol has not been able to initialize/configure EtherCAT properly, or slaves at run time are not working as expected.

How to recover:

  • Check that EtherCAT parameters (ethercat_mode, ethercat_inte_primary, ethercat_inte_redundant) are defined correctly in params.txt

  • Check that EtherCAT bus is physically connected to defined interface(s)

  • Check that all EtherCAT hardware and slaves are properly connected and powered

843 ERROR_ETHERCAT_CONFIG

Description: Error during Ethercat slave configuration.

Error level: Error

Error reason: Ethercat slave configuration failed. Ethercat HW and slaves might not be properly connected or powered.

How to recover: Check the log for more details. Contact Navitec support.

844 ERROR_ETHERCAT_HIGH_DT

Description: Update interval from vehicle interface to EtherCAT is too high (over control_interval_us * control_interval_error_ratio)

Error level: Error

Error reason: Vehicle interface is not responding to EtherCAT. In most cases, this error is caused by some other Ethercat error or issue with initialization of AGV. Might be caused by CPU overload of the IPC.

How to recover: Check the log or terminal for more details. Contact Navitec support.

847 ERROR_ETHERCAT_DEVICE_NOT_FOUND

Description: At least one EtherCAT slave device is not found on the bus

Error level: Error

Error reason: Some of the devices expected by Navitrol are missing from the bus.

How to recover: Check the log or terminal for more details. Check that all devices are powered and connected to the bus. Check Navitrol parameters. Contact Navitec support.

Advanced troubleshooting

Navitrol always logs some amount of events related to EtherCAT communication and EtherCAT related issues. Additional information logging might be enabled by the parameters mentioned below. These settings increase the amount of logged data and should not be used without a reason. Increased logging level might be needed only in cases when some issues with communication are present.

EtherCAT advanced parameters

NameTypeDefaultInformation
log_ethercatInt0Log EtherCAT communication details, 0 - min level ... 3 - max amount of details

All the EtherCAT related logging can be found by searching "EC:" in the Navitrol text log.

The sequence for establishing communication with the EtherCAT devices is described below:

  1. Registration of the devices Navitrol reads parameter file and checks machine type to determine EtherCAT devices expected to be on the bus (device name, address, configurations etc.).

Logging example:

EC: Ethercat_RegisterSlave - slave 2 successfully registered, nbrODO 33, parseFuncExist 1, buildFuncExist 1
EC: Ethercat_RegisterSlave - slave 1 successfully registered, nbrODO 33, parseFuncExist 1, buildFuncExist 1
EC: Object registration finished
  1. Initialization of the interface (opening socket)

Navitrol reads basic EtherCAT parameters and initializes the communication on specified interfaces.

Logging example:

EC: ec_init on eth0 eth1 succeeded
  1. Slave checks:

Navitrol reads information from the bus and checks if bus configuration matches to the list of registered devices.

At least, the following checks are performed:

  • What number of devices is on the bus?
  • Is the number of registered devices corresponds to the number of devices on the bus?
  • Is registered device types are on correct positions?

Note that Navitrol is able to perform checks only for device types. It cannot distinguish two devices of the same type switched together on the bus. For instance, from the bus configuration, it cannot indicate that left and right motor controllers in diff drives are swapped together. It is only possible to detect that devices of the same type swapped together during the further steps in commissioning of the AGV (e.g. by test-driving)

Logging example:

EC: 2 slave(s) found on the bus
EC: On the bus - slave 1, name SOMANET, Vendor:product 22d2h:201h
EC: On the bus - slave 2, name SOMANET, Vendor:product 22d2h:201h
EC: Registered - slave 1, name SOMANET
EC: Registered - slave 2, name SOMANET
EC: CheckSlaves - slave 1 found, name SOMANET
EC: CheckSlaves - slave 2 found, name SOMANET
EC: All registered Ethercat slaves found successfully
  1. Configuring slave devices

Navitrol configures found devices (if needed) by sending SDOs to them.

Logging example:

EC: PRE_OP state reached for all slaves.
EC: SDO wr OK. Slave 2 idx 0x1016, subIdx 0x1, size 4, data 8C 00 00 00, dataOk 1, wkc 1
.....
EC: Slave configuration success
  1. Putting devices to operational state

Navitrol switches all the devices to the operational state prior to communication

Logging example:

EC: Request operational state for all slaves
OPERATIONAL state reached for all slaves
  1. Start communication

After successful start-up, Navitrol starts communication. Short after that, ERROR_ETHERCAT_NO_COMMS and ERROR_ETHERCAT_HIGH_DT should be reset.

SIMOVE communication interface

Updated 13.06.2024

Overview

Introduction

SIMOVE is Siemens modular software platform for mobile robots. Navitrol is the navigation module in the system and communicates to onboard PLC/device via the interface specified by SIMOVE. The interface is kinematic free, thus the PLC/device onboard controls the motor controllers of the AGV. This document describes how to setup Navitrol. Contact Siemens about the details of the interface.

Limitations

The communication interface specifies only drive control between Navitrol and the PLC/device onboard the AGV. Actuator control and status of the AGV shall be communicated using some other interface, for example Ethernet supervisor communication interface.

Setup

Please note that even though the interface is kinematic free, the kinematics of the AGV affect how the AGV can be controlled. For example differential and steer drive AGVs are limited to be using only longitudinal component of the velocity vector. The communication parameters should be set according to the SIMOVE system setup.

Kinematic parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
kinematic_free_limited_drivingInt0AGV with kinematic free interface has driving limitations: 0 = None, 1 = Speed vector restricted to longitudinal only (nonholonomic). Software restart needed after change.

Communication parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
simove_navigation_port_inInt4001Navigation SW inbound data TCP/IP (UDP) port for SIMOVE navigation interface
simove_navigation_port_outInt12345Navigation SW outbound data TCP/IP (UDP) port for SIMOVE navigation interface
simove_navigation_ipString0.0.0.0IP address for SIMOVE navigation interface of the PLC / device onboard the AGV
simove_navigation_endianessInt1Endianess for SIMOVE navigation interface: 0 = little endian, 1 = big endian
simove_velocity_xy_normFloat160.0Normalizing factor for velocity vector's Vx and Vy in SIMOVE interface
simove_velocity_angular_normFloat0.017453Normalizing factor for angular velocity in SIMOVE interface (default PI/180)

Troubleshooting

Errors and warnings

858 - ERROR_SIMOVE_NAV_NO_COMMS

There is no communication to the navigation interface or it is too long since a valid received message. Verify that the communication parameters are correct and that the data sent to Navitrol is valid (header information, message length)

Advanced troubleshooting

Logging in Navitrol's text log (log.txt) has a prefix "SIMOVE:".

Motor control interfaces and setup

Updated 16.05.2024

  • Motor controller common
  • Schwarzmueller setup
    • Schwarzmueller parameters
    • Schwarzmueller troubleshooting
  • Curtis
  • Engel
  • Nanotec
  • Oriental
  • Synapticon
  • Roboteq Open loop
  • Roboteq Closed loop
  • MiControl
  • Kinco

Motor controllers common

Updated 11.07.2024

Overview

This document describes usage and set up of motor controllers in Navitrol. The document should be used for setting up the motor controller in Navitrol.

In this document, only common parameter and troubleshooting steps are explained.
The first setup steps are explained in Motor controller specific documentation that is available for every supported motor controller (for instance, instruction for Synapticon motor controller).

Introduction

A motor controller is a device that can coordinate in a predetermined manner the performance of an electric motor. In Navitrol, a motor controller can be used to control:

  • driving motor
  • steering motor
  • actuator motor

The required number and type of motors depends on the kinematic type of the AGV and installed actuators.
In case of diff kinematics, Navitrol expects to have two driving motors. Typically, those motors should be identical and installed symmetrically.
In case of steer kinematics, Navitrol expects to have one driving motor and one steering motor.
In case of mecanum kinematics, Navitrol expects to have four driving motors. Typically, those motors should be identical and installed symmetrically.
In case of omni kinematics, Navitrol expects to have typically at least two driving motors and at least two steering motors. The number of steering wheels is set in Navitrol parameters. It is supported to have some wheels that would perform only steering without driving.
Please note that steering motor typically should have also an absolute encoder that connects to the same bus as the motor controller.

The required number of motor controllers depends on amount of motors and the number of channels in the selected motor controllers.
Typically, motor controllers are single-channel. That means that only one motor can be connected to each motor controller. Most of the supported motor controllers are single-channel, for instance, Schwarzmueller, Engel, MiControl, Oriental, Synapticon. Check List of supported devices to see all the supported motor controllers. Some motor controllers have two channels, which makes it possible to control two motors with one motor controller. For instance, Curtis and Roboteq have two channeled models.
Few motor controllers, such as some Curtins models, have three channels. Those motor controllers can be used, for instance, as all-in-one solution for automating steer or diff AGV with actuator using just one motor controller.

Requirements

For setting up the motor controller in Navitrol, it is required that:

  • Motor controller - motor connection established
    • All electrical connections are done
    • Motor parameters have been set to the motor controllers
    • See Motor controller specific documentation for connection setup instructions (for instance, instruction for Synapticon motor controller)
  • Interface bus (CAN or EtherCAT) has been wired and connected to the motor controller
  • Basic interface parameters (for CAN or EtherCAT) are set correctly. Instructions for wiring and basic parameters are described in CAN communication or Ethercat communication document.

Limitations

Functionality is limited to motor controllers that are controlled by Navitrol. Only specific motor controller and AGV kinematic combinations are supported. See, List of supported devices.

Navitrol motor control is not supported for positioning only systems

Setup

The first setup steps are explained in Motor controller specific documentation. In this document, only common parameters are explained.

Quick start

For setting up the motor controller to work with Navitrol, communication parameters (motor controller addresses) should be used. Those parameters differ for EtherCAT and CAN motor controllers.

CAN Node Id parameters for motor controllers

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
Differential AGV
can_diff_drive_left_nodeidInt30Node id for diff drive left motor controller
can_diff_drive_right_nodeidInt31Node id for diff drive right motor controller
Steer AGV
can_steer_drive_steering_nodeidInt30Node id for steer drive steering controller
can_steer_drive_driving_nodeidInt31Node id for diff drive driving controller
Omni AGV
can_omni_steer_ctrl_nodeid[]Int0Node id for omni steering controller (array index - wheel index). 0 - disabled
can_omni_drive_ctrl_nodeid[]Int0Node id for omni driving controller (array index - wheel number). 0 - disabled
Mecanum AGV
mot_ctrl_mecanum_nodeid[]Int0CANopen NodeId. 0 - not defined, Indexes are 0 = FF (Forward Left), 1 = FR (Forward Right), 2 = RL (Rear Left), 3 = RR (Rear Right)
Differential sub-unit
can_diffunit_left_nodeid[]Int0CANOpen Node ID for diffunit left motor controllers. Array index: omni = wheel index, steer = 0.
can_diffunit_right_nodeid[]Int0CANOpen Node ID for diffunit right motor controllers. Array index: omni = wheel index, steer = 0.

Note: this table is not applicable for Roboteq motor controller. Check Roboteq Motor Controller Configuration document.

EtherCAT address parameters for motor controllers

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
Differential AGV
ethercat_diff_drive_left_ctrl_addrInt1Physical EtherCAT address of diff drive left motor controller
ethercat_diff_drive_right_ctrl_addrInt2Physical EtherCAT address of diff drive right motor controller
Omni AGV
ethercat_omni_steer_ctrl_addr[]Int0Physical EtherCAT address for omni steering controller (array index - wheel index). 0 = disabled
ethercat_omni_drive_ctrl_addr[]Int0Physical EtherCAT address for omni driving controller (array index - wheel index). 0 = disabled
Mecanum AGV
ethercat_mot_ctrl_mecanum_ctrl_addr[]Int0Physical EtherCAT address for mecanum motor controllers. 0 - not defined. Indexes are 0 = FL (Forward Left), 1 = FR (Forward Right), 2 = RL (Rear Left), 3 = RR (Rear Right)

Motor controller automatic disabling

In order to reduce energy consumption, Navitrol can disable drives when AGV is not moving. This involves currently all motor controllers directly controlled by Navitrol. By default, this happens 1 second after AGV has stopped moving and brakes have been activated. This feature can be configured by parameter mot_ctrl_disable_delay_ms, see table below for details.

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
mot_ctrl_disable_delay_msInt1000Motor controller disabling delay [ms] after activating brakes: -1 = never disable, 0 = no delay

NOTE: This feature is supported currently with the following motor controllers: Schwarzmueller, Curtis, Oriental, Kinco, MiControl, Synapticon and Roboteq (closed loop).

How to use

After successful setup, it is possible to drive and steer the AGV using the motor controllers (for instance, in manual mode using keyboard control).

After successful, AGV should be calibrated according to Initial Calibration Guide.

Motor controller test form

For most of the motor controllers, it is possible to manually set the outputs to the motor controllers.
This feature is useful during calibration, for instance, to tune the steering PID controller or PID for driving controllers. The benefit is that step response can be sent from this form.

This form is available for all the motor controllers except the following:

  • Roboteq
  • Nanotec
  • Syntron

The form can be opened from the "Navitrol" menu located in the top bar of Navitrol Monitor. The form is shown in figure below.

Motor controller test form

A command to be sent to a motor controller is prepared by following steps:

  • Select motor controller type - steer/drive/actuator
  • Type the motor controller's Node ID. Note: There is a special feature that is available for most motor controllers. When 255 is entered in Node ID field, all motor controllers of the selected type will receive the command.
    Note: Command is sent to the motor controller only when the correct combination of motor controller type and Node ID is selected.
  • Select output commands. Note that for every motor controller, different output commands are available and thus the form might look different.
  • Angle - available only for steering motor.
  • RPM - available for every motor. Note that when RPM is applied, the motor will start moving.
  • For some motor controllers, it is also possible to send proportional output and torque.

The prepared command is sent when "Send values" button is pressed. It can be stopped either with pressing "Stop sending" or closing the form.

Motor controller test form - Differential unit

When calibrating kinematics with differential units (Steer or Omni drive with differential unit), the user needs to verify that each differential unit is configured correctly.

The Differential unit's can be each separately tested that the unit turns to correct direction and that the speed inversions of the unit's are correct. The selected unit is visualized with a blue circle and the node ID:s of the selected unit are shown as well. After the user has selected a differential unit from the drop down menu, the desired angle or speed reference can be given the same way as for a single motor controller.

Controlling individual differential units through Motor controller test form

Troubleshooting

Errors and warnings

402 ERROR_MOTOR_CONTROL_FAULT

Description: Motor controller indicates fault

Error reason: Error comes from the motor controller.

How to recover: Check the error from the motor controller (for instance, using Linux terminal or from Navitrol log). Error code and error description should be printed there.

809 ERROR_AGV_CONTROLLER

Description: AGV controller alarm

Error reason: AGV controller reports error to Navitrol

How to recover: Check the error from the motor controller (for instance, using Linux terminal or from Navitrol log). Error code and error description should be printed there. Navitrol tries to reset error automatically when the error is gone.

Advanced troubleshooting

Following troubleshooting instructions are suitable for Engel, Oriental, MiControl, Curtis, Synapticon motor controllers.

Advanced troubleshooting parameter:

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
log_motor_controllersInt0Log motor controller details. 2 - Log all details

In case if there are no CAN/EtherCAT errors present, but machine is not driving, try following: Check if motor controller error is set (ERROR_MOTOR_CONTROL_FAULT and ERROR_AGV_CONTROLLER). In case if error is set, check from the Linux terminal or log file which error is set and on which controller. The keyword for search is: "FindAndLogErrors".

Other helpful log lines

Point of interestKeywordAdditional information
Navitrol inputs
State of the motor controllerLogStatusWordVisible when CAN communication is working
Speed + encoder data from each wheelLogDataInForKinematicsAvailable only when log_motor_controller > 1
Fault status on each motor controllerHandleFaults
Raw inputsParseRx
Navitrol Outputs:
Target speed for each controllerLogDataOutForKinematicsAvailable only when log_motor_controller > 1
Processed state and outputsLogControlDataNote that state of the AGV can be changed by Navitrol, so input state and output state are different.
It can mean that controller has fault or safe outputs or estop is active
Raw outputsBuildTx

Schwarzmueller Setup Instructions

Updated 26.01.2024

Basic Setup Instructions

  • Download service tool from powersolutions.danfoss.com and install the tool and drivers.

  • Connect the CG150 CAN-adapter to your computer and to the motor controller. Keep only one motor controller connected to the CAN at the same time during configuration.

  • Start the PLUS+1 service tool.

  • From the popup window choose the correct CAN-adapter and right channel.

  • See document Start up User Manual PLUS+1 Inverter Family V2.0 chapter 12 for more information.

  • Download the software File->File Download... e.g. 20014_STANDARD_CANOPEN_V100.lhx (see chapter 12.8.2 in manual).

    • "The selected file uses a different OS" warning can be ignored

  • Load the Service application File->Scan for Service Application File... e.g. 20014_Standard_CANopen_V100_01.p1d

    • "This Service Application file is not designed for the connected system" warning can be ignored

  • Service application let's user to modify the parameters of the device (see chapter 12.8.3 in manual).

  • Acquire parameter file (xml) for the motor from Navitec

    • Node 31 is for drive or right motor

    • Node 30 is for steer or left motor

  • The following are instructions for Navitec to generate parameter files for motors:

    • Acquire csv file for motor specific parameters (provided by Schwarzmueller)

    • Open SchwarzmuellerParamGen

    • Drag & drop the csv file into the program

    • Select controller from top left drop down menu

    • Enter ECU id of the controller as shown in System Navigator on the left, e.g. 255 as in:

  • Enter PI controller parameters (Kp, Ki, PartLoadReduc) as instructed by Schwarzmueller

  • Enter Acel & Dcel limits, values are rpm/s, usually thousands and may need to be adjusted afterwards

  • Enter maximum rpm as calculated from maximum wheel velocity & gear ratio

  • Enter encoder current range parameters (EE_MD_EncCurMax & Min)

    • If the encoders do not draw their power directly from the Schwarzmueller (5V), set the minimum current to 0,

    • Otherwise set the range according to encoder specifications

  • Save

  • In PLUS+1, select "All Parameters" (bottom of the left tree view)

Figure 1: Select "All Parameters"

  • Import parameters (xml) for motor controller (Figure 1).

Figure 2: Parameter import.

  • If loading parameters fails because of wrong ECU id, rename all "0,31" values ("0,30" for steer/left motor) in the parameter xml to the ECU id shown in PLUS+1 in the ECU column in the Parameter List and import the parameters file again

  • Select Parameter -> Check all parameters for download

  • Download parameters to Device Parameter->Download (from laptop to Motor Controller).

  • Restart device (full power cycle) to enable parameter changes (do not change view in PLUS+1).

  • Repeat for the other motor controller by disconnecting the newly configured controller and connecting the other controller.

    • It is also possible to have both controllers connected at the same time and switch the active controller but by having only one connected at the time is safer

      • Each page in the "System Navigator" view can have different controller selected so use extra caution when switching between controllers

      • Controller of each page is changed by right clicking page header -> Exchange existing ECU -> click yes to switch

      • Hovering over log variables will show the ECU id that the variable is read from, again 0,31 for drive/right motor and 0,30 for steer/left motor

Wiring Instructions

  • Connect pin 31(C1p31) to power + to enable CAN communication (Figure 3).

  • Connect pin 30 (C1p30) to power + to disable SafeStop (when SafeStop is ON connect to ground).

  • See chapter 12.6.1.1 for information about main contractor safety.

Figure 3: Diagnostics window.

  • Temperature sensor has to be connected to pins 34/35.

Basic diagnostics with PLUS+1

  • To view feedback from Schwarzmueller in real time, select any log page in "System Navigator" and press the green play button on the toolbar to start real time display

Safety Circuit

  • Click "Automated Guided Vehicle" in "System Navigator" to see an overview of the state of the Schwarzmueller

  • When Safety Circuit is broken, SafeStop should be open (pin 30 connected to ground) and show in red in the overview

  • When Safety Circuit is ok, SafeStop should be closed (pin 30 connected to +power) and show in green in the overview

  • CAN enable should also show in green (pin 31 connected to +power)

Communication with Navitrol

  • To be able to clear Schwarzmueller errors, Navitrol needs to be communicating with the motor controller.

  • To check in realtime what's happening in Navitrol CAN interface, connect to Navitrol PC with PuTTY (username: root, pw: navitrol) and type "./Navitrol dumps 0 can_inte". To stop echoing the log, press Ctrl+C

  • If Navitrol reports CAN write errors:

    • Check wires are connected, polarity is correct and both ends have 120 ohm resistors

    • Connect directly to Navitrol PC with CanKing with nothing else connected to the bus and check that data is flowing

    • Check baud rate is correct (250000) and node IDs are correct via PLUS+1 tool, if not, the motor controller parameters are incorrect update parameters and be sure to follow the instructions in Chapter 1 precisely

  • If Navitrol reports "CAN_ Obj xxx NotRxed" errors, motor controller parameters are incorrect update parameters and be sure to follow the instructions in Chapter 1 precisely

    • 21E, 19E and 29E are from node 30, it is the steer / left motor

    • 21F, 19F and 29F are from node 31, it is the drive / left motor

  • If Navitrol reports "safeStopActive" error / ESTOP, it means that the safety circuit connected to Schwarzmueller is broken (release estop / check wiring if already released).

  • If Navitrol reports "Schwarzmuellerfault", check with PLUS+1 the fault code and refer to Error_20014_Standard_CANopen_V100.pdf document to see what the fault code means

Schwarzmueller Parameter Setup Instructions

Updated 26.01.2024

Parameter Setup Instructions

Initialization

  • Download service tool from powersolutions.danfoss.com and install the tool and drivers.

  • Connect the CAN-adapter (e.g. CG150 or Kvaser Leaf Light) to your computer and to the motor controller. Keep only one motor controller connected to the CAN at the same time during configuration.

  • Start the PLUS+1 service tool.

  • From the popup window choose the correct CAN-adapter and double-click on the right channel.

  • See document Start up User Manual PLUS+1 Inverter Family V2.0 chapter 12 for more information.

Setup

  • Download the software

    • File->File Download...

    • Open the *.lhx file e.g. 20014_STANDARD_CANOPEN_V100.lhx.

    • "The selected file uses a different OS" warning can be ignored

  • The next window that opens lists all connected devices. At a CAN bus there could be several ones, this is the reason for this window. Choose the right device, with the right Node-ID. Only one device can be selected from the list. If there is only one device connected, it is automatically selected.

  • Click "Next >"

  • After clicking on "Next >" you need to confirm the change of the parameter structure. This is required when a new software with a different parameter structure is selected for the download and that will overwrite the existing structure in the inverter.

  • Click on "Confirm..."

  • A window opens now for the confirmation of the parameter setting

  • Click "OK"

  • The former window will appear again

  • Now click "Start download" and the download of the Software will be executed.

  • When then download has finished, the successful execution will be shown, continue with "Close"

  • Load the Service application File->Scan for Service Application File... e.g. 20014_Standard_CANopen_V100_01.p1d

    • "This Service Application file is not designed for the connected system" warning can be ignored

  • Service application let's user to modify the parameters of the device (see chapter 12.8.3 in manual).

  • Acquire parameter file (xml) for the motor from Navitec (or use a file from a controller already in use)

    • Node 31 is for drive or right motor

    • Node 30 is for steer or left motor

  • Before importing the parameters, check that the CAN Node-ID in PLUS+1 matches the correct motor controller Node-ID (e.g. 30 for steer)

  • If not, click "Edit Parameters". Otherwise jump to section 1.2.2.

Change CAN-ID

  • Write the correct Node-ID and click Parameter -> Download

  • Restart device (full power cycle) to enable parameter changes (do not change view in PLUS+1).

  • The changed Node-ID should now appear in the System Navigator

  • Click the line with the right Node-ID

  • Load again the Service application File->Scan for Service Application File... e.g. 20014_Standard_CANopen_V100_01.p1d

  • If the pop-up window below appears, browse and open the file.

  • Press "OK" if the program asks for a replacement ECU.

Load parameters

  • In PLUS+1, select "All Parameters" (bottom of the left tree view)

  • Import parameters (xml) for motor controller

  • If loading parameters fails because of wrong ECU id, rename all "0,31" values ("0,30" for steer/left motor) in the parameter xml to the ECU id shown in PLUS+1 in the ECU column in the Parameter List and import the parameters file again

  • Select Parameter -> Check all parameters for download

  • Download parameters to Device Parameter->Download (from laptop to Motor Controller).

  • Restart device (full power cycle) to enable parameter changes (do not change view in PLUS+1).

  • Repeat for the other motor controller by disconnecting the newly configured controller and connecting the other controller.

    • It is also possible to have both controllers connected at the same time and switch the active controller but by having only one connected at the time is safer

      • Each page in the "System Navigator" view can have different controller selected so use extra caution when switching between controllers

      • Controller of each page is changed by right clicking page header -> Exchange existing ECU -> click yes to switch

      • Hovering over log variables will show the ECU id that the variable is read from, again 0,31 for drive/right motor and 0,30 for steer/left motor

Troubleshooting Schwarzmueller

Updated 26.06.2024

Troubleshooting Topics

  • The motor rotates in the wrong direction

    • Check that Motor U/V/W are connected correctly to U/V/W of the inverter

    • Check the speed inversing parameters for motor controllers. Parameter name with different kinematics is slightly different, e.g. for omni drive it's mot_ctrl_omni_speed_inv_output

  • The motor runs at low speed but temperature starts to rise quickly

    • Endoder channel A/B are probably wired crossed

  • Navitrol has error ERROR_CAN_ALL_NODES_NOT_OPER

    • Navitrol hasn't received messages from all the nodes it expects.

    • In Putty type ./Navitrol dumpf and open the log.txt from /navitec/logs folder. Search "CAN: RX_SUM" and check what is/are the missing messages

    • In case no messages have been read, check CAN wiring and that there's end resistors. Check that you have the right CAN parameters:

      • can_nmt_master # Enables Navigation SW to work as NMT master on primary CAN. 0 = disable, 1 = enable
      • can_sync # Navitrol role for CANOpen SYNC messages: 0 = None, 1 = SYNC producer, 2 = SYNC consumer
      • can_bitrate_k

  • Check that the nodeID of the device matches the parameter in Navitrol.

  • Navitrol has error ERROR_CAN_RX_TIMEOUT

    • Check that Schwarzmueller parameter EE_CANopen_TPDO2_TransType is set to 1 in all inverters (only needed in earlier Navitrols than 6.24.00).

    • In Putty type ./Navitrol dumpf and open the log.txt from /navitec/logs folder. Search "CAN: RX_SUM" and check what message is/are not coming in time.

  • Navitrol has warning WARNING_ESTOP_ACTIVE

    • Safety circuit is broken. Release estop / check Schwarzmueller wiring if already released

  • Navitrol has error ERROR_DRIVE_MOTOR_CONTROL_FAULT

    • Check from PLUS+1 Service Tool error code from Error Status page and refer to Error_20014_Standard_CANopen_V101.pdf document which error is active.

    • Typical errors are:

      • 5401 Error_V_DC_Link; Undervoltage (level 1)

      • 5002 Error CAN timeout, RPDO1

      • 4101 Error motor; Config error

  • This is usually caused by having the wrong temperature sensor type selected in the Schwarzmueller parameters. If the error is active and the temperature is incorrect, check the EE_MD_TempSnsrType: 1 = Switch (NC) 2 = Switch (NO) 3 = Analog Sensor (SnsrTab)

  • 5201 Error motor; Overtemperature

  • Navitrol has error ERROR_DRIVE_MOTOR_CONTROL_FAULT, fault 5401 Undervoltage on Schwarzmueller's side, after a few seconds every time the main contactor is connected

    • Main contactor steady value is too low and when the settling time (defined by parameter EE_MCSettlingTime_ms) is reached, the current is drawn from the circuit instead.

    • Raise the steady value defined with the Schwarzmueller parameter EE_MCSteadyValue_pct2 (* 0.01%)

  • The brake does not release or it is switching on unwanted

    • Check that the Brake pin 13 is connected correctly.

    • If wired correctly and break output is shown on ServiceTool, the settling value of the brake output, defined with the Schwarzmueller parameter EE_BrkSettlingValue_pct2 (*0.01%), is too low.

    • If brake is switching on unintentionally when driving, the steady output, defined with the Schwarzmueller parameter EE_BrkSteadyValue_pct2 of the brake is too low.

  • Speed of the motor (RPM) doesn't reach our requested speed.

    • Check that Schwarmueller speed parameters are not limiting the speed EE_SpdMax_rpm1 -- Speed limit (e.g. 30000 -> 3000 rpm) EE_MD_SpeedMax_rpm1 -- Maximum motor speed

  • Other common problem sources

    • Make sure from PLUS+1 Service Tool that Analog CW / CAN Enable (pin31) shows green in the Automated Guided Vehicle page i.e. CAN is enabled

Curtis CAN motor controller

Updated 11.07.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
SDOService Data Object
PDOProcess Data Object
CITCurtis Integrated Toolkit
PCAN-USBPeak PCAN-USB adapter. Used to connect between CIT and motor controller

Introduction

Curtis motor controller is one of the motor controllers supported by Navitrol. Curtis offers wide range of single and multi-channel motor controllers that can be used for different purposes (steering, driving, actuator) in the AGV.

This documentation provides instructions for configuring the motor controllers to be used with Navitrol. Operation of the device is possible via CANopen fieldbus.

Following motor controllers are supported by Navitec Systems:

  • F2-T. This motor controller has 3 channels

    • 2 AC motor channels (can be used for driving/steering) and 1 DC pump (used for hydraulic actuator)

  • F2-D. This motor controller has 2 channels

    • 2 AC motor connections (can be used for driving/steering)

  • Fx-A series. This motor controller has 1 channel. Supported models are F2-A, F4-A, F6-A, F10-A

    • 1 AC motor connection (can be used for driving/steering)

The following motor types are supported.

  • AC Induction Motor (ACIM) This motor type by default uses the quadrature Encoder and supports auto-characterization. Contact Curtis if an ACIM application will use a Sin/Cos sensor (encoder)

  • Permanent magnet AC Motor (PMAC) PMAC motors by default use the Sin/Cos sensor type Encoder. Contact Curtis if a PMAC motor is chosen for the AGV

There might be some errors during commissioning procedure that are motor controller specific, so Navitrol support might be not able to solve them without Curtis support help. Contact information of Curtis support can be provided by Navitec Systems.

Currently, Curtis motor controllers can be supported for several kinematics:

  • Diff drive

  • Steer drive

  • Steer drive with a differential sub unit

  • Omni

Requirements

  • The parameterization and configuration of the motor controllers takes place with the Curtis Integrated Toolkit (CIT) software. The software needs a license and it can be purchased from Curtis.
  • Adapter to connect the motor controller to the CIT software. Curtis recommends PEAK System PCAN adapter
  • A Project file (.cprj) for the motor controller, provided by Navitec Systems
    • Different motor controllers have different project files. For example F2-D and F2-A models will use different project file
  • Servo mode tuning template file (.ctrc) is needed and is proviced by Navitec Systems

Limitations

  • Autocharacterization can be done only for AC induction motors (ACIM)
  • PMAC motors characterization is done by Curtis on their dynomometer lab and motor might need to be shipped to Curtis. Please contact Curtis if planning to use PMAC motor
  • Motor controller might not support all functions and kinematics. List of supported devices document should be checked to determine whether the combination of the function and kinematics is supported or not.
  • Currently, Navitrol is not able to control Curtis motor controllers with other motor controllers in the same AGV

Dependencies

  • Motor controllers common
  • CAN Communication
  • Initial Calibration Guide
  • Curtis Motor controller listing

Electrical connections

Electrical connections can be divided into several groups:

  1. High-current connections -- screw connections.

    a. Battery connectors -- B+ and B- Important note: The battery should be connected using the main contactor. This is because the motor controller has a quite large capacitor installed between connectors. If the battery is directly connected, it may have a large current spike.

    b. Motor terminals (U, V, W). Should be connected directly to the motor terminals

    c. Pump connection Some of the motor controllers might have DC pump for actuator control. Then pump should be connected between "Pump" and "B+".

  2. Low-current connections. All of the low power connections are through a single AMPSEAL connector. The following should be connected:

    a. Key Switch This is the logical power input. Additionally, used to reboot the motor controller.

    b. Coil Outputs (proportional valves). Those outputs are used for controlling the main contactor, brake release, and proportional valves. Wiring and pin number depends on the motor controller type.

    c. CAN connection

    d. SafeStop switch Pin that is used for E-STOP connection depends on the motor controller type. This pin should be powered during normal operation (Normally-closed contact).

    e. Motor sensors (available only for AC-channel): encoder and temperature sensor.

    f. Generic Switches Switches can be used as digital and analog inputs in some specific cases.

See Curtis Motor controller listing for more details.

Quick Setup

AGV off the ground

The following steps must be done so that AGV is lifted off the ground and motors can spin freely:

  • Connect the motor controller to the CAN-bus
  • Flash the project file to the motor controller with CIT software
  • Controller Parameter Setup
  • Auto Characterization for ACIM motor controllers
  • Internal PI controller tuning

AGV on the ground

After commissioning has proceed to a point that all motor controllers PI tuning has been completed, the AGV must be put back to ground and continue with following steps:

  • Navitrol parameterization
  • Tune Slip gain
  • Base speed configuration

How to use

To start the commissioning of Curtis motor controller, the following items are needed:

  1. Can USB adapter. PEAK System PCAN USB-adapter was tested by Navitec and recommended by Curtis

  2. CIT -- Curtis Integrated toolkit

  3. Project file for Curtis Motor Controller model provided by Navitec Systems

Connect motor controllers to the CAN bus

Connect the motor controller and CAN adapter to the CAN bus. The motor controller should be connected to the CAN bus for commissioning one by one.

If the motor controller is wired correctly, there should be a heartbeat on the CAN bus.

If a PCAN-USB adapter is used, open PCAN-View software and check that heartbeat is present on the bus.

Default node Ids are 0x26 (hex) = 38 (dec) and 0x27 (hex) = 39 (dec).

Note: two and three-channel motor controllers (F2-D, F2-T) have two communication interface. Therefore, if the above-mentioned controllers are used, there should be a heartbeat from two node Ids.

Flash the project file to the motor controller with CIT software

The first step that should be done in commissioning the motor controller is to Flash the controller.

To communicate with Navitrol, the motor controller should have appropriate software with Navitec-specific modifications. To install the software on the motor controller, the user should flash the project file to the motor controller. The project file is provided by Navitec Systems.

The project file is device-specific and supported devices are mentioned in the project file.

To flash the project file to the controller:

  1. Open the project.
  2. Select the correct CAN adapter at the bottom of the window.
  3. Next, press the green circle button to establish communication with the motor controllers.
  4. Once communication is established, press "Package and Flash" to go to the flashing menu of the motor controller. If motor controller is two or three channel, flash the file on both of them. Note: Navitrol needs to be turned of when flashing the project file to the controller

Flashing the project file on the Curtis controller

Controller Parameter Setup

General controller parameters should be set once flashing is completed. Parameter change must be performed for all motor controllers (and for both M1 and M2 controllers in case two-channel motor controllers are used).

To change parameters:

  1. Open Curtis Integrated Toolkit
  2. Connect to motor controllers using the green circle button
  3. Select motor controller (For example M1 or M2) and press "Programmer" in the right corner menu.

Programmer View

The following parameters should be checked from the Programmer:

Parameter NamePathRecommended ValueNotes
Control Mode SelectSystem Monitor Control Mode Select7Always Servo mode for Navitrol to be able to utilize the motor controller
Nominal Battery VoltageApplications Setup Battery Setup Nominal voltage24Typically 24 or 48 depending on the battery back
Main Contactor Pull in VoltageApplications Setup Main Contactor Pull in Voltage100Check from main contactor document the correct Pull in voltage. Typically 100
Main Contactor Holding VoltageApplications Setup Main Contactor Holding Voltage80Check from main contactor document the correct Holding voltage. Typically 80
EM Brake Pull in VoltageApplication Setup EM Brake Control Pull in Voltage100Check from Brake manufacturer document for correct Pull in Voltage. Typically 100
EM Brake Holding VoltageApplication Setup EM Brake Control Holding Voltage70Check from Brake manufacturer document for correct Holding Voltage. Typically 70
EM Brake TypeApplication Setup EM Brake Control EM Brake Type0Always 0, defined automatically by Curtis
CAN Baud RateApplication Setup CAN interface 1/2 Baud Rate0-2Baud Rate for the controller. Needs to be same as Navitrol Baud Rate.
Note: Change applied only after reboot
CAN Node IDApplication Setup CAN interface 1/2 CAN Node IDNodeId in hex (example 26h)Node ID for the motor controller in hexadecimal.
Note: Change applied only after reboot
EM Brake DriverController setup IO Assignments Coil drivers Em brake driver0Always 0, defined automatically by Curtis
Main Contactor DriverController setup IO Assignments Coil drivers Main contactor Driver5Check from Curtis Motor controller datasheet which driver is Main Contactor connected to. For example F4-A and F2-D Main Coil is connected to Driver 5
Position Sensor typeMotor Setup Position sensor type1Usually Quadrature encoder for ACIM motors. Check with customer which sensor they are using
Quadture Encoder 5V VoltageMotor Setup Quadrature Encoder 5V outputTrue
Quadture Encoder 12V VoltageMotor Setup Quadrature Encoder 12V outputTrue
Temperature Sensor TypeMotor Setup Temperature Sensor Sensor Type1-4Choose sensor type. 4 different sensors supported
Temperature Sensor EnabledMotor Setup Temperature Sensor Sensor EnableTrueCheck that temperature displayed in the menu corresponds to the actual temperature.
Temperature Sensor Max TempMotor Setup Temperature Sensor Temperature Max160Motor manufacturer provides this information
Temperature Sensor Hot TempMotor Setup Temperature Sensor Temperature Hot145Motor manufacturer provides this information
Interlock Input SourceController Setup IO Assignments Switch Assignment Interlock Input Source0Always 0, defined automatically by Curtis

For the PMAC motor set Sin/Cos Encoder parameters (Programmer Motor Setup Sin/Cos Encoder). Those parameters should be set according to the datasheet of encoder being used.

Once those parameters are set, it is possible to check Main Contactor and Brake operation. Go to:

  • Programmer Navitec Interlock force enable and select "Yes".
  • Check under System Monitor Outputs
    • Values increased from 0 to 70 or 80 the corresponding Drivers for example 5 and 2

Navitec menu in CIT

Once selected:

  • Main contactor should be engaged
  • Brakes should be released

Additionally, check if any errors appeared in Programmer. If there are some errors, react to them according to Curtis manual.

Auto Characterization for ACIM motor controllers

Once main parameters have been set and interlock can be released, characterizing the motor controller can be performed. Characterization means that the Motor controller will measure and tune motor parameters to establish optimal controllability of the motor.

The exact motor characterization model can be provided by Curtis. However, if Curtis does not have the characterization model available, the auto-characterization is needed. Autocharacterization and Slip Gain configuration are not needed when using the exact motor characterization model

The motor characterization should be performed for both M1 and M2 controllers in case two-channel motor controllers are used. Everything should be performed when wheels are off the ground.

Motor characterization is described in steps in Chapter 6 "Commissioning" of Curtis Manual. The procedure can be done in the following steps in Programmer:

  1. Set Motor Technology and Motor Type
Parameter NamePathRecommended ValueNotes
Motor TechnologyMotor Setup Motor TechnologyACIMACIM or PMAC
Motor TypeMotor Setup Induction Motor (ACIM) Motor Type-1-1 = Autocharacterization procedure used
1-588 = Exact motor characterization model provided by Curtis

  1. Clear Faults and do a power cycle of the controller. Only User 1 error (PDO timeout) can be present.

  2. Enter the desired Max Test Current and Max Test Speed for the characterization test (in Motor Setup Induction Motor (ACIM) Characterization Tests). Typical settings are 70% current and 1/3 of max speed of the motor.

  3. Enable interlock (Programmer Navitec Interlock force enable)

  4. Set Test Enable = On (Motor Setup Induction Motor (ACIM) Characterization Tests)

  5. Set Test Throttle = 1 (positive). After approximately 30 or more seconds, the motor will begin to pulsate and then rotate. It is critical to verify the motor is turning in the FORWARD vehicle direction. If it is not, set Test Throttle = 0, wait for the motor to come to a stop, then set Test Throttle = -1 (negative).

  6. When auto characterization is completed, a Parameter Change message will appear. Do a power cycle to the controller.

Motor characterization

Internal PI controller tuning

PI controller must be tuned in order to control the motor accurately and fast.

  1. Change Tuning Mode to value 1 to enable speed controller tuning.

Tuning mode select

  1. Set two speeds that will be used for speed tuning. The motor controller will switch between those speeds during the tuning procedure

  2. Set initial PI gains. First, leave Ki to 0.0 and set Kp to some initial value (0.2 is a good starting value)

Setting speed settings and PI coefficients

  1. Now go to the main page of the CIT software. Open TACT.

  2. Open the Tuning template file from the File menu. The Tuning template file will be provided by Navitec.

  3. Set Tuning Enable to value 1 in the Programmer

  4. Press the green triangle button in TACT to start

  5. The motor should start changing from Speed 1 to Speed 2 every Tuning Time interval. Increase Kp until slight overshoot is seen in the step response, then reduce the value of Speed Kp to approximately 2/3 of the present value. Typical values of well-tuned Speed Kp are 0.2-0.4 for small motors, much higher for larger motors.

  6. After Speed Kp value is determined, start slowly raising Ki. The motor should now exactly converge to the requested speeds. Take larger steps for Ki, e.g. +2.0. Increase Ki until overshoot is seen in the step response, then reduce the value of Speed Ki to approximately 2/3 of the present value. Typical values of a well-tuned Speed Ki are between 0.1 and 0.9.

Tuning process in Oscilloscope

  1. Once tuning is completed, change the Tuning Enable parameter back to 0.

Navitrol parameterization

  • Set CAN nodeId parameters according to Motor controllers common
  • Set CAN communication parameters according to CAN communication document.
  • The controller supports current limiting and control delays. Control delays are needed to ensure that the main contactor and brakes will be fully open when the motor controller will start driving.

Required parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
mot_ctrl_max_output_current_percentInt100Maximum output current (percent) sent to the motor controller
mot_ctrl_disable_delay_msInt1000Motor controller disabling delay [ms] after activating brakes: -1 = never disable, 0 = no delay
