mot_ctrl_startup_delay_main_contactor_msInt0Time given for main contactor to stabilize before enabling drive. 0 = no delay, 500 = recommended for Schwarzmueller and Curtis
mot_ctrl_startup_delay_brake_release_msInt0Time given for brakes to fully open before giving rpm out. 0 = no delay, 200 = recommended for Schwarzmueller, 100..300 = recommended for Curtis

Fine-tuning

If BMS is used, Navitrol can read BMS data from the motor controller. Set up BMS in CIT according to the controller manual. To activate BMS, use the parameters listed below

  • Note: Not all types of batteries are supported by built-in BMS. This information should be checked with Curtis support.

Optional parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
battery_percentage_from_mot_ctrlInt01 to read battery percentage from motor controller, 0 to calculate it from battery voltage
battery_alert_fromInt0Battery Alert Mode: -1 = no alert, 0 = alert from low voltage, 1 = alert from low battery percentage
battery_alert_percentageFloat5.0fWarning is set on low battery level [%] (battery_alert_from = 1)
can_syncInt1Navigation SW (Primary CAN) role for CANOpen SYNC messages: 0 = None, 1 = SYNC producer, 2 = SYNC consumer

Tune Slip gain

Slip gain need to be tuned after AGV is ready to be driven (Manually or with Navitrol). The steps to configure slip gain are:

  • Connect a load cell between the vehicle and something that does not move
  • A torque sensor needs to be connected to the motor to get the torque measurements
  • Running the motor that it stalls. Change torgues that it does not slip
  • Try to find highest torque produced by the motor and use that slip gain.
  • Open Programmer and change SlipGain (Motor Setup Induction Motor (ACIM) Characterization Tests)
    • First set to 3, then 1.5 and then 6. Check which produces the highest torque and fine-tune to find the highest torque produced

SlipGain on CIT Programmer

Curtis documentation tells more detailed how to configure the Slip Gain.

Base speed configuration

Base speed needs to be set up in order to utilize the motor controllers for driving. The following steps need to be executed.

  • Open Programmer in CIT software:

    • Motor Setup Induction Motor Field Weakening
      • Set FW Base Speed to 6000

  • Run the vehicle with very high acceleration. Controller will calculate the base speed itself and will inform the Base Speed Captured

  • Do the same test 5 times. Take the average Base Speed Captured

  • Set the FW Base Speed to the average calculated value

Base Speed setup on CIT Programmer

Curtis documentation tells more detailed how to configure the Base Speed.

Node Ids of the motor controller

Node Id:s should be configured in following way:

  • Two-channel motor controllers should have consecutive node ids, where channel 1 has the lower Id and channel 2 the larger. For instance, if node Id of M1 (channel 1) is 0x27, then node Id of M2 (channel 2) is 0x28.

Troubleshooting

CAN-bus errors

  • Troubleshooting CAN communication

Motor controller issues

If the motor controller indicates some errors, try the following:

  • If the motor controller is not rotated, check Navitrol terminal output or Navitrol Monitor errors or warnings. There should be some information about motor controller status and error if something is wrong.

  • If an error is active and does not reset after controller reboot, connect to the Motor controller with Curtis Integrated Toolkit to troubleshoot further.

Engel CAN motor controller

Updated 26.01.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
SDOService Data Object
PDOProcess Data Object
HomingProcess of finding home position
(position of zero steering angle)

Introduction

Engel motor controller is one of the motor controllers supported by Navitrol. Engel offers different range of single channel motor controllers that can be used for different purposes in the AGV.

In this documentation, instructions are provided for configuring the motor controllers to be interfaced with Navitrol.

Following motor controllers has been tested by Navitec Systems:

  • HFI series, HFI2660-N200-CO

However, according to documentation, other motor controllers also should be supported since CAN interface is common for all Engel motor controllers.

Operation of the device is possible either via fieldbus or via digital and analogue inputs and outputs. Communication via CANopen is supported by Navitrol.

The initial parameterisation/configuration of the device takes place with the parameterisation software DSerV.

For now, Engel motor controllers can be used:

  • For controlling steering in Schwarzmueller omni AGV

Electrical connections

Electrical connections can be divided into four groups:

  1. CAN bus. Terminal X2 with M12 connector is used to connect to the CAN bus. In order to connect to the can bus, pin 5 should be connected to CAN_L and pin 4 -- to CAN_H.

  2. Power supply. Terminal X1 (three internal wires) are used to connect to the power. Both main supply(A, BN) and logic supply (C, BK) should be powered.

  3. Series connection. Pins 10 (VT), 11 (GY-PK) and 8 (BK) should be connected to series adapter as it shown on the figure.

  4. Digital inputs and outputs.

The following digital inputs are used by Navitrol:

  1. DI1 (WH) is used in Engel state machine. It has to be powered, otherwise device cannot be put to "Operation Enabled" mode.

  2. DI3 (GN) is used as a negative limit switch for homing for steering.

  3. DI8 (BU-RD) can be used as an E-STOP (depending on Navitrol parameter I,mot_ctrl_engel_estop_enabled). If this pin is powered, safestop is disable. Once it loses power, safestop triggered (NC contact).

Commissioning steps

The following steps should be done in process of commissioning:

  1. Establishing serial connection to the motor controller

  2. Connection to DSerV software to enable CAN communication

  3. Changing Navitrol parameters

  4. Tuning internal PID controller

Note: By default, CAN communication is disabled in motor controller. It is mandatory to connect with DSerV software in order to enable it.

Establishing serial connection to the motor controller

Connection to the DSerV software is done using the serial port. Therefore, RS232-USB adapter should be used.

Connect wires as it shown in the Figure 1. Note that pins (2,3,5) shown on the figure are pinout of the DB9 adapter. In case of using Moxa adapter, pay attention that terminal block pin numbering is different to DB9 pinout. Additionally, it is important to connect ground (wire 8, BK) to pin 5 of the DB9.

Once wiring is done, make sure that drivers are installed correctly. RS232-USB adapter should create a COM port. The following settings should be set in Device Manager for the COM-port:

Additionally, in case of Moxa adapters, RS-232 interface should be selected in Device Manager -- Multi-port serial adapter:

Connection to DSerV software to enable CAN communication

In order to connect to motor controller, open DSerV software and select the COM-port to which motor controller is connected:

If wiring is correct and motor controller is powered, connection should be successfully established.

Once connection has been established, open tab Optimization -- Fieldbus operation. Select CANopen fieldbus. Enter bitrate (250 kbit/s is default for Navitrol) and Node-ID.

Note that all of the CANopen device on the bus should have different Node-IDs and the same bitrate.

Press "Send" and do a power cycle (remove power from the drive and apply it again).

Once it is done, motor controller is ready to communicate with Navitrol.

Changing Navitrol parameters

  • First, set Node ID to the corresponding parameter. For instance, if motor controller controlling steering in omni machine, set can_omni_steer_ctrl_nodeid to the same value that was set in previous step.

  • Set the communication parameters (can_ch and can_bitrate_k) according to CAN communication document.

  • Set some initial parameters for built-in PD controller mot_ctrl_engel_p_gain and mot_ctrl_engel_i_time_ms.

  • If motor controller is used for steering without external absolute encoder, homing offset can be changed using the parater mot_ctrl_engel_home_offset (4096 = 1 revolution). Corresponds to the object 607C in motor controller manual.

  • If estop should be enabled, set parameter mot_ctrl_engel_estop_enabled.

  • Other motor controller settings are done using SDOs by Navitrol.

Table 1. List of Navitrol parameters

TypeNameMinDefaultMaxInformation
Floatmot_ctrl_engel_p_gain0.00.21.0Engel motor controller internal P-gain
Floatmot_ctrl_engel_i_time_ms0.04.03276Engel motor controller internal Integration time in milliseconds
Intmot_ctrl_engel_home_offset-2.1*10902.1*109Engel motor controller homing offset
Intmot_ctrl_engel_estop_enabled011Engel emergency stop activation. Emergency stop activation comes from digital input 8 (BU-RD wire). DI8 should be powered in normal mode

Tuning PID coefficients

In order to tune PID controller, DSerV software in combination of Navitrol should be used. Note: tuning PID controller is typically done by customers.

In order to tune PID controller, step response should be given to the motor controller. Motor controller form can be used for giving out reference:

In motor controller form, the following features can be used:

  • Giving target angle

  • Giving target RPM

  • Brake release (should checked to drive the motor)

  • Safe stop (should be unchecked to drive the motor)

  • Reset fault

DSerV has Ocsilloscope feature that can be used for PID tuning (Diagnostic - Oscilloscope). For instance, the following configuration of channels would trigger capturing the step response:

If motor controller is used for homing operation, form can be opened and used after homing process has finished.

Note: it has been noticed that values captured by the DSerV software are not very accurate. It recommended to make every step response several times for the best results.

The following sequence of calibrating is recommended:

  • In Navitrol, open Motor controller form and put some RPMs.

  • Make channel setup similar to the one on the Figure

  • Check "Brake release" in Navitrol. Oscillogram should be captured.

  • In order to change the PID values, go to the DSerV software and select the Optimisation-Speed controller. Values sent from there are immediately changed in motor controller

  • Once optimal values are found, copy them to the Navitrol parameters (mot_ctrl_engel_p_gain and mot_ctrl_engel_i_time_ms)

Motor controller manufacturer recommends the following sequence of tuning PID controller:

DSerV software capabilities

The following functions are available in DSerV software:

  1. Optimisation. This tab allows to change, save and view parameters inside the motor controller. Typically, all of the needed parameters are written by Navitrol, so there is no need to change anything.

  2. Monitor. This tab allows to see current values of engineering parameters, such as current, speed, temperature, power, voltage and so on. Used for monitoring purposes.

  3. Diagnostic. This tab allows to open two windows: CAN monitor and Ocsilloscope. Oscilloscope can be used for monitoring purposes and for setting up PID controller. CAN Monitor shows all of the CAN-objects and can be used for monitoring.

  4. Device information. Is shows state of the motor controller, state of the CAN bus, errors and information about fieldbus parameters.

Troubleshooting

CAN-bus errors

If CAN-bus is not working correctly, make sure that following things are checked:

  • CAN-bus has 120ohm resistors activated on the both end of the bus. The total CAN-bus impedance has to be approximately 60 ohms.

  • Check that all motor controllers and other CAN-devices in the bus have same baudrate

  • Make sure that all CAN-devices on the bus have individual NodeID

  • Double-check Navitrol parameters in this document

  • Make sure that you have done also CAN-bus grounding

    • If CAN-bus GND is not grounded, there might occur error frames in the CAN-bus

    • Higher baudrates require CAN-bus grounding because they require more accurate voltage levels

  • More information about CAN-bus related errors can be found from Navitrol - CAN TroubleShoot

Motor controller issues

If motor controller indicates some errors, try the following:

  • If motor controller is not rotated, check the console or find for "LogEngelErrors" in the log.

  • More information about error can be received from EMCY message, Engel should send in error state. To read EMCY, find in the console of log: "CAN: EMCY from node"

  • Try to establish serial connection to check errors directly from the motor controller

If it is written it the console "okToDrive 0", this means that homing process has not successfully finished yet. For the first 20 seconds, it is normally. If process lasts more than 20 seconds, it means that there are some issues with homing process (probably, limit switch cannot be found).

If it is written in the console "DI1 is not set. It is not possible to set motor controller to operation mode" then DI1 should be powered to solve the problem.

Kinco CAN motor controller

Updated 26.06.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
ODObject Dictionary
SDOService Data Object
PDOProcess Data Object
NMTNetwork Management
RS232Recommended Standard 232. Communication protocol for serial communication.

Overview

Introduction

Kinco offers single channel motor controllers that can be used for driving in the AGV.

This document provides instructions for configuring the motor controllers to be compatible with Navitrol.

Requirements

Hardware:

  • Supported Kinco Motor controller models can be found from the List of supported devices.
  • Connectors for wiring (or alternatively Kinco cables with connectors). Without the connectors, it is not possible to wire the motor controller. Types and number of connectors can be found from the Technical Manual for the motor controller.
  • Adapter for connecting the motor controller to PC. RS232 cable is required by the KincoServo+ software.

Software

  • Motor controller related software can be downloaded from: Kinco Download site.
  • The following item should be downloaded for the commissioning:
    • KincoServo+ for parameters adjustment and diagnostics

Documentation

Technical manual is needed for the motor controller. It contains dimensions, wiring instructions and CANOpen messages. Additionally, it contains the commissioning instructions and the SDO object dictionary. Technical manual depends on the motor controller model and can be found on the Kinco Download site.

  • The manual for OD1X4S and FD1X4S models:
    • Kinco Low-Voltage User Manual
  • The Catalog contains some technical information of the driver and motor.
    • Kinco Catalog Low voltage servo

Limitations

  • Motor controller might not support all functions (steering, driving, actuating). See List of supported devices for information about the supported functionalities.
  • It is not possible to use Kinco motor controller with other motor controllers in the same AGV

Dependencies

  • CAN communication.

Electrical connections

The connections might vary depending on the motor controller model. See Kinco Download site for further info.

Quick setup

The following steps should be done during commissioning:

Step 1 (Option 1): KincoServo+

  • Change Node-ID and baud rate with KincoServo+

Step 1 (Option 2): General CAN-analyzer Commissioning

If you do not have KincoServo+ compatible adapter, the commissioning needs to be done by using a CAN analyzer.

  • Changing Node-ID and baud rate with CAN-analyzer

Step 2

After the Node and baud-rate are set on all motor controllers, proceed to:

  • Navitrol parameterization and controller tuning

Required parameters

NameTypeRequired valueDescription
The indices of the following array parameters are:
Differential drive:
0 = Left wheel
1 = Right wheel
Mecanum:
0 = Forward Left
1 = Forward Right
2 = Rear Left
3 = Rear Right
Drive Motor controllers
mot_ctrl_drive_controller_type_arr[]Int44 = Kinco
mot_ctrl_drive_p_arr[]Float30.0P value of the drive motor controller. 0.0 = this parameter not used. When tested with motor without any load, this was quite low value. For example, 30.0.
mot_ctrl_drive_i_arr[]Float0.0I value of the drive motor controller. 0.0 = this parameter not used. When tested with motor without any load, this was set to 0.
mot_ctrl_drive_can_nodeid_arr[]Int1Motor controller CAN node id for drive motor. 0 = this parameter not used. Default node id for kinco is 1.
mot_ctrl_drive_encoder_pulses_per_revUint4096Encoder resolution (pulses per revolution) used to calculate RPM if drive motor does not provide that. 0 = this parameter not used.
Other required parameters
can_primary_any_idInt1Primary CAN valid PDO id's that can be registered: 0 = Only valid PDO id's can be registered, 1 = Any id can be registered. For Kinco, this is required to be 1 for Error reset SDO message register to CAN PDO.
can_nodeguard_guard_time_msInt1000Nodeguarding guard time [ms]: 0 = Nodeguard disabled
can_syncInt1Navigation SW (Primary CAN) role for CANOpen SYNC messages: 0 = None, 1 = SYNC producer, 2 = SYNC consumer

Fine-tuning

Optional parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
mot_ctrl_reset_errors_timerInt500After the defined time (ms) Navitrol tries automatically reset motor control faults. Value 0 = fault reset disabled. When error is active on controller. Navitrol will start sending Error reset SDO within this interval until the errors are reset.
mot_ctrl_drive_encoder_pulses_per_rev_arr[]Int0Encoder resolution (pulses per revolution) used to calculate RPM if drive motor does not provide that. 0 = this parameter not used. If AGV has motors with different resolution, this parameter can be used to override mot_ctrl_drive_encoder_pulses_per_rev

KincoServo+ Easy Commissioning

Kinco offers KincoServo+ for easy commissioning. It can be downloaded from Kinco Download site.

Change Node-ID and baud rate

  • Download KincoServo+ software and connect your PC to the motor controller (communication interface RS232).

  • The default baud rate for RS232 is 38400 and COM ID 1. If user does not know the COM ID, broadcast address 127 can be used instead.

  • The default CAN Node-ID is 1. It can be changed from Driver -> Driver Configuration -> Node_ID.

    Change the Node-ID

  • Change the CAN baud rate. Default baud rate for Kinco motor controller is 500 kbd. Please note that the Kinco motor controller and Navitrol baud rate needs to match.

    Change the baud rate.

  • Go to the Driver -> Init Save Reboot and click Save Motor Parameters, after that click Reboot.

    Save Motor parameters

  • Repeat the same procedure for all motor controllers.

General CAN-analyzer commissioning (Option 2)

If you do not have the possibility to use KincoServo+ software, the commissioning needs to be done by using CAN analyzer. With this method each motor controller needs to be connected and configured separately on the bus.

Controller switch configuration

  • Connect the motor controller to your PC with a CAN-USB adapter.

  • NOTE: The controller might have DIP switch that activates 120-ohm resistor. A CAN-bus needs 120-ohm resistors on both ends of the bus

DIP switch from the OD124S controller.

Change Node-ID and baud rate with CAN-analyzer

The default Node-ID is 1 and the CAN baud rate is 500 kBd.

To change the baud rate and Node-ID, you need to change object 2F81:0h (baud rate) and 100B:0h (Node-ID). The changes in objects 2F81h and 100Bh must be stored by writing value 65766173h in object 1010h:1h. This can be done by following the sequence presented below in the table.

SEND/RESPONSECOB ID (in hex 0x)dlcData bytes (in hex 0x)Description
SEND60182F 0B 10 00 NODEID 00 00 00Define Node-ID (put desired Node-ID to NODEID)
RESPONSE581860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxSDO Response OK
SEND60182F 81 2F 00 19 00 00 00SDO Upload request:
Change baud rate to 250 kbs
0x01 = 10 kbd, 0x05 = 50 kbd, 0x0C = 125 kbd,
0x19 = 250 kbd, 0x32 = 500 kbd, 0x64 = 1000 kbd
RESPONSE581860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxResponse OK
SEND601823 10 10 01 73 61 76 65SDO Upload request:
Save all communication parameters

Change Node-ID and baud rate with CAN-analyzer

After you have done these changes, turn off the motor controller and then turn the motor controller back on, the Node-ID and baud rate should be set to the values you just sent to the motor controller.

Navitrol parameterization and controller tuning

Node-ID and CAN bus bitrate

Node-ID defines the address of the CANopen device and it must be in range from 1 to 127. In addition, the Node-ID has to be unique for each device on the CAN bus.

CAN bus bitrate (baud rate) is the communication speed. By following these instructions, this speed is set to 250 Kbit/s for the motor controllers. The speed needs to be the same for Navitrol and motor controllers, otherwise the CAN bus communication will not work.

Every motor controller has a Node-ID. params.txt file has a parameter for each motor controller Node-ID and a parameter for Navitrol CAN bus bitrate.

First, set Node-ID to the corresponding parameters:

  • mot_ctrl_drive_can_nodeid_arr

Set the communication parameters (can_ch and can_bitrate_k) according to CAN communication document.

PI-controller values tuning

All Kinco motor controllers have an internal PI-controller that must be tuned. These controllers must be tuned. Rule of thumb instructions to find the optimal parameters are presented below (reference from Kinco CANopen document).

*1. According to oscillation and noise sensed with the finger and the ears: This method is based on experience,but its efficient. The user can listen to or touch the machine, at the same time increasing and reducing the kvp. When an acceptable maximum kvp value is found, the current setting can be specified as the maximum velocity loop bandwidth.

  1. According to the scope image from KincoServo+: The user can create a jump command for velocity control and sample actual velocity and current while changing kvp. The right velocity curve should quickly fulfil the command without oscillation and unusual noise.*

Motor controller can be tuned

  • Modifying the Kvp and Kvi/32 parameters with KincoServo+ software. After the optimal parameters are found, save those to the Navitrol parameters (params.txt)
  • Modifying Navitrol P- and I-gain parameters with Navitrol and Navitrol Monitor. When Navitrol starts, it will always override the motor controller P- and I-gain values based on Navitrol parameters.

The P-gain can be set with mot_ctrl_drive_p_arr. These values are set to Kvp[0] (SDO Object Index 0x60F9 SubIndex 0x01) parameter from Kinco documentation. The I-gain can be set with mot_ctrl_drive_i_arr. These values are set to Kvi/32 (SDO Object Index 0x60F9 SubIndex 0x07) parameter from Kinco documentation. The Kvi[0] (SDO Object Index 0x60F9 SubIndex 0x02) is not used with Navitrol, it is kept as 0.

SDO-parameters for CAN-open

Navitrol configures a subset of Kinco motor controller's SDO-parameters when Navitrol starts. These configurations are sent as SDO-messages to the motor controllers. The SDO-messages that Navitrol configures can be seen on the table below. The parameters for automatic SDO-configurations (for example, SDO message interval and SDO message response timeout) are presented on the CAN communication document.

SDO Object table

NameAddressData typeValue in hexDescription
Invert direction607E0008Unsigned80Invert motion
0CCW is positive direction
1CW is positive direction
Kvp60F90110Unsigned160Bigger Kvp, bigger gain, but it may cause motor noise. Navitrol set the value based on mot_ctrl_drive_p_arr parameter. The parameter value is converted to integer. For example, if this parameter is set to 200.4, the written value is: 200 (0xC8 in hex).
Kvi60F90210Unsigned160Bigger Kvi, bigger gain, but it may cause motor noise
Kvi/3260F90710Unsigned160It is 1/31 of the normal kvi. Navitrol set the value based on mot_ctrl_drive_i_arr parameter. The parameter value is multiplied with 32 and rounded to the nearest larger integer. For example, if this parameter is set to 1.3, the written value is: 1.3 * 32.0 = 41.6 -> 42 (0x2A in hex).
Operation mode60600008Integer83Operation mode:
1: Position control
3: Speed control
4: Torque control
-3Speed control (Quick fast mode)
-4Pulse train control
6Home mode
7Differential complementarity based on CANopen
Din1_Function20100310Unsigned1620002: Reset Errors function set to Din1
Din_Simulate20100210Unsigned160bit0: Din1. Used to reset errors when bit0 is changed from 0 to 1.
Abort connection mode60070010Unsigned161CAN communication abort time determine action logic when driver still do not receive node protection message over node guarding time * node guarding factor
0: no process
1: error
Nodeguarding guard time100C0010Unsigned160xC8Nodes protect masters, it can monitor current state of every node. Masters (node protection time as period) send remote frame to check slave node state. Nodes need to response in a time. Otherwise, master nodes regard slave nodes off-line. Driver will have alarms. Navitrol set the value based on can_nodeguard_guard_time_ms parameter.
Life Time Factor100D0008Unsigned83Node guarding time factor

SDO Object table that Navitrol configures during startup.
The address contains Object Index, SubIndex and data type as following:
For example address 607E0208:
Object index = 0x607E
SubIndex = 0x02
Data type = 0x08 (0x08 = 1 byte, 0x10 = 2 bytes, 0x20 = 4 bytes)

Troubleshooting

Motor is not spinning when sending RPM value to it and there is no error code

The encoder resolution might be incorrect. Kinco communication protocol is not using RPM value for speed, but instead Kinco internal decimal value that Navitrol will calculate from RPM based on encoder resolution parameter. By default, these parameters are 0 and with that value the measured RPM and target RPM are so low that the motor is not spinning.

Citation from Kinco document:
For example, engineering unit of speed is rpm and internal unit is dec. The relationship is: 1RPM = 2730dec (Encoder resolution 10000)! It is assumed that if the speed is 10rpm, user need to write 27300dec (6AA4 in HEX) when use communication to control. The decimal value is calculated from this formula: DEC = [(RPM * 512 * encoder resolution) / 1875]

Check that these parameters have correct values.

  • mot_ctrl_drive_encoder_pulses_per_rev and mot_ctrl_drive_encoder_pulses_per_rev_arr

CAN-bus errors

If CAN-bus is not working correctly, make sure that following things are checked:

  • CAN-bus has 120 ohm resistors activated on the both end of the bus. The total CAN-bus impedance has to be approximately 60 ohms.
  • If the motor controller has PID switch for the resistor, check that it is set to correct position.
  • Check that all motor controllers and other CAN-devices in the bus have same baud rate
  • Make sure that all CAN-devices on the bus have individual Node-ID
  • Double-check Navitrol parameters in this document
  • Make sure that you have also done CAN-bus grounding
    • If CAN-bus GND is not grounded, there might occur error frames in the CAN-bus
    • Higher baud rates require CAN-bus grounding because they require more accurate voltage levels
  • More information about CAN-bus related errors can be found from Navitrol CANOpen Communication Troubleshooting.

References

Kinco Download site

  • KincoServo+
  • Kinco Low-Voltage User Manual
  • Models OD1X4S and FD1X4S

PEAK PCAN-USB Adapter

Nanotec CAN motor controller

Updated 26.06.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
ODObject Dictionary
SDOService Data Object
PDOProcess Data Object
NMTNetwork Management

Overview

Introduction

Nanotec motor controller is one of the motor controllers supported by Navitrol. Nanotec offers single channel motor controllers that can be used for different purposes (steering, driving, actuator) in the AGV.

This document provides instructions for configuring the motor controllers to be compatible with Navitrol.

Requirements

Hardware:

  • Supported motor controller (List of supported devices document should be checked)
  • Connectors for wiring (or alternatively Nanotec cables with connectors). Without the connectors, it is not possible to wire the motor controller. Types and number of connectors can be found from the Technical Manual for the motor controller.
  • Adapter for connecting the motor controller to PC. IXXAT or PEAK is required by the Nanotec Plug & Drive Studio software. It is recommended to check compatible CAN adapter versions from Plug & Drive Studio Quick Start Guide.

Software

  • In order to change motor controller parameters conveniently, Plug & Drive Studio 2 is recommended for use. Check Plug & Drive Studio Quick Start Guide to get familiar with the software.
  • Drivers and monitoring software for CAN analyzers according to Plug & Drive Studio Quick Start Guide.

Documentation

  • Technical manual for the motor controller. It contains dimensions, wiring instructions and pinout. Additionally, it contains the commissioning instructions and the SDO object dictionary. Technical manual depends on the motor controller type and can be found on the Nanotec official site. There are known differences between the firmware versions, therefore it is recommended to check that the technical manual is compatible with the motor controller's firmware version

Limitations

  • Motor controller might not support all functions (steering, driving, actuating) and kinematics. List of supported devices document should be checked to determine whether the combination of the function and kinematics is supported or not.
  • Currently, it is not possible to use Nanotec motor controller with other motor controllers in the same AGV

Dependencies

This feature is dependent on CAN interface. Therefore, it is recommended to check CAN communication document.

Electrical connections

Electrical connections must be done according to the Nanotec technical manual. The connections might vary depending on the motor controller model and user should refer to Nanotec motor controller technical manual.

Safety system connection

Since Nanotec motor controller does not have STO (Safe Torque Off) feature, safety system has to cut power from the motor/motor controller. However, there is a functionality that allows to stop the motor controller using digital inputs. This approach is not safety rated and therefore not recommended for use. This can be used only for prototyping at user's own risk.
In order to enable this stopping functionality, connect digital input 1 and 2 to the AGV:s stop button. Note that both inputs are NC - meaning that they should be powered in normal situation and power should be removed to stop the AGV.

Quick setup

The following steps should be done during commissioning:

Step 1 (Option 1): Nanotec Plug & Drive Studio Easy Commissioning

  • Controller switch and CAN-bus configuration
  • Change Node-ID and baud rate with Plug & Drive
  • Change OD-objects and execute Auto-Setup

Step 1 (Option 2): General CAN-analyzer Commissioning

If you do not have Plug & Drive studio compatible adapter, the commissioning needs to be done by using CAN analyzer.

  • Controller switch Configuration
  • Changing Node-ID and baud rate with CAN-analyzer
  • Auto-Setup for controller tuning with CAN-analyzer

Step 2

After the Auto-Setup has been done succesfully for all of the motor controllers, proceed to:

  • Navitrol parameterization and controller tuning

Required parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
mot_ctrl_nanotec_p_gainInt60000Nanotec motor controllers internal P-gain; min 1, max 270000
can_syncInt1Navigation SW (Primary CAN) role for CANOpen SYNC messages: 0 = None, 1 = SYNC producer, 2 = SYNC consumer
mot_ctrl_nanotec_p_gainInt500Nanotec motor controllers internal I-gain; min 1, max 10000
Differential AGV
can_diff_drive_left_nodeidInt30Node-ID for diff drive left motor controller
can_diff_drive_right_nodeidInt31Node-ID for diff drive right motor controller
Mecanum AGV
mot_ctrl_mecanum_nodeid[]Int0CANopen Node-ID. 0 - not defined, Indexes are 0 = FF (Forward Left), 1 = FR (Forward Right), 2 = RL (Rear Left), 3 = RR (Rear Right)

Fine-tuning

  • If needed, the warning for E-STOP can be enabled from the motor controller using the nanotec_emergency_stop_IO_enabled parameter
  • Automatic error reset can be disabled using mot_ctrl_reset_errors_timer.

Optional parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
nanotec_emergency_stop_IO_enabledInt0Activates Nanotec E-STOP check.
Emergency stop activation comes from digital input 1 and 2 on the motor controller
mot_ctrl_reset_errors_timerInt500After the defined time (ms) Navitrol tries automatically reset motor control faults. Value 0 = fault reset disabled

Nanotec Plug & Drive Studio Easy Commissioning

Nanotec offers Plug & Drive studio 2 (https://en.nanotec.com/products/2533-plug-drive-studio-2) for easy commissioning. However, only Ixxat and PEAK CAN-adapters are supported by Plug & Drive Studio.

Controller switch and CAN-bus configuration

Turn the rotary switches on the controllers so that they point to values 1, 2, 3 and 4. If you have only 2 controllers, use values 1 and 2. The Node-ID of the motor controller will be the same is the value on the rotary switch. The baud rate of the switch is fixed to 1000 MBd.

After the switches for all motor controller are turned accordingly, connect all motor controllers to the CAN-bus. Note that all controllers on the bus need to have different rotary switch value as the value of the rotary switch will be the initial Node-ID of the controller. Only rotary switch values 1-4 are allowed.

Set rotary switches to value 1, 2, 3 and 4

Connector assignment - right one shows bottom switches, including rotary switch / Hex coding switch.

When all controllers are connected to the CAN-bus, plug the CAN-adapter to the bus and open Plug & Drive Studio.

Change Node-ID and baud rate

  • Download Plug & Drive Studio 2.1.7 and connect to the CAN-bus

  • Update the firmware ( For example PD4-Cx-E-08-FIR-v2213-B1031134) to all motor controllers.

    Update the firmware

  • Change the Node-ID

    Change the Node-ID

  • Change the baud rate. Recommended baud rate is 125 kbd.

    Change the baud rate. 0x84 = 125 kbd, 0x85 = 250kbd, 0x86 = 500 kbd

  • Go to the Setup Tab and click Save from Settings. Choose CanOpen configurations and click Save.

    Save baud rate and Node-ID

  • Repeat the same procedure for all motor controllers. For example configure the motor controllers to Node-ID:s 5, 6, 7 and 8.

  • After these settings are done, turn of the motor controllers and change rotary switches to value 8 for all motor controllers. Turn on the motor controllers back again.

Change OD-objects and execute Auto-Setup

  • Connect controller with Plug & Drive Studio. Choose CanOpen and baud rate is 125kBd. Click Scan.

> Scan Node-ID:s

  • After a successful scan, choose motor controller from a list.

    Node-ID List

  • Change first OD 604C Subindex 2 to value 1 (VL Dimension Factor Denominator). This needs to be changed with newer firmware version.

    Change VL Dimension Factor Denominator

  • Click Setup from the navigation Tab and choose Auto-Setup.

    NOTE: the following prerequisites for performing the Auto-Setup:

    • The motor must be load-free.
    • The motor must not be touched.
    • The motor must be able to turn freely in any direction.

  • Start Auto-Setup. The motor will start to spin and make some noise. After Auto-Setup is completed, a pop-up window will show up to save Auto-Setup result. Click Save and restart.

    Start Auto-Setup

    Accept and Save Auto-Setup result

Repeat the same procedure for all motor controllers. After Auto-Setup has been successfully completed for all motor controllers, proceed to Navitrol Parameterization and Controller tuning.

General CAN-analyser commissioning (Option 2)

If you do not have the possibility to use PEAK PCAN-USB adapter or Ixxat adapter, the commissioning needs to be done by using CAN analyzer. With this method each motor controller needs to be connected and configured separately on the bus.

Controller switch configuration

  • Connect the motor controller to your PC with a CAN-USB adapter.

  • Set the rotary switch to value "1" from the bottom of the motor controller

  • NOTE: Next to the rotary switch is a DIP switch that activates 120-ohm resistor. A CAN-bus needs 120-ohm resistors on both ends of the bus

Set rotary switch to value 1

Connector assignment - right one shows bottom switches, including the rotary switch.

Change Node-ID and baud rate with CAN-analyzer

Turn the rotary switch so that it points to value "1". Then the Node-ID is fixed to value "1" and the baud rate is permanently set to 1000 kBd.

To change the baud rate and Node-ID, you need to change object 2005:0h (baud rate) and 2009:0h (Node-ID). The changes in objects 2005h and 2009h must be stored by writing value 65766173h in object 1010h:2h. This can be done by following the sequence presented below in the table.

SEND/RESPONSECOB ID (in hex 0x)dlcData bytes (in hex 0x)DescriptionNote
SEND601822 09 20 00 NODEID 00 00 00Define Node-ID (put desired Node-ID to NODEID)
RESPONSE581860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxSDO Response OK
SEND601822 05 20 00 84 00 00 00SDO Upload request:
change baud rate to 125kbs
0x84 = 125 kbd, 0x85 = 250kbd, 0x86 = 500 kbd
RESPONSE581860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxResponse OK
SEND601822 10 10 02 73 61 76 65SDO Upload request:
Save all communication parameters

Change Node-ID and baud rate with CAN-analyzer

After you have done these changes, turn off the motor controller and set the rotary switch to value "8". When you turn the motor controller back on, the Node-ID and baud rate should be set to the values you just sent to the motor controller.

Auto-Setup for controller tuning with CAN-analyzer

To determine number of parameters related to the motor and the connected sensors (encoders/Hall sensors), an Auto-Setup is performed. Closed Loop operation requires a successfully completed Auto-Setup.

NOTE: the following prerequisites for performing the Auto-Setup:

  • The motor must be load-free.
  • The motor must not be touched.
  • The motor must be able to turn freely in any direction.

To start the Auto-Setup do the following steps:

  1. Connect the motor controller to your PC with CAN-USB adapter and open CAN-analyzer.
  2. Test that the interface works by sending SDO 40 41 60 00 00 00 00 00 to the controller.
    a. The controller should response with: 4B 41 60 00 XX XX 00 00.
  3. Then the Auto-Setup sequence has to be done next. Messages are in CANopen SDO-format. Follow the table below to complete the Auto-Setup.

Ladder diagram of Auto-Setup sequence

SEND/RESPONSECOB ID (in hex 0x)dlcData bytes (in hex 0x)DescriptionNote
SEND0280 00NMT : Switch all nodes to pre-operational mode
RESPONSE700 + Node-ID27FNMT response: Response OK
SEND600 + Node-ID822 40 60 00 06 00 00 00SDO Upload request : enable voltage and disable quick stop
RESPONSE580 + Node-ID860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxResponse OK
SEND600 + Node-ID822 60 60 00 FE 00 00 00SDO Upload request : Put operation mode to "Auto Setup"
RESPONSE580 + Node-ID860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxResponse OK
SEND600 + Node-ID822 40 60 00 07 00 00 00SDO Upload request : Switch on the controller
RESPONSE580 + Node-ID860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxResponse OK
SEND600 + Node-ID822 40 60 00 0F 00 00 00SDO Upload request: Enable Operation
RESPONSE580 + Node-ID860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxResponse OK
SEND600 + Node-ID822 40 60 00 1F 00 00 00SDO Upload request: Start "Auto Setup executing"wait for 30-60 seconds!!!
RESPONSE580 + Node-ID860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxResponse OKwait for 30-60 seconds!!!
SEND600 + Node-ID822 40 60 00 00 00 00 00SDO Upload request: Stop and finish
RESPONSE580 + Node-ID860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxResponse OK

Auto-Setup sequence with CAN-analyzer

After the Auto-Setup is done, restart the controller. The controller should now be ready to be used.

Navitrol parameterization and controller tuning

Node-ID and CAN bus bitrate

Node-ID defines the address of the CANopen device and it must be in range from 1 to 127. In addition, the Node-ID has to be unique for each device on the CAN bus.

CAN bus bitrate (baud rate) is the communication speed. By following these instructions, this speed is set to 125Kbit/s for the motor controllers. The speed needs to be the same for Navitrol and motor controllers, otherwise the CAN bus communication will not work.

Every motor controller has a Node-ID. params.txt file has a parameter for each motor controller Node-ID and a parameter for Navitrol CAN bus bitrate.

First, set Node-ID to the corresponding parameter according to Table "CAN Node-ID parameters for motor controllers" in Motor controllers common document.

Set the communication parameters (can_ch and can_bitrate_k) according to CAN communication document.

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
can_bitrate_kInt125Primary CAN bus bitrate in Kbit/s
can_chInt0Primary CAN channel number
Differential AGV
can_diff_drive_left_nodeidInt30Node-ID for diff drive left motor controller
can_diff_drive_right_nodeidInt31Node-ID for diff drive right motor controller
Mecanum AGV
mot_ctrl_mecanum_nodeid[]Int0CANopen Node-ID. 0 - not defined, Indexes are 0 = FF (Forward Left), 1 = FR (Forward Right), 2 = RL (Rear Left), 3 = RR (Rear Right)

PI-controller values tuning

All Nanotec motor controllers have internal PI-controller. These controllers must be tuned. Rule of thumb instructions to find the optimum parameters are below (reference from Nanotec CANopen document).

1. You can increase the "P" value until the motor is starting to produce noise. Then reduce by half the value to get a good control loop setting.

2. If the motor is following the desired input parameter too slowly, increase the "P" value.

3. After finding a good "P" value, increase the "I" value to reduce the control error.

4. If the motor is producing overshoots after reaching the desired value, decrease the "I" value.

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
mot_ctrl_nanotec_p_gainInt60000Nanotec motor controllers internal P-gain; min 1, max 270000
mot_ctrl_nanotec_i_gainInt500Nanotec motor controller internal I-gain; min 1, max 10000

SDO-parameters for CAN-open

Navitrol configures a subset of Nanotec motor controller's SDO-parameters when Navitrol starts. These configurations are sent as SDO-messages to the motor controllers. The parameters for automatic SDO-configurations are presented below.

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
can_sdo_interval_msInt30SDO message interval [ms] used by Navitrol
can_sdo_timeout_msInt20SDO message response timeout [ms] used by Navitrol

Extra SDO-configurations

Nanotec motor controllers differ a bit depending on their firmware versions and motor controller models. Therefore, some extra SDO-configurations may be needed to make the motor controller work as expected. You can use either CAN Analyzer, Navitrol internal SDO-write configuration tools or Plug & Drive Studio to change the configurations. Configurations are listed below.

Object DescriptionSubIndexValue to Set in HexMotor Controller TypeDescriptionNote
604C21PD2-C, PD4-C, PD6-C, N5Dimension Factor DenominatorIf motor controller uses firmware version FIR-v2139 or newer
320204 or 45N5Automatic brake control- Value 45 with BLDC motors
- Value 4 otherwise

CAN analyzer

An example to change RPM scale using CAN-analyzer. The following messages needs to be sent to the motor controller (example Node-ID:s 5, 6, 7 and 8)

SEND/RESPONSECOB ID (in hex 0x)dlcData bytes (in hex 0x)DescriptionNote
SEND605822 4C 60 02 1 00 00 00RPM scale 604Ch Subindex 2h: stock firmware value 3Ch
RESPONSE585860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxSDO Response OK
SEND606822 4C 60 02 1 00 00 00RPM scale 604Ch Subindex 2h: stock firmware value 3Ch
RESPONSE586860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxSDO Response OK
SEND607822 4C 60 02 1 00 00 00RPM scale 604Ch Subindex 2h: stock firmware value 3Ch
RESPONSE587860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxSDO Response OK
SEND608822 4C 60 02 1 00 00 00RPM scale 604Ch Subindex 2h: stock firmware value 3Ch
RESPONSE588860 xx xx xx xx xx xx xxSDO Response OK

Table 1: Change RPM scale with CAN-analyzer

Navitrol SDO write

Another option to change the SDO-configurations is to write the SDO-configurations with sdo_write.txt file. Add first a parameter:

NameTypeRequired valueDescription
can_sdo_write_from_fileInt10 - no SDO writes from file, 1 - write content from sdo_write.txt

Then add sdo_write.txt file to /home/navitec folder with the SDO configuration content. Example below:

# This sdo_write.txt configuration file overrides RPM dimension scale
# Node 5 - 8
# WRITE,Node-ID,dataType,index.subIndex,value

WRITE,5,I32,0x604C.2,0x0001 # RPM scale 604Ch Subindex 2h: stock firmware value 3Ch, latest firmware value 01h

WRITE,6,I32,0x604C.2,0x0001 # RPM scale 604Ch Subindex 2h: stock firmware value 3Ch, latest firmware value 01h

WRITE,7,I32,0x604C.2,0x0001 # RPM scale 604Ch Subindex 2h: stock firmware value 3Ch, latest firmware value 01h

WRITE,8,I32,0x604C.2,0x0001 # RPM scale 604Ch Subindex 2h: stock firmware value 3Ch, latest firmware value 01h

Troubleshooting

Nanotec SDO errors

Nanotec SDO errors might occur if something was done incorrectly during the commissioning. The list of SDO errors can be found from Nanotec PD4-C Technical manual, page 102.

Nanotec SDO errors

CAN-bus errors

If CAN-bus is not working correctly, make sure that following things are checked:

  • CAN-bus has 120ohm resistors activated on the both end of the bus. The total CAN-bus impedance has to be approximately 60 ohms.

  • Check that all motor controllers and other CAN-devices in the bus have same baud rate

  • Make sure that all CAN-devices on the bus have individual Node-ID

  • Double-check Navitrol parameters in this document

  • Make sure that you have also done CAN-bus grounding

    • If CAN-bus GND is not grounded, there might occur error frames in the CAN-bus

    • Higher baud rates require CAN-bus grounding because they require more accurate voltage levels

  • More information about CAN-bus related errors can be found from Navitrol CANOpen Communication Troubleshooting

References

Nanotec PD4-CB59 Controller

PEAK PCAN-USB Adapter

Nanotec Plug & Drive Studio 2

Oriental CAN Motor Controller

Updated 26.06.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
SDOService Data Object
PDOProcess Data Object
BLTS-01Software for BLV-R Series motor controllers
MXE-02Upgraded software for BLV-R Series motor controllers

Introduction

Oriental motor controller is one of the motor controllers supported by Navitrol. Oriental offers single channel motor controllers that can be used for different purposes (steering, driving, actuator) in the AGV.

In this documentation, instructions are provided for configuring the motor controllers so that motor controllers would work with Navitrol. Operation of the device is possible via CANopen fieldbus.

Following motor controllers has been tested by Navitec Systems:

  • BLV-R Series. It contains of two parts: driver (controls the operation of the motor) and BLDC motor with encoder.
  • Driver has 1 DC motor connection (can be used for driving/steering).
  • Only Oriental motors are compatible with the driver.

The initial parameterization/configuration of the device takes place with the support software. Initially, configuration was done by BLTS-01 software. However, currently it is recommended to use updated software - MXE-02.

Currently, Oriental motor controllers can be supported for several kinematics:

  • Diff drive

  • Steer drive

  • Steer drive with a differential sub unit

  • Omni drive

  • Omni drive with a differential sub unit

  • Mecanum drive

Electrical connections

Electrical connections can be divided into four groups:

  1. Connecting main power supply Main power supply should be wired to the connector CN1. Special cable connector should be used.

  2. Connecting motor Motor should be wired to the connector CN2.

  3. Connecting encoder/brakes Brakes and encoder should be connected to the connector CN3.

  4. Connecting the I/O signals (CN4) Wires should be connected to the push terminals. The following pins are needed:

    a. CAN connection -- Pin 5 (CAN_L), Pin 6 (CAN_H) and Pin 7(CAN_GND)

    b. Power supply for communication interface -- PIN 20 (NET-VIN) and Pin 21 (NET-GND)

Figure 1. Electrical diagram

Commissioning steps

The following steps should be done in process of commissioning:

  1. Connection to support software to set up CAN communication
  2. Changing Navitrol parameters

Note: Motor controller tuning (PID tuning) is not needed with the motor controller. If needed, motor controller speed and sensitivity can be selected from some of pre-defined values in the software.

Connection to the software to set up CAN communication

Connection to the support software is done using the micro USB cable. Connect micro USB cable as it shown in the Figure 1.

It is recommended to use updated support software - MXE-02. However, for some cases, old support software BLTS-01 can be used.

Setting up CAN communication using MXE-02

Start the software. Note that it is recommended to use the software starting from version 4 in order to avoid incompatibility with older software versions of the driver.

Figure 2. Main interface of the MXE-02 software

Once window opened, click on "Select a product". The following panel should be opened in the left side of the screen.

Press "Detect communication port" (marked as step 1 on the figure) to refresh the list of devices. Once list is refreshed, select one of the options marked as step 2 on the figure.

Figure 3. Connection to the driver in MXE-02

Once connected, press "Start the simple settings". Software should establish connection to the motor controller.

After that, select desired NodeId and Baud Rate of the motor controller. NodeId and Baud Rate should match Navitrol parameters and NodeId of each device should be unique on the bus. Save those values to the motor controller by pressing "Reflecting on the driver".

Figure 4. Configuration in MXE-02

Now, motor controller is ready for communication with Navitrol.

Setting up CAN communication using BLTS-01

Start the software.

Figure 5. Main interface of the BLTS-01 software

Once window opened, click on "Setting of communication". Select ORIENTAL MOTOR COM port.

Figure 6. Connection to the driver in BLTS-01 software

Press "Ok" and window should be closed.

Next, press "Data Reading (Product -> PC)". The following window should be opened:

Figure 7. Configuration in BLTS-01 software.

Press "Start the simple settings". Software should establish connection to the motor controller.

After that, select desired NodeId and Baud Rate of the motor controller. NodeId and Baud Rate should match Navitrol parameters and NodeId of each device should be unique on the bus. Save those values to the motor controller by pressing "Reflecting on the driver".

Now, motor controller is ready for communication with Navitrol.

Changing Navitrol parameters

  • First, set Node ID to the corresponding parameter according to Table "CAN Node Id parameters for motor controllers" in Motor controllers common document.

  • Set the communication parameters (can_ch and can_bitrate_k) according to CAN communication document. In addition, set can_sync parameter to value 1.

  • In order to enable heartbeat, set parameter can_heartbeat_producer_enable to 1 and navigation_software_node_id to any nodeId between [1..127] which is not used by other devices in the bus.

  • It is highly recommended to enable heartbeat for safety reasons.

  • Other motor controller settings are done using SDOs by Navitrol.

Troubleshooting

CAN-bus errors

  • Information about CAN-bus related errors and troubleshooting can be found from Can Communication document

Motor controller issues

If motor controller indicates some errors and this error is not reset by Navitrol:

  • Try to establish serial connection to check errors directly from the motor controller. To check errors, connect with BLTS-01 or MXE-02 software. Connect it the same way as when configuring (according to the instruction above). Press "Start the simple settings". In the left bottom menu choose "Alarm monitor".

  • Check Navitrol parameter I,mot_ctrl_reset_errors_timer. It should be positive in order for Navitrol to reset the error.

  • Some errors cannot be reset from the CAN bus by Navitrol (for instance, overvoltage or encoder disconnection). In such a case, a power cycle is required for the motor controller.

Synapticon EtherCAT Motor Controller

Updated 22.05.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
SDOService Data Object
PDOProcess Data Object
OBLAC DrivesSoftware for commissioning Synapticon motor controllers
STOSafe Torque Off
SBOSafe Brake Output

Introduction

Synapticon motor controller is one of the motor controllers supported by Navitrol. Synapticon offers single channel motor controllers that can be used for different purposes (steering, driving, actuator) in the AGV.

In this documentation, instructions are provided for configuring the motor controllers so that motor controllers are compatible with Navitrol. Operation of the device is possible via EtherCAT fieldbus.

Following motor controllers has been tested by Navitec Systems:

  • SOMANET Node. This motor controller is single-channel and allows connecting BLDC motor with encoder and brakes.

The initial parameterisation/configuration of the device takes place with the software OBLAC Drives.

Currently, Synapticon motor controllers can be supported for several kinematics:

  • Diff drive (both left and right wheel)

  • Mecanum drive

Ethercat absolute encoder support is required for other kinematic models.

Electrical connections

Electrical connections should be done according to the Somanet Node wiring instructions. Connections can be divided into several groups:

Figure 1. Connectors overview

  1. Connecting main power supply Main power supply should be wired to the power terminal to pin 5 and pin 6.

    Figure 2. Power terminals

    TerminalDescription
    1Phase A
    2Phase B
    3Phase C
    4Phase D - brake 0-48 PWM
    5Ground
    6Main Power Supply 12-48 VDC
    7Optional Logic Ground
    8Optional Logic Supply 12-24 V

  2. Connecting motor BLDC motor should be connected to the power connector to pins 1,2,3.

  3. Connecting encoder Encoder should be connected to one of the Encoder ports (either port 1 or port 2) depending on the encoder type. Pinout for different encoder ports can be found using the Encoder and IO wiring instructions

    Figure 3. Encoder Port 2 connection

    PinHALLABI (differential)ABI (single-ended)BISSSSI
    1***MA-Clock-
    25V5V5V5V5V
    3GNDGNDGNDGNDGND
    4***MA+Clock+
    5C/H3A-ASLO-Data-
    6*A+*SLO+Data+
    7B/H2B-B**
    8*B+***
    9A/H1I-I**
    10*I+***

  4. Connecting brakes If Node controller is used, brakes should be connected between Phase D and Ground in Power Terminal. If Node Safety controller is used, brakes should be connected to SBC out.

    Figure 4. Brake connection (safety)

    TerminalDescription
    1Brake +
    2Brake -

  5. Connecting safety In case if Node Safety is used, setup of the safety features (STO, SBC) of the motor controller must be carried out by customer in order to use the motor controller according to the Setup of the safety functions instruction.

    At least, bypass pins should be connected together in order to run the motor controller from Navitrol.

    NOTE: Navitec is not liable for AGV safety

  6. Connecting EtherCAT bus EtherCAT in and EtherCAT out pins should be connected to the EtherCAT bus.

Commissioning steps

The following steps should be done in process of commissioning:

  1. Installation of OBLAC Drives
  2. Setting up the controller in the OBLAC Drives
  3. Installation of firmware
  4. PID tuning of the motor controller
  5. Changing Navitrol parameters

During the commissioning in OBLAC Drives, it is recommended to use the manufacturer's instruction

Commissioning should be done when AGV is off the ground.

Installation OBLAC Drives

There are two ways to run SOMANET OBLAC Drives:

  • OBLAC Drives - physical machine that comes preinstalled with Linux OS and runs OBLAC Drives

  • OBLAC Drives Virtual Machine that comes preinstalled with OBLAC Drives. It can be run on Windows, Linux and macOS.

Downloading and setting up OBLAC Drives Virtual Machine can be done using the link

Installation of firmware

  • Open Virtual Machine and wait until it is launched.

  • Type in browser the IP address shown in the virtual machine.

  • OBLAC Drives will scan the connected devices and find drives. If the drive does not have a firmware (it will be shown after connection) or firmware version is less than 5.0, new firmware needs to be installed. If new firmware is installed, this step can be skipped.

    Figure 5. Connecting the drive without firmware

    Figure 6. Connecting the drive without firmware

    • In Order to update the firmware, press on the "Configuration" icon. It will bring you to Configuration page. Select from menu "Install Firmware" option.

    Figure 7. Configuration - install firmware

    • Select from menu firmware to install (higher than 5.0) and press "Start Installation"

    Figure 8. Firmware installation

Setting up the controller

Process of setting up the motor controller is explained in details in the instruction

  • Open configuration page for the controller. Select "Launch setup wizard"

    Figure 9. Configuration - launch setup wizard

  • It will first ask you to give a name to your drive.

    Figure 10. Product name

  • Configure brakes. Enter pull voltage, hold voltage, pull time and disable delay. Note that if brakes are used, clutch-style brake control should be used since Navitrol is not commanding the output voltage. Test brakes so that they can be released.

    If there are issues with releasing brakes, check if "Safe State" active on the top of the page. If "Safe state" is active, check if safety system is powered or bypass is connected. Brakes cannot be released until safety system is powered (or safety bypass is connected).

    Figure 9. Brake set up

  • Enter the details of the motor. Pay attention to the engineering units since motor data can be scaled differently.

    Figure 11. Motor set up

  • Set up the encoder. First, choose the port where it is attached. After that, enter the parameters of the encoder. Rotate the shaft and check that it corresponds to the position of the shaft.

    Figure 12. Encoder port

    Figure 13. Encoder set up

  • Launch offset detection. It should start and finish automatically.

    Figure 14. Offset detection

PID tuning

Process of tuning the motor controller is explained in details in the configuration software.

  • Go to "Tuning" page and run system identification:

    Figure 15. System identification

  • Then go to velocity tuning.

    According to the manufacturer, it is recommended to:

    • Set all constants kp, ki and kd are set to 0.

    • Set the reference velocity to 50% of rated motor velocity [rpm].

    • Increase kP until the measured speed is around 70% of the reference speed. As a suggestion start with kp equal to 0.1, and in each step increase kp with a factor of 2

    • Increase ki incrementally to increase the speed of velocity controller (as a suggestion start with ki equal to 0.01 and in each step increase it by a factor of 2).

    • Fine tune the controller

    • The parameter kd of the velocity controller can be kept at its default value (0).

    Figure 16. System identification

Changing Navitrol parameters

  • First, set slave address to the corresponding parameter according to Table "EtherCAT address parameters for motor controllers" in Motor controllers common document. Slave addresses are given by master in direction of physical position of the devices in the bus. E.g. first device connected to master would have slave address 1 and the one connected after it would have address 2 and so on. Note that slave addresses of devices on the bus must be unique.

  • Set the communication parameters (ethercat_enabled, bus type ethercat_mode and interface ethercat_inte_primary, ethercat_inte_secondary) according to EtherCAT communication document

NOTE: Navitrol configures automatically communication related parameters in motor controller. Other motor controller settings are not set nor changed by Navitrol.

Troubleshooting

EtherCAT bus errors

  • Information about EtherCAT related errors and troubleshooting can be found from Troubleshooting section of Ethercat communication document

Motor controller issues

If motor controller indicates some errors and this error is not reset by Navitrol:

  • Try to establish connection with OBLAC Drives to check errors directly from the motor controller. Check if "Safe State" active on the controller. If "Safe state" is active, check the safety system.

  • Check Navitrol parameter I,mot_ctrl_reset_errors_timer. It should be positive in order for Navitrol to reset the error.

Roboteq Open Loop Motor Controller Configuration

Updated 22.05.2024

Introduction

Roboteq motor controllers are one of many motor controllers that Navitrol supports in AGVs. Roboteq offers different range of motor controllers that can be used for different uses via different interfaces. In this documentation, instructions are provided for configuring the motor controllers to be interfaced with Navitrol.

If a Roboteq motor controller is dual channel, then it can be used to control 2 motors. So, it means 1 Roboteq controller is needed for 1 steering + 1 driving motor or for 2 driving motors. For example, if there is an Omni AGV with 6 wheels, it would need 6 Roboteq controllers that can handle steering + driving of each of the 6 wheels.

It should be noted, that this document covers only open loop control mode with Roboteq controllers.

Setup

The Roboteq offers extensive support and documentation for getting started. All the Roboteq products have specific PC utility software that provides an interface to the user for configuring the Roboteq products.

All product specific datasheets, documentation and software can be downloaded from the Roboteq website. www.roboteq.com

In this document no specific version of motor controller is mentioned since the process for interfacing with Navitrol is same for all the motor controllers.

  • To configure the Roboteq motor controllers, Roborun, a Roboteq motor control utility software needs to be installed on Windows PC.

  • It is assumed that the user has completed all the necessary physical wiring of motor controllers to the driving or steering encoders of the AGV.

  • Use the USB cable to connect the computer with the Roboteq motor controller and start the Roborun utility software.

  • Start the 'Roborun+' app and it should appear as below:

Upload/Save Profile

A profile is basically a file that contains the values to different options and parameters in the configuration window. Make sure that the controller is connected, this can be verified by seeing the 'Connected' in the bottom right corner of the window and a green indicator.

There are different tabs in Roboteq motor control utility.

  1. The Configuration tab defines the settings for Inputs and outputs.

  2. The Run tab allows different options for debugging and testing the motor controllers.

  3. The Console tab allows outputs to be displayed while testing the motor controllers or running the scripts.

  4. The Scripting tab allows scripts to be uploaded to motor controller, write, or edit them, as well as simulate the script.

  5. The Load from Controller loads the profile if it already existing on the controller and then shows the values in Inputs/Outputs window.

  6. If no such profile exists by default on the controller, then user can upload their own profile by using Load Profile from Disk. The profile files can either have an extension of *.cpr or *.xml.

  7. The option 7 allows the script to be Run, Paused or Restarted. When a script is running then a user can test the motor controllers.

Input/Outputs Configuration

In Inputs/Outputs not all the parameters need to be configured. The user should decide based on their choice of motor controllers what parameters they need to configure. Navitrol needs only few of the parameters to be configured and they are explained below:

  1. Startup- If needed user can define a script that should work whenever the motor controller is started.

  2. Commands- In Commands section user need to set up the 'Watchdog' parameter. The watchdog is used for safety and will set the warning or errors after a certain time limit until they are resolved. The first command priority can be set to Serial and a second command priority can be set to Pulses; in case the first priority stops working.

  3. Spektrum RC: Navitrol does not use RC so this does not need to be configured.

  4. CAN- This needs to be configured if the Roboteq motor controllers are connected using CAN bus and the values for the motor controller parameters should match the Navitrol parameters. For example, Bit rate should be same in both motor controller and Navitrol to allow communication to be carried out via CAN bus. Listen Node ID in the options refers to the Navitrol. CAN mode and communication interval must be defined, and this can be selected from the options such as CAN mode and MiniCAN Send Rate (ms). Roboteq motor controller uses MiniCAN.

a) CAN Mode: MiniCAN should be selected as the option

b) Bit rate: CAN bitrate and should match with can_bitrate_k parameter.

c) Node ID: the Node ID of the Roboteq controller and should match with can_roboteq_nodeid

d) Listen Node ID: should be same as the define in parameter, can_roboteq_listen_nodeid

e) Heartbeat (ms): doesn't matter.

f) MiniCAN Send Rate (ms): 10 Send rate is the interval between each TPDO. So if there are 4 PDO's having and control interval of 40 ms then it should be set to 10ms (40/4).

g) TPDO 1 Send Rate (ms): 10CAN Open

h) TPDO 2 Send Rate (ms): 20

i) TPDO 3 Send Rate (ms): 30

j) TPDO 4 Send Rate (ms): 40

k) TPDO 1 Transmission Type: 255 Transmission Type is CANOpen stuff

l) TPDO 2 Transmission Type: 255

m) TPDO 3 Transmission Type: 255

n) TPDO 4 Transmission Type: 255

o) CANOpen Autostart: Disabled Not relevant to MiniCAN

  1. Encoder- This option also needs to be configured for the encoders of the motor controllers. User can select between Command or Feedback option.

  2. Digital Inputs: Navitrol does not use any digital inputs but this can be set based on the use case the customer is using or if a customer has a requested a certain feature that requires this to be configured.

  3. Analog Inputs- Navitrol does not use any analog inputs.

  4. Pulse Inputs- Navitrol does not use any pulse inputs.

  5. Digital Outputs- The digital output should be set as high when Motor is on.

  6. User-Defined Values- Navitrol does not require any values to be defined but user can set them if needed.

Power Output Configuration

The power output is to be configured by the user based on the choice of motor controllers. Since the value will vary depending on different models of the motors and motor controllers, the responsibility lies on the user to get all the instructions from Roboteq for configuring the Power output parameters.

Once the Input/Outputs and Power Output parameters are configured they should be saved to the Controller.

Scripting

The scripts are only required when the Roboteq motor controllers are connected via the CAN bus. These scripts are provided by Navitec to the customers and there are different scripts available for different kinematics such as:

  • Differential drive kinematic has its own script that reads information related to driving of the wheels.

  • Omni and Steer driven have their own script that reads the driving and steering of the wheels.

The user does not need any scripts if the motor controllers are connected via Serial connection.

Uploading Script

To upload the script to the motor controller, click on the 'Scripting' tab on the Motor control utility. Then click on the 'Open' option and select a file from the location where it is saved. The script files are micro basic format and have an extension of 'xx.mbs'. Once uploaded script may look like shown in the picture below:

Saving & Upload Script Files

To save a script file click on the icon that says 'Save As' and select a location where you want to save it. The file will be saved as a 'xx.mbs' file.

Once the file is opened in the motor control utility then it should be uploaded to the motor controller. This can be done via pressing the 'To Device' option.

Testing

Once the parameters are configured correctly or profile is loaded, they should be saved to the Controller. Afterwards if needed then script should be uploaded to the Controller as well. Then click the Run tab for testing the motor and motor controllers as seen in the picture below:

Based on the picture it can be seen that the motor controller is connected via Serial connection (Not CAN) as red indicator is visible on the top left corner before the 'Serial' and under 'Status'.

The 'RunScript' option also has a red light on that means that the script is running.

Also, under 'Digital Input' the digital input 1 is lit red that translate to motor controller having a single input. The Digital outputs shows a green light that translates to motor controller giving outputs.

Press the Pause button for the script and a Red light should turn off next to 'RunScript' option as shown below:

Use the scroll bars highlighted in the picture above to move the wheel by sending target rpm. Make sure ONLY one scroll bar is moved at a single time.

When sending the rpm the wheel should start rotating. This verifies that the connections and parameters are set correctly for the motors and Roboteq motor controllers.

Under 'Channel' on bottom right corner different values can be selected from a drop-down list and they will become visible and change as wheels rotate.

Also test that the encoder value and rpm are being read from the motor controller. This can be checked by selecting the Counter 1 or 2 option and Speed 1 and 2 RPM from the drop-down list. This again depends on the parameters set in the Configuration tab.

Navitrol Parameters

There are different parameters related to Roboteq and they should be configured depending on what kinematic AGV is being used. The general parameters can be configured if needed.

General Parameters

  • I, mot_ctrl_max_out, 1000 # maximum output

Parameters for serial connected Roboteq

  • I, roboteq_check_echo, 1 # "0 do not check command echo, 1 check but don't give error if echo doesn't match, 2 give error if echo doesn't match"

  • S, roboteq_lift_serial_port, /dev/ttyS0 # Serial port for Roboteq lift controller

  • I, roboteq_brake_output1, -1 #digital out number for first brake, -1 if disabled

  • I, roboteq_brake_output2, -1, #digital out number for second brake, -1 if disabled

  • I, roboteq_motor_controller_type, 0, #Roboteq motor controller type: 0 for brushless, 1 for brushed

  • S, mot_ctrl_serial_port, /dev/ttyS2 # Serial port for first Roboteq controller (steer/diff)

  • S, mot_ctrl_serial_port2, /dev/ttyS2 # Serial port for second Roboteq controller (mecanum)

  • I, roboteq_channel1_right*,* 1 #Set this parameter to 1 if channel 1 of Roboteq motor controller is connected to right wheel, otherwise set it to 0.

  • I, roboteq_channel1_steer*,* 1 # Set this parameter to 1 if channel 1 of Roboteq motor controller is connected to steering of the wheel, otherwise set it to 0.

  • I, mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq1_channel1_wheel, 0 #0 = FL, 1 = FR, 2 = RL, 3 = RR

  • I, mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq1_channel2_wheel, 0 #0 = FL, 1 = FR, 2 = RL, 3 = RR

  • I, mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq2_channel1_wheel, 0 #0 = FL, 1 = FR, 2 = RL, 3 = RR

  • I, mot_ctrl_mecanum_roboteq2_channel2_wheel, 0 #0 = FL, 1 = FR, 2 = RL, 3 = RR

CAN Parameters

  • I, can_roboteq_listen_nodeid, -1 # Roboteq controller CAN listen node id

  • I, can_roboteq_comms_mode, 0 # 0 - miniCAN, 1 - CANOpen; common setting for all Roboteq controllers. For now, it has to be miniCAN and same should be selected on Roboteq side configuration.

  • I, can_roboteq_nodeid, -1 # Roboteq controller CAN transmit node id

  • I, roboteq_channel1_right*,* 1 #Set this parameter to 1 if channel 1 of Roboteq motor controller is connected to right wheel, otherwise set it to 0.

Roboteq Closed Loop Motor Controller Configuration

Updated 30.07.2024

Introduction

Roboteq motor controllers are one of many motor controllers that Navitrol supports in AGVs. Roboteq offers different range of motor controllers that can be used for different uses via different interfaces. In this documentation, instructions are provided for configuring CANOpen closed loop motor controllers to be interfaced with Navitrol.

If a Roboteq motor controller is dual channel, then it can be used to control 2 motors. So, it means 1 Roboteq controller is needed for 1 steering + 1 driving motor or for 2 driving motors. For example, if there is an Omni AGV with 6 wheels, it would need 6 Roboteq controllers that can handle steering + driving of each of the 6 wheels.

It should be noted, that this document covers only closed loop control mode with Roboteq controllers.

Setup

The Roboteq offers extensive support and documentation for getting started. All the Roboteq products have specific PC utility software that provides an interface to the user for configuring the Roboteq products.

All product specific datasheets, documentation and software can be downloaded from the Roboteq website. www.roboteq.com

In this document no specific version of motor controller is mentioned since the process for interfacing with Navitrol is same for all the motor controllers.

  • To configure the Roboteq motor controllers, Roborun, a Roboteq motor control utility software needs to be installed on Windows PC.

  • It is assumed that the user has completed all the necessary physical wiring of motor controllers to the driving or steering encoders of the AGV.

  • Use the USB cable to connect the computer with the Roboteq motor controller and start the Roborun utility software.

  • Start the 'Roborun+' app and it should appear as shown below.

Upload/Save Profile

A profile is basically a file that contains the values to different options and parameters in the configuration window. Make sure that the controller is connected, this can be verified by seeing the 'Connected' in the bottom right corner of the window and a green indicator.

RoboRun overview.

There are different tabs in Roboteq motor control utility.

  1. The Configuration tab defines the settings for Inputs and outputs.

  2. The Run tab allows different options for debugging and testing the motor controllers.

  3. The Load from Controller loads the profile if it already existing on the controller and then shows the values in Inputs/Outputs window.

  4. If no such profile exists by default on the controller, then user can upload their own profile by using Load Profile from Disk. The profile files can either have an extension of *.cpr or *.xml.

Input/Outputs Configuration

In Inputs/Outputs not all the parameters need to be configured. The user should decide based on their choice of motor controllers what parameters they need to configure. Navitrol needs only few of the parameters to be configured and they are explained below:

  1. Startup- Script Auto-Start should be set to Disabled as script is not used.

  2. Commands- In Commands section user need to set up the 'Watchdog' parameter. The watchdog is used for safety and will set the warning or errors after a certain time limit until they are resolved. The first command priority can be set to Serial and a second command priority can be set to Pulses; in case the first priority stops working.

  3. Spektrum RC: Navitrol does not use RC so this does not need to be configured.

  4. CAN- This needs to be configured as Roboteq motor controllers are connected using CAN bus and the values for the motor controller parameters should match the Navitrol parameters. For example, Bit rate should be same in both motor controller and Navitrol to allow communication to be carried out via CAN bus.

    a) CAN Mode: CANOpen should be selected as the option

    b) Bit Rate: CAN bitrate and should match with can_bitrate_k parameter.

    c) Node ID: the Node ID of the Roboteq controller and should match with mot_ctrl_drive_can_nodeid_arr

    d) Listen Node ID: should be same as above.

    e) Heartbeat (ms): doesn't matter.

    f) CHB Lost Action: Should be either Safety Stop or Emergency Stop.

    g) MiniCAN Send Rate (ms): Not used with CANOpen.

    h) CANOpen TPDO Send Rate: Not needed. Navitrol will set these automatically.

    i) CANOpen Transmission Type: Not needed. Navitrol will set these automatically.

    j) CANOpen Autostart: Should be set to enabled.

    k) DS402 FSA: Should be set to enabled.

  5. Encoder- This option also needs to be configured for the encoders of the motor controllers. Should be set to Feedback. If the controller has two channels, the channels should be selected accordingly.

    Dual channel encoder setup.

  6. Digital Inputs: Navitrol does not use any digital inputs but this can be set based on the use case the customer is using or if a customer has a requested a certain feature that requires this to be configured.

  7. Analog Inputs: Navitrol does not use any analog inputs.

  8. Pulse Inputs: Navitrol does not use any pulse inputs.

  9. Digital Outputs: The digital output should be set as high when Motor is on.

  10. User-Defined Values: Navitrol does not require any values to be defined but user can set them if needed.

Power Output Configuration

The power output is to be configured by the user based on the choice of motor controllers. Since the value will vary depending on different models of the motors and motor controllers, the responsibility lies on the user to get all the instructions from Roboteq for configuring the Power output parameters.

At least the PID gains should be tuned and saved to the controller as Navitrol doesn't do it.

PID settings for Closed loop Speed.

Once the Input/Outputs and Power Output parameters are configured they should be saved to the Controller.

Testing

Note: For testing, set the DS402 FSA to Disabled, otherwise the controller assumes specific states to be set before it can run. Remember to set Enabled after testing.

DS402 FSA setting.

It is recommended to first test to spin the motor in open loop mode and then move to closed loop mode after it has been verified that the motor works with open loop.

Once the parameters are configured correctly or profile is loaded, they should be saved to the Controller. Then click the Run tab for testing the motor and motor controllers as seen in the picture below:

Run tab main view.

Based on the picture it can be seen that the motor controller is connected via Serial connection (Not CAN) as red indicator is visible on the top left corner before the 'Serial' and under 'Status'.

The 'RunScript' option should not have red light as the script should not be used.

RoboRun sending RPM to the controller.

Use the scroll bar highlighted in the picture above to move the motor by sending target rpm to the controller. Make sure ONLY one scroll bar is moved at a single time. The second scroll bar can be used to send commands to the second channel if that is in use.
