When sending the rpm the motor should start rotating. This verifies that the connections and parameters are set correctly for the motors and Roboteq motor controllers.

The arrow icon on top of the CHART window is used to start recording the live data. The same button can be also used to stop the recording for analyzing the data.

Under 'Channel' on bottom right corner different values can be selected from a drop-down list and they will become visible and change as motor rotate.

Also test that the encoder value and rpm are being read from the motor controller. This can be checked by selecting the Counter 1 or Counter 2 option and Speed 1 RPM and Speed 2 RPM or Feedback 1 and Feedback 2 from the drop-down list. This again depends on the parameters set in the Configuration tab.

Object Dictionary (OD) parameters

Navitrol configures a subset of motor controller's OD-parameters when Navitrol starts. These configurations are sent as SDO-messages to the motor controllers. The OD-parameters that Navitrol configures can be seen on the table below. The parameters for automatic SDO-configurations (for example, SDO message interval and SDO message response timeout) are presented on the CAN communication document.

OD parameter table

NameObject indexSubindexData typeValue in hexDescription
Estop and fault clearance200Dh0Unsigned80Clears estop and faults.
Consumer heartbeat time1016h1Unsigned32Based on parametersHeartbeat time is configured if enabled by parameter can_heartbeat_producer_enable.
First two bytes are heartbeat time based on 3.5 * control_interval_us parameter and byte 3 is Navitrol's node id from navigation_software_node_id parameter.

Note: Navitrol does not configure the PID values of the controller. It should be done using Roborun.

Navitrol Parameters

There are different parameters related to Roboteq and they should be configured depending on what kinematic AGV is being used.

Required parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
The indices of the following array parameters are:
Differential drive:
0 = Left wheel
1 = Right wheel
Mecanum:
0 = Forward Left
1 = Forward Right
2 = Rear Left
3 = Rear Right
Drive Motor controllers
mot_ctrl_drive_controller_type_arr[]Int05 = Roboteq single channel
6 = Roboteq dual channel 1
7 = Roboteq dual channel 2
mot_ctrl_drive_can_nodeid_arr[]Int0Motor controller CAN node id for drive motor. 0 = this parameter not used.
mot_ctrl_drive_inv_input_arr[]Int0Invert drive motor controller input. 0 = no inversion, 1 = invert input
mot_ctrl_drive_inv_output_arr[]Int0Invert drive motor controller output. 0 = no inversion, 1 = invert output
Other required parameters
can_heartbeat_producer_enableInt0Enables Navigation software to be Heartbeat producer for primary CAN.
navigation_software_node_idInt0Navigation Software CAN Node ID: 0 = not defined, 1-127 = valid node ID.

Optional parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
mot_ctrl_reset_errors_timerInt500After the defined time (ms) Navitrol tries to automatically reset motor control faults. Value 0 = fault reset disabled. When error is active on controller, Navitrol will start sending fault reset on the control word with this interval until the errors are reset.

Troubleshooting

Motor does not spin when trying to give RPM using RoboRun

  • Check that the DS402 FSA is set to Disabled.

DS402 FSA setting.

MiControl CAN motor controller

Updated 26.01.2024

Overview

Introduction

MiControl motor controller is one of the motor controllers supported by Navitrol. MiControl offers single channel motor controllers that can be used for different purposes (steering, driving, actuator) in the AGV.

In this documentation, instructions are provided for configuring the motor controllers so that motor controllers are compatible with Navitrol.

Operation of the device is possible via CANopen fieldbus.

The initial parameterization/configuration of the device takes place with the software mcTools.

Requirements

Hardware:

  • Supported motor controller (List of supported devices document should be checked)
  • Connectors for wiring. Without the connectors, it is impossible to wire the motor controller. Types and number of connectors can be found from the mcmanual https://www.micontrol.de/en/download/documentations/mcmanual.
  • Adapter for connecting the motor controller to PC - miCAN-Stick2 https://www.micontrol.de/en/products/devices/mican-stick2](#https://www.micontrol.de/en/products/devices/mican-stick2) .

Software

  • The feature is supported by Navitrol starting from version 6.44.00.
  • Parameterization/configuration software - mcTools. Can be downloaded from the manufacturer's website: https://www.micontrol.de/en/download/software. Note that it is needed to register on a website in order to download software or device manuals.

Documentation

  • The documentation can be downloaded from the manufacturer's website: https://www.micontrol.de/en/download/documentations/mcmanual.

Limitations

  • Motor controller might be not supporting all functions (steering, driving, actuating) and kinematics. List of supported devices document should be checked to determine whether the combination of the function and kinematics is supported or not.
  • Currently, it is impossible to use MiControl motor controller with other motor controllers in the same AGV
  • MiControl motor controller support is available to position control systems only

Dependencies

This feature is dependent on CAN interface. Therefore, it is recommended to check CAN communication document.

Electrical connections

Electrical connections should be done according to the Drive Controller section in mcmanual. Connections can be divided into several groups:

  1. Power connection. Connect power to both main power supply and electronic power supply.
  2. Motor connection. Connect the motor to the motor terminals of the motor controller.
  3. Encoder connection. Connect the encoder to the encoder port.
  4. Safety connection. If the device has STO function, wire the STO-A and STO-B pins to the safety controller. Those pins should be powered whenever it is safe to drive the motor. Check Safety Manual section in the documentation for a specific controller for checking safety procedures and commissioning of the safety feature.
  5. CAN bus connection. Connect CAN wires to the CAN terminal of the motor controller. Additionally, connect the miCAN-stick2 to the CAN bus for commissioning. Wiring of the CAN bus should be done according to CAN communication document.

Setup

The following steps should be done in process of commissioning:

  • Changing the motor controller parameters
  • Changing Navitrol parameters

Changing the motor controller parameters

In order to change the motor controller parameters, connect the miCAN-Stick2 to the PC with mcToolssoftware installed. Additionally, it is recommended to read mcTools section from the mcmanual.

In order to change parameters, open mcTools. Select "Scan baudrate" and press "Scan device". The connected devices should appear to the list as shown on the Figure bellow.

> Device scanning

Changing communication parameters

Once the device is connected, it is recommended to change the node id of the device. In the Tools panel, select "CAN config". In the opened window, type the Node id and baud rate. Node Id and Baud Rate should match Navitrol parameters in the subsequent commissioning steps. Node Id of each device should be unique on the bus. Baud rate should be the same for all of the devices on the bus, recommended value is 250 kBit. Save entered values to the motor controller by pressing "Set".

> Changing node id

Changing motor parameters, Tuning PID controller

Those steps should be performed in accordance to the Documentation. Navitec Systems do not have successful experience in tuning motor controller. In case of issues, MiControl/supplier support should be contacted.

Note: It is possible to save the configuration of the device by opening DSA config and selecting from File menu in the left top corner the option "Save as". After saving, those parameters can be loaded from the same File menu to another motor controller.

Changing Navitrol parameters

  • Prior to communication, set the parameters (can_ch and can_bitrate_k) according to CAN communication document.
  • Since the device is supporting heartbeat, it is highly recommended to set parameter can_heartbeat_producer_enable to 1 and navigation_software_node_id to any node Id from 1 to 127 which is not used by other devices in the bus
  • Set Node ID to the corresponding parameter according to Table "CAN Node Id parameters for motor controllers" in Motor controllers common document.

Fine-tuning

  • If needed, the warning for E-STOP can be disabled from the motor controller using the mot_ctrl_micontrol_estop_check_enabled parameter
  • Automatic error reset can be disabled using mot_ctrl_reset_errors_timer.

Optional parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
mot_ctrl_micontrol_estop_check_enabledInt1Activates MiControl E-STOP check.
Emergency stop activation comes from digital input 6 and 7 (STO-A and STO-B)
mot_ctrl_reset_errors_timerInt500After the defined time (ms) Navigation SW tries automatically reset motor control faults. Value 0 = fault reset disabled

How to use

After successful setup, the motor should be rotating after giving the commands from Navitrol.

Troubleshooting

Most common issues

Errors and warnings

CAN errors

The information about CAN-bus related errors and troubleshooting can be found from CAN communication document

Motor controller errors (ERROR_AGV_CONTROLLER)

If motor controller indicates some error, Navitrol will automatically try to reset this error (unless mot_ctrl_reset_errors_timer set to zero).

If error is not reset by Navitrol:

  • Check the motor controller error code and description from Linux terminal. Try to resolve it. Power cycle the controller.
  • Try to connect using mcTools software to the motor controller. Connect it the same way as when configuring (according to the "Changing the motor controller parameters" section). Open "DSA Status" and check the motor controller parameters.
  • Contact Navitec or Motor controller support.

Advanced troubleshooting

For checking the logs, the keywords "MiControl" and "MotorController" can be used to find the information related to the motor controller operation.

Laser scanners

Updated 26.01.2024

  • Scanner configurations
  • Scanner communication troubleshooting

Scanner Configurations

Updated 24.04.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
UDPUser Datagram Protocol
TCPTransmission Control Protocol

Universal scanner parameters

Scanner mounting location and angle

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
scan_rear_xFloat0.99The rear scanner's X coordinate w.r.t. navigation point of vehicle
scan_rear_yFloat0.0The rear scanner's Y coordinate w.r.t. navigation point of vehicle
scan_front_xFloat-0.09The front scanner's X coordinate w.r.t. navigation point of vehicle
scan_front_yFloat0.0The front scanner's Y coordinate w.r.t. navigation point of vehicle
scan_rear_sen_angFloat90.0The rear scanner's angle difference between the vehicles and the scanners coordinate systems (degrees)
scan_front_sen_angFloat90.0The front scanner's angle difference between the vehicles and the scanners coordinate systems (degrees)
scan_rear_beam_min_ang_degFloat0.0Min angle to define the range for valid scanner measurements for the rear scanner with 0 being the first measurement beam (degrees)
scan_rear_beam_max_ang_degFloat360.0Max angle to define the range for valid scanner measurements for the rear scanner with 0 being the first measurement beam (degrees)
scan_front_beam_min_ang_degFloat0.0Min angle to define the range for valid scanner measurements for the front scanner with 0 being the first measurement beam (degrees)
scan_front_beam_max_ang_degFloat360.0Max angle to define the range for valid scanner measurements for the front scanner with 0 being the first measurement beam (degrees)
scan_rear_upside_downInt0Set 1 if rear scanner is installed upside down
scan_front_upside_downInt0Set 1 if front scanner is installed upside down
scan_rear_use_nth_measInt1Use only every nth meas from each rear scanner scan for localization
scan_front_use_nth_measInt1Use only every nth meas from each front scanner scan for localization
scan_rear_offset_mmInt0Rear scanner measurement offset correction (mm)
scan_front_offset_mmInt0Front scanner measurement offset correction (mm)
scanner_dAng_factorFloat-1.0Common scanner dAng scaling, -1 to disable, >0 scaling factor for dAng (reasonable values 0.995 ... 1.005) NOTE:Never use without consulting Navitec first
scanner_dAng_factor_rearFloat-1.0Rear scanner dAng scaling, -1 to disable, >0 scaling factor for dAng (reasonable values 0.995 ... 1.005) NOTE:Never use without consulting Navitec first
scanner_dAng_factor_frontFloat-1.0Front scanner dAng scaling, -1 to disable, >0 scaling factor for dAng (reasonable values 0.995 ... 1.005) NOTE:Never use without consulting Navitec first

Other generic

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
scanner_protection_zone_sensitivityInt1Number of consecutive scanner protection zone violations required
scan_max_dt_err_msInt5The maximum allowed time difference in scanning interval, triggers WARNING/ERROR_SCANNER_FRONT/REAR_HIGH_DT
scan_delayFloat0.0Delay of scanner measurements in ms relative to odometry measurements (negative if scanner is slower than odometry)

Front/rear and localization scanner selection

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
scan_rear_front_selectionInt3Defines which scanners are connected: 1 = rear scanner only, 2 = front scanner only, 3 = both scanners
scan_rear_front_localization_selectionInt3Defines which scanners are used for localization: 1 = rear scanner only, 2 = front scanner only, 3 = both scanners
scanner_model_frontInt0Front scanner model:
0 = Sick Ethernet
1 = Sick S300
2 = Omron OS32C
3 = P+F R2000 UHD
4 = obsolete
5 = Leuze RSL400
6 = Hokuyo UAM-05LP
7 = Keyence SZ-V 32N
8 = Sick uScan
9 = Sick S300 TCP/IP
10 = Reserved
11 = Quanergy M1
12 = Hokuyo SCIP
13 - reserved for internal use
14 = Ouster
15 = DDS
16 = Leuze RSL200
scanner_model_rearInt0Rear scanner model - Look for model number from the scanner_model_front -- parameter description

Front/rear scanner communication settings

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
front_scanner_serial_portString"/dev/ttyS0"Serial port used for front scanner communication
rear_scanner_serial_portString"/dev/ttyS1"Serial port used for rear scanner communication
front_scanner_ipString""Front scanner IP address
rear_scanner_ipString""Rear scanner IP address
front_scanner_portInt44818Front scanner port
rear_scanner_portInt44818Rear scanner port

Safety zone configurations

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
wallmon_scanner_zone_modeInt10 = ignore safety zones; over 0 to slow down with warning zone 2 and to stop with warning zone 1 and protection zone, 1 = stopping is done with slow down ramp, 2 = stopping is done immediately
wallmon_scanner_zone_trigger_bothInt00 = trigger only slow/stop to front/rear scanner direction, 1 = trigger both fw&bw slow from a single scanner, 2 = trigger also stop to both directions from a single scanner

Distance limits

Maximum distance (in meters) to use can be defined per scanner model using the following parameters (with defaults)

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
scan_min_distFloat0.2General minimum measurement distance
scan_s300_max_distFloat29.9Maximum distance measurement to use for Sick s300
scan_sick_eth_max_distFloat65.0Maximum distance measurement to use for Sick eth
scan_pef_max_distFloat131.0Maximum distance measurement to use for Pef
scan_omron_max_distFloat65.5Maximum distance measurement to use for Omron
scan_hokuyo_max_distFloat39.9Maximum distance measurement to use for Hokuyo
scan_leuze_rsl200_max_distFloat25.0Maximum distance measurement to use for Leuze RSL200
scan_leuze_rsl400_max_distFloat65.5Maximum distance measurement to use for Leuze RSL400
scan_velodyne_max_distFloat100.0Maximum distance measurement to use for Velodyne
scan_keyence_max_distFloat60.0Maximum distance measurement to use for Keyence
scan_uscan_max_distFloat65.5Maximum distance measurement to use for micro scan
scan_ros_max_distFloat100.0Maximum distance measurement to use for ros virtual scanner
scan_quanergy_m1_max_distFloat65.5Maximum distance measurement to use for Quanergy
scan_ouster_max_distFloat65.5Maximum distance measurement to use for Ouster
scan_dds_max_distFloat100.0Maximum distance measurement to use for DDS

Scanners for safety only

Navitrol supports up to four scanners that are used for safety only. Only the model of the scanner and IP address/port or serial port path are required for the set up.

Parameters:

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
safety_scanner_model[]Int-1 = not definedLook for model number from the scanner_model_front -- parameter description
safety_scanner_addr[]String""Serial port path or ip:port
Parameter Example
I,safety_scanner_model[0], 22 = Omron OS32C
S,safety_scanner_addr[0], 192.168.1.1:44818
I,safety_scanner_model[1], 66 = Hokuyo UAM-05LP
S,safety_scanner_addr[1], 192.168.1.2:10940

Note: Not all the scanner models supported by Navitrol can send safety status. Supported scanners for safety only (Navitrol 6.17.00)

  • Omron OS32C

  • Hokuyo UAM-05LP

  • Keyence SZ-V 32N

  • Sick uScan/nanoScan

  • Sick S300 -- full support starting from Navitrol 6.32.00

  • Leuze RSL400

  • Leuze RSL200

Additional measurement scanners

In addition to localization scanners (front/rear), Navitrol supports two additional measuring scanners. Measurement scanners can trigger slow down and stop based on warning zones if parameter wallmon_scanner_zone_mode is non-zero. Any scanner model supported by Navitrol can be defined to be used as measurement only scanner as well. These scanners can be used for

  • Obstacle avoidance

  • Target detection

Array parameters are used to define these additional measurement scanners. Up to two additional scanners (indexes 0 and 1) are supported. Most parameters are familiar from front/rear scanner parameter set. The following lists all parameters with some sample values:

NameTypeExample valueDescription
scanner_meas_model[]Int3-1 disabled is the default
scanner_meas_addr[]String192.168.2.182:80IP:port or serial port
scanner_meas_x[]Float0.0The measurement scanner's X coordinate w.r.t. navigation point of vehicle
scanner_meas_y[]Float0.0The measurement scanner's Y coordinate w.r.t. navigation point of vehicle
scanner_meas_sen_ang_deg[]Float0.0The measurement scanner angle
scanner_meas_beam_min_ang_deg[]Float0.0Measurement scanner beam min angle define the range of valid scanner measurement beams for each scanner with 0 deg being the first measurement beam
scanner_meas_beam_max_ang_deg[]Float360.0Measurement scanner beam max angle define the range of valid scanner measurement beams for each scanner with 0 deg being the first measurement beam
scanner_meas_upside_down[]Int0Set 1 if measurement scanner is installed upside down
scanner_meas_use_nth_meas[]Int1Use only every nth meas from each measurement scanner scan for localization
scanner_meas_offset_mm[]Int0Measurement scanner offset correction (mm)
scanner_meas_dAng_factor[]Float-1.0Common scanner dAng scaling, -1 to disable, >0 scaling factor for dAng (reasonable values 0.995 ... 1.005) NOTE:Never use without consulting Navitec first
scanner_meas_scan_delay[]Float0.0Delay of scanner measurements in ms relative to odometry measurements (negative if scanner is slower than odometry)
scanner_meas_scan_rot_cor_invert_dir[]Int0Invert direction in rotation correction
scanner_sends_every_nth_meas[]Int1Scanner sends only every nth meas - not Navigation SW controllable, valid for specific scanners only

Leuze

RSL200

Scanner configuration

Download Leuze configuration and diagnostic software Sensor Studio. Additionally, download and install Safety Device Collection software to have device library and be able to configure the scanner. If Sensor Studio has been installed already the old will need to be uninstalled first before installing a new interface.

Connect the scanner via USB to your PC. Start the configuration software and select device search online. Press [Next].

>Select device RSL200

Press [Next].

Search for the device. Select USB as Adapter

Start search

Search complete

Press [Next].

Access from: Settings Data telegrams

Set the IP address to the connected port of the IPC, set Telegram interval and Index interval as shown in the above Figure. Set the port to a unique port setting.

Access from: Settings Communication LAN

Set the IP address to the same subnet as the port.

Download the parameters.

Press the download button highlighted by a black square. A popup will appear, the default password is provided below.

The software will require authentication.

User: Engineer

Password: safety

Press OK on the next popup to update the parameters.

RSL400

Scanner configuration

Download Leuze configuration and diagnostic software Sensor Studio. Additionally, download and install Safety Device Collection software to have device library and be able to configure the scanner.

Connect to the scanner via ethernet to your PC. Start the configuration software and select device search online. Press [Next].

Select the device to which you are trying to connect with the software and press [Next]. If you cannot see any devices in the list, make sure that Safety Device Collection is installed.

Select LAN as interface and Ethernet as adapter.

Press [Start] to begin the search.

Select the correct device from the list and press [Next].

In order to get the scanner communicating with Navitrol, the UDP telegram needs to be configured to send packets to the IP of the navigation PC to the specified port.

Go to SETTINGS Data telegrams.

Set the following settings:

When the configurations are finished, download the setting to the device by pressing the download button.

The software will require authentication.

User: Engineer

Password: safety

Set the following parameters to params.txt:

I,scanner_model_front/rear, 5

I,front/rear_scanner_port, 9999/9998 (The port that was set for the UDP telegram)

F,reflector_rssi_min_ratio, 0.80

Leuze can be configured to use 2 or 4 safety zones and Navitrol supports only 3. To choose which option is configured with Leuze, add the following parameter:

I,scan_leuze_use_two_prot_funcs, 0 = 2 protective fields (default), 1 = 4 fields

To select which warning zones to trigger from the Leuze status message, add the following parameter:

I,scan_leuze_warning_zone_mode, 0 (default)

If Leuze is configured to use 2 safety zones:

Mode Selection

0 = protection + warning zone 1
2 = protection + warning zone 2
5 = warning zones 1 + 2

If Leuze is configured to use 4 safety zones:

(usually P = estop, W1 = soft stop, W2 = slowdown)

Scanner reset

When scanner has been configured in the Sensor Studio and the configuration is not known, then it may become impossible to connect to it. In such a case it may become necessary to reset it using the following procedure.

  1. Switch off the scanner

  2. Remove scanner from the CU - mounting base (2 in the Figure)

  3. Remove Jumper PNP/NPN (1 in the Figure) like it is shown on the figure

  1. Attach scanner on the base

  2. Switch on the scanner

  3. Message "HIDE COVER TO RESET CONFIGURATION" should be displayed on the scanner

  4. Within 2 minutes: Cover the screen (360) with a cloth, so that all measurement values are small than 150mm.

  5. If successful , the scanner deletes the configuration; CONFIGURATION WAS RESET -- WAITING FOR CONFIGURATION"

  6. Switch off scanner

  7. Remove scanner from CU

  8. Insert Jumper PNP/NPN

  9. Attach scanner to CU

Sick

S300

There are several variants of S300 available. S300 Expert feature list includes "Extended measured data output via RS-422 with landmark recognition", which means that

  • S300 Expert can transfer all measured data in real-time (i.e. 40 ms interval), if the interface is set to 500 kBaud and no filter is set.
  • S300 Expert has built-in reflector detection (landmark detection).

Other S300 variants do not support reflector detection and can transfer only every second measurement (i.e. 80 ms interval), if the interface is set to 500 kBaud.

So, if reflector detection is needed, then Expert model S300 scanners must be used. Because of capability to transfer all measurement data in real-time, S300 Expert is strongly recommended for localization use in all cases.

Configuration of the S300 is done with SICKs CDS-software.

Configuration as Localization Scanner

The S300 scanners should be configured as described in this section to be used as localization scanners. It should be noted that, for communication protocol version 1.03 and later, it is not possible to get warning zone information from the scanners when used for localization, only protection zone information is available.

The baud rate has to be set to 500 kBaud, the send mode needs to be Continuous data output and the Measured data output has to be Distance with no ranges selected. Also, the Message structure must be 1 message and all I/O data outputs need to be unchecked. These configurations can be done from the Measured data output-tab.

Also the field mode has to be set to 4 x 0.5 from the Resolution/scanning range-tab.

Set the following parameters to params.txt:

I,scanner_model_front/rear, 1

S,front/rear_scanner_serial_port, "The name of the serial port that the scanner is connected to

F,reflector_rssi_min_ratio, 0.75

Configuration as Safety Scanner

The S300 scanners can be configured as safety scanners with both warning zone and protection zone information available for communication protocol version 1.03 and later. The only difference in the configuration software from the localization case is that OSSDs from I/O output needs to be enabled as seen below. All the other settings should be the same as in localization scanner configuration.

In params.txt file, the following parameters should be set:

I,safety_scanner_model[0], 1

S,safety_scanner_addr[0], "The name of the serial port that the scanner is connected to"

microScan/nanoScan

Download and launch Sick Safety Designer configuration software.

Connect to the device with a micro USB cable.

Select Search for devices.

Double-click the found device to add it to the project.

Open Configuration Data output.

  1. Select On request and additionally countinuously to target computer as Send mode.

  2. Set the IP address of the port in which the scanner is connected as the IP address (IPC LAN1 port default IP is 10.10.6.100).

  3. Set the UDP port to be the same as in params.txt (default 2111 for front scanner and 2110 for rear scanner).

  4. Set the scanner to send every measuring.

  5. Set the scanner to send all of the data available.

Download the configurations to the device with the Transfer button.

Confirm by pressing Yes.

The software will require authentication.

User group: Authorized client

Password: SICKSAFE or sicksafe

To activate the new configurations, the device must be started in test mode and the configurations must be verified.

Press Yes on the Start device in test mode -window that appears after the transfer.

To confirm that the settings are valid, press Verify.

Approve the verification report by pressing Yes.

Set the following parameters to params.txt:

I,scanner_model_front/rear, 8

I,front/rear_scanner_port, 2111/2110 (The port that was set for the UDP telegram)

F,reflector_rssi_min_ratio, 0.75

Safety zone configurations

By default, only two zone triggers (one protection zone and warning zone) are used. To have two warning zone violations reported to Navitrol, extra configuration is needed, both in Sick Safety Designer as well as Navitrol parameters. Scanner has to be configured to use cutoff paths to communicate violated zone to Navitrol.

Following instructions for scanner configuration was provided by Sick

Configuring with Safety Designer.

After creating a project in Safety Designer with chosen nanoScan3 device and optionally accessing the device with USB, you should be able to see the measurements from nanoScan3 in the "Fields" configuration window. The configuration file can also be made without the device.

The field coordinates window can be zoomed using CTRL+Scroll

The first protective field can be drawn with the rectangle-tool circled with yellow marker. In this example protective field is 500 mm wide, 800 mm high ranging from 200 mm to 1000 mm. Software automatically adds a triangular shape in front of the protective field, so blinding the scanner would not prevent safety output from activating.

Warning fields can be added using the top right marked button "Add field to field set" and it can be set as a "Warning field" by choosing "Field type" in the bottom right corner. After that you can similarly define the field with "Draw rectangle" or with other shape tools.

Below we can see 3 fields. One protective field defined from 200 -- 1000 mm, two warning fields with 1000 - 1500 mm and 1500 -- 2000 mm ranges respectively.

After defining the fields, move to "Inputs and outputs, local" to define the digital outputs. In this example we assign two "Monitoring results" into inputs 2 and 3.

After defining the outputs, move to "Monitoring cases"-tab to assign the fields defined before to the outputs, by dragging the field set. After that tick the "Universal outputs", so the safety scanner knows which outputs to activate, when field is intercepted.

Now you have configured the scanner to use two warning fields and one protective field. Next step is to send the configuration to the scanner if you have one available by clicking "Transfer", or to save the configuration for later use.

Safe Cut-off path needs to be configured for protective field, and Non-safe Cut-off paths for warning fields. In the example case above the cut-off paths were set to following values:

  • Protective field has safe cut-off path 1

  • Warning field 1 has non-safe cut-off path 2

  • Warning field 2 has non-safe cut-off path 3

These values we need to configure to the Navitrol parameters.

Navitrol parameters

Navitrol parameters are configured to same path numbers (1-20) as defined in Safety Designer to map fields into zones in Navitrol. After fields are defined and configurations done in both Safety Designer and Navitrol, configuration should be verified by connecting Navitrol Monitor and triggering the scanner fields to see if matching warning is raised in Monitor.

Parameters:

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
scan_sick_protection_zone_safety_cutoff_pathInt0Used to check protection zone violation, 0 for disabled; min 0, max 20
scan_sick_warning_zone1_safety_cutoff_pathInt0Used to check warning zone 1 violation, 0 for disabled; min 0, max 20
scan_sick_warning_zone2_safety_cutoff_pathInt0Used to check warning zone 2 violation, 0 for disabled; min 0, max 20

TIM***, LMS1**, LMS511

Download and launch Sopas Engineering Tool.

  1. Search for devices by pressing the Search devices: Default button.

  2. Press the Edit IP address button.

  1. Select Use the following IP settings.

  2. Select an IP address for the scanner. It is recommended to set the front and rear scanners to different domains. The ethernet port in which the scanner is connected to must also be in the same domain.

  3. Set the Subnetmask to 255.255.255.0.

Set the following parameters to params.txt:

I,scanner_model_front/rear, 0

S,front/rear_scanner_ip, "The IP address that was set for the scanner"

I,front/rear_scanner_port, "The port that was set for the scanner"

F,reflector_rssi_min_ratio, 0.75

Omron

OS32C

Download the OS32C Configuration Tool software.

Connect to the device via Ethernet.

Configure your local area connection of your PC to obtain an IP address automatically.

Start the configuration software. A Discover Sensors window will pop up.

Press [Continue] to search for devices that are connected to your PC.

When a sensor is found the software will require authentication.

User: Supervisor
Password: supeusr

Go to Utilities Sensor Ethernet Configuration. The Ethernet Configuration screen pops up.

  1. Select Use the following address.

  2. Select an IP address for the scanner. It is recommended to set the front and rear scanners to different domains. The Ethernet port of the IPC in which the scanner is connected must also be in the same domain.

  3. Set the Subnet mask to 255.255.255.0.

  4. Press [Write to Sensor]

Confirm the changes in Ethernet configuration.

An information window is displayed. Read the message and decide if you want to continue to use the current IP address or start using the new address by restarting the sensor. To confirm and change the IP, press [Connect].

Set the following parameters to params.txt:

I,scanner_model_front/rear, 2

S,front/rear_scanner_ip, "The IP address that was set for the scanner"

I,front/rear_scanner_port, 44818

F,reflector_rssi_min_ratio, 0.85

scan_omron_set_warning_zones 1 to change the warning zone set and 0 if they are valid

Hokuyo

UAM-05LP

Changing IP-address

Download the UAM project Designer SW.

Connect to the device using USB cable. Configuration is password protected and default password is 12345678. For details, see "Safety Laser Scanner UAM-05LP User's Manual"

Factory default values are

  • IP address : 192.168.0.10

  • Default gateway : 192.168.0.1

  • Subnet mask : 255.255.255.0

  • Port number : 10940

When all the configurations are complete, click "Confirm" button to verify the configuration and send to device or save to SD card.

Navitrol parameters

Set the following parameters to params.txt:

I,scanner_model_front/rear, 6

S,front/rear_scanner_ip, *The IP address that was set for the scanner*

I,front/rear_scanner_port, 10940

F,reflector_rssi_min_ratio, 0.5

Smart-URG series

NOTE: Only model UST-10LX-H02 tested by Navitec

Download the data viewing tool UrgBenriPlus.

Connect to the device using Ethernet.

Default IP-address of the scanner is 192.168.0.10. You can change it by connecting to the device and then pressing the Change IP Address button. This opens the window shown below.

Navitrol parameters

Set the following parameters to params.txt:

I,scanner_model_front/rear, 12

S,front/rear_scanner_ip, "The IP address that was set for the scanner"

I,front/rear_scanner_port, 10940

F,reflector_rssi_min_ratio, 0.75

Keyence

SZ-V32N/SZ-V32NC

SZ-V series is a modular design safety scanner, consisting of two main components; scanner head and display unit. Different component combinations then result in different device variants. From Navitrol point of view the relevant thing is to have display unit having network interface and device having 'N' in model name:

  • No N: No network connection capability

  • N: With PROFIsafe (PROFINET, UDP, EtherNet/IP)

  • NC: With CIP Safety (EtherNet/IP, UDP)

Connecting

The picture below shows different options for connecting SZ-V series devices to network. Complete units (having both head and display unit) can be connected directly to IPC or via switch. They can be connected "daisy-chained" using dual connectors in display unit.

SZ-V series devices also support master-slave connection, where head units without display units are connected to full unit via special expansion cable; see red rectangle in picture above In such a case communication to slave units (heads) can be realized through the master device.

NOTE: Navitrol does not support this master-slave communication method.

Operating modes

SZ-V series has two operating modes; Standard Mode and High Speed Mode.

High Speed Mode is required by Navitrol. It does with some shortcomings though.

The measurement distance data can be received in increments of 0.2 in standard mode and in increments of 0.4 if the Operating mode is High Speed mode.

Keyence also has an option for "measured value stabilization filter"; which is not recommended as it adds extra delay to measurements.

Configuration

Configuration can be done using Keyence SZ-V configuration software SZ-V Configurator; included in the Safety Device Configurator. It is possible to communicate with the SZ-V configuration software (SZ-V Configurator) via Ethernet or USB.

Detailed step by step instructions for different connection options are described in "Keyence Safety Laser Scanner SZ-V32N / SZ-V32NC Communications Manual". The following pictures show the relevant communication settings when used with Navitrol. Communication protocol shall be UDP and scanner should have a static IP address.

Select communication protocol

Set IP address

Navitrol parameters

Set the following parameters to params.txt:

I,scanner_model_front/rear, 7

S,front/rear_scanner_ip, "The IP address that was set for the scanner"

I,front/rear_scanner_port, 8800

Pepperl+Fuchs

R2000

The only manual setting required is the IP address setting of the Ethernet connection of the scanner. The Navitrol application handles the other scanner settings at startup. There are two methods to edit the IP setting; local user interface and PACTware software.

Using PACTware software

  • Download the PACTware software and Device Type Manager (DTM) from the software section on the page: pepperl-fuchs.com

  • Connect the scanner to the computer via Ethernet cable.

  • Set your computer IP address to 192.168.0.xxx (the scanner default IP address is 192.168.0.1).

  • If the scanner is restored to factory default settings just set your computer to DHCP mode (the scanner is in Auto IP mode).

  • Start the PACTware software.

  • In the Device catalog, select communication by double clicking the R2000 IP Comm (see Fig 10). The selected IP communication should appear in the Structure window.

Figure 10: Select communication.

  • Select the device in the Device catalog by double clicking the proper device model, like OMDxxx-R2000 UHD (see Fig 11). The selected device should appear in the Structure window (see Fig 12).

Figure 11: Select device.

  • Select R2000 IP Comm in the Structure window and click connect in the top bar. Do the same for OMDxxx-R2000. If a connection is established the connection picture in the Structure window should turn green (Fig 12).

  • When connected, double click the OMDxxx-R2000 (Fig 12) to open a scanner configuration window (Fig 13).

Figure 12: Connect.

In the scanner configuration window (Fig 13):

  • Select the Ethernet Setup.

  • Tick Enable update of IP configuration.

  • Change the IP address in the New Settings.

  • Store the settings in the device.

  • Reboot the scanner or turn it off.

Figure 13: Ethernet Setup.

Using local user interface

Local user interface can be used to change the IP address settings.

Buttons 3 and 4 can be used to navigate into local menu system for acquiring and modifying some settings, like IP settings. Visual feedback is presented in area marked with 7. Local menu is pretty intuitive to use -- menu structure and more detailed instructions can be found from P&F OMDxx-R2000 user manuals.

NOTE: Changes to the IP configuration take effect only after a restart.

Navitrol parameters

Set the following parameters to params.txt:

I,scanner_model_front/rear, 3

S,front/rear_scanner_ip, "The IP address that was set for the scanner"

I,front/rear_scanner_port, 80

F,reflector_rssi_min_ratio, 0.75

There are also several P&F R2000 specific parameters in params.txt. Available and recommended settings for these values depend on R2000 device family. See chapter R2000 variants for details.

R2000 variants

There are three variants of R2000 -- UHD, HD and SD. UHD model is most capable and the recommended model. One clear difference is the maximum sampling rate. Navitrol documentation has in the past recommended settings that are valid for UHD model only.

NOTE: Some values (2800/3150) in the table above are not REALLY usable. Another thing to consider is that increasing the number and frequency of measurements increases the load on the CPU.

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
scan_pef_samples_per_scanInt2400Valid values: 72, 90, 120, 144, 180, 240, 360, 400, 450, 480, 600, 720, 800, 900, 1200, 1440, 1800, 2400, 3600, 4200, 5040, 5600, 6300, 7200, 8400, 10080, 12600, 16800, 25200
scan_pef_freqInt25Valid max values for freq/samples: 10/25200, 15/16800, 20/12600, 25/10080, 30/8400, 35/7200, 40/6300, 45/5600, 50/5040 (NOTE: UHD limitations)
scan_pef_use_nth_scanInt1Use only every n~th~ scan
NOTE: This is Navigation SW internal parameter - not sent to scanner.
scan_pef_use_nth_measInt1Use only every n~th~ measurement from each scan for natural features navigation
NOTE: This is Navigation SW internal parameter - not sent to scanner.
scan_pef_display_onInt00 = scanner display off, 1 = display on
scan_pef_lcm_modeInt0Lens Contamination Monitor (LCM) sensitivity: 0 - disabled, 1 - low, 2 - medium, 3 - high

Navitrol reads the device model/family information from the device connected and validates parameters (scan_pef_samples_per_scan/scan_pef_freq) based on the actual capabilities of the device connected.

R2000 UHD

Recommended parameters to begin with depend also on the Navitrol version and IPC capabilities.

Navitrol versions prior to 6.34.00

ParameterWith natural features onlyWith reflectors
I,scan_pef_samples_per_scan24005040
I,scan_pef_freq5050
I,scan_pef_use_nth_scan22
I,scan_pef_use_nth_meas12
I,scan_pef_display_on00

Navitrol versions 6.34.00 and later

With one P&F used for localization OR high spec IPC/CPU when using two scanners for localization (consult Navitec).

ParameterWith natural features onlyWith reflectors
I,scan_pef_samples_per_scan36007200
I,scan_pef_freq5025
I,scan_pef_use_nth_scan21
I,scan_pef_use_nth_meas12
I,scan_pef_display_on00

If these settings cause too much load on the CPU, then settings recommended for Navitrol versions prior to 6.34.00 should be used instead.

R2000 HD

Setup of HD variant is the same as UHD -- only difference is that there are some limitations in sampling rate.

Recommended parameters to begin with:

Navitrol versions prior to 6.34.00

ParameterWith natural features onlyWith reflectors
I,scan_pef_samples_per_scan25202520
I,scan_pef_freq2525
I,scan_pef_use_nth_scan11
I,scan_pef_use_nth_meas11
I,scan_pef_display_on00

Navitrol versions 6.34.00 and later

With one P&F used for localization OR high spec IPC/CPU when using two scanners for localization (consult Navitec).

ParameterWith natural features onlyWith reflectors
I,scan_pef_samples_per_scan36003600
I,scan_pef_freq2323
I,scan_pef_use_nth_scan11
I,scan_pef_use_nth_meas11
I,scan_pef_display_on00

If these settings cause too much load on the CPU, then settings recommended for Navitrol versions prior to 6.34.00 should be used instead.

Quanergy

Quanergy M1

Quanergy M1 comes in different variants; M1-CORE, M1-PLUS and M1-ULTRA (consult Navitec for variant selection). They differ in some features like maximum scan distance. Configuration for each model is however the same.

The Quanergy M1 Sensor Settings Management application (web server) runs in a web browser over the HTTP communication protocol to support a direct connection between the web server (scanner) and client. For details see "Quanergy M1 Sensor User Guide". The following lists some basic settings that shall be set for navigation use.

NOTE: Reflectors can't be used for localization with Quanergy M1 scanner.

Connecting

Connect the scanner to any PC with browser.

  • Open a web browser.

  • In the browser URL field, type the URL, which is simply the sensor IP address appended by :7780. For example 192.168.1.180:7780

  • Press the Enter key. The M1 Sensor tab appears

By default, the login credentials are:

Username: editor
Password: <sensor_serial_number>

Settings

Relevant settings can be found from "Settings-Edit Settings" and "Settings-Edit Network Settings".

Network settings

Set static IP address of your choice and "Submit" and "Reboot".

Sensor settings

Select maximum frame rate of 20 Hz. This results in roughly 0.134 degree angular resolution.

It is recommended to use Return data: Return 0. If any other data selection is used, then

  • single return -- Navitrol obviously uses the data set selected

  • multi return (ALL) -- Navitrol picks return 0 value (causes unnecessary extra network load)

Navitrol parameters

Set the following parameters to params.txt:

I,scanner_model_front/rear, 11

S,front/rear_scanner_ip, "The IP address that was set for the scanner"

I,front/rear_scanner_port, 4141

Scanner Communication Troubleshoot

Updated 26.01.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
NavitrolNavigation software for an individual vehicle.
NavitrolMonitorMonitoring software for the Navitrol positioning software running on an individual vehicle.
NavithorToolsSoftware for creating and editing environment and routes for the Navitrol navigation software.
SupervisorOn-board PLC or PC controlling some components of the AGV. Communicates with Navitrol.
Navigation computer/IPCThe computer system running Navitrol.
RSSIReceived Signal Strength Indicator.
UDPUser Datagram Protocol.
TCPTransmission Control Protocol.

Setup

Ethernet scanners

Depending on the scanner model, the communication between the scanner and Navitrol can be either UDP or TCP/IP. In both cases the recommendations for the network layout and the setup apply.

It is recommended to setup the scanner(s) to communicate to Navitrol in an excluded network to avoid any possible routing mistakes. If possible, the best way to do this is to connect the scanner(s) to their own designated LAN port on the IPC on which Navitrol is running on. This way the only possible source of delay for the communication is the cable in between.

In a standard case with an IPC with 2 LAN ports, if possible, the scanners should be separated to different ports that are configured into different domain addresses.

Example IPs for LAN ports and scanners:

  • LAN1: 10.10.6.100
    • Scanner 1: 10.10.6.1
  • LAN2: 10.10.7.100
    • Scanner 2: 10.10.7.1

IPC interfaces

If there are other devices that need to communicate to the IPC via ethernet, it is recommended to separate the scanners into their own LAN port and domain address and handle all other communication via the second LAN port. In this case it is important, that in case of two (or more) scanners, each scanner is configured to communicate using different IP address/port combination. In any case each scanner shall have a unique IP address.

Example IPs for scanners on one LAN port and other ethernet devices on another:

  • LAN1: 10.10.6.100
    • Scanner 1: 10.10.6.1:2111
    • Scanner 2: 10.10.6.2:2111
  • LAN2: 10.10.7.100
    • Supervisor: 10.10.7.1

In case of UDP scanners, scanners shall be configured to send their messages to different ports while target IP-address is the same for all -- that being IP address of the IPC. That port is then configured in Navitrol parameter file accordingly for each scanner (see parameters at the end of this chapter).

Example IPs for UDP scanners:

  • IPC: 192.168.3.20
    • Scanner 1: 192.168.3.20:2111
    • Scanner 2: 192.168.3.20:2112

In case of TCP/IP scanners, it is enough that each scanner has a unique IP address. Port can be the same in each scanner (can be unique also). Each IP-address/port combination is then configured in Navitrol parameter file (see parameters at the end of this chapter).

Example IPs for TCP/IP scanners on the same domain:

  • LAN1: 10.10.6.100
    • Scanner 1: 10.10.6.1:2111
    • Scanner 2: 10.10.6.2:2111

In all cases, where you have several components communicating through the same LAN port, you have the devices connected through a router or ethernet switch. It is important to make sure that this router or switch is good enough to be able to keep up with the amount of traffic.

Example IPs for several devices on the same LAN port:

  • LAN2: 10.10.7.100
    • Supervisor: 10.10.7.1
    • Router: 10.10.7.2
    • Other ethernet sensor: 10.10.7.3

After setting up the physical layout and the scanner configurations, Navitrol has to be configured to have to the correct IPs (in case of TCP/IP scanners) and the correct ports with the following parameters:

  • S,front_scanner_ip, = IP address of the front scanner

  • S,rear_scanner_ip, = IP address of the rear scanner

  • I,front_scanner_port, = Port for the front scanner (default: Sick 2111, PEF 80, Omron 44818, Velodyne 2368, Hokuyo 10940, Leuze 9999, Keyence 8800)

  • I,rear_scanner_port, = Port for the rear scanner

For safety and extra measurement scanners IP-address and port are combined as follows:

  • S,safety_scanner_addr[0],"1.1.1.1:500"

  • S,scanner_meas_addr[0],"10.10.6.22:5000"

Serial scanners (Sick S300)

In order to communicate with serial Sick S300 scanners, Navitrol requires an IPC with a RS422 port. This is due to the higher (and non-standard) baud rate that is required for the scanner communication.

For this communication a standard serial port is replaced with a dual RS422 card. The card is from Diamond Systems, therefore the mark DS below the port, see the figure below. The SICK S300 scanners shall be connected to the D9 connector according to the figure.

After the card is physically installed, it must be made sure that the RS-422 ports are available for Navitrol. The mother board serial ports IRQs can clash with the DS IRQs which will result into non-functional RS-422 port. Because of this, it is sometimes necessary to disable at least 2 of the mother board serial ports from the BIOS settings of the IPC in order to get the DS ports visible on the Debian side.

Active serial ports can be checked with the following command: dmesg | grep tty

Output should be similar to the example below. In this case the DS serial ports are ttyS2 and ttyS3.

See what the names are for the DS serial ports. In Debian Jessie and newer distros, the ports are named ttyS* but in Debian Wheezy they appear as ttyXR*.

In order for the S300 communication to work, the baud rate of the RS-422 ports need to be set to 500 kBaud. Add the following line to the beginning of the startNavitrol.sh files that can be found inside the /home/navitec directory in the IPC (* being the number of the serial port):

For Debian Jessie and later distros

stty -F/dev/ttyS* 500000

stty -F/dev/ttyS* 500000

For Debian Wheezy

stty -F/dev/ttyXR* 500000

stty -F/dev/ttyXR* 500000

The correct serial port names for the DS have to be defined also in the Navitrol parameters:

  • S,front_scanner_serial_port, /dev/ttyS2 (example) = Serial port of the front scanner

  • S,rear_scanner_serial_port, /dev/ttyS3 (example) = Serial port of the rear scanner

Troubleshooting

If there are issues in the scanner communication, Navitrol will display an error or warning notifying of this. Here are the errors and warnings that you might encounter and the ways to resolve the issues generally.

There are also some scanner model specific features that can be adjusted to prevent issues.

General

In order to see how well the scanners are communicating, it can be checked either from Navitrol Monitor or from the Navitrol text logs.

From Navitrol Monitor you can see the cycle times for the incoming scanner measurements from Charts Positioning Cycle Times.

Here you can monitor the "FrSc" graph (blue) for the intervals between the measurements from the front scanner and "ReSc" graph (yellow) for the rear scanner:

The graph should ideally be as steady as possible around the nominal/configured scan frequency. If there are spikes in the communication, the cause for this should be looked at, since too much deviation from the expected interval will result into timeouts on Navitrol's side.

No communication

If Navitrol has been configured to expect communication from a scanner and there is no communication, Navitrol will display the following error depending on if it is a front/rear scanner:

ERROR_NO_SCAN_FROM_FRONT_SCANNER

ERROR_NO_SCAN_FROM_REAR_SCANNER

If the scanner is configured as a safety scanner only, Navitrol will display the following error:

ERROR_NO_SCAN_FROM_SAFETY_SCANNER

If the scanner is configured as an additional measurement scanner, Navitrol will display the following warning:

WARNING_NO_SCAN_FROM_MEAS_SCANNER

In the case of a complete communication loss, here are some things to check:

  • Ethernet Scanners
    1. Try to ping the scanner from the IPC
      • If the ping does not go through
        • Check the wiring
        • Check the configurations on the scanner side -- IP, port
        • Check the IP configurations on the LAN port of the IPC where the scanner is connected
      • If the ping goes through
        • Check the Navitrol parameters -- IP, port, scanner model, etc...
        • Check the output on the scanner side -- measurement output active
  • Serial Scanners
    1. Check the wiring
    2. Check the serial port configuration in Navitrol parameters and startNavitrol.sh
      • Correct serial port name
      • Correct baud rate
    3. Check the serial port configurations on the IPC
      • RS422 port available

Communication high dt

If the communication interval is deviating from the optimal interval, this can be either caused by incorrectly set targets or thresholds for the communication in the Navitrol parameters or something outside of Navitrol, like a wiring or routing issue.

Each scanner model has their own interval for the measurements which Navitrol sets automatically.

If the average deviance exceeds the value set with the following parameter: I, scan_max_dt_err_ms, 5 (Default value)

Navitrol will trigger the error for too high deviance depending on which scanner is in question:

ERROR_SCANNER_FRONT_HIGH_DT

ERROR_SCANNER_REAR_HIGH_DT

If the scanner in question is not used for navigation, Navitrol will prompt a warning instead:

WARNING_SCANNER_FRONT_HIGH_DT

WARNING_SCANNER_REAR_HIGH_DT

In the case of high deviancy in the interval, here are some things to check:

  • Ethernet Scanners
    1. Check the scanner intervals from the Cycle Times chart to see how much the interval is deviating from the target
      • In case the deviance is rare and just above the default error limit, the scan_max_dt_err_ms parameter can be raised (NOTE! this can have a negative effect on the localization since Navitrol allows a larger delay between the measurements which will then also increase the localization cycle of Navitrol)
    2. Set a continuous ping from the IPC to the scanner with communication issues to see if the issue is related to the network connection in general
      • If there are delays in the ping
        • Check if the issue is related to the network layout (chapter 1.1) -- It is possible that the measurements are routed incorrectly causing for some delay
        • Check if the issue is in the router by connecting the scanner directly to the IPC and testing the communication again
        • Check if the issue is in the cable by testing with another one
        • Check if the issue is in the LAN port of the IPC by testing the other port as well -- If there are issues only in one LAN port
      • If the ping is going through without issues but there are still delays in getting the measurements
        • Analyse the network traffic from between the scanner and the IPC to see if the delay can be seen there as well with for example Wireshark
        • If the delay is visible, the issue is most likely something on the scanner side so the suppliers support should be contacted
        • If the delay is not visible when monitoring the traffic but visible on the Navitrol side, take a log file and contact Navitec Support
  • Serial Scanners
    1. Check the scanner intervals from the Cycle Times chart to see how much the interval is deviating from the target a. In case the deviance is rare and just above the default error limit, the scan_max_dt_err_ms parameter can be raised (NOTE! this can have a negative effect on the localization since Navitrol allows a larger delay between the measurements which will then also increase the localization cycle of Navitrol)
    2. Check the wiring a. In order for the pin layout in the DP9 connector to be correct, the wiring from the DS card to the port has to be correct as well b. Serial communication is prone to disturbances so make sure that the wires are not led near motors or cables with higher voltages since these can result into inductive current

Reflectors not detected

In order to detect reflectors, Navitrol requires an RSSI (signal strength) value to be sent by the scanner for each scanner measurement.

If Navitrol is not able to detect reflectors, make sure that your scanner is configured to send the RSSI value in the output. Since different scanner models detect different levels of RSSI values from the same reflector, the ratio needs to be setup scanner specifically according to the Navitrol -- Scanner Configurations document.

Optical Code Reader

Updated 26.01.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
TCPTransmission Control Protocol - connection oriented network communication protocol
SOPASSICK SOPAS engineering tool is a device configuration SW provided by SICK AG
Read GateRead Gate control is the term used for SICK Lector reading activation

Supported models

For now Navitrol supports SICK Lector 6xxx using Ethernet interface (TCP). SICK Lector is an image-based code reader capable to read many different type of QR-code and bar-codes. It also has limited capability to tell how far from centerline the reader is.

Device configuration

SICK Lector 6xxx

Prior to configuration:

  • SICK SOPAS software should be downloaded and installed.
  • IP address of the connected PC should be changed to match the domain with that of SICK Lector device.
  • SICK Lector shall be connected to PC using Ethernet and powered up.

SICK Lector shall be configured both for intended application and for communication with Navitrol. There are two optional methods to do this configuration.

  • Configure each SICK Lector with SOPAS, one by one
  • Configure SICK Lector by Navitrol using file exported from SOPAS

In both options at least one SICK Lector needs to be configured using SOPAS. When configuration has been done, it can be stored to a file in different formats; to be used by SOPAS for later use or in another format to be used by Navitrol.

The following shows how to connect to the device using SOPAS and settings needed for the device to communicate with Navitrol in expected manner.

Connect to SICK Lector 6xxx with SOPAS

Connection starts by searching the devices. First click A. "Search devices". Connected device(s) should then appear in the list B. Each Lector has two optional connections (ports 2111/2112).

Double click the second connection in the list and you should see the device on the left side pane.

Double click the "icon" of the device on the left side pane and select Advanced user interface.

Finally you should be connected to the device and tree like settings selections are visible on the left side pane.

Reset, read, write SICK Lector 6xxx configuration with Sopas

First decision point is whether one would like to do configuration by

  • Starting with factory defaults OR
  • Further modifying existing settings

New device is in factory defaults when delivered. If one wishes to force device to factory defaults at any time, then select from menu: "DeviceName" - Parameter - Load factory defaults in device.

As noted by SOPAS, also communication parameters will go to factory defaults. IP address shall then be set to right value as shown below.

If one would like to modify existing configuration instead, then existing configuration can be read from device by clicking the icon with green up arrow.

Then finally when configuration is done, it can be written to device by clicking the icon with red down arrow. And finally saved permanently by clicking memory chip icon.

One can also save the project in SOPAS for later use (see SOPAS documentation) or export the settings as explained in later chapter.

Configure SICK Lector 6xxx with SOPAS

Configuration for the device to communicate in expected manner with Navitrol is presented in figures below. Only those settings that are different from device default settings are shown. Primary objectives with these settings are immediate response when code (QR-code, bar code,..) is detected and continuous communication with reasonable interval for device monitoring purposes.

Object Trigger Control

Read Gate shall be controlled by Navitrol using SOPAS commands. We also want immediate "Good Read" message sent out as in some features repetitive reading is necessary.

Evaluation Conditions

Output Control

In most applications we want immediate response without any delays.

Output Format

It is vitally important to have right output format for "Good Read". Failing to comply with this format will result in Navitrol trashing the message sent by the device.

NOTE: Even though the format must be exactly as shown here, Navitrol SICK Lector interface does not require all data fields to be present. Message has to start with "GoodRead;" as shown here, but then minimum one out of the four data fields (ID, X, Y, Z) is required. Navitrol SICK Lector interface reports which fields have been read and it finally depends on the Navitrol feature used what data is truly needed. Even if the Navitrol feature in question would not need all data fields, there is no benefit really for defining different output message than that shown in figure.

Ethernet

Heartbeat message with interval of 1 sec is required by Navitrol for device monitoring purposes.

Configure SICK Lector 6xxx by Navitrol

When one device has been fully configured with SOPAS, one can export the settings and corresponding configuration commands to a file as shown below.

This results in ASCII-file with all commands that are needed for device configuration by Navitrol.

In order for Navitrol to use this configuration file, it shall be stored to same folder as Navitrol executable and params.txt for example. Then the file name is defined in Navitrol parameters. After that Navitrol will use the file at startup and after any communication break to send all those commands to the device. This feature makes it also simple to replace SICK Lector with new one if needed, as Navitrol takes care of writing the same configuration to a new device. See chapter Navitrol configuration for further details for parameters involved.

NOTE: First command in configuration file is for setting Access Mode required for configuration. Last HEX value is the HASH password for the device. If devices have different passwords, then this should be modified for each device separately.

Navitrol configuration

The SICK Lector camera is regarded as an external localization sensor and therefore the following parameters shall be correctly set. Most of the parameters are array parameters; valid indexes being 0...3 and indexing should start with 0.

Parameters for basic communication and configuration

ParameterDescription
I,ext_loc_eth_model[],Model of ethernet external localization sensor: 0 = PGV camera, 1 = reserved, 2 = SICK Lector
S,ext_loc_eth_ip[],IP address of the device
I,ext_loc_eth_port[],Communication port of the device (with SICK Lector 2112 with defined configuration)
S,ext_loc_config_file[],SICK Lector sensor configuration file name, if such exits (*)
I,ext_loc_config_msg_interval_ms[],SICK Lector sensor configuration command transmit interval [ms]. Defaults to 100 ms.

(* NOTE: Defining configuration file name means that configuration made by Navitrol is required. If defined file does not exist, Navitrol will report configuration failure and SICK Lector interface will not work.

Parameters for log control

ParameterDescription
I,log_ext_log,Log communication details, 0 - min level ... 3 - max amount of details.

Parameters for mounting - feature & application specific

ParameterDescription
I,ext_loc_x_offset[],SICK Lector longitudinal position offset from navigation point
I,ext_loc_y_offset[],Camera transversal position offset from navigation point
I,ext_loc_y_offset_deg[],Heading offset in degrees between machine coordinate system and camera coordinate system, heading angle of focal axis when vertical
I,ext_loc_focal_orientation_deg[],Orientation of camera coordinates around focal axis when the axis is horizontal. The rotation angle should be such that reported detection X is to the left and Y up when seen behind the camera to the markers

NOTE: For these parameters see further details in in feature specific documentation

WARNINGS

Navitrol SICK Lector interface does not raise any ERROR, but it can raise WARNINGS.

WarningDescription
WARNING_CODE_READER_NO_COMMSNo communication to the device. This WARNING should not be set after startup.
WARNING_CODE_READER_STATUS_NOT_OKError reported by device itself or device configuration error. Configuration error can happen for example if defined configuration file does not exist or device password is not right in configuration file.

NOTE: SICK Lector startup time is quite long - around 1 minute. So it is normal to have some WARNING after startup for longer period than with most other sensors.

Encoders

Updated 26.01.2024

  • EtherCAT encoders

Ethercat Encoders

Updated 26.01.2024

Overview

Introduction

Absolute encoders are devices that provide position information of the moving shafts (e.g. steering axle or driving axle).

In Navitrol, EtherCAT encoders can be used:

  • As feedback for the steering angle in steer AGV
  • As feedback for the steering angle in omni AGV

Requirements

Prior to the integration, all devices should be connected to the bus and powered. For additional information, consult Ethercat communication document. It is expected that user has basic EtherCAT knowledge.

Before setting the parameters, the user must find a datasheet for the particular encoder. This datasheet should contain information about:

  • Pulses per revolution (also can be named as counts per revolution, ppr) - number of pulses/counts in one revolution.
  • Pulses overflow (also can be named as resolution) - maximum value of pulses/counts that encoder can have before overflow.

Limitations

  • At the moment, EtherCAT encoders as a steering encoder must be used for any steer or omni AGV that have Ethercat as control interface.
  • At the moment, EtherCAT encoders can be used only with machines that use EtherCAT as control interface (for the motor controllers).
  • Currently, EtherCAT encoders cannot be used as actuator encoder.
  • Currently, EtherCAT encoders cannot be used as drive/distance encoder.
  • Navitrol supports a limited number of encoder models. The list of tested and approved encoders can be found in Supported device list

Dependencies

Basic EtherCAT parameters should be defined prior to the integration.

Setup

Quick start

For the correct operation, initial parameters should be set.

  1. Set the basic EtherCAT parameters as described in Ethercat communication document.
  2. Set the communication parameter(s) that define position in the EtherCAT bus depending on the encoder function (steering/driving/actuating) and kinematics according to the table below.

Communication parameters for steering encoder in steer AGV

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
ethercat_enc_steer_addrInt0Physical EtherCAT address for steering absolute encoder in steer drive. 0 - disabled

Communication parameters for steering encoder in omni AGV

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
ethercat_enc_omni_addr_arr[]Int0Physical EtherCAT address for steering absolute encoder in omni drive. 0 - disabled
Array index - omni wheel number
  1. Set device specific parameters depending on the encoder function (steering/driving/actuating) and kinematics according to the table below. Most of the values can be found in the encoder's datasheet.

Device specific parameters for steering encoder in steer AGV

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
ethercat_enc_steer_modelInt1Ethercat encoder model in steer drive, 1 = Generic (Sick AFS/AFM60)
steer_enc_pulses_overflowUint268435455Maximum value of pulses/counts that encoder can have before overflow
steer_enc_pulses_per_revInt10000Number of pulses/counts in one revolution
steer_enc_zeroInt0Number of pulses/counts corresponding to the zero steering angle
Has to be found very precisely for good driving
Can be left zero during the first launch

Device specific parameters for steering encoder in omni AGV

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
ethercat_enc_omni_model_arr[]Int1Ethercat encoder model in steer drive
1 = Generic (Sick AFS/AFM60)
Array index - omni wheel number
omni_steer_enc_pulses_overflow_arr[]Uint268435455Maximum value of pulses/counts that encoder can have before overflow
Array index - omni wheel number
omni_steer_enc_pulses_per_rev_arr[]Uint10000Number of pulses/counts in one revolution
Array index - omni wheel number
omni_steer_enc_zero_arr[]Uint0Number of pulses/counts corresponding to the zero steering angle
Has to be found very precisely for good driving
Can be left zero during the first launch
Array index - omni wheel number

  1. Calibrate the encoder zero manually. The procedure is included in the Calibration guide. This step is needed for the steering encoder only.

    The only parameter that must be tuned manually is encoder zero since it is the only parameter dependent on the mounting. The calibration process consists of the following consecutive steps:

    • Kill Navitrol from Linux terminal or using SSH connection (e.g. Putty)
    • Physically set the steer wheel as straight as possible.
    • Start Navitrol
    • Read raw encoder pulses with command from Linux terminal or Putty: ./Navitrol dumpl 0 "EthercatAbsEnc_TryParseRxMsg".
    • Put the value to a corresponding encoder zero parameter.

How to use

For steering encoders, after successful setup it is possible to see changes of the steering angle in Navitrol Monitor as shown on the figure below:

Omni AGV. Inside the frame, the position of the wheels is shown and steering angles are displayed. Wheel 0 has steering angle of -16.98 deg, wheel 1 is turned 16.98 deg and wheel 2 is positioned straight.

Troubleshooting

Most common issues

Encoder initialization failed - ERROR_ENCODER_CONFIG visible

At the beginning of the operation, Navitrol reads in the encoder configuration. If there are any issues with the encoder initialization, Navitrol shows the above-mentioned error.

The most common reasons behind the error are invalid communication parameters - such as ethercat_enc_steer_addr or ethercat_enc_omni_addr set incorrectly, e.g. to 0.

It is recommended to double-check parameters for the encoder. Additionally, check the log or Linux terminal for more details.

Errors and warnings

848 ERROR_ENCODER_CONFIG

Description: Invalid encoder configuration. Check encoder parameters

Error level: Error

Error reason: Some of the encoder parameter is not valid.

How to recover: Check the log or terminal for more details. Check Navitrol parameters. Contact Navitec support.

Advanced troubleshooting

Keywords for analyzing logs:

  • AbsEnc - keyword to find all information related to the absolute encoders,
  • EthercatAbsEnc_TryParseRx - keyword for checking raw data coming from the ethercat encoder. Present in the logs only after encoder communication is successfully established
  • AbsEnc_CopyDataIn - keyword to find additional information on matching encoder raw data to machine data (e.g. additional information on assigning steering angle of omni wheel 0)
  • EthercatAbsEnc_HandleFaults - keyword on checking if any encoder internal error or warning is set

Navitrol Monitor - User Instructions

Updated 13.09.2024

Introduction

Navitrol Monitor is a Windows application that aims to work as a service and/or control tool for the AGV onboard software Navitrol. It provides useful real-time information about localization, positioning and system status etc. while also giving the user the possibility to directly control the AGV provided that Navitrol is not running in position-only-mode. In addition to this, Navitrol Monitor does also act as the primary log analysing tool and features a playback mode to read in the binary logs generated by Navitrol.

System Requirements

Navitrol Monitors ability to visualize the information sent by Navitrol in real time sets requirements on both software and hardware:

Minimum hardware requirements

  • Screen resolution: 1920x1080

  • CPU: 4 logical cores, 2.4 GHz

  • RAM: 8 GB

  • GPU: OpenGL 2.0 support

  • Storage: 120 GB

Recommended hardware requirements

  • Screen resolution: 1920x1080

  • CPU: 4 logical cores, 3.0 GHz

  • RAM: 16 GB

  • GPU: OpenGL 2.0 support

  • Storage: 120 GB

Software requirements

  • Operating system: Windows 7, Windows 10 or Windows 11

  • Net Library 4.7.1 installed

    • https://www.microsoft.com/net/download/framework

  • C++ Redistributable package 2017 X86 version

    • https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/downloads/

    • https://aka.ms/vs/15/release/VC_redist.x86.exe

Getting Started

Folder Structure and Password Configuration

The Navitrol Monitor executable NavitrolMonitor.exe is found under its root directory together with its configuration file NavitrolMonitor.exe.config and various dll files. On startup Navitrol Monitor will prompt for a password and by default this is set to ntnavitec. Changing the password is done via the UI by pressing *Change...*and entering the new information. In order to disable the password check completely the user has the possibility to change to an empty password. Resetting the password requires the user to delete the ConfigFiles directory that is generated once the application has been started once.

Connecting to Navitrol

Connecting to Navitrol requires that Navitrol and Navitrol Monitor are in the same network and that the firewall has been configured correctly. The user is then able to add machines via the UI by clicking the Edit button from the main toolbar and setting the name and IP/port of the machine of interest. These fields can later be modified.

To establish a connection, first select one of the configured machines from the drop-down list and click Connect. The connection status can then be seen at the bottom of the main window.

User Interface

This section aims to give an instructional overview of the different options and functionality that Navitrol Monitor offers.

Navitrol Monitor Main Menu

Under the main menu of Navitrol Monitor the user is able to find different file handling alternatives, visualization options, data illustrations etc. The different menus will be covered in detail in the following subsections.

File menu

Under the file menu the user has the possibility to perform general file related actions:

  • Open Log -- Used to open and load a binary log file for visual playback.

  • Save Log -- Used to save a binary log that does not contain any text log. Not recommended when sending logs to Navitec Systems for analysis as the text log is often needed.

  • Convert to Teach File -- Converts the binary log to a teach file that Navithor Tools can process.

  • Exit -- Shuts down the application.

View menu

The view menu lets the user manipulate how things are visualized in the main frame of Navitrol Monitor but does also give access to more advanced features such as the State Form:

Options:

  • Follow Vehicle -- Allows the user to follow the vehicle while it is moving through the map.

  • Freeze Monitor Data -- Stores a shade of the current vehicle position and scanner measurements in a lighter color than the real-time data. Useful when calibrating the odometry of the machine.

  • Show Graphs -- Show/hide the right-side graphs in the main window.

  • Show State Form -- Gives the user access to the Navitrol State Form where machine errors and the Navitrol console outputs are shown. Useful during debugging.

  • Visualization Options -- Visualization Options popup window
  • Draw Trajectory speeds -- Enables a color gradient (from red to green, RGB color heatmap) visualization of the calculated trajectory speed.
  • Show Segment IDs -- Visualizes segment IDs and their directions when zoomed close to the route network

Visualization Options

  • Zone Visualization -- Lets the user enable/disable different zone visualizations. Options are enabled if zones are added to the production in NavithorTools project

  • Front scanner -- Front scanner visualization

  • Rear scanner -- Rear scanner visualization

  • Measurement 0 scanner -- Measurement 0 scanner visualization

  • Measurement 1 scanner -- Measurement 1 scanner visualization

  • Large Points -- Large scanner points visualization

  • RSSI Values -- Received Signal Strength Indication visualization. Helpful when identifying reflectors in the surroundings

  • Distance to environment -- Visualizes how close individual scanner points are to the environment points. See Scanner point distance to environment visualization

  • Dynamic Map -- Lets the user toggle the Dynamic mapping scanner points in the main view.

  • External localization -- Lets the user toggle External localization and DMC Docking V2 visualization

  • Custom properties -- Lets the user toggle Custom properties visualization. See Navithor Tools documentation for further info on Custom properties

  • PLC warnings -- Lets the user toggle PLC warnings visualization

  • Position control triggers -- Lets the user toggle the position control triggers being displayed in the top left corner of the main window. Gives the user information about what causes for example soft stops/hard stops on the position control level. Only available when Navitrol controls the driving.

Charts menu

The charts menu gives access to informative charts that visualize the raw data collected by Navitrol in a more user-friendly way. From here the user has the possibility to retrieve information about odometry measurements, speed and angle reference values, scanner corrections etc. Most of these charts are machine type specific as it is based on the underlying kinematic. Therefore, not all charts will display any information for the connected machine.

Charts:

  • Steer Drive Motors -- Contains information about the steering PID control and the driving PD control as well as measured steering angle/drive speed and the corresponding reference values set by Navitrol.

  • Differential Drive Motors -- Contains information about the drive motor PD control for each differential wheel as well as measured speed vs. reference speed.

  • Mecanum Drive Motors PD Control -- Contains information about the drive motor PD control for each mecanum wheel.

  • Mecanum Drive Motors Speed Control -- Contains information about the measured speed vs. reference speed for each mecanum wheel.

  • Position Control -- Shows the predicted and measured curvature.

  • Speed Control -- Shows the speed reference from different sources as well as the final speed reference vs. measured value.

  • Navigation Point Velocity Vector -- Shows navigation point lateral, longitudinal and angular speed references and measurements.

  • Omni Steer Wheels Control -- Contains information about each steer wheels reference angle vs. measured angle.

  • Omni Steer Motors PID Control -- Contains information about each steer motors PID control.

  • Omni Drive Wheels Control -- Contains information about each wheels reference speed vs. measured speed.

  • Omni Drive Motors PD Control -- Contains information about each drive motors PD control.
