Navitrol supports binary actuator control during coupled driving. Actuator control signals are sent through Leader AGV only and status signals are also expected from Leader AGV. Additionally, actuator control is supported only when formation is in LOAD state at load/unload points. There will be no actuator action during coupled AUTO driving.

Actuator control in coupled driving is disabled by default. It could be enabled by setting the parameter coupled_actuator_control to 1. Note that despite this parameter being set to 1, coupled actuator control will work only if actuator_type parameter is set to binary actuator control (value 3).

External Localization in Coupled Driving

Basic concept of external localization remains the same in coupled drive system. There are no extra parameters either. In coupled drive, it is required that both AGVs have two PGV cameras installed. The cameras should be installed in machine coordinates to the X-axis or to the Y-axis passing navigation point. The cameras should be in the opposite sides relative to navigation point (see > Figure 6). External localization is active when at least 3 out of 4 PGVs can read measurements from the data matrix.

The AGVs must also be in the coupled configuration so that their navigation point lies on the coupled system's X-axis or Y-axis (see Figure 7). The heading of AGVs relative to the coupled system can be freely chosen as longs as the previous conditions hold. Coupled system can be driven longitudinally or transversally and it can follow one to four data matrix tapes depending on the configuration. The more data matrix tapes it must follow, the more burdensome is the teaching process of the lines into map. Define only one connection per data matrix tape in Navithor Tools. A few example configurations are shown in Figure 8.

Figure 6: Possible camera placements

Figure 7: AGV positions on X-axis or Y-axis of coupled system

Figure 8: Different possible configurations of AGVs in the coupled system. There can be one to four data matrix lines that the coupled system can follow.

Obstacle detection and obstacle avoidance during Coupled driving

If obstacle detection and obstacle avoidance features are enabled for a single AGV, they will be disabled for the duration of coupled driving.

Warnings and Errors

In addition to normal position control warnings and errors, following are coupled driving specific errors.

ErrorDescriptionComments
ERROR_COUPLED_DRIVE_COMMSCommunication error with one or more machines in coupled driveMake sure that IPs and machine ids in coupling command are correct and AGVs are able to ping each other over configured network.
ERROR_NAVI_COMM_VERSIONVersion mismatch in Navitrol-Navitrol communicationCheck Navitrol versions on coupling machines and ensure that they are the same.
ERROR_COUPLED_DRIVE_CONFIGInvalid configuration for coupled driveMake machine types and load configurations are supported by Navitrol.
ERROR_LARGE_FORMATION_ERRFormation error is larger than configured limitsIf active at the time of coupling, ensure that AGVs are at correct positions and formation configuration is correct.
If recurring during driving, tune coupled control parameters.
ERROR_COUPLED_FORMATION_OFFSET_DETECTIONCoupled formation offset detection measurement failureFormation error measurements not received by Navitrol. Check error sensor setup.
ERROR_COUPLED_DRIVE_ACTIVE_ERRORSErrors are active on one or more machines in coupled driveResolve any active errors on coupled AGVs before coupled driving.

Parameters

Coupled drive related Navitrol parameters are listed in table below:

NameData TypeDefault ValueComments
Basic Configurations
coupled_drive_enabledInt0: disabledEnable/disable coupled driving feature
coupled_max_drive_vFloat0.3 m/sMaximum allowed driving velocity in coupled driving
coupled_actuator_controlInt0: disabledEnable/disable actuator control in coupled driving
Formation Error Sensor configuration
coupled_formation_err_sensorUInt0: Simulated from localizationConfigures the type of sensor setup used for formation error measurements.

0: Simulated
1: Measurements from CAN/Supervisor interface
2: Pattern-detection based error calculation
coupled_formation_err_disable_route_propertyStringFormationErrCtrlDisabledName of route property that can be used to disable coupled formation error on specific routes.
coupled_formation_offset_max_read_fail_countInt5
CAN sensors for Formation Err
coupled_formation_err_x_can_enc_idxInt-1
coupled_formation_err_h_can_enc_idxInt-1
Reflector Pattern for Formation Err
pattern_detection_refl_board_pos_xFloat0.0 mX position of reflector pattern in vehicle coordinate frame
pattern_detection_refl_board_pos_yFloat0.0 mY position of reflector pattern in vehicle coordinate frame
pattern_detection_refl_board_angle_degFloat0.0 mAngle of reflector pattern in vehicle coordinate frame
Communication Parameters
navicomm_inte_ipStringIP for AGV-to-AGV communication -- empty bydefault.

navicomm_inte_portInt1236Port used for AGV-to-AGV communication.
Must be identical on all AGVs in coupled driving
coupled_comm_status_update_interval_msInt100 ms
coupled_comm_control_ref_timeout_msInt200 ms
coupled_comm_loss_stop_timeFloat2.0 sec
coupled_comm_loss_fstop_timeoutFloat5.0 sec
Formation Error Control Parameters
coupled_pid_heading_err_pFloat1.0Proportional gain for heading error
coupled_pid_heading_err_iFloat0.0Integral gain for heading error
coupled_pid_lon_dist_err_pFloat2.0Proportional gain for distance error in the direction of motion
coupled_pid_lon_dist_err_iFloat0.0Integral gain for distance error in the direction of motion
coupled_pid_trans_dist_err_pFloat2.0Proportional gain for distance error perpendicular to direction of motion
coupled_pid_trans_dist_err_iFloat0.0Integral gain for distance error perpendicular to direction of motion
coupled_pid_delta_v_limFloat0.2 m/sMaximum allowed change in velocity due to formation error compensation
coupled_pid_delta_c_limFloat0.3Maximum allowed change in curvature due to formation error compensation
Override Formation Error Control Parameters
coupled_pid_override_lon_dist_err_cmFloat0.0Coupled drive longitudinal distance error controller will use override gains if error is below this distance
coupled_pid_override_trans_dist_err_cmFloat0.0Coupled drive transversal distance error controller will use override gains if error is below this distance
coupled_pid_override_head_err_degFloat0.0Coupled drive heading error controller will use override gains if error is below this limit
coupled_pid_override_heading_err_pFloat0.0Coupled drive controller gain for heading error control in override control region
coupled_pid_override_lon_dist_err_pFloat0.0Coupled drive controller gain for longitudinal distance error control in override control region
coupled_pid_override_trans_dist_err_pFloat0.0Coupled drive controller gain for transversal distance error control in override control region
Formation Error Diagnostics Parameters
coupled_max_dist_err_cmFloat3.0 cmAn error will be raised if error between nominal and current AGV position exceeds this limit
coupled_max_head_err_degFloat2.0 degreeAn error will be raised if error between nominal and current AGV heading exceeds this limit

Quick Start Guide

Please ensure system requirements listed in Section System Requirements before starting this guide. Follow the steps below to start coupled driving.

  1. Enable coupled driving on each AGV Copy the parameter below in params.txt file I,coupled_drive_enabled, 1 Note that this requires feature license for coupled driving.

  2. Check Formation Error Sensor Settings For preliminary testing, localization-based simulation of sensor setup can be used with following parameter: U,coupled_formation_err_sensor, 0 Refer to Section Formation Error Sensor Setup for correct configuration according to formation error sensors present on AGVs.

  3. Drive AGVs to coupling start position Drive individual AGVs to coupled driving start positions on the map. Start positions must correspond to desired coupling formation configuration as specified in Section Coupling Formation Configuration.

  4. Command AGVs to COUPLED state AGVs can be commanded to coupled state from Navithor or Supervisor interface. Navitrol state will change to COUPLED if coupling command was successful.

  5. Ensure that machines are coupled and no errors are active COUPLED state indicates that an individual AGV is in coupled driving mode; however, it may not be connected to formation yet. Leader AGV will load coupled driving segment file when switched to COUPLED state. ERROR_COUPLED_DRIVE_COMMS remains active until communication is established between the AGVs. If communication error is active after all AGVs has been switched to COUPLED state, it may indicate an error in IP configurations or communication network. Before starting coupled driving, ensure that no errors are active on any AGV in formation. Formation state can be monitored through Leader AGV (from Monitor, Supervisor or Navithor). Formation must be in STANDBY state for auto driving.

  6. Drive Order Once coupling has been successful and there are no active errors, drive orders can be sent to Leader AGV the same way as sent to a single AGV. This can be done through Monitor, Navithor or Supervisor interface.

  7. Tune formation error controllers When configuring the feature for first time, it is essential to monitor formation errors and calibrate error control parameters accordingly for acceptable machine response. List of controller parameters can be found in Section Parameters.

  8. Adjust Coupled Driving Configuration A list of settings for coupled driving including maximum allowed formation errors, max drive velocity, actuator control etc. can be configured through parameters. All coupled driving parameters are listed in Section Parameters.

Line following with a magnetic tape sensor

Updated 26.01.2024

Overview

Introduction

The feature is used for following a magnetic tape, allowing for more precise docking and position control. It is used for position control, but not for localization. For localization and position control or for accurate stopping when docking, the data matrix feature is required. The sensor provides a lateral error and is of use when the route segment requires high lateral accuracy. The AGV drives with laser scanner localization until the tape is detected. Then it disables the horizontal laser scanner corrections and uses the magnetic line instead until the drive is finished or the magnetic tape is no longer detected. The AGV follows the magnetic tape when present and the feature is enabled for the route segment and therefore limits the versatility of the AGV.

Requirements

  • SICK MLS magnetic tape sensor
  • External localization license
  • Web UI for teaching
  • Magnetic tape. See SICK MLS manual for more information

Limitations

  • Not supported in curved routes and intersections
  • Teaching of line points only with Web UI

Setup

Quick start

The sensor measures the offset to the sensor's geometrical center point in millimeters. A measurement is obtained if a magnetic tape is detected, and its track level (induction) is above a certain threshold. The sensor has two LEDs, when the magnetic tape is detected with sufficient field strength the first LED is yellow and the second one is green or blue. The light of the second LED depends on which side of the sensor's centre point the magnetic line is detected. Avoid initializing the sensor on magnetic tape, as this might result in non-deterministic measurements. Powering off the device can fix the issue. See Sick MLS manual for more information.

The AGV will minimize its the error with respect to the magnetic tape, and follow the magnetic tape instead of the route if the two diverge. During docking with magnetic line following, a magnetic tape equaling a distance of at least line_following_sensor_pos_x[0] or line_following_sensor_pos_x[1], depending on which sensor is first to detect the magnetic tape, is assumed after the last trajectory point.

The nominal sensor position is determined by parameters line_following_sensor_pos_x and line_following_sensor_pos_y with respect to the AGV's navigation point for each sensor. Negative measurements are obtained from the centre towards the cable outlet.

In the below Figure line_following_sensor_flipped[0] is 0 and line_following_sensor_flipped[1] would be 1. The navigation point is represented as a black circle and the nominal sensor position line as a dashed orange line in the below Figure. The y-deviation with respect to the nominal sensor position (dashed orange line) is defined by parameter line_following_sensor_offset_y for each sensor, visualized as offset1 y in the Figure

>> Line following sensor positions

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
line_following_sensor_communicationInt00 - disabled, 1 - CAN, 2 - Ethernet
line_following_sensor_model[]Int00 - disabled, 1 - Sick MLS
line_following_sensor_pos_x[]Float0.0The sensor X-position with respect to navigation point. See above Figure for reference
line_following_sensor_pos_y[]Float0.0The sensor Y-position with respect to navigation point. See above Figure for reference
line_following_sensor_offset_y[]Float0.0The y deviation from the nominal sensor position. See above Figure for reference
line_following_sensor_flipped[]Int0A flipped sensor will give wrong signs for the measurements, to transform the measurements to machine coordinate frame, parameter line_following_sensor_flipped is introduced. See above Figure for reference
line_following_max_dist_since_last_measFloat0.1Maximum allowed driven distance between two measurements before error

Teaching the magnetic line

The principle of teaching the magnetic line is the same as for teaching external localization tape. The basis of saving teach points, can be time, distance or user input. The parameters introduced below are for saving on a distance basis. For more information on the parameters and the procedure, see document External localization

Teaching is done via web UI. Drive the AGV along the magnetic tape with the feature enabled and the parameters set. The below parameters are for teaching the magnetic line points based on distance.

NameTypeRequired valueDescription
teach_file_formatInt5Required for teaching magnetic tapes. See external localization document for more information
ext_loc_teach_modeInt3Distance based teaching of points. See external localization document for more information
ext_loc_teach_interval_distFloat0.1Distance between teach points. See external localization document for more information

Add the teach file into Tools. Under Routes Route properties, select 'MagneticLineFollowing' as visualized in the Figure below.

>> Teach points in Tools

CAN setup

The baud-rate and node-id must be modified for allowing CAN communication with Navitrol. The default node-id for the sensor is 10, in decimal, and the default baud rate is 125k. Changing the default node id and baudrate can be done via e.g. CANKing. Set the device to pre-operational state with the following instructions in the below Figure

>> Setup of node-id and baudrate in CANKing

Send the following commands to the device to change node-id and baudrate. Baudrate 250 Bd corresponds to 03. Restart the device after saving the new parameters. The below table is described in hexadecimal.

Setting node-id and baudrate via CAN

CAN identifierByte 0Byte 1Byte 2
7E5040100
7E55E0000
7E511NodeId00
7E51300Baudrate
7E5170000
7E5040000

See Sick MLS manual for more information regarding Sick MLS specific parameters.

Ethernet protocol

The message structure for each sensor is the same, only the port differs for the ethernet communication. The endianness can be configured by parameter, line_following_swap_bytes.

The message protocol is a direct copy of the CAN message PDO1 and is sent to Navitrol in UDP format, separately for each sensor. The IPC will act as a server and the default port is 5333, but can be changed via parameter line_following_sensor_eth_port.

Ethernet UDP message

Data fieldTypeLength (bytes)Comment
Sending countUint_162Incremented for each message, to verify if the received message is valid
LCP1Int_162Position of Line Center Point 1 [mm]
LCP2Int_162Position of Line Center Point 2 [mm]
LCP3Int_162Position of Line Center Point 3 [mm]
Line infoUint_81Bits0...2:
0 - No track found
2 - One track found
3 - Two tracks found: Left diverter
6 - Two tracks found: Right diverter
7 - Three tracks found or 90 intersection
StatusUint_81Bits0...3
7 - Field level 4500-2000
6 - Field level 1750
5 - Field level 1500
4 - Field level 1250
3 - Field level 1000
2 - Field level 750
1 - Field level 500
0 - Field level 450
0 - Field level 350

In case of one magnetic line present, the measurement reading will be read from LCP2

Parameters

CAN parameters

NameTypeRecommended valueDescription
line_following_sensor_nodeid[]Int10CAN node id (decimal)
can_sick_mls_event_timer_msInt10Time between two transmissions. See MLS document
can_sick_mls_calibrate_offset[]Int0Trigger offset calibration. See MLS document
can_sick_mls_factory_reset[]Int0Factory reset the sensor. See MLS document

For more information about the can_sick_mls parameters see the SICK MLS manual.

Ethernet parameters

NameTypeRecommended valueDescription
line_following_sensor_eth_port[]Int5333Port of the device
line_following_swap_bytesInt0Swap bytes in line following ethernet interface. 0 = Little endian, 1 = Big endian

How to use

The line following is active when the sensor in the direction of motion, as seen from the navigation point, detects the tape and when the driven route has line following tag. If these conditions are met Navitrol Monitor will print Line following active in the top left corner while in AUTO state.

>> Line following active in Monitor

Troubleshooting

Errors and warnings

225 - ERROR_NO_DATA_FROM_LINE_FOLLOWING_SENSOR

No valid data received for ethernet procotol. Verify that the received data is valid by setting parameter log_veh_inte_eth to 4. Setting the parameter allows to see the received raw data in the log with prefix SICK_MLS_ERROR byte. Reset after received valid data.

226 - ERROR_MSG_PARSE_LINE_FOLLOWING_SENSOR

The error is triggered for the Ethernet protocol if the sending counter is invalid or error parsing the measurement data, and for CAN if there is an error parsing the measurement data. Verify that the sent data is valid and there is connection to the device, and that the sending counter, if using Ethernet, is valid from SICK MLS ethernet - current sending counter. Error is reset after received valid data.

227 - ERROR_LINE_FOLLOWING_NO_MEASUREMENT

The AGV has driven a distance of line_following_max_dist_since_last_meas since last measurement on a route with magnetic line following tag. Line following active will be visualized in Navitrol Monitor if measurements are received on the magnetic tape. In case there are 2 sensors an error is triggered if the second sensor to detect the tape does not detect the tape after driving a distance equaling the sum of line_following_sensor_pos_x[0], line_following_sensor_pos_x[1] and line_following_max_dist_since_last_meas after the first sensor has reached the line following route tag start point. The error is reset by driving manually or by setting parameter line_following_sensor_communication to 0.

Advanced troubleshooting

The parsed data for ethernet and CAN is logged as follows:
SICK MLS - LCP1, LCP2 (raw), LCP2, LCP3, LCP status, Measurement status, Track status,
where LCP1-3 is the sensor reading in millimeter, LCP status is the line info (how many tracks are detected), measurement status is a Boolean describing if the track is detected and track status is the induction level of the track (range 0 to 7). LCP is logged twice, the raw data and the potentially flipped data.

Line following is not active although the sensor is on the magnetic tape

Under the assumption that the trajectory has magnetic line following tag, that the curvature of the trajectory is negligible and the AGV is not currently pivoting, the root cause is invalid sensor measurements. A measurement (LCP) of 0 is valid and can mean it is in the center of the sensor, or that no measurement was received. To differentiate between these, see output of Measurement status and/or Track status, with the above mentioned log line. The measurement status and/or track status will be non-zero if a measurement was received and the magnetic tape was detected. LCP1 and LCP3 are used to detect multiple magnetic lines and should be zero if there is only one detectable line. Place the sensor closer to the magnetic tape to see if the track status changes to non-zero. If issue persists, verify that the wiring is correct.

Line following is active but the driving is not robust

The line_following_sensor_flipped parameter might be wrong for one or more sensors. Another possible cause is that the sensor has been initialized on the magnetic line, which might result in infeasible measurements. A feasible measurement range is sensor dependent, and is within [-range / 2, range / 2], if the centre offset has not been altered. The measuring range for the MLSE-0300 is -15000 and 15000. If the Measurement status or Track status is non-zero but the measurement value for LCP2 remains 0 regardless of where the magnetic line is with respect to the sensor's centre point, the measurements is invalid.

Trailer Transport

Updated 26.01.2024

Overview

Introduction

Trailer transport is a Navitrol feature that makes it possible to transport trailers with an omni AGV. When connected to the trailer, the omni AGV behaves like a truck pulling or pushing the trailer with it.

Example trailer

In a typical use case an uncoupled omni AGV gets an order to transport a trailer from location to another. The AGV drives to the trailer location and couples itself to the kingpin of the trailer. Then the AGV drives to the target location and uncouples itself from the trailer.

When the AGV is coupled to a trailer, the coupled trailer system behaves like a steer drive where the navigation point is in the middle of the middlemost axle of the trailer and the omni AGV acts like a steering wheel. See the image below.

Blue AGV coupled with with gray trailer frame.
1. Navigation point of the omni AGV and location of trailer kingpin.
2. Trailer support legs.
3. Navigation point of the trailer.
4. Trailer wheels

In case you are looking for a way to use multiple AGVs simultaneously to transport a single large resource, see Coupled driving feature instead.

Requirements

Knowledge:

  • Basics of AGV calibration

Hardware:

  • A well calibrated omni drive AGV, see Initial calibration guide
  • Actuators for coupling and uncoupling a trailer and an AGV
    • The AGV system is responsible of controlling the actuators based on generic commands from Navitrol
  • 2D scanner for trailer angle detection
    • This is used to determine the angle between the AGV and the trailer based on wheels of the trailer.
    • Optionally this scanner can be attached to extendable telescope structure
  • Separate scanner for positioning
  • For outdoor environments
    • GPS sensors and IMU for navigating without scanner measurements. See GPS positioning
  • Trailer must have two support legs

Software:

  • Navitrol standalone or Navithor fleet control based production system
  • Navitrol version 6.34.00 or later
  • Ethernet supervisor communication interface with messages 3002 - section 12, 3102 - section 17, 3042 and 3142.
  • Pallet detection v2 feature, requiring target detection license
    • Required for trailer angle detection
    • Highly recommended for docking to trailer before coupling

Environment and routes:

  • Enough space for long straight routes for coupling and uncoupling
  • Routes must be suitable for both the uncoupled AGV and the coupled trailer system

Limitations

  • Low drive speeds when transporting a trailer
    • Typically maximum of 1.5m/s forwards and 1m/s in reverse
  • UI visualization
    • Trailer is not visualized in Navitrol monitor and Navithor client
  • When using with Standalone, separate pick up and drop of symbolic points must be defined for each trailer size
  • The trailer angle detection scanner must be installed to the middle of the AGV's rear end

When coupled to a trailer following features cannot be used:

  • Omni frame heading
  • Obstacle avoidance

Dependencies

  • Pallet detection & Docking
  • Ethernet supervisor interface
  • Return to Route
  • Standalone OR Navithor
  • GPS positioning
  • Imu and Sensor Fusion

Set up

Quick start

  1. Install the required hardware to the AGV
    • See "Requirements" chapter
    • Imu and Sensor Fusion
    • GPS Positioning
  2. Calibrate positioning and driving of the omni AGV without trailer
    • Initial Calibration Guide
  3. Teach the production environment
  4. Define routes suitable for the coupled and uncoupled AGV systems
  5. Set up pallet detection feature for detecting and docking to trailer legs
    • Pallet Detection
    • Coupling sequence, see "Coupling sequence" chapter.
  6. Implement the required supervisor messages
    • See "Requirements chapter" and Ethernet Supervisor Interface Specification
  7. Enable trailer transport feature
    • Add trailer_transport_enabled to params.txt and set the value to 1
  8. Calibrate Trailer angle detection
    • See the related chapter
  9. Calibrate driving with a trailer
    • See the related chapter
  10. Set production control parameters
    • Either Navitrol standalone
    • Or Navithor fleet control, see "Navithor set up" chapter

Required parameters

NameTypeRequired valueDescription
trailer_transport_enabledInt1Enables the trailer transport feature

Fine-tuning

Calibrating trailer driving

For route following purposes the uncoupled AGV behaves like a normal omni AGV and when coupled to a trailer the system behaves like a steer drive. When switching between the two the behavior of the AGV system will change so much that separate control gain parameters will be needed.

Uncoupled system uses normal control parameters (pc_pid_heading_p, pc_pid_dist_p and related speed-based gains).

Coupled system uses loaded gain parameters (pc_pid_heading_p_loaded, pc_pid_dist_p_loaded and related speed adjusted gains). In addition to normal control gains the coupled systems uses trailer_transport_pid_heading_err_p which determines how aggressively the detected trailer heading error is corrected. Heading, distance and trailer heading gains must be adjusted so that the AGV system follows the route as accurately as possible.

If the coupled system drives accurately on slower speeds but starts to oscillate on higher ones, pc_pid_speed_setting_loaded parameters can be used to define separate control gains for different speeds. Typically lower gains are needed for higher speeds.

Note: When the AGV is pulling a trailer (AGV system is driving forwards) the trailer angle error naturally decrease so accurate control on higher speeds can be achieved compared to the situation where AGV is pushing the trailer. For this reason, it is recommended to design routes so that forward direction is used wherever possible.

It is also important to calibrate the angle detection well so that there is no offset. Otherwise, the trailer heading error correction will constantly fight against the normal heading and distance control. The trailer angle detection offset can be measured by driving the AGV manually straight forward for couple of meters while pulling the trailer. After the drive the real trailer angle should be zero. If the detected trailer angle is not, scanner heading parameters should be tuned.

Instructions on how to use the forementioned parameters and how to calibrate the heading and distance control can be found from the Initial Calibration Guide

Fine tuning parameters

Coupling and uncoupling sequence parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
trailer_error_timer_msInt60000Determines the wait time during coupling and uncoupling sequences to adjust the actuator between states.
For example, at the start of coupling sequence Navitrol request the AGV system to prepare actuator for coupling. If supervisor has not sent coupling status "ready for coupling" within the time defined by this parameter ERROR_TRAILER_TRANSPORT_COUPLING will be triggered.
The value should be larger than the time required for the slowest (un)coupling action.
trailer_kingpin_approach_max_distFloat1.0The maximum drive distance in meters for approaching/searching the kingpin during the coupling sequence. If the AGV system does not report that the kingpin has been detected before this distance has been driven Navitrol will stop the AGV and ERROR_TRAILER_TRANSPORT_COUPLING will be triggered.
The value should be set so that it is large enough to cover the distance from the pick up sp to to the kingpin but low enough that the AGV is safely stopped in case the AGV does not detect the kingpin.
trailer_kingpin_approach_max_vFloat0.2Defines the maximum velocity during the kingpin approach search drive.
In general, lower speeds increase position control accuracy and are safer where higher ones save time.
trailer_uncoupling_straight_leave_distFloat0.5The drive distance after unlocking the actuators from kingpin during uncoupling.
Will be driven straight so that the AGV gets fully out of under the trailer before resuming normal driving and following the defined routes.
The value should be large enough so that after the drive AGV can move freely without a possibility to collide with the dropped of trailer.
trailer_uncoupling_straight_leave_max_vFloat0.2Defines the maximum velocity during the uncoupling straight leave drive. In general, lower speeds increase position control accuracy and are safer where higher ones save time.

Parameters for defining maximum trailer heading errors based on the scanner telescope length

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
trailer_max_heading_err_close_degFloat7.0Used for stopping the AGV before the compressed scanner telescope can hit the trailer wheels
ERROR_TRAILER_ANGLE_TOO_LARGE is set, if trailer heading error is larger than this value and scanner telescope length is less than the distance to frontmost axle
trailer_max_heading_err_far_degFloat1.5Used for stopping the AGV before the extended scanner telescope can hit the trailer wheels
ERROR_TRAILER_ANGLE_TOO_LARGE is set, if trailer heading error is larger than this value and scanner telescope length is larger than the distance to frontmost axle

Trailer max heading error visualized:
1. Navigation point of the AGV (kingpin of the trailer).
2. Scanner telescope length
3. Distance to frontmost axle
4. Trailer heading error

Note: If the system does not have scanner telescope, only one of these parameters are used, based on the constant scanner telescope length provided to Navitrol

Position control parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
trailer_transport_pid_heading_err_pFloat3.0Position control gain for trailer to AGV heading error control in trailer transport.
Affects how aggressively the heading error is corrected towards zero.
This control gain will compete with normal heading and distance correction gains (pc_pid_heading_p,loaded pc_pid_dist_p_loaded).
The higher the value of any of these parameters the more the related correction is prioritized over the other two.

Logging parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
log_trailer_transportInt0Used to control amount of trailer transport related logging. 0 - basic level, 1 - detailed logging enable.
If you encounter any issues with the feature set the value to 1 before taking and sending a log for further inspection.

Navithor set up

When Navithor fleet control system is used with trailer transport feature following parameters must be set to make sure that the coupled/uncoupled status will be updated between the systems even outside pick up and drop off situations.

ProductionManager_ResourceMismatchRules to set

ProductionManager_AlwaysCheckResourceMismatch set to True

How to use

Use case sequence

  1. An uncoupled AGV is on standby waiting for a production order
  2. AGV receives a production order to pick up a trailer
  3. AGV starts to drive towards the target pick up symbolic point
  4. AGV approaches the trailer reversing
  5. Target detection determines the exact trailer position for example based on the trailer legs.
    • Note: If pallet detection is not used the trailer must be located on the target symbolic point with minimal position and angle errors.
  6. Navitrol docs to the pick up symbolic point
  7. Coupling sequence is performed
    1. AGV reverses straight towards the kingpin of the trailer and stops when the kingpin is reached
    2. AGV locks to the trailer and lifts it up
    3. AGV sends trailer dimensions to Navitrol
    4. Navigation point is changed from the AGV to the trailer wheels
    5. The AGV and trailer are now coupled and work as a trailer system
    • See related chapter for more info
  8. Trailer system gets a drive order to a drop of symbolic point
  9. Trailer system drives to the target symbolic point so that
    • The trailer navigation point follows the defined routes
    • The detected trailer angle is used for position control
  10. Trailer navigation point reaches the drop of symbolic point
  11. Uncoupling sequence is performed
    1. AGV lowers and unlocks the trailer
    2. AGV drives straight forward from under the trailer so that it won't hit the trailer support legs
    3. AGV preforms return to route function
    • See related chapter for more info
  12. The AGV is now ready for next production order

Trailer coupling and uncoupling

Coupling sequence

A description of the trailer coupling sequence from Navitrol point of view.

The terms in italic are references to "coupling actions" and supervisor's "coupling status" information defined in the ethernet supervisor document.

  1. Production order to pick up point
    • Navitrol gets drive order to a pick up symbolic point while unloaded
      Note: The AGV is considered unloaded when it is uncoupled from the trailer. The trailer is considered uncoupled after the Supervisor has sent Uncoupled as Trailer coupling status
  2. Docking to the pick up point with pallet detection
    • Pallet detection can be used to dock to the target pick up point
    • Optional but recommended step as without docking it is very hard to hit the kingpin.
    • Requires pallet model based on the trailer legs
    • For more information see pallet detection documentation

Docking to trailer coupling start point using pallet detection. The red circle is the load symbolic point where the coupling sequence will start. Parameter docking_stop_dist defines the expected distance from the symbolic point to the middle of the trailer legs -- the pallet detection will search the target around that point.

  1. Arriving to pick up point
    • The AGV arrives to pick up symbolic point (with or without docking)
    • Navitrol enters load state starting the trailer coupling sequence.
  2. Navitrol requests coupling preparations
    • Navitrol sends trailer coupling action to Prepare for coupling. This action is sent in Trailer transport status section's "Trailer coupling action"-data field
  3. Navitrol will wait until coupling preparations are done
    • AGV system sends this information by changing the Trailer coupling status to Ready for coupling.
    • Coupling preparations can be for example raising actuator to kingpin level.
  4. Navitrol will start reversing towards the kingpin
    • Navitrol will start reversing straight backwards from the current position until Trailer coupling status changes to Kingpin detected
      • trailer_kingpin_approach_max_v defines the speed of the drive
      • trailer_kingpin_approach_max_dist defines the maximum distance of the drive
    • If the maximum distance is driven without receiving Kingpin detected trailer coupling error is raised
  5. AGV stops at the kingpin
  6. Navitrol request coupling action
    • Navitrol will send Couple action
    • Coupling action in this phase can include for example raising the actuator and locking AGV to the kingpin of the AGV
  7. Navitrol will wait until coupling is ready
    • AGV system send this information by sending Coupled status
  8. Navitrol will wait for trailer dimensions
    • Only happens if the trailer dimensions have not been received before this point
      • Note: Navitrol will start requesting this information when the coupling sequence starts after entering the load state
    • Navitrol needs the trailer dimensions for trailer angle detection
  9. Coupling sequence is ready
    • The AGV is coupled to the trailer and is ready to transport it based on incoming production orders

Coupling sequence communication diagram

Uncoupling sequence

A description of the trailer uncoupling sequence from Navitrol point of view.

The sentences in italic are references to coupling actions and coupling status in supervisor document.

  1. Production order to drop off symbolic point
    • Navitrol receives drive order to an drop off symbolic point while loaded.
      Note: The AGV considered loaded when the trailer is coupled to the AGV. Trailer is considered coupled when AGV system sends Coupled in Trailer coupling status data field of Supervisor trailer transport status section
  2. AGV enters the target drop off point
    • Uncoupling sequence starts
  3. Navitrol request uncoupling preparations
    • Navitrol sends action to Prepare for uncoupling
    • Uncoupling preparations at this point can include for example lowering the actuators so that the trailer is unlocked and the AGV can be driven out from under the trailer.
  4. Navitrol will wait until uncoupling preparations are ready
    • AGV system must inform this by changing Trailer coupling status to Ready for uncoupling
    • AGV is now physically uncoupled from the trailer
  5. Navitrol will drive from under the trailer
    • Navitrol will drive straight forward away from the kingpin for a defined distance
    • trailer_uncoupling_straight_leave_dist defines the drive distance that is driven fully
    • trailer_uncoupling_straight_leave_max_v defines the speed of the drive
  6. Navitrol will stop and request finishing uncoupling
    • Navitrol sends action to Uncouple
    • Finishing uncoupling can include for example lowering the actuators to a drive height
  7. Wait until uncoupling has been finished
    • AGV system must inform this by sending Uncoupled status.
  8. Navitrol will perform automatic return to route
    • It is possible that the AGV is not on the defined route, if the straight drive from under the trailer is very long and there is even a slight angle error at the beginning
    • Note: the return to route feature parameters need to be calibrated to suit your needs
  9. Uncoupling sequence is ready
    • The AGV is free for new trailer production orders

User interfaces

Navitrol monitor When the AGV is coupled to a trailer, following trailer transport related information is available in Navitrol Monitor:

Trailer transport Navitrol Monitor view:
1. Trailer Navigation point,
2. Detected trailer wheels / angle,
3. Scanner that is moved with telescope

Navithor client Navithor client has no trailer transport specific visualization implemented. Instead the position of AGV can be seen to jump on the map when the navigation point changes from AGV to the picked up trailer at the end of coupling sequence. This can be partly hidden by defining the carried resource to match the trailer dimensions.

Communication between AGV and Navitrol

Trailer transport feature requires the trailer status and dimension data from the AGV.

The status data should be sent with recommended interval of 40-100ms. After Navitrol has received the status once, Navitrol expects to get it at maximum interval of one second. If the data is not received ERROR_TRAILER_STATUS_NOT_RECEIVED will be set.

The trailer dimension data is needed for trailer angle detection. Navitrol will request the data using Navitrol trailer status section. Without trailer angle detection Navitrol cannot control the trailer and will refuse driving in auto mode.

The data can be sent using trailer transport messages in Ethernet Supervisor interface. See the Supervisor documentation for following messages:

  • Message 3002 - Supervisor status, Trailer transport status section (section ID = 12)
  • Message 3102 - Navitrol status, Trailer transport status section (section ID = 17)
  • Message 3042 - Set trailer dimensions
  • Message 3142 - Set trailer dimensions result

Trailer angle detection

The angle between the trailer and the AGV is required for controlling the system. The angle can be detected using 2D laser scanner either from front or behind the trailer rear wheels. Optionally this scanner can be attached to an extendable telescope structure so that the scanner can be moved behind rear wheels. This makes it possible to use the same scanner for safety when reversing with the trailer.

Trailer angle detection with 2D scanner. The measured angle is the angle between the AGV and the trailer. Trailer angle is determined by the front wheels (orange) using pallet detection feature.

The trailer angle detection algorithm requires the trailer wheel dimensions which can be provided with the Ethernet supervisor message 3042 - Trailer Transport: Set Trailer Dimensions.

The detection scanner is selected with target_detection_scan_selection parameter. The scanner must be installed to the center of the AGV frame (on the x-axis of the AGV frame) as seen in figure above. It gets the distance from the navigation point (kingpin) from the Scanner Telescope Length data in Ethernet supervisor status message 3002 section Trailer transport section.

The detection algorithm uses the pallet detection v2 implementation. Parameter pallet_det_2_detect_only_front_legs should be set to 1.

The angle detection results might be noisy which will affect directly to the calculated trailer navigation position and furthermore the stability of the driving. To filter the noise in the angle detection results, parameter target_detection_results_dampening can be used. The closer to zero the value is set the more the angle results are filtered. However, too much filtering will cause delay to the angle detection. Value 0.3 is a good starting point for further tuning.

Troubleshooting

Most common issues

Trailer system oscillates while driving

Oscillation is most often caused by several accumulating error sources.

Check from "Calibrating trailer driving" chapter that:

  • Omni AGV is well calibrated when not coupled to the trailer
    • The AGV follows control references accurately
    • Scanner (and GPS) positioning is accurate
  • Trailer angle detection is accurate
    • The scanner must be firmly attached in relation to the AGV frame
    • The given trailer wheel positions and dimensions must be accurate
    • There is no angle offset when the trailer is straight
  • Driving with trailer is well calibrated
    • Loaded gain parameters are tuned
    • Given trailer dimensions must be accurate
  • Routes are planned so that the trailer system drives forward as much as possible as the control is more stable when the AGV is pulling the trailer compared to pushing.

Errors and warnings

713 - ERROR_TRAILER_TRANSPORT_COUPLING

This error is set, and drive stopped if

  • Trailer was lost or connected unexpectedly
    • While coupled or uncoupled the trailer coupling status from supervisor is changed unexpectedly.
    • For example, while Navitrol thinks that the trailer is coupled to the AGV and driving and reported coupling status changes to uncoupled.
    • No error is raised on unexpected changes during coupling and uncoupling sequences
  • Kingpin was not found
    • During coupling when reversing to kingpin the maximum drive distance is reached without coupling status indicating that the kingpin is detected.
    • Max drive distance is determined by trailer_kingpin_straight_drive_dist
  • The AGV system does not respond to coupling action requests
    • During coupling or uncoupling sequence the reported state has been same for over the max wait time determined by trailer_error_timer_ms
  • During uncoupling if the automatic return to route fails
    • Either return to route parameters have not been calibrated correctly or the AGV is too far from the route to return.

The error is fatal, and it needs to be reset manually by the user after the issue causing it has been resolved.

After the error is cleared Navitrol will determine the correct coupling state based on the coupling status received from the AGV system.

715 - ERROR_TRAILER_ANGLE_NOT_DETECTED

This error is set if trailer angle is not detected successfully when coupled to a trailer. Possible reasons are that the pallet detection is not enabled and set up correctly or the angle detection scanner does find the wheels in the near the axles defined with "Set trailer dimensions"-message.

The error is automatically reset when the trailer angle is successfully detected -- Successfully detected angle is rendered as a green line in Navitrol Monitor.

716 - ERROR_TRAILER_ANGLE_TOO_LARGE

This error is set if detected trailer angle error compared to the AGV angle is larger than the limits set with parameters trailer_max_heading_err_close_deg and trailer_max_heading_err_far_deg. See the "Fine tuning parameters" chapter for more information.

The error is automatically reset when the trailer angle is back within the limits. However, getting the angle error to the limits while error is active will most likely require manual control since automatic driving is prevented by the error.

714 - ERROR_TRAILER_STATUS_NOT_RECEIVED

This error is set if valid trailer status has been received once but after that either the communication is lost, or data received is invalid for more than one second.

To fix the issue make sure that the supervisor sends Message 3002 -- Supervisor status, Trailer transport status section (section ID = 12) with valid data.

Advanced troubleshooting

This chapter provides instructions for advanced trouble shooting. See the Guide for taking and reading log files as well.

Logging parameters
Set both log_trailer_transport and log_veh_inte_eth to value 1 before taking a log for advanced troubleshooting.

Log keywords
Following keywords can be used to search more information on specific points of interest. They are case sensitive.

Point of interestKeywordUse case
Everything"railer"Start point for narrowing down the issue if it is not quite sure what goes wrong.
Coupling state changes"Trailer state"Helpful if there seems to be issues in coupling or uncoupling sequences.
Supervisor interface"trailer transport"Can be used to check if Navitrol receives the required trailer transport data over the supervisor interface and if Navitrol responds with valid data to the supervisor.
Trailer angle error"TrailerTransport - Angle error"Can be used to observe trailer angle error and for example to calibrate angle detection offset.

Barrier Stop

Updated 26.01.2024

Overview

Barrier stop is a Navitrol feature that allows the use of signals, such as line sensors, to stop omni wheels individually to increase stopping orientation accuracy. Designed only for two wheeled omni drive.

Example case:

  • There is a line on the ground on the stopping area and two sensors on the AGV for detecting the line.
  • When AGV approaches the stopping point it waits for signals from the sensors.
  • When it receives a signal, it stops the related wheel while the second wheel keeps driving (turning the AGV around the stopped wheel) until the second signal is received or fail safe timer is triggered.
  • As a result, the AGV should turn to same orientation (both wheels on the line) each time.

How to use

Preconditions

  • An omni drive with exactly two wheels
  • Two sensors for detecting the line
  • Some kind of line that can be detected by the sensors and can be installed at the desired stopping location
  • Ethernet supervisor communication interface
    • Message 3002 -- Supervisor status, Inputs section (section ID = 4)

Set up

  1. Install the line(s) at the desired stopping location(s)
  2. Use Navithor Tools to a. Add symbolic points to those locations b. Enable barrier stop feature at the added symbolic points c. Enable "NavitrolEna" virtual tag with no additional features checked (value 65280). See the images below. If you cannot see "Barrier stop"-option in "Navitrol features"-list please update Navithor Tools software to version 4.07.00 or newer.

  1. Define Navitrol parameters
  • F,barrier_stop_check_dist,0.2
    • Enables the barrier stop if larger than zero.
    • Defines the distance from the symbolic point (before and after) where the barrier stop signals are expected.
    • The signals are ignored when the AGV is outside of this distance from a barrier stop symbolic point
  • I,barrier_stop_signal_max_wait_time_ms,2000
    • Defines the maximum wait time between the first and the second signal to prevent the AGV potentially spinning in place if the second signal is not received.
  • I,use_virtual_io,1
    • Enables virtual IO for delivering the signals to Navitrol
  • I,disable_sending_inputs, 0
    • Must be 0 or blocs the input actions
  • I,input_0_action, 201
    • Defines that bit 0 is the signal for the wheel 0
  • I,input_1_action, 202
    • Defines that bit 1 is the signal for the wheel 1
  • I,physical_binary_inputs_n, 2
    • Defines the total number of binary inputs in use.
    • The parameter value needs to be 2 (barrier stop inputs) + number of other binary inputs in use (if any).

Implementing the messages

  1. Use the "Inputs"-section (id = 4) of "Supervisor status"-message to send the sensor signals to Navitrol.
  2. For more information see document: Ethernet Communication specification between Navitrol and AGV supervisor_v4.docx

  1. Only binary inputs are needed
    • "Num of binary inputs" should be 2
    • When value 1 (8 bit unsigned int) is sent
      • Binary input index 0 stops the wheel 0
      • Binary input index 1 stops the wheel 1

Activating the stop

  1. When a sensor detects the line, related inputs section bit for that wheel should be set to 1 (0 otherwise)
    • This activates the stop if the AGV was driving to a symbolic point that has barrier stop enabled and is within the distance defined by barrier_stop_check_dist-parameter

Warnings

WARNING_BARRIER_STOP_FAILED is set and drive stopped if

  • AGV drives barrier_stop_check_dist past the symbolic point without getting both signals
  • First signal is received, but the second is not received within barrier_stop_signal_max_wait_time_ms

Note: The warning will be set for couple of seconds. The AGV will try to continue the drive order after that.

Data Matrix Code (DMC) Docking V2

Updated 29.04.2024

Overview

Introduction

In context of External localization, Data matrix docking is a separate feature that requires its own license. The idea is to use the data matrix tape for line following only. This means that data matrices are not taught to the environment nor will their exact position on the map be known. Instead, symbolic points on the route network will hold the needed information about the data matrix lines.

In short, the AGV is given a drive order to a destination symbolic point which has data matrix information defined. When the AGV is close enough to the symbolic point and receives a valid measurement from the PGV camera, it goes to a docking state and uses from here on the data matrix code / QR code line as a reference for the drive. This means that the AGV will correct its position to the center of data matrix line and simultaneously correct it's heading to be aligned with the line.

The AGV will stop based on a predefined stopping values on the data matrix tape. After it gets a drive order to leave the location, it will follow the data matrix tape until the primary sensor is far enough from the symbolic point (configurable). The feature provides accurate docking since the cameras can provide sub millimeter X,Y position on the data matrix.

The DMC Docking V2 is an improved version of the old Data Matrix docking. The improved version provides the means for:

  • Docking to a same symbolic point forward and backward
  • Docking to a symbolic point that is middle of the route
  • Docking to a symbolic point from all directions
  • Docking with DMC line ascending and descending values
  • Choosing active PGV cameras to be used when docking
  • Possibility to use 4 PGV cameras

DMC Docking V2 is available in Navitrol 6.48 Official Release

Requirements

Hardware requirements for the feature include Position Guided Vision sensor(s) and Data matrix code tape from Pepperl+Fuchs. Navitrol can read data directly from sensors using CAN Open. For other type of sensors, the customer is required to read the data from the sensors and send the data to Navitrol via Ethernet TCP/IP connection (see Appendix).

Note: From Navitrol 6.32 onwards, two cameras can be mounted also to the left and right side of navigation point.

Limitations

The DMC docking has following limitations for its configuration:

  • The Data matrix tapes cannot cross each others.
  • AGV can follow only one QR-code line at a time.
  • The route should be straight and without branches whenever the AGV is following the data matrix tape.
  • Symbolic point must have DMC docking enabled. In addition, symbolic point must be placed so that it is close to the location that the AGV is needed to be stopped. Maximum allowed distance is 0.1 meters.
  • If AGV has restarted or driven manually closer than "Check path ready" distance from the symbolic point, The DMC docking does not activate in following situations:
    • If route is forward or reverse only
    • Data matrix docking stop point is defined only to be approached from one direction and starting to drive to the other side of the symbolic point
  • Drive order to the same symbolic point where AGV already docked not possible if AGV would approach the same segment (i.e. a loop). AGV should be given drive order to somewhere else first.
  • When testing with Navitrol Monitor, disable fleet control since it can cause problems (I, fleet_control_type, 0)

AGV can follow only one data matrix line at a time, but there can be one or two PGV cameras used for driving. However, only the PGV camera that is configured as primary camera will be used for stopping the AGV. The other (secondary camera) is used only for alignment with respect to data matrix line.

Dependencies

  • External localization

Setup

Quick start

  • Configure and calibrate the PGV cameras
    • External localization - Calibration of camera positions
    • External localization - Calibration of the AGV position relatvie to the Data matrix line
    • External localization - Calibration setup for vehicle with two PGV:s
  • Create straight routes and symbolic points along the DMC lines
  • Define stopping points for these symbolic points (Configuration)
  • Give a drive order to the symbolic point along the route DMC docking was configured

Required parameters

NameTypeRequired valueDescription
ext_loc_docking_enabledInt1Enable docking
0 = Disabled
1 = Enabled
ext_loc_docking_versionInt2Data matrix code (DMC) Docking version.
1 = Version 1 (V1)
2 = Version 2 (V2)
ext_loc_stop_point_enabledInt1Stop point is given in data matrix coordinates for sensor (X-position) instead of driving to route end position. Needs to be enabled with DMC docking.
0 = Disabled
1 = Enabled
ext_loc_for_pos_ctrl_modeInt1-3External localization used directly for position control (e.g. in case of line following)
0 = disabled
1 = using only one sensor
2 = using two sensors when applicable
3 = require always two sensors (Navitrol 6.32 onwards)
ext_loc_max_dist_since_last_measFloat0.01 - 1.0Maximum travelled distance since last valid measurement when inside external localization area
ext_loc_check_path_ready_distFloat0.01 - 0.2Distance from stop point inside of which the stopping check starts. After drive is ready and before next stop can be checked, a measurement must be outside of this distance from stop value.
ext_loc_strict_max_dist_since_last_measFloat0.01 - 0.5Maximum distance in meters since last valid measurement when data matrix following is active and the AGV inside "Check path ready dist"
ext_loc_path_ready_max_dist_errFloat0.0001 - 0.2Max distance between PGV measurement and stop point to determine drive to be instantly ready at the start of new drive order.
ext_loc_docking_max_h_err_degFloat0.5 - 180.0Maximum heading error in degrees to the target heading when data matrix line follow is active
CANOpen Communication parameters
pgv_enabledUint1PGV sensor enabled (CAN only)
pgv_can_node_id[0...3]Int1-127CAN node ID of camera
pgv_model[0...3]Int00 = default
1 = safePGV

Optional parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
ext_loc_x_offset[0...3]Float0.0Nominal X offset from the navigation point to sensor in machine coordinate system, positive forwards
ext_loc_y_offset[0...3]Float0.0Nominal Y offset from the navigation point to sensor in machine coordinate system, positive to the left
ext_loc_h_offset_deg[0...3]Float0.0Nominal heading offset between machine coordinate system and sensor coordinate system, positive CCW
pgv_x_offset[0...3]Float0.0X-offset in meters from nominal position, only small correction values
pgv_y_offset[0...3]Float0.0Y-offset in meters from nominal position, only small correction values
pgv_angle_offset_deg[0...3]Float0.0Angle offset in degrees from nominal heading
ext_loc_pos_ctrl_dist_err_onlyInt0Position control option to use only distance error from line, when just one sensor is reading the data matrix. Intended for non-omni type vehicles that have sensor(s) outside of navigation point (Navitrol 6.32 onwards).
ext_loc_heading_filt_alphaFloat1.0Filtering gain for heading measurement from sensor (0.1 -- 1.0)
ext_loc_pid_heading_pFloat0.0Position control gain for heading when external localization is active
<= 0.1 use normal pc_pid values<br>> 0.1 use this parameter
ext_loc_pid_dist_pFloat0.0Position control gain for distance when external localization is active
<= 0.1 use normal pc_pid values<br>> 0.1 use this parameter
ext_loc_stop_distance_offsetFloat0.0Additional offset for stopping (pc_stop_distance_offset in general use) on data matrix. Positive value if the AGV stops too early.
ext_loc_stop_point_min_agv_dist_from_spFloat0.5AGV needs to be within this distance from the target symbolic point to start checking for the stop point
pgv_max_missing_msgInt5Number of missing messages for error to be triggered (Ethernet only)
pgv_cam_res_xFloat0.0001The x-axis resolution of the PGV cameras in meters
pgv_cam_res_yFloat0.0001The y-axis resolution of the PGV cameras in meters
pgv_cam_res_hFloat0.1The heading resolution (deg) of the PGV cameras
Ethernet Communication parameters if CanOpen not used
ext_loc_eth_model[0...3]Int-1Linefollowing config for ethernet comms
-1 = disabled
0 = PGV
ext_loc_eth_protocol[0...3]Int21 = Stream
2 = DGRAM
ext_loc_eth_port[0...3]Int5333Linefollowing port
ext_loc_eth_swap_bytesInt00 = little endian
1 = big endian

Example parameters to get started for two PGV (CAN Open) cameras

ParameterValue
I,ext_loc_docking_enabled,1 # Data matrix docking enabled
I,ext_loc_docking_version,2 # Data matrix docking V2 active
I,ext_loc_stop_point_enabled1
F,ext_loc_x_offset[0],0.5
F,ext_loc_y_offset[0],0.0
F,ext_loc_h_offset_deg[0],0.0
F,ext_loc_x_offset[1],-0.5
F,ext_loc_y_offset[1],0.0
F,ext_loc_h_offset_deg[1],0.0
I,ext_loc_for_pos_ctrl_mode,2
F,ext_loc_heading_filt_alpha,0.3
U, pgv_enabled,1
I,pgv_can_node_id[0],3
I,pgv_can_node_id[1],4
F, pgv_x_offset[0],0.0
F,pgv_y_offset[0],0.0
F,pgv_x_offset[1],0.0
F,pgv_y_offset[1],0.0
F,pgv_angle_offset_deg[0],90.0
F,pgv_angle_offset_deg[1],-90.0

How to use

Configuration

In Navithor Tools, symbolic point should be filled with the data matrix tape information. These include

  • Selected symbolic point and approaching segment: The approaching segment needs to be selected for each docking direction separately

    • If you want to dock from different directions relative to symbolic point you must define all these cases separately

  • Docking direction: Forward or Backward. This defines the direction with which the AGV docks the symbolic point.

  • Start point: Starting value defines

    • The first value read from the DMC tape when approaching docking location
    • The last value when leaving docking location the same route.

  • End point: Defines the last value read from the DMC tape when leaving docking location over the docking symbolic point.

  • Stop point (X-coordinate): Stop point will trigger stopping of the AGV. It is incorporated with stopping offsets (pc_stop_distance_offset & ext_loc_stop_distance_offset) for targeting that PGV reading would be close to the stop point value at the end.

  • Sideway offset: The offset in Y direction wrt the AGV forward driving direction. If AGV drives forward normally, the sideway offset is positive to the left. This will offset the center of the camera by this value from the tape. Thus, a positive sideway offset will drive the AGV to the left side from the route heading.

  • Heading offset: Defines the heading offset with which to drive the DMC tape. Allowed range [-10, 10] degrees. Positive heading offset will drive the AGV rotated to counter-clockwise direction. Offsets should be kept small.

  • Primary Camera: The index of the primary camera used for DMC position control and for stopping to the defined X-coordinate Stop-point. Primary camera index needs to be always defined as the AGV is stopped based on the primary camera to the defined stopping point.

    • Indexes match to parameters:
      • PGV:s defined with CanOpen: pgv_can_node_id[index]
      • PGV:s defined with Ethernet communication: ext_loc_eth_model[index]

  • Secondary Camera: Defines the index of the secondary camera used for DMC position control. Only used for Y-directional (perpendicular direction with respect to the DMC line) and heading corrections.

Docking configuration

DMC line configuration for symbolic point on Navithor Tools

Logic and error detection

Main logic

When the AGV is approaching the symbolic point that has data matrix values defined, it will change the driving reference point from route to data matrix line as soon as following conditions are met:

  • PGV:s primary X-measurement is between defined start and end point.

    • If parameter ext_loc_for_pos_ctrl_mode is set to 3, then both primary and secondary camera X-measurements need to be between start and end point.

  • Distance along the route between the AGV and symbolic point is less than data matrix length + small tolerance (0.4m)

  • Heading of the AGV relative to the tape is close enough to the target heading (parameter ext_loc_docking_max_h_err_deg).

Once the AGV changes to follow data matrix line, it will not switch to follow route in the same drive order anymore.

The AGV starts to calculate when to stop after the primary PGV X-measurement is closer than "Check path ready dist" from the stop point value. Trigger to stop, as mentioned, is determined by the primary PGV X-measurement and stopping offsets.

After finishing the stop and executing possible tasks at the location, the AGV will be given a drive order away from the symbolic point. The AGV will be following the data matrix line until primary camera measurements are between start and end point (If both PGV cameras required, then data matrix line following is stopped when either of the cameras are outside start or end point values).

Navitrol Monitor can visualize the active data matrix line by opening a form Navitrol >> Data Matrix Docking V2. In addition, when DMC docking is activated, the primary PGV camera measurements are shown in green and secondary camera measurements in orange.

Docking to symbolic point 2 backwards using camera indices 0 and 1

Docking to symbolic point 2 forwards using camera indices 2 and 3

Error detection

As it is desired to drive to the data matrix stop point accurately, it will be constantly supervised that the AGV is receiving valid PGV measurements while approaching or leaving the symbolic points.

  1. Approaching the symbolic point

  • The AGV must get at least one valid PGV measurement before it is closer than "Check path ready dist" from symbolic point, otherwise error ERROR_EXT_LOC_NOT_SAFE_TO_DRIVE is triggered.

  • After getting first valid measurement and changing to data matrix line follow, it is checked that the AGV does not travel without valid measurement for more than ext_loc_max_dist_since_last_meas while outside "Check path ready dist" from the symbolic point. Otherwise error EXT_LOC_TOO_LONG_SINCE_VALID_MEASUREMENT is triggered. Note: If AGV stops to this error at very start of data matrix line, it is likely that the heading validation has failed.

  • While inside "Check path ready dist" from symbolic point, a stricter limit is used ext_loc_strict_max_dist_since_last_meas.

  1. Leaving the symbolic point

  • The AGV must get valid PGV measurements also when leaving the symbolic point while inside active DMC line start and end value. Otherwise error ERROR_EXT_LOC_TOO_LONG_SINCE_MEASUREMENT is triggered.

    • Parameter ext_loc_strict_max_dist_since_last_meas will be used for error detection within "Check path ready dist" from the symbolic point.
    • After that parameter ext_loc_max_dist_since_last_meas is used for measurement validation

  • After the primary camera PGV X-measurements are outside of start and end values of active DMC line, the AGV will change to route following.

  1. After software reboot

    • If the AGV is closer than "Check path ready dist" from the symbolic point that is target for a new drive order (or there is some other ambiguity from which direction the AGV is approaching the stop point), it will be checked whether the drive is ok to be ready.

      i. Drive is ready if PGV X-measurement is closer than ext_loc_path_ready_max_dist_err from the stop point.

      ii. Error ERROR_EXT_LOC_NOT_SAFE_TO_DRIVE will be triggered if the first condition is not true

Troubleshooting

  • Data matrix Docking does not start even though PGV gets readings from the tape when close to symbolic point

    • Check that your camera parameters are correct. Typical issue is that heading of the camera is wrong and a sanity check rejects the measurement (ext_loc_docking_max_h_err_deg).

    • From Navitrol 6.48 onwards there is a possibility to show the PGV positions in Navitrol Monitor.

    • Check that the camera parameters for the position and for the connection have the same index. In other words, the measurements come from the correct camera.

    • Check that the Data matrix docking has been configured to the symbolic point and for the correct driving direction.

  • ERROR_EXT_LOC_TOO_LONG_SINCE_MEASUREMENT is shown

    • The data matrix docking is active and PGV camera should be able to read the QR code but PGV has not received any valid measurements. The Error is triggered after the AGV has travelled distance longer than ext_loc_max_dist_since_last_meas without valid measurements (when close to symbolic point using the ext_loc_strict_max_dist_since_last_meas value when defined).

    • Check what is the reason for not receiving measurements from the PGV. For example, is the tape damaged or is the PGV camera too far away from the tape.

    • To get AGV out of the error situation, move the AGV manually to route point that is out of the the data matrix.

  • AGV does not drive accurately enough on the data matrix tape

    • View the performance of the AGV by opening the graphs from the upper left corner 'Show Graphs' of the Data Matrix Code Docking V2 window.

    • Verify that the target offsets are set correctly.

    • Check the calibration of the PGV camera pose.

    • Tune the position control gains (pc_pid_dist_p, pc_pid_heading_p / ext_loc_pid_heading_p, ext_loc_pid_dist_p).

    • Slow down the AGV's speed if possible.

    • Correct the stop position with stop offset (pc_stop_distance_offset / ext_loc_stop_distance_offset).

    Graphs show the lateral position and heading of the AGV on the data matrix line.

Note! Some of the errors are persistent. Put the AGV to Manual state and possibly drive away from the error location. Turn off the Manual state and wait for the error to be cleared.

Appendix

Ethernet communication protocol

Please refer to External localization document for configuring PGV cameras for Etherner communication protocol

External localization - ethernet communication protocol

Docking

Updated 25.06.2024

Overview

Docking allows for deviating from the nominal route to align the AGV to the target by creating a new route. If docking is not enabled, then the AGV will only drive on the route until it reaches the Symbolic point.

Introduction

Docking can be for example used with a forklift AGV to align the fork tips with the pockets of a EUR-pallet for more precise pick-up, allowing the position and heading of the pallet to deviate from the symbolic point.

Dependencies

The source for the docking pose can be any of the following.

  • Target detection:
    • Pallet detection
    • Pattern detection
    • 3D load detection
    • Table detection
    • External target detection

Setup

Quick start

Required parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
docking_to_target_enabledInt01 = Enables docking to target. 2 = docking with custom route. If target_detection_type_selection = 0, won't do anything.
docking_stop_distanceFloat0.5Defines how close to the target vehicle tries to drive (calculated from navigation point to target).
docking_approach_distFloat1.25After this distance vehicle stops, if the approach error is too big.

Fine-tuning

Optional parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
docking_max_start_distanceFloat3.5Beyond maximum distance docking won't be triggered.
docking_max_start_angleFloat15.0Maximum angle difference from navigation point to the target compared to tarjectory's end point's heading, when starting to dock [+-degrees fov].
docking_max_start_headingFloat5.0Maximum angle diff for vehicle heading and trajectory's end point heading, when starting to dock [+-degrees fov].
docking_max_dist_error_from_end_pointFloat0.5Maximum distance difference for the stopping point compared to the symbolic point.
docking_max_target_angleFloat15.0Maximum difference between target and end point's headings.
docking_y_offsetFloat0.0Offset in y-coordinate for docking (in machine coordinates).
docking_approach_max_dist_errFloat0.1If distance error is bigger than this in approach area, vehicle stops.
docking_approach_max_h_err_degFloat5.0If heading error is bigger than this [deg] in approach area, vehicle stops.
docking_allow_maneuverInt0If errors are too high on approach, 0 = stop the machine, 1 = try to maneuver back and forward.
docking_small_gains_distFloat0.5The distance before stopping where curvature is limited with docking_limit_curv_on_approach.
docking_limit_corr_distFloat0.5The distance before stopping which is driven only with odometry. Location correction disabled or limited with docking_max_xy_corr and docking_max_h_corr.
docking_small_gainsInt1Enables curvature limit that uses docking_limit_curv_on_approach and docking_limit_curv_on_approach_dist.
docking_max_xy_corrFloat0.0001Maximum XY-corrections while approaching target.
docking_max_h_corrFloat0.003Maximum heading corrections [deg] while approaching target.
docking_limit_curv_on_approachFloat0.1Fraction to limit the calculated curvature. For example, 0.1 means that the curvature is 10% from the calculated value.
docking_limit_curv_on_leaveFloat0.05Fraction to limit the calculated curvature. For example, 0.05 means that the curvature is 5% from the calculated value. Used only when docking_leave_unload_loc_straight is set to 1.
docking_limit_drive_vector_angle_change_on_leaveFloat0.01Fraction to limit the drive vector angle change when leaving a docking situation. For example, 0.05 means that the drive vector change is 5% from the calculated value. Used only when docking_leave_unload_loc_straight is set to 1.
docking_dist_gainFloat1.0Factor for the position control distance gain when docking. 0 = use pc_pid_dist_p.
docking_heading_gainFloat1.0Factor for the position control heading gain when docking. 0 = use pc_pid_heading_p.
docking_ref_v_sourceInt0Speed source when doing docking: 0 = calculated from distance to target, 1 = using route velocity value, 2 = use fixed parameter docking_speed.
docking_speedFloat0.3Speed while docking, if docking_ref_v_source == 2. If it is 0, this is minimum starting speed for the docking drive.
docking_limit_leave_speedFloat0.2Limit speed while driving out from docking location, if docking_limit_leave_speed_and_actuator_height_dist > 0. If it is below 0, speed is not limited.
docking_limit_leave_speed_and_actuator_height_distFloat-1.0Distance from the unload location, where the speed is limited to docking_limit_leave_speed and fork height kept at the measured value. If negative, they are not limited. If enabled, must be smaller than docking_mode_to_fleet_control_dist parameter.
docking_leave_unload_loc_straightInt0Enables limit curvature when leaving unload or docking location.
docking_leave_unload_loc_straight_distFloat1.0Limit curvature until this distance from load or unload.
docking_mode_to_fleet_control_distFloat2.5Keep the reported docking mode for fleet control active for this distance after leaving the docking location. The distance is measured from the navigation point position at the end of previous docking to its current position.
docking_notify_approach_distFloat0.5Distance from docking target when a notification is sent to the AGV control.
docking_stopping_point_offset_modeInt00 = Use general stopping offsets, 1 = offsets are defined individually for each pallet model with parameters.
docking_follow_route_propertiesInt1Use defined properties on the route while creating custom route for docking.
docking_refpoint_max_errFloat-0.5Maximum error [m] for the docking point after started docking. Indicate pushing pallet. If negative, not used.
docking_actuator_height_control_modeInt0Defines how lift / fork actuator is controlled in relation to the detected target height during docking. 0 = Disabled, 1 = Direct control. Detected target height is given directly as actuator height reference. 2 = Relative control. Actuator is controlled so that detected height matches value defined by docking_actuator_target_height.
docking_actuator_target_heightFloat0.0Defines the desired target height [m] during docking. Actuator is controlled so that height of the detected target matches this value. Only used when docking_actuator_height_control_mode is set to 2.
docking_actuator_height_strict_distFloat0.0Defines a distance [m] from the docking target point within which actuator height must be on the reference or the drive is stopped.
docking_actuator_height_start_distFloat20.0Defines a distance [m] from the docking target point within which the actuator height control is allowed.
docking_control_point_1_dist_from_machineFloat0.2Minimum required distance for the node straight to the AGV heading. The start node is calculated automatically, but if it is closer to the AGV than this parameter, an error is set. Used to avoid driving too sharp curves.
docking_control_point_2_dist_from_targetFloat0.8Distance for the node to create straight route before target.
docking_allow_custom_route_updateInt00 = custom route is locked after it is created, 1 = custom route is updated if the target changes.
docking_custom_route_min_xy_diffFloat0.02Minimum distance difference [m] between the old pallet and the new to update the last part of the custom route. If set to positive, custom route is updated. Also uses target_detection_max_diff_in_xy_results to check that the difference is not too large.
docking_custom_route_min_angle_diffFloat2.0Minimum angle difference [deg] between the old pallet and the new to update the last part of the custom route. If set to positive, custom route is updated. Also uses target_detection_max_diff_in_angle_results to check that the difference is not too large.
docking_custom_route_max_allowed_xy_diff_for_targetFloat0.2Maximum limit [m] for the custom route update related to the initial target. The custom route is not updated if the new target is further away than this parameter from the initial target (target location when the custom route is created for the first time).
docking_use_route_headingint0Defines how the docking end heading is selected. 0 = Detected heading of the target is used requiring more space for manouvering. 1 = Route heading is used allowing a heading offset to the target. Only used when docking_to_target_enabled = 1.
Designed to be used in narrow corridors with large AGV:s.
When the route heading is used the nominal route from the docking start point forwards must be exactly straight.
Note: Replaces detected target heading with current trajectory point heading.
Supported only when docking_to_target_enabled = 1.
docking_approach_warning_to_error_timeout_sint-1Defines a time [s] after which the WARNING_TARGET_APPROACH_ERROR activates ERROR_DOCKING_FAILED.
-1 = Never.
It is recommended to set this to suitable value so that failed docking attempt becomes clearly visible as an error.
docking_with_only_distance_control_enabledint0Enables docking to target with only distance control. docking_to_target_enabled must be 1 for this parameter to have effect.

The docking is started when:

  • AGV is within the docking_max_start_distance to Symbolic point the target is found

  • Pallet heading is inside docking_max_start_angle (related to symbolic point)

  • AGV heading is inside docking_max_start_heading (related to symbolic point)

  • AGV is driving to same direction as the trajectory end.

  • Target is within docking_max_dist_error_from_end_point distance from symbolic point

  • There are no pivot points or direction changes on the active path between AGV and the target symbolic point

These start condition parameters are explained with pictures down below.

The docking target points is calculated from the middle point from the front line. It can be changed with these parameters:

F,docking_stop_distance, 0.50 # Defines how close to the target vehicle tries to drive (calculated from navigation point to target)

F,docking_y_offset, 0.0 # Offset in y-coordinate for docking (in machine coordinates)

NOTE! The y-offset is not needed in normal use if the scanner is calibrated correctly. It is useful for example for AGV that has to always drive to the side. For example, if the pallet is weighted or the forks are on the side of the AGV.

Offsets. The small red circle is the middle of the target. The docking_stop_distance and docking_y_offset is calculated from that location to get the target where the AGV will drive (blue dot). The coordinate shows what direction the offsets are calculated related to the small red circle.

If both parameters are zero, the target will be on the middle of the front line (the small red circle on the picture above). This red circle is not normally drawn on Monitor, but used here only for explanation. The offsets are calculated always related to the navigation point and its coordinates. The positive x is forward to the forward driving direction and positive y is left-hand side (see the coordinates on the picture).
