On this picture, the AGV is driving backwards, that's why the offsets are calculated on this direction.

These two parameters are general for all models. If there is a need to define different offsets for certain model, they can be set with these model-based parameters. These model-based parameters are used instead if parameter docking_stopping_point_offset_mode is set to 1.

F,pallet_model_y_offset[0], 0.0 # Offset in y-coordinate for docking (in machine coordinates)

F,pallet_model_stop_distance[0], 0.0 # Defines how close to the target vehicle tries to drive (calculated from navigation point to target)

Docking_max_start_distance is calculated as linear distance.

Angle difference between symbolic point heading and angle from a line calculated from navigation point to the symbolic point has to be within limit of docking_max_start_angle.

Angle difference between symbolic point's and AGV's headings has to be withing limits of docking_max_start_heading.

Angle difference between target angle and symbolic point's heading has to be within limits of docking_max_target_angle.

Distance error between symbolic point and the calculated stopping point has to be inside limit of docking_max_dist_error_from_end_point.

Recommended docking mode for kinematic type

With non-omnidirectional AGVs, such as steer and diff drives, custom route docking should be preferred.

  • If the error to the path is large when the docking starts, the position controller might start oscillating, which would decrease docking accuracy.

  • Custom routes are smoother to drive.

With omni drive both modes work well, so it is a preference question

  • Driving the straight path allows correcting the position faster and position can be still corrected while driving.

  • Custom route is smoother but requires more space.

Normal docking

Normal docking (docking_to_target_enabled = 1) updates the reference point (green point on the pictures below) to the straight line from the target and to AGV navigation point. Recommended to be used with omni.

The target is locked when the AGV is at the distance of pallet_det_2_min_dist_from_nav_point_to_traj_end from the end point. After that distance, the reference point is not updated.

Normal docking with steer or diff

One downside with normal docking with steer or differential is that the position correction is done based on heading and distance gains (pc_pid_dist_p and pc_pid_heading or docking_dist_gain and docking_heading_gain). This might cause issues, because these kinematic types can't follow large changes on reference point very fast.

The green reference point is created to straight line from the target. The blue point is the target.

The AGV starts to control itself to the reference point based on pid heading and distance gains. With steer type AGV, the heading correction cannot be done very fast.

There might be some error at the end with steer type AGV, because it requires much space to get the heading correct.

Normal docking with mechanum or omni

With omni or mechanum kinematic types, the normal docking is recommended, because these types allow the AGV to correct its position quickly to the reference point. The next four Figures shows one example where the mechanum is driven under table. Then the next four Figures shows more extreme example drive with mechanum. This is quite extreme case, but the idea is just to show the difference related to the steer type AGV and how fast the position can be corrected. This kind of situation would even not be possible in every location, because the angle difference is so high and it makes the AGV to drive quite far from the route.

Normal example with mechanum.

Now the AGV has driven close to the reference point.

AGV will drive closer to the pallet.

AGV arrives at target.

This is extreme example with mechanum AGV. This shows where the reference point can go if the pallet angle is not ideal.

The mechanum and omni AGVs can start driving immediately to the reference point.

Then the AGV can just drive straight to the target.

Docking with custom route

In this mode (docking_to_target_enabled == 2), the custom route is created from the AGV position to target. It is created based on five nodes. The nodes are created to these locations.

  1. AGV navigation point.

  2. AGV heading direction to line that goes through target and node 3. See Figure down below.

  3. Straight to the target angle (see black dashed line on Figure down below) and docking_control_point_2_dist_from_target distance.

  4. Same as 3, but to the half distance from target.

  5. Target x + docking_stop_distance and target y + docking_y_offset.

The 2nd node distance (blue arrow) is the smallest distance from the line that goes to target heading to navigation point (black arrow). Here the black and blue arrow has the same length, but blue just indicates the direction where the node is created. The node is created to AGV heading direction depending on driving direction.

The main advantage for the normal docking is that the straight part to the target can be modified with parameter. That is really useful for steer and differential kinematic types.

By default, the custom route is created only once and it is not updated after that. Even if the target location changes. However, the custom route can be updated during the drive if this parameter is set:

I,docking_allow_custom_route_update, 1

Then the target is locked when the AGV is at the distance of pallet_det_2_min_dist_from_nav_point_to_traj_end from the end point.

NOTE! Custom route cannot be created if the AGV is closer to the target than docking_control_point_1_dist_from_machine + docking_control_point_2_dist_from_target. Otherwise the route would be impossible to create. The control_point_1 parameter is used only to check the minimum distance from the AGV to the 2^nd^ node, but it's not used for calculating the route.

Start of the custom route docking. If the custom route is not allowed to update, this would be the route to the target.

Here the update is allowed, so the last three nodes are moved based on the updated target location. The first two are keep as static, so the AGV would be close to the route.

AGV will continue driving the custom route and updating the target position.

The lock distance is roughly 0.5m, so the target is still update quite late.

AGV at the target.

Docking with only distance control

Docking with only distance control is a docking method in which the angle and sideways offset of a detected target are ignored and the docking is performed by stopping at docking_stop_distance from the target.

Docking with only distance control works similarly to setting a longitudinal offset to a drive order but instead of using constant offset from the original target location, the offset is calculated based on the detected target location.

The feature was designed for docking to a target in narrow spaces where angle and sideways corrections in relation to the target are either not desired or are otherwise not feasible.

Docking with only distance control is a sub feature of docking without a custom route.
As a sub feature of docking without custom route the same parameters can be used with the sub feature as well.

The feature can be enabled with docking_with_only_distance_control_enabled.

Related parameters that can be adjusted:

  • docking_to_target_enabled
  • docking_stop_distance
  • docking_max_dist_error_from_end_point
  • docking_max_start_distance

Docking speed

Adjusting driving speed while docking:

F,docking_ref_v_source, 0

Speed source when doing docking, 0 = calculated from distance to target and linearly decreased (starting speed is current driving speed when docking starts), 1 = using route velocity value, 2 = use fixed parameter docking_speed.

NOTE! With speed source parameter 0, the start speed is quite critical. If for example the docking starts on the curve, the initial start speed can be quite slow already and then the speed is just linearly decreased from that value based on distance.

F,docking_speed, 0.30 (m/s)

Speed while docking, if docking_ref_v_source == 2. If docking_ref_v_source is 0, this defines the minimum start speed for the docking drive.

F, docking_limit_leave_speed, 0.20 (m/s)

Limit speed while driving out from docking location, if docking_limit_leave_speed_and_actuator_height_dist > 0. If it is below 0, speed is not limited.

F, docking_limit_leave_speed_and_actuator_height_dist, -1.0

Distance from the unload location, where the speed is limited to docking_limit_leave_speed and fork height is limited to the measured value. If negative, they are not limited. If enabled, has to be smaller than docking_mode_to_fleet_control_dist parameter.

Actuator height control

Fork and lift actuators can be controlled based on the height measurement from target detection algorithm when approaching the docking position. This requires using target detection method, such as reflector height detection, that provides z coordinate of the target in addition to x and y coordinates.

Feature requires height measurements from the controlled actuator and that the target detection gives height / z coordinate in meters and actuator operation unit is millimeters.

Typically target height based height control is only needed when docking is done while driving on uneven floor or when the target height can vary. On even floor constant approach height defined as route property is typically sufficient.

I,docking_actuator_height_control_mode, 0
Defines how lift / fork actuator is controlled in relation to the detected target height during docking.
0 = Disabled, height actuator is not controlled based on target detection.
1 = Direct control. Detected target height is given directly as actuator height reference. Makes it possible to detect different targets as long as the target detection gives the correct docking height. Requires that detected target height is independent from actuator height control.
2 = Relative control. Actuator is controlled so that detected height matches value defined by docking_actuator_target_height. Makes it possible to dock relatively to target without knowing its exact height and in cases where the target detection measurement changes in relation to the actuator height.

F,docking_actuator_target_height, 0.0
Defines the desired target height [m] during docking. Actuator is controlled so that height of the detected target matches this value. For example if detected target height is 1.5m and the parameter value is set to 1m actuator is lowered 0.5m.
Only used when docking_actuator_height_control_mode is set to 2.
To define correct value for this parameter, first dock manually to desired height, then check the height received from the target detection and set the value to this parameter.

F,docking_actuator_height_start_dist, 20.0
Defines a distance in meters from the docking target point within which the actuator height control is allowed. Should be adjusted if it is not desired to start controlling the actuator height instantly when the docking is started. Must be larger than docking_actuator_height_strict_dist.

F,docking_actuator_height_strict_dist, 0.0
Defines a distance in meters from the docking target point within which the actuator height must be on the reference value or the drive is stopped until measured value reaches the reference. Must be smaller than docking_actuator_height_start_dist.

In case the the actuator control must be limited when leaving the docking location (undocking) use docking_limit_leave_speed_and_actuator_height_dist parameter as described in "Docking speed" chapter.

Limit curvature on approach

Curvature can be limited also when approaching a target in order to prevent any unnecessary heading corrections in the end of the docking.

If the docking to target goes fine, these do not need to be changed from their default values.

I,docking_small_gains, 1

If set to 1, the curvature is limited with docking_limit_curv_on_approach gain within docking_small_gains_dist distance.

F,docking_small_gains_dist, 0.50 (meters)

When AGV is closer than this distance to the target, the curvature is limited.

F,docking_limit_curv_on_approach, 0.1

Limiting gain parameter for maximum curvature, while approaching target. Setting this to 0.0 would mean no curvature is allowed at all. 0.50 would mean half of the normal curvature calculated is still applied.

Limit curvature on leave

In some situations, the AGV should not be allowed to make any heading corrections, after a pallet has been picked up to avoid collisions with pallets or other obstacles nearby the loading location.

  • When the AGV starts driving away, it has to return to the nominal route, which often causes the AGV to turn.

  • This is not a problem, if the pallets are always very close to the expected location, or if there is enough space between the pallets.

While driving away from the load location after using target detection (or after unloading), curvature change can be limited with parameters:

F,docking_limit_curv_on_leave, 0.05

Limiting gain parameter for maximum curvature, while leaving the location. Setting this to 0.0 would mean no curvature is allowed at all. 0.50 would mean half of the normal curvature calculated is still applied.

F,docking_leave_unload_loc_straight_dist, 1.0 (meters)

Curvature is limited until the AGV has driven further away from the target detection location than the distance defined by this parameter. (Even though it says unload_loc, the parameter has multiple uses).

I,docking_leave_unload_loc_straight, 0

Limit curvature after unloading, if set to 1. Parameters above are applied also for this case.

This feature works even without pallet detection being enabled.

Without limiting the curvature, AGV just drives straight back to the route.

AGV is back on the route.

When limiting curvature, AGV will drive straight for certain distance before returning back to route.

Adjusting position correction

In some cases, driving under target blocks the sight of the scanner or scanners in a way that it affects the localization causing unnecessary peaks in the scanner corrections. This can be limited by applying more strict maximum values for corrections, while close to the target:

F,docking_limit_corr_dist, 0.50

When AGV is closer to the target than the distance defined by this parameter, docking_max_xy and h_corr are used.

F, docking_max_xy_corr, 0.0001

Max loc xy corr while approaching target.

F, docking_max_h_corr, 0.003

Max loc h corr while approaching target.

If both parameters are set to 0, scanner correction is disabled and the AGV drives this distance based on odometry alone.

Parameters described down below have more effect when using normal docking, as custom route should usually work with the normal PID values. Use different position controller values while docking:

F,docking_dist_gain, 1.0

Dist gain while docking, 0 = use standard pc_pid_dist_p

F,docking_heading_gain, 1.0

Heading gain while docking, 0 = use standard pc_pid_heading_p

These are gain parameters, that scale the standard position controller values, so using value 1.0 mean that normal correction values are used.

Values over 1.0 strengthen the distance or heading correction and lower value lessens the correction.

Distance gain

If the AGV does not correct the position to the path fast enough, dist gain should be increased - Increasing too much causes oscillation.

If position controller is unstable, dist gain should be lowered.

Heading gain

If the AGV does not keep the correct heading when under the pallet, heading gain should be increased.

Troubleshooting

Errors and warnings

569 ERROR_DOCKING_FAILED

This error indicates that the docking has failed in a way that a manual intervention is required.

For example this error is set after the WARNING_TARGET_APPROACH_ERROR has been active for longer than docking_approach_warning_to_error_timeout_s.

How to recover:
See the automatically taken log for more details and resolve the docking situation and the error reason manually. Release the fatal error and retry docking from the beginning.

613 WARNING_TARGET_APPROACH_ERROR

This warning is given in various situations:

When AGV is within docking_max_start_distance from the target but the distance or angle error between the detected target and the expected target location exceeds the limits defined by docking_max_dist_error_from_end_point or docking_max_target_angle.

When AGV is within docking_approach_dist from the target and either the target is not found, is lost or the heading or distance of the calculated docking position compared to the original drive end position would exceed the limits defined by docking_approach_max_h_err or docking_approach_max_dist_err.

This warning always pauses the docking but if the issue causing it is resolved, the docking continues.

By default the docking can be paused indefinitely with only the warning being visible. To set an error to notify the operator for the need of manual intervention see docking_approach_warning_to_error_timeout_s.

How to recover:
Check the reason for the warning from the log, adjust the target location or parameters accordingly and try again.

612 WARNING_TARGET_NOT_DETECTED

This warning is set if the target is lost when the AGV is within docking_max_start_distance from the target. If the target is detected again, the warning disappears and the docking process continues.

How to recover:
Check that the correct target is placed into a correct location and that the target detection parameters are calibrated correctly.

Driving Options

Updated 26.01.2024

Overview

The purpose of this document is to give reader an overview of the different alternatives that exist for driving the AGV. There is a vast variety of different tools and interfaces from which the vehicle can be commanded to drive. This is to ensure that there are enough options to cover the needs of different productions, and to provide effective tools for calibration and testing. To achieve smooth and accurate driving, there are also some tips on how to affect the driving performance.

Driving manually

Manual driving refers to the cases where the reference values given to the AGV are coming from a manual source rather than from a predefined trajectory. It is needed for different purposes, e.g., teaching the environment, initial calibrations and driving vehicle out of production for maintenance. Navitrol provides a few different ways to handle this.

Web interface

Web interface gives a joystick-like control for manual driving. The user can type the IP address of the ethernet port in IPC to a browser e.g., in mobile phone and open the user interface. See more information of the Web interface in its own document.

Navitrol - WebInterface Instructions

Keyboard control

Keyboard control can be used in Navitrol Monitor. It can be enabled from the Navitrol selection (See Figure 1) or by holding Shift-key whereafter the arrow keys are used to set the reference values. In some situations, this may not offer enough degree of freedom to accurately perform a certain driving sequence. Thus, keyboard control is usually used only for initial calibration and testing. For more information, see the document Navitrol Monitor - User Instructions.

Figure 1: Keyboard control

Ethernet Interface

The ethernet interface gives customers the freedom to use their owndevice to control the vehicle manually through Navitrol. There are two Supervisor status message sections that are offered: Remote control section and Manual section. The definition for these can be found in the Ethernet Communication specification between Navitrol and AGV supervisor document.

The remote-control section allows user to have the same joystick-like control as the previously mentioned Web interface and relies on the same parameters.

Manual section gives a keyboard-like control, so driving forward, backward, turning left and turning right. The speed can be set in the message itself while the turning rate is defined using parameters:

F,veh_inte_manual_ang_vel 0.785 # turning rate in radians per second F,max_turn_rate_deg_p_s 30.00 # maximum limit for turning rate (deg/s)

Driving automatically

In automatic driving mode, the vehicle follows a virtual route to a target location and a map must be defined for the AGV to be able to localize itself. There are multiple sources that can initiate the driving, but this document mainly concentrates on the Navitrol Monitor software which is the main tool when taking new vehicles into use.

Overview of driving commands

As mentioned before, there are many ways to command vehicle to start automatic driving. Table 1 briefly describes all the current drive command options.

Table 1: Different types of drive commands

Navitrol MonitorDescription
Route driverClick the target symbolic point or use Hold-Release functionality. The vehicle plans the route automatically.
Production SimulationSelect a driving path on the route or add multiple targets and do production demos.
Custom routeGive a custom route to the vehicle.
Return to routeDrive the vehicle to a route close by automatically.
Navithor fleet control
GotoXYClick on a target on the route or at a symbolic point using Navithor Client.
Resource-based triggeringResource added to a symbolic point triggers a drive order for one of the enabled vehicles.
Transfer requestPickup location, target location and resource type are sent to Navithor
Hold, ReleaseVehicle is released from current location where it is in Hold to the next desired target location by a timer or external input.
Production order listsSimilar to Hold-Release but the destinations the vehicle drives are given in one or several lists
Standalone / (fleet control)
Supervisor -- Go to destinationExternal system on vehicle gives drive command to a symbolic point.
Supervisor -- Hold, ReleaseExternal system releases vehicle from a symbolic point where it is in Hold to another symbolic point.
Supervisor -- Start new drive / Extend driveExternal system on vehicle sends trajectories for the vehicle to drive.
Supervisor -- Return to routeDrive vehicle to a route close by automatically.
Supervisor -- Drive order from segmentsExternal system gives drive orders in segments parsed from the segment file created with Navithor Tools.
Touch screen -- Hold, ReleaseThe user releases the vehicle from a symbolic point where it is in Hold to another location using Navitec's Touch screen solution.

Different driving motions

By default, the vehicle follows the route with one continuous motion so that the heading of the vehicle follows the tangent of the route. This section provides a few alternatives for increased flexibility of the AGV motion.

Pivot point

Most of the AGVs can rotate around their navigation point which often is useful in compact spaces. In Navitec's products, these are called as pivot points and they can be added when defining the routes for the project in Navithor Tools. The vehicle will slow down before it stops at a pivot point, to then start rotating around its axis to the heading of the subsequent route.

Figure 2: Driving through a pivot point

Wheel turning point

Wheel turning points are special pivot points that are available for omnidirectional AGVs. The difference between a pivot point and a wheel turning point is that the AGV frame can't turn on a wheel turning point. The AGV stops on a wheel turning point. Turns the wheels to the driving direction and continues the when the wheels point to the correct direction.

Direction change

A direction change means that the sign of velocity in the route changes. A simple example is that vehicle drives first in forward direction, stops at the direction change point and then continues driving in reverse (see Figure 3). In similarity to pivot points, the vehicle will slow down before the direction change to stop more accurately. A short stop during the direction change is defined by the parameter pc_direction_change_wait_ms with the purpose to let the motor controllers stabilize before changing the direction. Vehicles which have steered wheels will also wait for the wheels to reach an acceptable angle before giving a speed reference.

Figure 3: Direction change motion

Omni driving

For vehicles with omni directional capabilities, where the frame heading is not tangent to the direction of motion, additional options are available. Route sections can be defined to be driven with a certain frame heading with respect to the map coordinates. For example, in Figure 4 the vehicle drives in and out of pivot point maintaining the same orientation during the whole motion. Only the wheels of the vehicle are steered 90 degrees on the pivot point to move the vehicle accordingly.

Figure 4: Omni driving in a pivot point. Vehicle maintains its orientation.

Standalone Feature

Updated 13.09.2024

Introduction

The standalone Navitrol, as the name suggests, means that Navitrol works independently of any fleet controller that would otherwise keep track of the AGV and get the production tasks done. In this case Navitrol is still dependant on an external source to provide it with the commands and directions to perform the tasks. Navitrol provides many of the features that are available if used with Navithor, the Navitec's fleet control software, but not all. The standalone version of Navitrol is feasible for the case where the user wants to have full control over the tasks performed by the AGV and wants to command the AGV at every step of the production using the AGV's onboard PLC. Navitrol calculates the routes to target destination itself in standalone mode whereas when connected with the fleet controller, the route segments are specified by the fleet controller. This gives Navitrol the capability to drive to any specified location independently.

Standalone Navitrol is also suitable for use in the cases where there is no need to a coordinating fleet controller. Such cases are not limited to but include the assembly line or single AGV production scenarios.

Licenses required

The IPC that hosts and runs Navitrol should have the correct licenses so that the AGV can drive. The licenses required are Route driver license along with the license for any additional feature that is needed and is enabled only if a valid license is available.

Basic requirements for standalone Navitrol

The basic requirement is that Navitrol can receive the commands for driving the AGV i.e. the drive orders. The external drive orders can be recieved via ethernet interface connected to a supervisor which, in most cases, is a PLC. The supervisor interface specifies the message formats and the protocol specifications. The messages that can be used to drive the AGV are given in section 1.2.2.

Route Driver

The Navitrol route driver must be enabled in the Navitrol parameter file by setting the following parameter

I,route_driver_enabled, 1 # 1 to enable route driver; min 0, max 1

Since the fleet control will not be used in the case of standalone Navitrol, it is better to set fleet_control_enabled as 0 to disable the fleet control in standalone mode.

Messages to drive the AGV

Navitrol will need to be commanded to perform the driving tasks using, for example, the following non-exhaustive list of supervisor messages:

Message ID 1001 - Initialize position

Used to initialize position at a certain location.

Message ID 1002 - Initialize position at symbolic point

Used to initialize the position at a certain symbolic point.

Message ID 3001 - Release Hold

When Navitrol drives the AGV to a certain symbolic point then it goes to hold state. It can then be released from the hold state using the 'release hold' message which triggers the AGV to drive to the selected destination.

Message ID 3004 - Release hold to custom destination

In the case that the AGV is to be driven to a certain destination and is in hold state then it can be released using this message where the next destination is specified. This message is then acknowledged by Navitrol using message ID 3104.

Message ID 3005 - Go to destination

When the AGV is to be driven to any of the defined symbolic points then this message can be sent to Navitrol by the supervisor. This message always specifies the ID of the symbolic point to be driven to.

Message ID 3006 - Pause drive

Used to pause the current drive order being executed by Navitrol.

Message ID 3007 - Resume drive

Navitrol resumes a previously paused drive when this message is received.

Message ID 3008 - Abort drive

The current drive being executed will be aborted upon reception of this message.

Please see the document titled 'Ethernet Communication specification between Navitrol and AGV supervisor' for the details regarding the above messages. The above list of messages is not exhaustive.

Message ID 3102, Section 2 - Hold section

Tells whether AGV is in Hold and the defined possible destinations to release the AGV.

Destination update

By default drive commands from supervisor (e.g. Go to destination - 3005) are accepted only when AGV is in STANDBY state. With the destination update feature it is also possible to update drive destination during AUTO driving. Destination update feature can be enabled by setting following parameter:

I, route_driver_dest_update_enabled, 1 # Enables option of updating destination during drive

When destination update is enabled, drive commands during driving will be processed as destination update commands. Route driver will plan for a new route to updated destination. New route is accepted only if it can be continued from AGV's position and driving direction. If appropriate route is not found, drive command will be rejected and AGV will stop driving.

Driving distance of AGV during route planning for destination update can be limited using parameter:

F, route_driver_dest_update_stop_dist, 0.0 # Maximum distance [m] to drive when planning route for destination update during drive. No stopping if zero.

Hold-release production in standalone mode

Hold-release feature offers easy configuration for simple production logic like assembly lines. AGV drives from one symbolic point to another and it is held until released to next given location. Please note that hold-release is different feature than stop-and-hold where AGV stops and waits for a release to continue the drive.

The routes and symbolic points have to be defined in the Navithor Tools project for Navitrol's standalone production. Then, the AGV can be commanded via the supervisor interface or via the Navitrol Monitor's 'Standalone' form opened with the 'Drive Orders' button to drive to a specific symbolic point.

As the AGV arrives at the symbolic point, Navitrol goes into 'Hold' state and can be released using one of the messages which will trigger the AGV to drive to the selected destination. When the release is requested using message ID 3001, then Navitrol will release the AGV and command it to drive to the default symbolic point or to one of the three alternatives, possible to define in Navithor Tools. This is also shown in the figure below.

The highlighted symbolic point at the right end of the example route is of type Stop and is named 'Body and assembly' for this example. On the pane onto the left of the figure, the characteristics of the selected symbolic point are shown. The first checkbox is checked to enable the hold state at the symbolic point. The release timer can be set by checking the 'Release after' checkbox and then setting a value for the release timer. This value is in seconds. Then comes the default destination followed by the three optional or alternate destinations that can be set for any symbolic point.

The message ID 3004 also offers the possibility to define a specific symbolic point ID to drive to irrespective of what has been defined in the Navithor Tools.

Stop-and-hold

Updated 26.01.2024

Overview

Introduction

Stop-and-hold is a feature for stopping the AGV to a defined location to wait for a trigger to advance on the same drive order. There could be for example a gate in front of a pick-up location and the AGV must wait behind the gate until the path is free, after which it is triggered to advance the drive.

Please note that this is a different feature than hold-release production logic where the AGV goes to 'Hold' state when entering a symbolic point and can be released to drive to some other symbolic point. More information on hold-release can be found in Standalone document.

Requirements

Project settings:

  • Symbolic point with StopAndHold type

Set up

Quick start

  1. Define a symbolic point that is of StopAndHold type somewhere on the route that the AGV will drive over.
  2. Set I, stop_and_hold_mode, 0 (triggered with timer) and I, stop_and_hold_moving_delay_msec, 3000
  3. Give drive order for the AGV so that the end location is somewhere ahead of the StopAndHold location.
  4. AGV should stop close to the StopAndHold point, wait for 3 seconds and move on to the end location.

Example setting

Required parameters

NameTypeRequired valueDescription
stop_and_hold_modeInt>= 0-1 = ignore all,
0 = release AGV from StopAndHold point with timer,
1 = release signal from supervisor message 3002 section 1,
2 = release signal from fleet control,
3 = release signal from supervisor message 3011

Related parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
stop_and_hold_moving_delay_msecInt2000Delay time in msecs before AGV continues driving from StopAndHold symbolic point
stop_and_hold_stop_distance_offsetInt0.0Stopping distance offset from stop-and-hold point (to positive if AGV stops too early)

How to use

AGV will stop close to StopAndHold symbolic point when it has a drive order which passes the StopAndHold point. The stop point can be fine-tuned with the stop_and_hold_stop_distance_offset parameter. At StopAndHold point, AGV will wait in 'AUTO' state for a release signal to continue the drive. While AGV is stopped, warning WARNING_SLOWED_DOWN_AUTO_MOVE_DELAY will be shown.

Release signals to continue the drive

  • Timer: Set stop_and_hold_mode, 0 and adjust the waiting time with stop_and_hold_moving_delay_msec
  • Supervisor interface: There are two different messages that can be used to give release signal. Supervisor message 3002 section 1 or supervisor message 3011 (preferred). Choose with stop_and_hold_mode which one to use. Information whether AGV is held at StopAndHold can be read in status message 3102 section 5.
  • Navithor: Release signal can be given using MES interface ReleaseStopAndHold (ID=362) or using HTTP API (URL: /api/ReleaseStopAndHold). It's also possible to use button in Navithor Client for releasing the AGV. Set stop_and_hold_mode, 2

VDA5050 interface

Updated 26.08.2024

Overview

The VDA5050 interface allows the interoperability of different fleet control systems with the AGV control software. The protocol is based on JSON data serialization format that is sent over MQTT broker. The AGV publishes status, connection and visualization topics and listens to order and instantActions topics. The topics have the following format

uagv/ProtocolVersion/Manufacturer/SerialNumber/topic eg. uagv/v1/Navitec/0001/connection

The AGV control software implements several versions of the VDA5050 protocol for interoperability with different fleetcontrol systems. Only one of these dialects is active at a time.

Unfortunately, the documentation for VDA5050 protocol version 1.012 is no longer available online. The protocol version 2.0 is available at https://github.com/VDA5050/VDA5050/releases/tag/2.0.0 and version 1.1 at https://github.com/VDA5050/VDA5050/blob/1.1.0/VDA5050_EN.md

Prerequisites

  • The VDA5050 interface requires separate license option.
  • The interface has to be enabled in the parameters

Parameters

Parameter nameDefault valueDescription
vdma_version2VDMA version - 0 = v1.01.2, 1 = v1.1, 2 = v.2.0.
vdma_drive_order_type2VDMA dialect - 0 = JSON mapped segment (v.1.01.2), 1 = Segment based dialect (v1.1 and v2.0), 2 = Trajectory based (v1.1 and v2.0).
vdma_host127.0.0.1Hostname or IP of the MQTT broker the VDMA interface should connect to
vdma_port1883The port the MQTT broker for VDMA interface is on
vdma_manufacturerNavitecThe name of the AGV manufacturer for the VDMA interface
vdma_serial_number0001The serial number of the AGV for the VDMA interface
vdma_visualization_interval_ms1000The update interval [ms] for the visualization topic. 0 to disable
vdma_mqtt_passwordPassword for connecting to the MQTT broker
vdma_mqtt_userUsername for connecting to the MQTT broker
vdma_area_name_overrideOverride the area name from map, in case the fleet control uses different name
vdma_interface_nameuagvThe interface name part of the MQTT topics
vdma_topic_override_version0Override the version number part of the MQTT topic name. 0 to use default (no override)
log_dump_vdma_max_files20Maximum number of log files triggered by VDMA to keep on disk.
fleet_control_type00 - No fleet control, 1 - Our own fleet control, 2 - External fleet control, 3 - VD(M)A fleet control
vdma_default_drive_speed_m_p_s2.0In trajectory drive mode, the default drive speed if no drive speed is given
vdma_traj_min_radius_m0.5The turning radius used in the trajectory interpolation (trajectory mode only)
vdma_traj_pt_dist_m0.1How dense the trajectory interpolation is before the spline smoothing is applied
vdma_traj_interpolation_type20 disables the trajectory interpolation (only spline smoothing), 1 uses the Dubins curves, 2 - Linear interpolation (default)
log_vdma_extra01 enables extra logging for debug purposes
vdma_debug_topic_enabled01 publishes extra debug information on the MQTT broker (about the interpolated trajectory)
vdma_actions_check_sp1Require compatible symbol point on the map to perform certain actions (eg. loading) 1 yes, 0 no
vdma_actions_sp_close_dist0.3How close does the symbol point have to be to be accepted (see previous parameter)
vdma_treat_all_loads_as_racks0In the trajectory mode, forces the VDA to treat all load&unload as racks
vdma_ssl_mode10 Disable, 1 use the same parameters as the rest of Navitrol (ssl_enabled, ssl_agv_certificate_file, ssl_agv_key_file, ssl_pem_password, ssl_ca_file, ssl_cipher_list), 2 Enable using separate parameters (vdma_ssl_agv_certificate_file, vdma_ssl_agv_key_file, vdma_ssl_pem_password, vdma_ssl_ca_file, vdma_ssl_cipher_list)
vdma_ssl_agv_certificate_fileThe name of the certificate file to use to identify the AGV. Empty means none.
vdma_ssl_agv_key_fileThe keyfile used by the AGV. Only needed if vdma_ssl_agv_certificate_file is set
vdma_ssl_pem_passwordThe password used to unlock the key file
vdma_ssl_ca_file./agv_certs/root.crtThe root certificate file used to verify the server certificate
vdma_ssl_cipher_listThe list of allowed ciphers. Empty means use default cipher list
vdma_ssl_version2Which TLS version to use. 0 = TLS v1, 1 = TLS v1.1 and 2 = TLS v1.2
vdma_ssl_verify_hostname1Whether the certificate hostname is required to match the actual server hostname. 1 = Yes, 0 = No
vdma_escalate_errors_to_fatal_timeout_s0.0Navitrol errors are first considered 'warnings' until this time passes and then escalated to 'fatal'
vdma_error_reporting_policy00 report only active Navitrol errors, 1 Keep orders that happen during drive order active for longer time
vdma_loadunload_check_load_state1Should vdma load&unload actions check the AGV load state.
vdma_trivially_reach_multiple_nodes1Make the VDA5050 interface treat multiple nodes in the beginning of the order as trivially reachable.
vdma_use_symbolic_points_for_actions0Use virtual symbolic points to implement actions. Currently only used for racking
vdma_pivot_generation_angle_deg30.0Automatically generate pivots if there are sharper corners in the route than this
vdma_rotation_on_edge_margin_points2When rotating on an edge, reach the target orientation this many (linear interpolation) points before the end of the edge. Increase if the AGV doesn't reach the target orientation in time.
vdma_reverse_tolerance_deg90Tolerance for reversing on an edge, in degrees. AGV will reverse when edge has tangential orientation that deviates from PI at most by this margin
vdma_clear_order_when_losing_position1Make the VDA5050 interface clear the order if position is not initialized.
vdma_escalate_errors_to_fatal_timeout_s0.0Timeout for escalating errors to fatal. Navitrol errors are initially reported as 'warnings' and changed to 'fatal' after this time. 0 = disabled (immediately fatal).

v2.0 Navitec trajectory based dialect

How to enable

Set fleet_control_type to 3 and vdma_version to 2 and vdma_drive_order_type to 2. vdma_host and vdma_port should be configured to the address where the fleet control software (or in some cases separate MQTT broker) is running. Navithor has a built-in MQTT broker. If the broker uses username and password to authenticate, those should be set in vdma_mqtt_user and vdma_mqtt_password. In this mode the Navitrol doesn't require a route definition file, but will still require an environment model if Navitrol is responsible for localization.

Description

This is perhaps the most natural version of VDA5050 for use with third party fleet control systems. The drive is based on node coordinates and optionally edge trajectories and node and edge names don't have to encode any special information.

Trajectories on edges

The edge trajectory currently only supports degree 1. It doesn't use any actual NURBS algrithm, but fits a spline to the points internally. The trajectory points can specify orientation as in v1.1 specification, but that may be dropped when the implementation evolves.

rotationAllowed property

The rotation allowed property defaults to 'false' on edges with trajectory (contrary to what the VDA5050 specification says). If you try to specify rotationAllowed property as "true" on an edge with a trajectory, it will cause an error and the drive order will be rejected. We consider the rotationAllowed to be an allowance for the AGV, an option we choose not to exercise in this case. This is because rotating on a curved trajectory would require careful control to make sure the driving is smooth.

Pivot points

To encode a pivot point, use two edges with the "rotationAllowed" property set to false. The AGV will pivot where the edges meet.

Direction changes

The drive direction is determined by the orientation of the previous node or the orientation of the edge. orientationType property can be set to GLOBAL or TANGENTIAL as in v2.0 specification. When the orientation is opposite to route orientation, the AGV will reverse. For the direction change to work, there should be a sharp corner in the route.

Route interpolation

Navitrol will attempt to interpolate between node coordinates if the nodes are far apart. The interpolation is similar to Dubins curve: it contains only circle arcs and straight lines. These are further softened a little bit before driving.

Actuator control

If the AGV has reference controlled actuator, for example a fork lift, the reference base height comes from parameter actuator_home_val_mm (default 0 mm). The actuator has also minimum and maximum height (actuator_min_val && actuator_max_val) defined. A load aboard offset (actuator_load_aboard_offset_mm) is added on top of the base height when the AGV is carrying a load.

There are custom actuator actions supported for the trajectory based dialect called "setActuator" and "releaseActuator". The "setActuator" action can be used to set for example a fork lift height according to a shelf height in a node before the pick/drop node so that the AGV has the fork's at correct height before driving to the shelf location. When the AGV has driven away from the shelf location, another node with "releaseActuator" action can be set to control the forks back to the normal base height i.e. home position.

Additionally pick and setActuator actions can override the actuator_load_aboard_offset_mm, the parameter that determines the difference between the actuator reference height when the AGV is carrying a load and when it is not. This is useful when the AGV is picking up a load that needs to be carried at a different height than the default load aboard offset. Both actions can override this parameter by setting a value for the "loadAboardOffset" parameter. This parameter is valid until the next drop actions. When AGV executes a drop action, the load aboard offset is set back to the default value (i.e., actuator_load_aboard_offset_mm). This feature is implemented in version 6.56.

Important: Navitrol stores actuator reference height for safety, if Navitrol is restarted between the "setActuator" and "releaseActuator" actions. To reset actuator to home position send order with "releaseActuator" action. Alternatively, release the height by moving the actuator manually using Navitec's UI tools (e.g., Actuator control form in Navitrol Monitor). Always drive AGV out from the rack manually before releasing the actuator!

ActionImplemented (Navitrol version)CustomNotes
pickYes (6.38)No
dropYes (6.38)No
setActuatorYes (6.52)YesSet actuator base height at node and keep until released.
Parameter: "height" [m]
releaseActuatorYes (6.52)YesRelease actuator height that was set with "setActuator" action. No parameters.

Pallet detection and docking

Navitrol supports docking to a pallet using action "detectObject" on an edge. Enable docking from parameters docking_to_target_enabled > 0. The node following the edge should be the assumed pick-up location. Set the "allowedDeviationXY" for the node to be large enough as the actual pick-up position will vary based on the position of the pallet. The optional "objectType" parameter can be left out from the message or set to a string "PALLET". Parameters for the pallet detection and docking should be adjusted. Read Pallet detection document to get more information.

There is also optional parameter called "duration" [s] which is a timeout for the action. If the docking has not finished in the specified time, the action will fail. By default there is no timeout for the action. The action will fail if the drive is interrupted on the edge (e.g., error is raised or docking fails for some reason). To reach the next node, it is required that the action finishes succesfully. In case of failure, cancel the current order before giving a new order.

ActionNavitrol versionCustomNotes
detectObject6.54NoEdge action used for docking to a pallet.
action parameters:
"objectType" (string, optional)
"duration" (Integer, optional) [s]

Buffer lanes

Buffer lane is feature that allows to pickup or drop-off loads that are in a queue. To activate the feature, the order must be given to a node with either pick or drop action that has stationType "buffer", and the edge leading to the node must have action "detectObject". The loads are placed in a straight queue on the edge leading to the node.

The length of the buffer lane is determined by the allowed deviation object "allowedDeviationXY" of the node, and the loads should be placed within this length. Navitrol validates that the length is given and reports error with errorType "invalidAction" if it is not. The edge leading to the node should be long enough so that the AGV has time and space to detect the first load on the edge and possibly to dock to it.

There are required parameters that need to be set to use the buffer lane feature itself. Read Buffer lane document for more information. Specifically for VDA-5050, parameter unload_buffer_error_when_lane_full is recommended to be set to 1. This is to detect a failed state when the drop buffer lane is already full of loads.

ActionNavitrol versionCustomNotes
detectObject (edge)
And
pick / drop (node)		6.54NoBuffer lane actions are started on an edge with "detectObject" action that leads to a node with pick/drop action having stationType "buffer".

Block stacking

With block stacking feature the pallets can be either picked from a stack or dropped to a stack. Dropping to the stack always requires also a buffer lane but picking from a stack can be performed without one from a single stack. To enable these features, configure the related parameters with the help of the documentation.

The feature can be activated with an order to a node with pick or drop action that has stationType "stack", and the edge leading to the node must have action "detectObject". To incorporate the block stacking with buffer lane, the stationType should have value "buffer stack".

The action is required to finish on the edge before the node is reached and pick/drop action can be performed. In case the action fails due to any interrupt while doing the block stacking sequence, the order should be cancelled and then new order must be given.

ActionNavitrol versionCustomNotes
detectObject (edge)
And
pick / drop (node)		6.56NoBlock stacking actions are started on an edge with "detectObject" action that leads to a node with pick/drop action having stationType "buffer stack" or "stack" (latter only for pick action).

Factsheet topic

Navitrol supports sending a factsheet topic to the fleet control, as specified in VDA5050 2.0. The data that is sent is currently a fixed base document describing the implementation, but manufacturer specific values can be set in vda_factsheet.json file. This file should be placed in the folder containing the Navitrol executable. The file must contain a JSON object that gets recursively merged with the base values: if a key is present in the object its value will override the value in the base factsheet unless the value is an object in which case it will get merged with the object in the base factsheet using this same recursive strategy. The base factsheet describes the trajectory based VDA5050 dialect, so the sending is automatically disabled if another dialect has been picked. Be careful when editing the factsheet as the values are not checked for standard conformance before sending them to the fleet control. See VDA5050 standard documentation for the structure of factsheet and the possible values.

An example of a vda_factsheet.json that overrides the seriesName property

{
    "typeSpecification": {
        "seriesName": "Exampe of an override value"
    }
}

Navitec trajectory based dialect

How to enable

Set fleet_control_type to 3 and vdma_version to 1 and vdma_drive_order_type to 2. Otherwise the configuration is the same as for the v2.0 Navitec trajectory based dialect

Description

This is very similar to v2.0 Navitec trajectory based dialect except that it sends v1.1.0 as the version number. When receiving v1.1 orders, there are couple of small differences, such as the default value for rotationAllowed property and the coordiate system in which the route orientations are given. Please refer to the protocol specification for details if needed.

Navitec segment ID based dialect

How to enable

Set fleet_control_type to 3 and vdma_version to 1 or 2 and vdma_drive_order_type to 1. vdma_host and vdma_port should be configured to the address where the fleet control software (or in some cases separate MQTT broker) is running. Navithor has a built-in MQTT broker. If the broker uses username and password to authenticate, those should be set in vdma_mqtt_user and vdma_mqtt_password.

Description

This is the first VDA5050 implementation that is interoperable with the Navithor fleet control. The Navitec segment ID based dialect is based on VDA5050 version 1.1. It uses the edge IDs to send the route segments that form the drive order. There are some custom extensions to the protocol that allow things like sending an fstop (which immediately stops the machine) and handling environment and segment files.

Edge and node names

Navitrol doesn't depend on node names in this mode. Edge names should be either just segment IDs or, if there is an internal node in the middle of a segment, segment id followed by colon followed by a number, eg. "2:2"

Map sharing

The VDA5050 interface doesnt at the moment specify how the maps should be shared between fleet control and AGV control software. Navitrol has its own map format for the environment, which is a binary file. The routes are stored in a proprietary XML-based format. Navitrol implements two custom actions in the instantActions topic for the map sharing:

  1. getFileVersions is used to query the environment and route file versions. It takes no parameters and returns a string of the form actionVersion|environmentName|environmentVersion|segmentFileVersion|segmentFileMD5
    • actionVersion is 1 for this implementation
    • environmentName is the first 25 characters of area name, with any possible pipe characters replaced by an underscore; or empty string if no environment file is loaded
    • environmentVersion is the version of the environment file; or 0 if no environment file is loaded
    • segmentFileVersion is the version of the segment file; or 0 if no segment file exists
    • segmentFileMD5 is an md5 hash of the segment file as 32 hexadecimal numbers. All of these are 0 if no segment file is loaded.
  2. The fleet control then decides if it should send new files. Currently these files are sent with SFTP protocol, but it is intended to be replaced in the future. The drawback is that with SFTP the fleet control needs to know the IP of the AGV:s
  3. The fleet control then issues reloadAreaFiles action, which causes Navitrol to read new files in. This action takes no parameters.

Actions

NameImplemented (Navitrol version)CustomNotes
initPositionYes (6.38)NoMapID is the current floor ID
cancelOrderYes (6.38)No
logRequestYes (6.38)NoSaves the log with different name than other triggers
stateRequestYes (6.38)No
startChargingYes (6.38)NoNot tested
stopChargingYes (6.38)NoNot tested
pickYes (6.38)Noparameters not supported yet
dropYes (6.38)Noparameters not supported yet
startPauseYes (6.38)ParamsSupports also F-stop via parameter pauseType: "fstop"
stopPauseYes (6.38)ParamsSupports also F-stop via parameter pauseType: "fstop"
reloadAreaFilesYes (6.38)YesReloads the segment and environment files
getFileVersionsYes (6.38)YesReturn Environment and segment file versions
finePositioningNoNo
detectObjectExperimentalNoSupport is implemented but has not been verified

v1.0 dialect

How to enable

Set fleet_control_type to 3 and vdma_version to 0 and vdma_drive_order_type to 0. vdma_host and vdma_port should be configured to the address where the fleet control software (or in some cases separate MQTT broker) is running. If the broker uses username and password to authenticate, those should be set in vdma_mqtt_user and vdma_mqtt_password. vdma_area_name_override parameter can be set to the environment name that the fleet control is using. If not provided, the environment name is assumed to be the same as the area name in the environment file.

Description

This dialect is based on VDA5050 version 1.012. It uses a JSON configuration file to convert the edge IDs to the segments that form the drive order. This file is called VDArouteNetwork.json

Background

Navitrol drives based on a route network. This route network is defined in Navithor Tools and uploaded to the AGV. The routes are composed of segments and these segments have segment points. The segment point placement describes the geometrical properties of the routes and the network also contains information about the topological properties: which segments are reachable from any given other segments. On the segments, there are special points where the AGV performs functions such as charging and loading or unloading. These special points are called symbolic points in our terminology. The fleet control traditionally gives the drive order to the AGV in the form of a list of segment IDs and a desired stopping point. The fleet control uses proprietary binary protocol for this purpose. The AGV has limited capability to navigate outside the route network: in some obstacle avoidance scenarios the AGV may autonomously plan an avoidance route. The AGV is also capable of returning to the route network if its current location is sufficiently close to the network. Note that these functionalities have not yet been integrated with the VDMA protocol. Because of this history, Navitrol receives a lot of the information it needs to perform actions or drive routes from the segment file. Some actions may not be available unless near a compatible symbolic point and some of the properties like frame headings etc. are read from the segment file rather than through the VDA5050 interface. Those optional properties are therefore not supported in the drive orders. Because Navitrol implementation of VDA5050 support begun when the standard was still in its early phases, it is sometimes internally referred to as the VDMA protocol. This naming is currently used in eg. parameters.

Errors

The VDA5050 protocol supports sending error messages to the fleet control software. How these errors are visualized to the user depends on the fleet control. In addition to the errors specified by the standard, there are some errors that are custom to the drive control software. Most of these internal errors are described in other documents. Here is a list of errors that you may encounter specific to the VDA interface.

errorTypeError MessageExplanationFix
internalErrorVDA5050 license option is missing from the AGVVDA5050 support is sold as a separate license option and has not been enabledGet a license with the option enabled and install it on the AGV
internalErrorFailed to build routeInternal error when building a drive trajectory from the orderSend logs to support
internalErrorFailed to send routeInternal error when sending the trajectory to the component controlling the driveSend logs to support
versionMismatchSegment file version # doesn't match route network file #The VDArouteNetwork.json has gone offsync with the route fisegment file on the AGVRe-export the files from Tools and upload to the AGV
modeErrorInvalid mode for autodrivingAGV is in wrong mode for autodriving (eg. in manual control, driving disabled from supervisor status message 3002 section 7 Drive control)Release manual control or enable drive orders from supervisor. If nothing else helps, restart the AGV.
noRouteErrorMap id mismatchLevel ID in the order didn't match the expected value
noRouteErrorPosition not initializedAGV doesn't know where it is and can't driveUse fleet control to initialize the AGV position
noRouteErrorStarting position too farThe starting position of the drive order is too far away from AGV positionDepends on fleet control
orderUpdateErrorOrder already activeThe fleet control sent a new drive order, but previous one is still activeCancel the previous order with cancelOrder action
invalidActionAction type is not supported as instantActionSome VDA5050 actions can only be used as a part of an orderDepends on fleet control
invalidActionAction has invalid format or invalid parametersAn action was received, but it was malformedDepends on the fleet control.
invalidActionAction type is not supported, invalid parameters or invalid formatFleet control sent an unsupported action or parameters as a part of the orderDepends on fleet control
noOrderToCancelCancel order action was sent by fleet control, but no order is activeTypically no fix needed
mapNameMismatchMap name '' is not a valid level numberFleet control sent a position initialization action with incorrect map IDMake sure that the map files are in sync between the AGV and fleet control.
mapNameMismatchMap name '' doesn't match expected ''Fleet control sent a position initialization action with incorrect map IDMake sure that the map files are in sync between the AGV and fleet control. Use 'vdma_area_name_override' parameter if needed
internalErrorFailed to replace orderSomething went wrong with order replacementContact support if this problem persists
orderUpdateErrorOrder update failedSomething went wrong in updating an existing drive orderContact support if this problem persists
validationErrormessage depends on validation errorThe fleetcontrol has sent an order that was somehow malformed. The problem is described in the message

Critical actions

A critical action is an action that has to be completed in order for the drive order to meaningfully continue. Therefore the critical actions upon failure cause the order to stop and a fatal error to be reported to the fleet control. The actuator related actions pick, drop, setActuator and releaseActuator are critical by default. The criticality of individual actions can be configured using the JSON configuration file

Navitrol error levels are mapped to VDA5050 error levels according to the following rule:

Navitrol error levelVDA5050 error level
WarningWarning
Error (vdma_escalate_errors_to_fatal_timeout_s set)First warning, then turns to fatal
Error (vdma_escalate_errors_to_fatal_timeout_s = 0)Fatal
FatalFatal

VDA5050 SSL configuration

VDA5050 supports connecting over SSL encrypted connections. Using this feture requires the server to have a certificate that is signed by a root certificate. The root certificate is placed on the AGV. In addition the AGV itself can have a certificate and a key that are used to verify the AGV:s identity when it connects to the fleetcontrol. By default VDA5050 uses the same SSL configuration than the rest of the Navitrol. So if SSL is enabled according to the SSL guide, it will also be enabed for VDA5050 connections. However, it is possible to disable the SSL for VDA5050 even when it is otherwise in use by setting vdma_ssl_mode to 0 or enable it just for VDA5050 by setting vdma_ssl_mode to 2.

By default the VDA5050 interface checks the hostname of the server it connects to and it has to match the value in the server certificate. This can sometimes be problematic and it can be disabled by setting vdma_ssl_verify_hostname to 0. The vdma_ssl_version parameter can be used to select the TLS version used, but there should rarely be need to change it. The other vdma_ssl_ parameters are used only when vdma_ssl_mode is set to 2 (The SSL is turned on separately for VDA5050) and each of those has a corresponding regular Navitrol SSL parameter that it replaces (eg. vdma_ssl_agv_key_file is used instead of ssl_agv_key_file).

Troubleshooting

SSL errors come from the OpenSSL library and are not always the easiest to understand. Here are couple of them you might encounter, but the list is not exhaustive.

Erroneous certificate common names

OpenSSL Error: error:1416F086:SSL routines:tls_process_server_certificate:certificate verify failed

The Certificates used (CA certificate, AGV certificate and the server certificate) need to have different Common Name (CN) field values.

Wrong hostname in certificate

Error: host name verification failed. OpenSSL Error: error:1416F086:SSL routines:tls_process_server_certificate:certificate verify failed

vdma_ssl_verify_hostname is enabled and the certificate host name doesn't match the server host name. Could be due to wrong certificate, changed hostname or yuo may need to disable the vdma_ssl_verify_hostname parameter. It can also be caused by an attempt by an attacker to impersonate the server.

AGV certificate not configured

OpenSSL Error: error:14094410:SSL routines:ssl3_read_bytes:sslv3 alert handshake failure

This error could be because you have not configured the AGV certificate, but the server has requested it.

Certificate and key files don't match

OpenSSL error: error:0B080074:x509 certificate routines:X509_check_private_key:key values mismatch

The certificate file doesn't match the key file. Perhaps one of them was updated and the other one wasn't.

Features affected when using VDA5050 interface

Updated 03.06.2024

Features affected by VDA5050

The rule is that anything related to localization is not affected by VDA5050 and everything related to driving the AGV or controlling the actuators on the AGV are affected. There are also differences between the different dialect options. In the segment based dialect Navitrol still has the segment file and reads it in. Thus many of the features that rely on the information stored in the segment file work with the segment based dialect but might not yet work with the trajectory based dialect. Below is a table which shows common Navitrol features and if they are supported by different VDA5050 dialects.

VDA5050 does not affect the supported hardware.

Localization features

FeatureTrajectory based dialectSegment based dialect
Precision positioning
Ramp zones
Dynamic mapping
GPS
IMU and sensor fusion
Magnetic line following
External localization

Drive control features

FeatureTrajectory based dialectSegment based dialect
Speed on route
Omni frame heading
Pivoting
Other route properties
DMC Docking
Obstacle avoidance
Synchronized driving
Return to route*
Barrier stop

*The fleet control can drive the AGV back on its own definition of a route.

Actuator control features

FeatureTrajectory based dialectSegment based dialect
Pickup from floor / default height
Pickup from different heights at different locations
Pallet detection*
Buffer lanes
Block stacking**
Racking

*Limitations on how far away from the original segments must be set to the nodes correctly for the AGV to be able to dock to target that are not right at the expected destination.

**Only loading from a single symbolic point

Miscellaneous features

FeatureTrajectory based dialectSegment based dialect
Parameter zones
Charging

Return to Route

Updated 29.04.2024

Overview

Introduction

Return to route is a feature that allows an AGV that is off the route to drive to the closest suitable route. The feature can be useful when driving the AGV manually near the route and then performing the automatic return to route so that the AGV can be taken into production.

There's also option to allow a larger deviation from the route at the start of a drive without the need for return to route.

Limitations

  • AGV is in standby state when given return to route order
  • Does not acknowledge obstacles or environment points.

How to use

The return to route feature always requires an external trigger. It can be triggered for example from the Supervisor interface, Navitrol monitor or Navithor client.

Set up

Return to route by shortest route for omni

For omni AGVs without steering limitations. It generates a reference point on the route to which it drives.

Required parameters

ParameterRecommended valueDescription
I, rtr_use_custom_route0Sets the return to route mode:
0 = Shortest route for omni
1 = Custom route for Diff/Steer drive
2 = Custom route for limited omni wheels

Return to route with custom drive order

The AGV cannot return to the route by reversing to a route that only supports forward driving. Supported by all kinematic models. An AGV must have relatively small heading and distance errors to at least one route defined in the active map to successfully return to route. Return to route path is constructed automatically to the closest suitable point. It always consists of four route points connected with splines. The four points include start point, start smooth distance point, end smooth distance point and the end point.

Required parameters

ParameterRecommended valueDescription
F, rtr_max_dist2.0This limit constitutes the maximum Euclidean distance (m) from the navigation point to a trajectory segment point.
F, rtr_speed0.3The maximum speed (m/s) during the return to route drive
F, rtr_max_head_err_deg5.0The maximum heading error when checking if the AGV is already on the route and return to route is not needed
F, rtr_max_head_diff90.0The maximum heading difference between the heading of potential route point and the current heading of the AGV, for the return to route to be feasible.
I, rtr_use_custom_route1Sets the return to route mode:
0 = Shortest route for omni
1 = Custom route for Diff/Steer drive
2 = Custom route for limited omni wheels
F, rtr_control_point_dist2.5Required minimum Euclidean distance (m) to potential return to route target point.
F, rtr_control_point_start_smooth_dist0.8Defines the smooth distance at the start of the return to route path
F, rtr_control_point_end_smooth_dist0.8Defines the smooth distance before the end of the return to route path
F, rtr_already_on_route_dist0.1The maximum distance error when checking if the AGV is already on the route and return to route is not needed

The below Figure visualizes the custom drive order return to route. The orange line denotes the Euclidean distance between navigation point and nominal trajectory segment point. This distance must be smaller than rtr_max_dist for the return to route to be further evaluated. The rtr_control_point_dist-parameter constitutes how aggressively it converges to the nominal route.

Return to route - Custom drive order.

Return to route for omnis with limited steering

This subfeature is only supported by omni and mecanum kinematic models. Limited return to route is designed for omni drive AGVs that have heavy steering limitations and are not able to pivot or perform any other high curvature manoeuvres. See documentation for Omni steer limit. Limited steering return to route mode will approach the nearest route by crab-like movement, see Figure below. There is a small, curved part in the very end of the path to adjust wheels.

Crabbing to route

The AGV tries to correct any heading errors while returning to the route. For the latter subfigure below, adjusting the frame heading to the route when approaching requires larger wheel angles.

Crabbing to route with frame heading errors

Required parameters

ParameterRecommended valueDescription
I, rtr_use_custom_route2Strictly curvature limited custom route.
F, rtr_already_on_route_dist0.05If the distance to nearest route segment point is smaller than this value AGV is considered to be on route. The return route is calculated but not driven.

Optional parameters

ParameterRecommended valueDescription
F, rtr_max_dist2.00Defines the maximum search distance [m] for the first target point on the route.
F, rtr_speed0.30Upper threshold [m/s] for the rtr trajectory speed.
F, rtr_max_head_err_deg5.00Lower threshold for the angle [deg] between the vehicle and the route for return to route to be possible.
F, rtr_max_head_diff30.0Maximum heading difference between the vehicle and the target point on the route.
F, rtr_control_point_dist0.25Defines the maximum distance from close point (see rtr_max_dist) to a custom return to route target point.
F, rtr_control_point_end_smooth_dist0.05Defines the minimum distance between the last two control points in the custom route creation.

Parameter rtr_control_point_start_smooth_dist has no affect on this subfeature.

Limited omni steering recovery

Limited omni steering recovery is a feature for trying to drive the AGV automatically back to the route if it has been driven too far from the route. The idea is that in a case, where there normally would be the POS_CONT_POS_ERROR or POS_CONT_HEADING_ERROR, this rescue return to route is triggered instead. Navitrol will then take segment points from the history that the AGV has just driven that are closer than the rtr_max_dist parameter and tries to create custom route to those points. There is a cost function that tries to find a segment point that

  • Has the smallest heading error to the AGV current heading.
  • The limited omni feasibly can drive. Only segment points with wheel target angles within limits are considered.

The rtr_control_point_end_smooth_dist parameter is used to define the length of the curved part in the end of the custom route.

Required parameters

ParameterRecommended valueDescription
I, rtr_use_custom_route2Strictly curvature limited custom route.

Optional parameters

ParameterRecommended valueDescription
I, rtr_omni_steer_limit_recovery_time_ms200000 = Disabled

5000 - 100000 = Enabled
Heavily limited omni stuck in warning_limited_steering_active too long time trigger limited steering recovery.
Active only when rtr_use_custom_route is set to value 2.

Preconditions

  • AGV is limited steering omni
  • WARNING_LIMITED_STEERING_ACTIVE is enabled
  • AGV is further away from route than pc_max_dist_err or AGV heading error to the route is higher than pc_max_head_err

AGV has overshot the trajectory curve due to limited steering.

Navitrol will use return to route feature to drive the AGV back to some route point in the history.

AGV has driven back to the nominal route.

Errors and warnings

657 - WARNING_RETURN_TO_ROUTE_FAILED

551 - ERROR_RTR_AND_VECTOR_DRIVE_CONFLICT

See Error description.

Troubleshooting

Advanced troubleshooting

ParameterRecommended valueDescription
I, log_rtr_generation1Enables logging of return to route generation.

All related logging is under prefix "RTR:"

Allow larger deviation from route at the start of drive

There is also possibility to increase the allowed deviation from the route at the start of drive so that a trigger for return to route wouldn't be needed. The AGV can then start the drive faster, as it corrects the distance error to the route while driving. The downside compared to the return to route feature is the lower controllability.

AGV starts the drive with larger deviation from the route than normally allowed when driving

This feature is enabled by setting the parameter pc_start_err_factor > 1. This parameter multiplies the normal deviation limit pc_max_dist_err at start. The larger deviation limit will last until the AGV is well inside pc_max_dist_err limit or it has travelled a distance of pc_start_err_max_travelled_dist. The user can also limit how far from starting point of the path the larger deviation can be activated with a parameter pc_start_err_max_dist_to_traj_start.

>AGV is too far from the start of the trajectory to allow larger start deviation

Limitations

  • The route planner needs to be able to find the starting point. For example in Standalone production route_driver_max_diff_dist_m must be set high enough to find the start point from the route.
  • Navitrol Monitor's production simulation doesn't support this feature
  • Heading error limit to the route is not affected. Non-holonomic vehicles might change the heading too much when returning to the route with large deviation from route at start, which will trigger an error.

Parameters

ParameterTypeDefault valueDescription
pc_start_err_factorFloat1.0Determines maximum distance error [m] from the route at the start of drive order (multiplies pc_max_dist_err)
pc_start_err_max_travelled_distFloat1.0Maximum travelled distance [m] from the start of drive order when larger deviation from route is allowed
pc_start_err_max_dist_to_traj_startFloatFLT_MAXMaximum distance [m] to the first point of trajectory to allow the larger deviation at start to activate

Obstacle Avoidance

Introduction

Obstacle avoidance is an algorithm that detects collisions and drives around the obstacles to continue the mission. Thus, the AGV may react dynamically to changes in the environment. The collision detection uses 2D safety scanners to predict whether there are any upcoming collisions. Upon a collision detection, the AGV will begin to plan a new route.

If there is enough space to perform the bypass, fleet control is sent a message to request the bypass and reserve the area from other AGVs in the fleet. After getting the permission the AGV will begin the bypass and continue to poll the environment for other obstacles.

To ensure controlled behavior there are several constraints under which obstacle avoidance plans the paths such as time spent planning and the area in which the bypass must happen. These are discussed in more detail below.

The complete list of obstacle avoidance parameters, their valid values and explanations is in the end of this document. The obstacle avoidance parameters are marked with bold when referenced in text. They always begin with prefix obst_.

Obstacle Avoidance Modes

There are two modes of obstacle avoidance that can be used in Navitrol. By setting obst_av_mode parameter to 1, only detection mode of obstacles is activated, meaning that the AGV will detect obstacles on its path and stop a certain distance before collision, but will not attempt to plan a route to avoid obstacles.

Setting obst_av_mode to 2 enables obstacle detection and avoidance mode. With this mode, AGV will detect obstacles on its path and plan a bypass route avoiding them.

Note for those using coupled driving feature: Both obstacle detection and obstacle avoidance will be disabled for the duration of coupled driving, but they will work normally when the AGVs are uncoupled.

Obstacle avoidance zones

By default, obstacles may be detected and avoided only if the AGV is inside an obstacle avoidance zone. There may be one or many obstacle avoidance zones. The zones hold information on direction policy, or in other words, which direction the AGV may use to drive around the obstacle. The AGV must be always inside an obstacle avoidance zone when it is driving around the obstacle. Thus, if the obstacle is too close to obstacle zone boundaries, the AGV may not drive around it. The zones can be ignored, allowing obstacle avoidance anywhere by setting the value of the parameter obst_use_zones to 0.

With default value of 1 obst_use_zones obstacles are bypassed only if the bypass route can be planned inside the zone according to zone rules. Obstacles themselves are however detected everywhere also outside zones, and AGV is stopped according to the obstacle avoidance related parameters. With obst_use_zones in value 2 obstacles are not only bypassed, but also only detected inside zones. This option makes it possible to configure obstacle avoidance to be used only in certain areas, without affecting the AGV driving globally. It should be noted that this option also ignores the scanner points outside of the obstacle zones, meaning that even when the AGV is inside a zone, obstacles outside of a zone will not be detected or avoided.

Figure 1: the AGV (grey) sees an obstacle (red) because the AGV is inside an obstacle avoidance zone (blue). There is enough space to bypass the obstacle inside the obstacle avoidance zone. The route around the obstacle is shown with green dashed line; the nominal route is shown with black dashed line.

Figure 2: The AGV will detect the obstacle but there is not enough space to bypass the obstacle because the obstacle is close to obstacle avoidance zone boundaries. The route around the obstacle would be outside the obstacle avoidance zone (red dashed line). Thus, driving around the obstacle is not possible. In this scenario, AGV will stop and wait for the obstacle to disappear.

Detecting collisions

The seamless functioning of obstacle detection is crucial for obstacle avoidance. If no obstacles are detected, it is impossible to drive around them.

The parameter obst_detection_scanners determines which localization scanners are used for obstacle detection. Different scanners may be used for localization and obstacle detection. Please see the Appendix for instructions on how to set this parameter for different scanners.

Similarly, the parameter obst_detection_meas_scanners determines which measurement-only scanners are used for obstacle avoidance.

For each route point, if there are at least obst_detect_min_scan_points number of scanner measurements close to the AGV, a collision is detected in that route point. Being "close" to the AGV is determined by obst_free_zone_left, obst_free_zone_right, obst_free_zone_front and obst_free_zone_rear parameters, which determine the zone that must be obstacle-free around the vehicle.
