This is a limit from the base level ('floor level') and does not affect actuator position when reference is above this value

      • Should be set to the same value with Navitrol actuator_load_min_val

  • Load sensor to Navithor

    • LOAD_STATUS_KNOWN defines if AGV has load sensor or not. If this is set to 0, Navithor does not use the load status sent from Navitrol for anything. If this is 1, Navithor can use for example resource mismatch rules or sync the load status based on what Navitrol sends.

  • Fork dimensions (If fork type is selected)

    • DIM_FORK_GAP defines the gap between 2 forks. Used for visualization of the fork.

    • DIM_FORK_LENGTH defines the length of the forks. Used for visualization of the fork.

Fork type AGV on the Machine Tool.

  • Actuator orientation for sideloader
    • ACTUATOR_ORIENTATION (none, right, left) defines where the fork is pointing relative to the AGV body. On the figure down below the front of the AGV is orange color and rear is grey color and the actuator is pointing to the left side.

Sideloader AGV on the Machine Tool.

Route properties in Navithor Tools related to Actuator

Height reference for the fork actuator is set to route in Navithor Tools. Height can be set separately for both lanes.

User can also define if the "Strict" feature is ON. Strict means that machine won't drive until measured height of the actuator is the same as the reference height.

Actuator value property on Navithor Tools.

Strict actuator property on Navithor Tools.

How to set reference height of the actuator on the route.

  1. Select property "Actuator Value (mm)"

  2. Select the lane (Single lane or Both)

  3. Select the part of the route to be adjusted

  4. Set value for the "Actuator Value (mm)" and press Set Selection

How to set Strict height of the actuator on the route.

  1. Select property "Strict Actuator"

  2. Select the lane (Single or Both)

  3. Select the part of the route to be adjusted

  4. Set value for the "Strict Actuator" and press Set Selection

Actuator Control form

Once actuator control is activated (actuator_type > 0) "Actuator control" -form appears under the tab "Navitrol"

Actuator control form with reference controlled fork.

With this form it is possible to see the measured and reference values of some actuators and to take actuators to Manual control.

Measurement, reference and other values

On the left side of the form, there is a list of data. The items are:

  • measured value
    • Measured height of the fork in mm. With binary actuator, this will be 0 always.
  • reference value
    • Reference or target value for lift. For reference controlled lift, this is the reference height in mm and for binary lift, 0 = no control, 1 = decrease command, 2 = increase command.
  • activate actuator
    • Navitrol command to activate lift. 1 = lift control active, 0 = no control.
  • increase actuator
    • Navitrol command to increase lift. 1 = increase active, 0 = no control. Usually when actuator control is active (activate actuator bit), the direction is told with this or the decrease bit.
  • decrease actuator
    • Navitrol command to decrease lift. 1 = decrease active, 0 = no control. Usually when actuator control is active (activate actuator bit), the direction is told with this or the increase bit.
  • low limit active
    • Lift actuator at the low limit. Not used with reference controlled lift. This comes usually from customer interface and shows if the actuator is at the low limit sensor (actuator at low position).
  • high limit active
    • Lift actuator at the high limit. Not used with reference controlled lift. This comes usually from customer interface and shows if the actuator is at the high limit sensor (actuator at high position).
  • load sensor used
    • If load sensor is in use. This comes usually from customer interface and shows if the AGV has load sensor or not. 1 = sensor is used, 0 = no sensor data. If the number is higher than 1, then the system has more sensors.
  • load detected
    • Load sensor data. If the load sensor detected the load or not. Not used if the "load sensor used" is 0. Usually the value is 0 = load not detected or 1 = load detected. If the "load sensor used" is higher than 1, Navitrol will set load aboard only when the load is detected with all sensors.
  • scanner height reference
    • Scanner lift actuator reference value in mm. Relative to the fork, for example -200 means that the scanner lift target is 200 mm below the fork.
  • scanner height measurement
    • Scanner lift height measurement value in mm. Relative to the fork, for example -200 means that the scanner lift is 200 mm below the fork.
  • aux lift measurement
    • Auxiliary/Secondary lift measurement value in mm.
  • aux lift reference
    • Auxiliary/Secondary lift reference or target value in mm.
  • rotate meas deg
    • Rotate fork measurement value in degrees. 0 = fork pointing forwards, 90 = fork pointing to the left (counter-clockwise), -90 = fork pointing to the right (clockwise)
  • rotate ref deg
    • Rotate fork reference or target value in degrees.
  • secondary load sensor used
    • If load sensor is in use for secondary lift. This comes usually from customer interface and shows if the AGV has load sensor or not. 1 = sensor is used, 0 = no sensor data.
  • secondary load detected
    • Load sensor data for secondary lift. If the load sensor detected the load or not. Not used if the "secondary load sensor used" is 0. 0 = load not detected, 1 = load detected.

Buttons

  • Start/stop control
    • "Take Control" -button
      • Enables the Actuator manual control and takes AGV into Manual state.
    • "Stop" -button
      • Stops the manual control and changes state to Standby.
  • Reference control
    • "Numeric up/down"
      • Sets the reference value for the actuator
    • "Send" -button
      • Multiple send buttons that will send the current reference value from the left-side numeric up/down to Navitrol. The reference values are not sent if this button is not pressed.
  • Control buttons
    • "Load / Unload" -button.
      • Has text "Load" when Navitrol load status is empty.
      • Has text "Unload" when Navitrol load status is loaded.

How to take Manual control of the actuator

  1. Open Actuator Control form

  2. Press "Take Control"

  3. Set the wanted "Reference value"

  4. Press "Send" and system starts to drive the actuator to the given reference value.

  5. Pressing "Stop" button will stop the Manual control.

Pickup/Dropoff sequence

"Load" -button will start the pickup sequence as described in "Pickup and Dropoff sequences" chapter. This button can be clicked once the "Take Control" is pressed. After the pickup sequence is ready, the button text is changed to "Unload". Pressing that button will start dropoff sequence. This button is useful for example testing the pickup and dropoff sequences if they are something else than default.

Other actuator controls

Binary actuator can be enabled with actuator_type 3. Then its possible to command the lift to increase or decrease. Then the Actuator Control form will look like this:

Actuator control form with binary actuator

Scanner lift control can be enabled with actuator_scanner_lift_enabled parameter as 1. Monitor will show "Scanner Height Reference value" where scanner height reference value in mm can be set.

Auxiliary/Secondary lift control can be enabled with actuator_auxiliary_lift_enabled parameter as 1. Monitor will show "Aux lift ref" where auxiliry/secondary lift reference value in mm can be set.

Rotate fork control can be enabled with actuator_rotate_enabled parameter as 1. Monitor will show "Rotate ref" where rotate fork reference value in degrees can be set.

Actuator control form with all active actuators

Ethernet Navithor Server -- Information to Navithor

Actuator related information is passed from Navitrol to Navithor by mapping the I/O information to the machine profile. These are not recommended to use anymore after Navithor 2.x.x.x.

Both params.txt and Machine parameter.xml are used for mapping.

I/0 binary mapping on Machine Tool

  • Actuator Position measurement

    • Navitrol parameters: actuator_val_io

    • Machine Tool: ActuatorPosition : i0...iN

    • Example:

      • Actuator height shall be passed to Navithor with the first value of the Integer I/O vector: actuator_val_io = 0 and ActuatorPosition = i0

  • Actuator Load detected information

    • Navitrol parameters: actuator_load_det_io

    • Machine Tool: LoadDetected : b0...bN

  • Actuator Load status information

    • Navitrol parameters: actuator_trust_io_load_status and actuator_load_status_io

Select source for actuator inputs

Typically the actuator inputs of a machine come from one interface/source to Navitrol. However, when the actuator inputs come from multiple different sources, then there can be some ambiguity which input Navitrol uses. For example some machine type might have read the inputs for a lift from custom CAN interface before, but for a new project it is desired that the actuator inputs come from the Ethernet supervisor interface.

To define the actuator input source explicitly, the following parameters can be set:

  • I, actuator_input_source_arr[]
  • I, actuator_input_type_arr[]

If all inputs of actuators are desired to come from one source only, then only actuator_input_source_arr needs to be set. For example to read all the inputs from Supervisor status 3002 actuator section set:

  • I, actuator_input_source_arr[0], 2 # ... 2 = Supervisor status section

User can also set different sources for different actuator types. For example if Navitrol has previously read fork's lift and reach input from custom CAN interface, but now the fork's lift input needs to be read from Ethernet supervisor interface, following parameters can be set:
Disclaimer: All configurations not supported. Consult Navitec whether the desired configuration is supported.

  • I, actuator_input_source_arr[0], 2 # ... 2 = Supervisor status section
  • I, actuator_input_source_arr[1], 10 # ... 10 = Custom CAN
  • I, actuator_input_type_arr[0], 1 # ... 1 = Lift
  • I, actuator_input_type_arr[1], 3 # ... 3 = Reach

Troubleshooting

Most common issues

Monitor doesn't show correct actuator measurement

  • Check that actuator_type parameter is 2.
  • Check control interface that Navitrol receives correct measurement
    • Ethernet control with supervisor status message ID 3002 actuator section 1:
      • Set parameter log_veh_inte_eth to 1
      • Check this kind of log line: "veh_inte_ethernet: Supervisor actuator val 0 act 0, lowL 0 highL 0 loadSen 0 loadDet 0"
      • This log line shows what data Navitrol receives via supervisor message. The values are:
        • val = Actuator height in mm
        • act = Actuator is active (0 or 1)
        • lowL = Low limit sensor (0 or 1)
        • highL = High limit sensor (0 or 1)
        • LoadSen = Load sensor is in use (0 or 1)
        • LoadDet = Load sensor value (0 or 1)
    • Ethernet control with supervisor message ID 1031/1131
      • Set parameter log_veh_inte_eth to 2
      • Check these kind of log lines: "ETH_CTRL_IN 1031"
        • Verify that the correct actuator type and actuator measured position is received.
    • CAN Encoder. Schwarzmueller or Curtis
      • Check this log line: "HAL_CopyActuatorMeasToShared". It should show the actuator measured height.
      • If this line is not shown, check that this parameter is enabled: can_actuator_ctrl_model
      • Check that these parameters are correct:
        • can_enc_actuator_calib_val_enc
        • can_enc_actuator_calib_val_act
        • can_enc_actuator_pulses_per_rev

Actuator doesn't move to reference value

  • Check that actuator_type parameter is 2.
  • Check control interface that Navitrol sends out the correct reference
    • Ethernet control with supervisor status message ID 3002 actuator section 1:
      • Set parameter log_veh_inte_eth to 1
      • Check this kind of log line: "veh_inte_ethernet: Send actuator refVal 0 act 0 inc 0 dec 0 bin1 0 bin2 0 bin3 0 bin4 0"
      • This log line shows what data Navitrol sends out via supervisor message. The values are:
        • refVal = Actuator reference in mm
        • act = Activate command (0 or 1)
        • inc = Increase command (0 or 1)
        • dec = Decrease command (0 or 1)
        • bin1 = Bitmapped value (bit 0: activate, bit 1: increase and bit 2: decrease)
        • bin2 = Bitmapped value (reserved for future use)
        • bin3 = Bitmapped value (bit 0: stop and hold active)
        • bin4 = Bitmapped value (reserved for future use)
    • Ethernet control with supervisor message ID 1031/1131
      • Set parameter log_veh_inte_eth to 2
      • Check these kind of log lines: "ETH_CTRL_OUT 1131"
        • Verify that the correct actuator type is sent out and there is some reference value.
        • If the numOfActuators is 0, check that the correct actuator is enabled and correct control type is set on params.txt file. Check also that Navitrol receives actuator data on this log line: "ETH_CTRL_IN 1031". Navitrol is not answering if it doesn't receive anything.
    • CAN Encoder. Schwarzmueller or Curtis
      • Check this log line: "HAL_ControlSingleCanActuatorRPM". It should show actuator rpm and reference values.
      • If this line is not shown, check that this parameter is enabled: can_actuator_ctrl_model

Actuator overshoots the reference

  • Check that actuator_outer_tolerance_mm has valid value. Increase if possible.
  • Try to decrease actuator_inner_tolerance_timer_ms, if it has some value.
  • Try to decrease actuator_inner_tolerance_mm, if it is non-negative.

Actuator does not move when driving out from drop-off location

Check the distance to the drop-off location and check if any of these parameters are higher than that distance:

  • docking_limit_leave_speed_and_actuator_height_dist
  • actuator_keep_height_after_dropoff_aborted_distance_m

Check this kind of log line: "Actuator use not allowed before driven 1.2 m distance from the last unload location. Dist: 0.5. Act: 0"

  • This is related to the docking_limit_leave_speed_and_actuator_height_dist parameter. The actuator control is not allowed until AGV has driven this parameter distance from last unload point.

AGV doesn't go to Standby when arriving to Pickup or Dropoff symbolic point

AGV will go to Standby when actuator control is finished, meaning that actuator is within tolerance from the reference value or it is at the target low/high limit and actuator is not active on AGV system. Check the communication that actuator is not active on the AGV system.

Check if this log line is shown: "Actuator not within limits or is active, move not allowed (inLimits: 0, strictFork: 0, softLimit: 0, actActive: 1". This indicates if actuator is not within tolerance or it is still active from customer interfaces.

AGV stops to Pickup buffer

Check these parameters:

  • disable_safety_distance_on_buffer is positive.
  • load_buffer_mode is 1 or 2.
  • buffer_stop_AGV_when_decreasing_fork_before_load is 1. This is 1 by default, so if this parameter is not on the params.txt file, it is set.

If those parameters are set, the AGV is stopped, because the fork is trying to go to the floor level, but for some reason can't finish the action. This buffer_stop_AGV_when_decreasing_fork_before_load will stop the AGV until the fork has reached the floor level (actuator_min_val).

Check the value of actuator_min_val and that actuator is at that height. Another option is to disable the stop check by setting the buffer_stop_AGV_when_decreasing_fork_before_load to 0.

Load sensor conflict with navithor after Pickup/Dropoff aborted

Navithor load status is kept on wrong value if Pickup/Dropoff is not completed correctly. It can be reset to previous value on abort if this parameter is set navithor_load_status_reset_on_pickup_dropoff_abort = 1

Errors and warnings

WARNING_POS_CONT_FORK_WAR

This warning is set when AGV is in Auto state and

  • some actuator is moving and AGV is inside strict route property or
  • reference controlled fork (actuator_type = 2) measurement value goes below ACTUATOR_MIN_VAL machine_type parameter or
  • binary controlled actuator (actuator_type = 3) is commanded to increase but highlimit bit is not active

How to recover: This is not critical warning, but if it does not reset automatically, check that there are no active actuators and the binary actuator highlimit is set if it is commanded to increase. This should be reset automatically when all actuators are within limits.

ERROR_POS_CONT_FORK_TIME_ERR

This error is triggered if actuator control is not ready within time of actuator_timer_s parameter.

How to recover: Actuator moves too slow to the target value. Try to increase actuator speed or increase this timer parameter.This error has timeout of 20 seconds, so it is reset automatically.

ERROR_ACTUATOR_USE_NOT_ALLOWED

This error is triggered if actuator_only_on_sp is enabled, pickup or dropoff action is active and

  • AGV is not at any symbolic point
  • Actuator is tried to decrease on Pickup symbolic point
  • Actuator is tried to increase on Dropoff symbolic point
  • AGV is further away from symbolic point than actuator_max_dist_err_from_sp.

This error is also triggered if actuator_check_load_sensor_status_before_loading is 1 and racking_mode is 1 and load sensor does not detect the load while doing pickup action.

How to recover: Check the conditions for this error and check if any of those fullfills. This error has timeout of 20 seconds, so it is reset automatically.

WARNING_ACTUATOR_USE_NOT_ALLOWED

This warning is triggered if actuator_only_on_sp is enabled, pickup or dropoff action is active and

  • AGV is not at any symbolic point
  • Actuator is tried to decrease on Pickup symbolic point
  • Actuator is tried to increase on Dropoff symbolic point
  • AGV is further away from symbolic point than actuator_max_dist_err_from_sp.

How to recover: Check the conditions for this warning and check if any of those fullfills. This warning is reset only when Pickup or Dropoff action is finished.

WARNING_SENSOR_FAILURE_IN_LOADING

Load sensor does not detect the load while doing pickup. This warning is reset if load sensor detects the load or AGV goes to STANDBY state. AGV is stopped from moving until the warning is reset. This error check can be disabled with the actuator_check_load_sensor_status_before_loading parameter if the load sensor cannot be used while doing the pickup.

How to recover: Check that pallet is firmly placed on the forks and move it closer to the sensor if possible. Check the sensor that it reports correct data.

ERROR_LOAD_SENSOR_CONFLICT_AFTER_PICKUP

Load sensor doesn't detect the load after pickup action. This error is fatal error so it has to be reset by customer. This error check can be disabled with the actuator_check_load_sensor_status_after_loading parameter if the sensor cannot be used for this kind of check.

How to recover: Check that pallet is firmly placed on the forks and move it closer to the sensor if possible. Check the sensor that it reports correct data. Reset the error from Client, Monitor or Supervisor interface.

ERROR_LOAD_SENSOR_CONFLICT_AFTER_DROPOFF

Load sensor detects the load after drop-off action has been completed. This error is fatal error so it has to be reset by customer. This error check can be disabled with the actuator_check_load_sensor_status_after_unloading parameter if the sensor cannot be used for this kind of check.

How to recover: Check the sensor that it reports correct data. Reset the error from Client, Monitor or Supervisor interface.

ERROR_LOAD_SENSOR_CONFLICT_WITH_NAVITHOR

Load sensor and fleet control reported load status does not match. Error is reset after there is no conflict. Two modes that can be selected with load_sensor_conflict_mode parameter.

Mode 1: Check is done in three different situations:

  1. At actuator_disable_load_sensor_distance distance before AGV drives to the Pickup or Dropoff point.
  2. At the beginning of Pickup or Dropoff buffer.
  3. When AGV state changes from Manual to Standby.

On situation 1 the check starts when AGV is at actuator_disable_load_sensor_distance distance from the Pickup or Dropoff point and ends when AGV has driven min_distance_to_check_the_load_sensor distance. On situation 2 the check starts when AGV is at the beginning of Pickup or Dropoff buffer and ends when AGV has driven min_distance_to_check_the_load_sensor distance. There is an option to force AGV to go to Manual state if this error is triggered. That can be done by setting this parameter: load_sensor_conflict_goes_to_manual. There is also parameter that defines what source is used for reset the manual state: load_sensor_conflict_manual_reset_source.

Mode 2: Check is done when AGV is in Auto state. Uses load_sensor_status_change_timer_ms parameter as a timer to avoid glitches. Not checked if AGV is closer to the Pickup or Dropoff symbolic point than actuator_disable_load_sensor_distance.

How to recover: Check that pallet is firmly placed on the forks and move it closer to the sensor if possible. Check the sensor that it reports correct data. Check Navithor Client that it has correct resource status. If Navithor has incorrect status do pickup/dropoff action from Client or remove/add resource from the AGV to get the status correct.

ERROR_LOAD_SENSOR_STATUS_CHANGED_IN_AUTO

Load sensor status changes in Auto state. Fatal error that requires customer to reset it. Timer is used to avoid glitches taken into account, meaning that if the sensor just quickly changes to 0 and the back to 1, it does not raise an error. Timer timeout can be set with load_sensor_status_change_timer_ms parameter.

How to recover: Move pallet correctly to the sensor and check that load sensor reports correct value. Error can be reset from Client, Monitor or Supervisor interface after the sensor is checked.

ERROR_ACTUATOR_SAFE_ZONE_VIOLATION

Actuator is too far from the reference when AGV is inside Actuator safety zone. This check uses actuator_outer_tolerance_mm for checking the difference between reference and measured values. If the AGV is doing Pickup or Dropoff actions actuator_load_aboard_offset_mm parameter is used with the tolerance parameter.

How to recover: Check that the actuator is close enough to the reference. If it drifts slowly or is very close to the outer tolerance, that might trigger this error. This is fatal error that can be reset from Client, Monitor or Supervisor interface after the reason is clear.

ERROR_LOAD_UNLOAD_HEIGHT_TOO_LOW

Actuator reference is too low during Pickup or Dropoff actions. This error is used only with reference controlled fork (actuator_type = 2)

  • Dropoff: Actuator reference is below actuator_min_val - actuator_outer_tolerance_mm
  • Pickup: Actuator reference is below the current height - actuator_outer_tolerance_mm. Meaning that actuator is tried to decrease when doing pickup.

How to recover:

Check these parameters:

  • actuator_min_val
  • actuator_outer_tolerance_mm
  • ACTUATOR_MIN_VAL from machine_type parameter file
  • ACTUATOR_LOAD_MIN_VAL from machine_type parameter file
  • Route height where the Pickup or Dropoff is done

This log line shows the minimum allowed height: "lowest allowed height".

This is fatal error that can be reset from Client, Monitor or Supervisor interface after the reason is clear.

Advanced troubleshooting

Useful log lines

Load statuses. This log line shows load statuses and some load sensor related information. This log line is visible only if there is load sensor used on the system.

  • "Actuator check load sensor: loadState 0 driveToLoad 0 driveAway 0 end 0 loadAboard 0 loadSensor 1 loadDet 0 navithorLoad 1, stateChanged 0 loadDetScannerHeightInHome 0"
    • loadState = AGV in LOAD state
    • driveToLoad = AGV is closer to the end symbolic point than actuator_disable_load_sensor_distance
    • driveAway = AGV is closer to the last symbolic point than actuator_disable_load_sensor_distance
    • end = AGV arrived to the trajectory end
    • loadAboard = Navitrol load status (bitwise number), 0 = empty, 1 = main lift has load, 2 = secondary lift has load, 3 = both lifts has load.
    • loadSensor = Load sensor in use
    • loadDet = Load sensor status. 0 = no load detected, 1 = one sensor detects the load, 2 = two sensors detects the load...
    • navithoLoad = Navithor load status. 0 = unknown, 1 = empty, 4 = full.
    • stateChanged = AGV state changed from Manual to Auto
    • loadDetScannerHeightInHome = Not used for anything

Lift actuator control. This log is active when AGV is not in Standby state.

  • "Actuator control: mcsForkMin 0, forkMin 0, forkLoadMin 0, targetVal 100, curVal 0, activate 1, incAct 1, decAct 0, strictFork: 0"
    • mcsForkMin = Minimum fork height from Navithor. Same as ACTUATOR_MIN_VAL from machine_type parameter file.
    • forkMin = Parameter actuator_min_val
    • forkLoadMin = Parameter actuator_load_min_val
    • targetVal = Fork reference value in mm or binary command (0 = no control, 1 = decrease, 2 = increase)
    • curVal = Fork measurement in mm
    • activate = 0 = Actuator control not active, 1 = Actuator control active
    • incAct = 0 = Actuator not commanded to increase, 1 = Actuator commanded to increase
    • decAct = 0 = Actuator not commanded to decrease, 1 = Actuator commanded to decrease
    • strictFork = 0 = AGV is not inside strict property, 1 = AGV is inside strict property

Auto state lift actuator.

  • "Act: Auto_state, load sensor in use 0, load det 0, load aboard 0, mcsForkMinH 0, fork_min_val 0, targetVal 100"
    • Load sensor in use = Load sensor in use or not.
    • load det = Load sensor value
    • load aboard = Navitrol load status
    • mcsForkMinH = Minimum fork height from Navithor. Same as ACTUATOR_MIN_VAL from machine_type parameter file.
    • fork_min_val = Parameter actuator_load_min_val
    • targetVal = Fork reference value in mm or binary command (0 = no control, 1 = decrease, 2 = increase)

Other actuator controls in Auto state.

  • "Actuator control general: type %s, curVal 0.0, targetVal 50.0 (%s), activate 0"
    • type = Actuator type as string
    • curVal = Actuator measurement value
    • targetVal = Actuator reference value
    • (%s) = String to tell if actuator values are in degrees (deg) or millimeters (mm).
    • activate = Actuator control active

Other actuator controls in Load state.

  • "Actuator control load sequence 1 for type %s: curVal 0.0, targetVal 10.0 (%s), activate 0, timer 100 ms"
    • load sequence = Sequence number. See "Pickup and Dropoff sequences" chapter.
    • type = Actuator type as string
    • curVal = Actuator measurement value
    • targetVal = Actuator reference value
    • (%s) = String to tell if actuator values are in degrees (deg) or millimeters (mm).
    • activate = Actuator is requested to be active
    • timer = Time passed since actuator control has started in ms.

Load sensor data. Logged in every state.

  • "Actuator loadSenUsed 0 loadDet 0"
    • loadSenUsed = Load sensors in use
    • loadDet = Load detected with sensors

All actuators in the system. Logged in every state. If some actuator is missing, check the communication that Navitrol receives data from all actuators.

  • "CommonActuator 0 type %s, source %d, meas 0.0 (%s)"
    • 0 = This first number is only array index for actuator
    • type = Actuator type as string
    • source = Source number where the actuator data comes in to the system.
    • meas = Actuator measurement value
    • (%s) = String to tell if actuator values are in degrees (deg) or millimeters (mm).

Lift actuator control in Manual mode.

  • "Actuator control: targetVal 100, curVal 0, activate 1, incAct 1, decAct 0"
    • targetVal = Fork reference value in mm or binary command
    • curVal = Fork measurement in mm
    • activate = 0 = Actuator control not active, 1 = Actuator control active
    • incAct = 0 = Actuator not commanded to increase, 1 = Actuator commanded to increase
    • decAct = 0 = Actuator not commanded to decrease, 1 = Actuator commanded to decrease

Lift actuator is active.

  • "Actuator not within limits or is active, move not allowed (inLimits: 0, strictFork: 0, softLimit: 0, actActive: 1"
    • inLimits = 1 when actuator is within tolerances
    • strictFork = 1 when AGV is within strict property
    • softLimit = Fork is below ACTUATOR_MIN_VAL or below actuator_load_min_val when AGV has load or binary lift is not at high limit when it should be.
    • actActive = Actuator active. This info comes via customer interface.

Useful log lines for communication

Ethernet control with supervisor status message ID 3002 actuator section 1. See Supervisor document.

Incoming message to Navitrol:

  • Set parameter log_veh_inte_eth to 1
  • "veh_inte_ethernet: Supervisor actuator val 0 act 0, lowL 0 highL 0 loadSen 0 loadDet 0"
    • val = Actuator height in mm
    • act = Actuator is active (0 or 1)
    • lowL = Low limit sensor (0 or 1)
    • highL = High limit sensor (0 or 1)
    • LoadSen = Load sensor is in use (0 or 1)
    • LoadDet = Load sensor value (0 or 1)

Outcoming message from Navitrol:

  • "veh_inte_ethernet: Send actuator refVal 0 act 0 inc 0 dec 0 bin1 0 bin2 0 bin3 0 bin4 0"
    • refVal = Actuator reference in mm
    • act = Activate command (0 or 1)
    • inc = Increase command (0 or 1)
    • dec = Decrease command (0 or 1)
    • bin1 = Bitmapped value (bit 0: activate, bit 1: increase and bit 2: decrease)
    • bin2 = Bitmapped value (reserved for future use)
    • bin3 = Bitmapped value (bit 0: stop and hold active)
    • bin4 = Bitmapped value (reserved for future use)

Ethernet control with supervisor message ID 1031/1131. See Supervisor document.

Incoming message to Navitrol:

  • Set parameter log_veh_inte_eth to 2

  • "ETH_CTRL_IN 1031: MsgNum 123, numOfActs 2, numOfMeas 0, targetSensorsAvailable 0, targetSensors 0, safeSensorsAvailable 0, safeSensors 0"

    • MsgNum = Message number, should be increased by one for each message
    • numOfActs = Number of actuators to control
    • numOfMeas = Number of measurement sensors
    • targetSensorsAvailable = Bitmap value of available sensors
    • targetSensors = Bitmap value of active sensors
    • safeSensorsAvailable = Bitmap value of available safety sensors
    • safeSensors = Bitmap value of active safety sensors

  • Actuator array. Logged if numOfActs is greater than 0.

  • "ETH_CTRL_IN 1031: Actuators[0] requestedControl 2, status 1, actPos 50, reserved 0"

    • Actuators[i] = Array index of actuator
    • requestedControl = Actuator type to control.
    • status = Actuator status.
    • actPos = Actuator mesurement in mm or 0.1 degrees.
    • reserved = Reserved for future use.

  • Measurement sensors array. Logged if numOfMeas is greater than 0.

  • "ETH_CTRL_IN 1031: Measurements[0] type 1, measVal 0"

    • Measurements[i] = Array index of sensor.
    • type = Sensor type.
    • measVal = Measurement value. Distances in millimeters, angles in 0.1 degrees, weights in kilograms.

Outcoming message from Navitrol:

  • Set parameter log_veh_inte_eth to 2

  • "ETH_CTRL_OUT 1131: sent num 124, msgStatus 0, numOfActuators 2"

    • sent num = Message number, should be increased by one for each message
    • msgStatus = 0 ok, 1 configuration error (an actuator section is sent with status bit 15 set)
    • numOfActuators = Number of actuators that Navitrol controls

  • Actuator array. Logged if numOfActuators is greater than 0.

  • "ETH_CTRL_OUT 1131: type 1, refVal 150, binary 1"

    • type = Actuator type
    • refVal = Actuator reference value in millimeters or 0.1 degrees
    • binary = Actuator status. Bit0 = activate, bit1 = increase, bit2 = decrease

CAN Encoder. Schwarzmueller or Curtis

Incoming mesage to Navitrol:

  • Check that this parameter is enabled: can_actuator_ctrl_model
  • "HAL_CopyActuatorMeasToShared: Actuator 0 measured value 50 mm"
    • Actuator = Actuator index
    • measured value = Measured value in mm.

Outcoming message from Navitrol:

  • Fork up, using rpm.

  • "HAL_ControlSingleCanActuatorRPM: Actuator 0 control: refval 0.5, activate 1, outputRPM 500, maxOutputRPM 1000, brakes 0".

    • Actuator = Actuator index
    • refVal = Reference value in m
    • activate = If actuator should be activated
    • outputRPM = RPM value out
    • maxOutputRPM = Maximum RPM value. actuator_ctrl_max_output parameter.
    • brakes = Brakes enabled or not

  • Fork down, using proportional valve.

  • "Actuator p control, out 500, err 10, Pout 1.5, Iout 1000, min 0, max 1000"

    • out = Output value for valve
    • err = Error value for control
    • Pout = Proportional value for controller
    • Iout = Integral value for controller
    • min = Minimum value of the control. can_actuator_ctrl_prop_valve_min parameter.
    • max = Maximum value of the control. can_actuator_ctrl_prop_valve_max parameter.

Scanner Lift Actuator

Updated 26.01.2024

Overview

Scanner lift control is a feature that makes it possible to raise and lower 2D laser scanner to detect targets or empty space from multiple heights. This is often required in racking applications.

Scanner lift is controlled with target values given by the Navitrol. Customer controls the lift based on those references and sends measured scanner height value to Navitrol.

Typically, Navitrol controls the scanner between scanner home position (actuator_scanner_lift_home_val_mm) and detection level (actuator_scanner_lift_detection_level_val_mm), but if there is not enough room to move the scanner reference value can be something between the two.

Use cases

  • Rack height detection

  • Empty space detection

  • Load detection

  • Unload buffers

Preconditions

  • Communication interface for sending scanner lift height measurements and reading the height references. For example, supervisor message 1031 actuator type sensor lift can be used.

Set up

Parameters

  1. datatype, parameter_name, default value

  2. I, actuator_scanner_lift_enabled, 0

    • Scanner lift that is attached to fork. 1 enabled, 0, disabled

    • Set to 1

  3. I,actuator_scanner_lift_type, 2

    • 1 = manual control, 2 = reference value controlled actuator, 3 = binary controlled actuator (low/high pos only)

    • NOTE! With type 3, the measurement height of the scanner is not known and the safety height check is done only based on the actuator_scanner_lift_detection_level_val_mm parameter. The assumption is that the scanner lift is controlled to that height when decreasing it to low position. If the target height goes below the safety height, the scanner lift is increased to high position.

  4. I, actuator_scanner_lift_home_val_mm, 0

    • Home value for scanner lift.

    • If the actuator_scanner_lift_type is 3, this parameter should be a height where the scanner is on the high position.

    • Value relative to the fork

      • Positive > scanner above the fork

      • zero > scanner at the fork level

      • Negative > scanner below the fork

    • Should be safe for any fork height and a bit above the fork level if used for load detection

  • I, actuator_scanner_lift_detection_level_val_mm, -150

    • Scanner height value in which the scanner can see past a loaded resource.

    • If the AGV is loaded scanner is moved to this height when it is used for detection

    • If the actuator_scanner_lift_type is 3, this parameter should be a height where the scanner is on the low position below the fork.

    • Value relative to fork

      • Positive > scanner above the fork

      • zero > scanner at the fork level

      • Negative > scanner below the fork

  • I, actuator_scanner_lift_min_safe_val_mm, 100

    • Minimum allowed difference from the zero height of the fork to scanner lift height value

    • Measured by lowering the fork to minimum height and then lowering the scanner as low as safely possible. The measured scanner lift height value at that position is the value for actuator_scanner_lift_min_safe_val_mm

    • This value is used to calculate safe fork references when the scanner is below the fork and could be crushed if the fork is lowered too much.

  • I, actuator_scanner_lift_used_for_load_det, 0

    • Scanner in lift is used for load detection. 0 = No, 1 = Yes

  • I, actuator_tolerance_scanner_lift_mm, 2

    • Tolerance for scanner lift. Actuator is being controlled towards target value until the measured value is inside this tolerance.

  • F, actuator_lower_scanner_before_unload_buffer_dist, 0.6

    • Distance from unload buffer when scanner is lowered (in meters)

Racking User Instructions

Updated 26.01.2024

Introduction

Warehouse racking feature introduces large inventory and warehouse support in Navitec software products. From Navitrol's point of view this means ability to load and unload items from multiple heights (shelves) in one location. Racking also comes with a variety of detection features for more accurate and safer operation.

In addition to a normal drive order to symbolic point, Navitrol gets a shelf ID which incorporates height information. Racks and shelves in the production area are defined in Navithor Tools software. Please read the Navithor Tools warehouse racking document for more information.

General Instructions

There are two minimum requirements to start up the feature in Navitrol.

  1. Update racking feature license to AGV

  2. Set parameter racking_mode to 1

For loading and unloading, parameter actuator_load_aboard_offset_mm needs to be defined. This tells how much forks are lifted to pick up a pallet. Note that in racking it is required that parameter actuator_load_min_val is set to 0. Next, it is represented how to define fork movements when approaching the rack.

Define fork movements close to rack

For safety, it is important to carefully define the minimum distance from the rack symbolic points outside of which AGV can move the forks while driving. This ensures that if the AGV is still trying to move the forks while inside the distance limit, it will stop to an error avoiding possible collision to shelf. This parameter is called racking_min_dist_rack_to_move_actuator_meters. To avoid safety errors, parameter called racking_check_point_before_min_dist_rack_offset_m is introduced. This parameter defines the distance from the safety limit where AGV is triggered to stop if forks are still not at target height or AGV must do some detection routines like pallet detection or empty space detection (see Figure 1). AGV continues driving when the detection routines are ready and forks are on the correct height. This offset parameter is used also when leaving rack to make sure that it is safe to start lowering the fork.

Error: ERROR_ACTUATOR_OUT_OF_TOLERANCES_CLOSE_TO_RACK

Figure 1: Minimum distance from rack symbolic point to allow fork movements (left fig.). Check point to stop AGV for controlling forks to target level and to do detection routines (right fig.).

Define fork movements approaching rack

There are two options how AGV can approach the rack. In first option, AGV can move the forks to target level while driving before it gets close to the rack. In second option, AGV drives close to the rack forks down and stops in front of the rack to control forks to the target level.

The following set of parameters can be used to control fork movements while approaching the rack:

ParameterDescription
actuator_move_allowed_while_driving_loadedto allow fork control while driving and carrying a pallet.
actuator_move_allowed_while_driving_unloadedto allow fork control while driving without pallet.
racking_max_dist_from_rack_begin_lift_actuator_metersdefines how early the AGV can start controlling forks to target level.
racking_actuator_speed_loaded_mm_per_stells the speed of the forks when AGV is carrying a pallet. It is used to calculate starting point for lifting the forks so that they are at target level before the check point in front of the rack.
racking_actuator_speed_not_loaded_mm_per_stells the speed of the forks while driving without pallet.

Define AGV speed approaching and close to rack

AGV's speed in racking uses the same principals as in normal navigation. However, there can be an additional limitation for AGV's speed when forks are not at driving level or so-called home position. Even if the speed limitation is not taken into use, the parameters that describe the speed are used for calculating the start point for controlling forks to next target level. This is in case forks can be moved while driving.

Parameters:

ParameterDescription
actuator_not_in_home_position_limit_agv_speedto limit speed when forks are not at home position
actuator_not_in_home_position_agv_speed_loaded_m_per_sdefines the speed when AGV is carrying a pallet and forks are not at home position
actuator_not_in_home_position_agv_speed_unloaded_m_per_sdefines the speed when AGV is driving without pallet and forks are not at home position
actuator_home_val_mmdefines the home position when driving without a pallet.
This can be either actuator_min_val or the actuator value defined in route properties in Navithor Tools, whichever is larger.

Actuator zones

Actuator zones are polygons in the map that can be added and edited in Navithor Tools. When AGV is inside a zone, certain detections and actions take place depending on the type of the zone. AGV is considered to be inside Actuator zone when one of its corner points or navigation point is inside the zone. There is also a small safety margin applied around AGV to extend the corner points from the actual dimensions. There are two types of Actuator zones which are next represented in more detail.

Safety zone

Actuator safety zone is planned to be used close to racks. It is meant as a redundant safety method if the main logic would fail. It detects if the target value of the forks differs more than tolerance from the measured value and if so, triggers an error to stop the AGV. This means it only supervises that forks are not controlled of tolerances when they are inside a rack, and that target value does not change when inside a rack. The safety zone feature does not check whether the forks will hit the shelf when driving to the rack and it does not know if a pallet is being pushed for example.

Error: ERROR_ACTUATOR_SAFE_ZONE_VIOLATION Parameter(s):

  • actuator_safety_zone_margin_meters to extend corners of the AGV's frame for actuator safety zone check.

Home position zone

Home position zone is meant for driving in the cross aisles and generally whenever it is needed to drive with forks down. When AGV is inside the zone, it is forced to lower the forks to home position which ensures safety driving outside of the rack corridors. If the AGV enters the zone with forks not at the home position, target value for the forks immediately changes to the home position value. User can choose whether AGV stops or can continue driving while moving the forks to home position.

ParameterDescription
actuator_home_valis home position when driving without a pallet. When carrying a pallet home position is actuator_home_val + actuator_load_aboard_offset_mm.
actuator_home_pos_safety_margin_metersto extend corners of the AGV's frame for actuator home position zone check.
actuator_strict_for_home_pos_zone0 = continue driving while controlling forks to home position, 1 = stop the AGV while controlling forks to home position.

Figure 2: Use of actuator home position zone. When AGV comes out of the rack aisle to the cross aisle, it is forced to control the forks to home position.

Pallet detection

Pallet detection modes

Two modes:

  • 1. Pallet detection:Check pallet location and angle.

  • 2. Pocket detection:Scanning the correct height for the pallet legs using scanner and controlling the forks to the middle of the legs.

Docking. Meaning that AGV will change theroute to drive to the detected target.

Pallet location check

Pallet detection in the racking feature means that pallet location and angle is verified using pallet detection. If the angle is too high or if pallet is too far from the expected location, error is set.

Symbolic point location depends on the navigation point (AGV kinematics), so it might not be on the middle of the rack.docking_stop_distanceparameter is usedto check thepalletlocation related to thesymbolicpoint. Then the pallet location is verified with parameterdocking_max_dist_error_from_end_point. If the pallet is further away from the symbolic point, error will be set. The pallet angle is checked with parameterdocking_max_target_angle. These checks are doneon both modes, also after pocket detection has controlled the forks to the pocket height.

Figure 3: Symbolic point related to the pallet location.

Pocket detection

Pocket detection is a feature that will search the correct height for the pocket (space between the legs) using laser scanner.

Sequence:

  • When the forks are lifted to shelf level, the target height value is decreased bystack_loading_max_pocket_size_mmamount to start the scan and to make sure the scanner is below the legs of the pallet. SeeMin height to allow pocketson Figure 4.

  • Then the pallet detection is activated and target height is set to two times thisstack_loading_max_pocket_size_mmparameter. SeeMaxpocket heighton aFigure 4.

  • Now during the lifting phase, thelow and highheights of the legs are stored. SeeFigure 5.

  • When the lifting is done, the last found pocket that is over thestack_loading_min_pocket_size_mm parameter is chosen.

  • ERROR_PALLET_POCKET_NOT_FOUNDis set if there are no pockets found on this phase.

  • Then the actuator is controlled to the middle of the pocket. Here the height difference between the actuator height and scanner height is taken into account using the measurement of the scanner height (if available) + offset parameter or only the offset parameter:target_detection_actuator_offset_to_scanner_mm.

Figure 4: Example of the pocket detection.

Figure 5: Pocket height values. The pocket height is middle of these two values.

Pallet detection errors

This error is set if pocket is not within max and min limit parameters.

  • ERROR_PALLET_POCKET_NOT_FOUND: Couldn'tfindsuitablepocket.

  • This will be fatal error, so it would needoperatoractionto reset.

This error is set if target heading is too large or iftarget is too far from symbolic pointor if target is not found.

  • ERROR_PALLET_DET_FAILURE:Couldn't find pallet or target is too far away from expected location

  • This will be fatal error, so it would needoperatoractionto reset.

Pallet detection parameters

ParameterDescription
I,racking_pallet_det_mode, 10 = Disable the check
1 = pallet detection checked on precheck state
2 = Trying to find the middle point of the pocket by scanning the shelf height +-stack_loading_max_pocket_size_mm.
I,racking_pocket_det_height_offset_mm, 0Offset added to the detected pocket height.
I,docking_to_target_enabled, 11 = Enables docking to target.
2 = docking with custom route
F,docking_stop_distance,Used to calculate new stopping point for AGV navigation point. Calculated from navigation point to the pallet front line.Depends on AGV kinematics.
F,docking_max_dist_error_from_end_point,0.2Used to check that pallet is found close enough the rack symbolic point
F,docking_max_start_angle, 10.0Max allowed angle for the pallet related to the symbolic point.
I,stack_loading_max_pocket_size_mm, 130Max allowed height for pocket. Used also to lift the forks over the shelf height to make sure that we detect the pocket. Shelf height +- this parameter.
I,stack_loading_min_pocket_size_mm, 70Min allowed height for pocket.
I,stack_loading_min_hits_top_legs, 2Counter for consecutive leg detections. When legs are detected enough times, the height measurement from first detection is used as pocket bottom value.
I,stack_loading_min_false_hits_legs, 2Counter for consecutive false leg detections. When legs are not detected enough times, the height measurement from first scan is used as pocket top value.
I,target_detection_actuator_offset_to_scanner_mmHeight offset from the scanner to the fork. Used to get the correct height for the fork when detecting the middle point of pocket with scanner. Because when the scanner sees the middle point, the fork might not be on correct level to be able to drive to the pocket. If the scanner can be moved, then its measurement value + this offset is used instead.

Beam detection

The idea with the beam detection is to detect the shelf height with scanner. If the shelf height is only defined in Tools, itmight betoo risky to use because the height needs to be measured accurately to avoid hitting the shelf.

NOTE!The beam detection is done only when the AGV is loaded and driving to emptyshelf to do unload.

Figure 6: Shelf example.

Sequence:

  • On the precheck state, the scanner will be decreased to low position (also might require lowering the forks for a small amount).

  • The forks are lifted to predefined height. The height should be high enough so the whole shelf can be detected with the scanner.

  • The pallet detection is enabled with linear model search. There is assumption for the length of the shelf (pallet_model_width_y+pallet_det_linear_model_max_err).

  • The detected line is matched for this assumption.

  • If the shelf is detected, we keep increasing.

  • Whenthe shelf is not detected anymore (meaning that we had detected it before at least once) -> The current detection height is the shelf height.

  • Thenracking_shelf_height_to_fork_offset_mmparameter and the scanner height measurement are added to this detected height to get correct height for the actuator.

  • Lines that are longer than the assumption are accepted. There is alsocheckforthe x and y coordinates and the angle to makes sure that we detect the shelf and not wallbehind the shelf.

Figure 7: The start of the beam detection. Here the AGV is on the Precheck state and the forks are lifted to the shelf level.

NOTE!racking_shelf_height_mmdefines the distance from the safe drive-in height to below the shelf height. The forks are lowered to this height just to make sure that we scan the whole shelf. The scan will be started after the forks are at correct position below the shelf.This parameter should be the height of the shelf. If there are shelves with different heights, this parameter should have the value of the shelf that has the largest value.

Figure 8: Start of the scan. Here the scanner is decreased below the shelf to start detecting the beam.

When the beam detection does not detect the shelf anymore, the lifting is stopped, and that scanning height is used as a shelfheight. Theheight for the fork will be then measured fork height -- measured scanner height +racking_shelf_height_to_fork_offset_mm

Figure 9: End of the beam detection. Here the shelf height is detected with the scanner and that is used to control the forks to correct height.

Beam detection error

This error is set if the actuator reaches the target height on the lifting phase and the shelf top height is not detected.

  • ERROR_RACKING_BEAM_DETECTION_FAILED:Could notfind suitable beam for detecting the shelf height.

  • This will be fatal error, so it would needoperator actionto reset.

Beam detection parameters

ParameterDescription
I,racking_shelf_height_detection_enabled, 11 = enable beam detection
0 = disable
I,racking_shelf_height_mm, 100Defines roughly the height of the shelf
F,racking_shelf_max_dist_err_m, 0.2Maximum distance where the shelf can be from the symbolic point (uses docking_stop_distance)
F,racking_shelf_max_angle_err_deg, 10.0Maximum angle error for detected shelf
I,racking_shelf_height_to_fork_offset_mm, 30Offset from the accurate shelf height to the fork height, where the AGV can safely drive in and out from the shelf without hitting the shelf.
I,actuator_load_aboard_offset_mm, 100Height offset when AGV is loaded
I,actuator_scanner_lift_detection_level_val_mm,Detection height for the scanner (related to the fork). If the scanner is not movable, this can be used as an offset.
F,pallet_model_width_y[0], 0.8Pallet width. If we detect something that is wider than any of pallet models (+ error), it is defined as beam
F,pallet_det_linear_model_max_err, 0.05Error added to the pallet width.

Empty space detection

Empty space detection is a feature that will check if the unload location is empty using the laser scanner. This is used only when the AGV is loaded and driving to unload location.

Sequence:

  • Starts when the AGV is at precheck state. This detection is used only on unload case.

  • Search area is the pallet size.

  • Search height can be set in two ways:

    • From the current shelf height to the shelf height above -- offset parameter.

    • Height is current shelf height + height parameter.

  • At first, the scanner is decreased to detection height and forks are lifted to level where the scanner can see above the shelf.

  • AGV starts scanning the area by lifting the forks. The empty space check is done only when lifting up. After the scan, the forks are lowered back to the shelf height.

  • If the area has more scanner points than the limit (the max number of scanner points can be set with parameter), the area is not empty, and error is set. If no scanner points are found, the area is empty and AGV can continue driving to the shelf.

NOTE! If pallet detection is used, the last found pallet model is used to define the search area. If pallet detection is not used, the pallet model with index 0 is used as default.

Figure 10: Empty space height to the shelf above.

Figure 11: Search area from above.

Symbolic point location depends on the navigation point (AGV kinematics), so it might not be on the middle of the rack. The docking_stop_distance is used to check the correct location related to the symbolic point. Then the empty space detection is used only for the area where the pallet will be unloaded. The pallet length and width are known based on the pallet detection results from last load point or the zero index pallet model parameters.

The Navitrol 6.32 has two additional parameters that can define larger area for empty space detection. These values are added to the pallet dimensions (width and length). The parameters are empty_space_area_width_addition_m and empty_space_area_length_addition_m

Empty space detection error

This error is set if scanner points exceed the occup_check_min_hits on the search area.

  • ERROR_RACKING_EMPTY_SPACE_NOT_DETECTED: Unload area not free, cannot continue driving.

  • This will be fatal error, so it would need operator action to reset.

Empty space detection parameters

ParameterDescription
I,racking_empty_space_check_mode:10 = Disable the check, 1 = Check to the height of the rack above, 2 = Use onlyracking_empty_space_det_height_mmparameter to define the height.
I,occup_check_min_hits, 2Defines how many scanner points are needed inside the search area to trigger the error.
I,racking_empty_space_det_height_mm, 200How far from the current shelf we can lift the actuator to check the empty space. By default, the height is taken from the shelf above, but if it is not found this parameter is used. In most cases, increasing only 20cm might already be enough to see if the unload area is empty or not.
I,racking_shelf_height_mm, 100Estimate for the shelf height. Used in empty space detection to get the detection height below the shelfabove.
F,docking_stop_distance,Used to get thesearch area related to thesymbolic point. Calculated from symbolic point to the imagined unloadlocation (pallet front line).
F,pallet_model_width_y[0], 0.8Width of the search area.
F,pallet_model_length_x[0], 1.25Length of the search area. Calculated from thesymbolic point +docking_stop_distance.
F,empty_space_area_width_addition_m, 0.00Positive value increases the width of the empty space detection area. This value is added to the pallet width to both directions. If this value is 0.05 and width is 0.8 the safety area width is 0.9. Min -1.0 Max 1.0 (meters)
F,empty_space_area_length_addition_m, 0.00Positive value increases the length of the empty space detection area. This value is added to the pallet length to both directions. If this value is 0.05 and length is 1.25 the safety area length is 1.35. Min -1.0 Max 1.0 (meters)

Data Matrix marker detection for position correction of side loader loading position

Data matrix detection is used to detect the position of a marked load to ensure the correct picking position. Additionally, the identity of the load is verified to ensure that the correct load is picked. The detection works according to the following sequence.

  • The AGV gets a drive order to a symbolic point for loading.
  • The AGV stops a certain distance before the loading point and raises the actuator to the basic shelf level increased with an additional marker detection height.
  • When the actuator is at the search height, the camera gets a start measuring signal
  • Measurements are collected until five measurements give approximately the same stopping point
  • The AGV drives further to the calculated stopping point.
  • When the distance is driven and the AGV has stopped, the stopping position is verified with an additional marker detection. After verification the camera measurements are stopped.
  • If the AGV position is within accuracy limits, the target marker ID is sent to the fleet control for verification. If the stopping accuracy limit is not met, the picking sequence is interrupted.
  • If the marker ID is correct, the racking sequence continues with a loading command from fleet control, else the load is not picked and the racking sequence is ended.
  • A new drive order can be given.

Marker detection errors

This error is set if the camera is not providing measurements when requested:

  • ERROR_MARKER_DETECTION_INACTIVE: Marker detection sensor not responding to activation, check connections and configuration

This error is set if the actuator reference is set too high for marker detection:

  • ERROR_DETECTION_TARGET_REF_TOO_HIGH: Target detection reference goes higher than actuator_max_val

Marker detection parameters

The target marker detection is currently implemented for racking, therefore the below racking paramters shall be set.

The camera used for marker detection is handled as an external localization sensor requiring the additional below parameters.

ParameterDescription
F,target_verification_distance_from_sym_point,0.08Stopping for target position verification at this distance [m] from symbolic point. Suitable values 0.050.15 largely depending on camera optics and detection distance.
F,racking_max_dist_from_rack_begin_lift_actuator_meters, 0The earliest point to start moving the actuator to rack level. Distance in meters. Must be bigger than target_verification_distance_from_sym_point
I,target_marker_search_height_mm, 0Additional lifting of the actuator over its nominal level for detection purposes. A slight angle between camera and load is recommended and the height is adjusted accordingly
F,target_marker_stop_accuracy_limit, 0.01Required stopping accuracy to end point of the correction drive.
F,target_marker_position_offset, 0.0Position offset between marker and lifting (mid) point of the load. Positive value when the marker is on the right of the lifting point when the load is seen from the AGV.
I,racking_mode, 10 = disabled 1 = enabled.
I,racking_pallet_det_mode, 30 = disabled, 1 = check that pallet is found on Precheck state, 2 = check that pocket is found on Precheck state, 3 = marker detection to localize load; min 0, max 3.
I,ext_loc_eth_model[0], 2model 2 is the Sick Lector which currently is the only sensor type for this kind of detection. The first external sensor defined to be of type 2 is selected for use.
S,ext_loc_eth_ip[0]IP according to camera settings.
I,ext_loc_eth_port[0]Port according to camera settings.
F, ext_loc_x_offset[0]camera longitudinal position offset on the vehicle. 0 if in the vehicle navigation point i.e., on Y-axis.
F,ext_loc_y_offset[0]camera transversal position offset, 0 in the vehicle navigation point i.e. on X-axis.
F,ext_loc_h_offset_deg[0]0 heading offset in degrees between machine coordinate system and camera coordinate system, horizontal heading angle of focal axis.
F,ext_loc_focal_orientation_deg[0]0 orientation of camera coordinates around focal axis. The rotation angle is the angle between the X-axis of the yellow camera coordinate frame and the X-axis of the red navigation coordinate frame measured from the red X-axis.

Figure 12: Camera coordinate frame and Navitrol coordinate frame. If the camera is mounted cables down, the ext_loc_focal_orientation_deg shall be -90 degrees, if the cables are pointing up-wards it shall be +90 degrees.

The marker position on the load should match the camera position on the fork or machine. So, the marker position offset parameter should be the same as the camera ext_loc_x_offset.

Figure 13: Basic case with camera on the centre line of the fork or machine and the marker on the centre line of the loading point.

Figure 14: If the camera is set with an offset to the centre line, all markers must have the same offset.

Figure 15: Camera offsets relative to the vehicle coordinates i.e., the navigation point of the vehicle.

Buffer Lanes

Updated 23.02.2024

Introduction

Buffer lanes are a feature that allows unloading resources one after another and similarly loading first resource from a line of resources. Normally there can be only one resource per symbolic point but with this feature it is possible to add a buffer area, that can fit multiple resources. Figure 1 shows example of the unload buffer. On that Figure, the object is detected with scanner and then the AGV does the unload in specified distance from that detected object.

Figure 1: Example picture of unload buffer.

Unload buffer

Unload buffer is a feature that allows AGV to unload resources in a line. When AGV is inside the buffer area, it uses laser scanner to detect where the last unloaded resource is and calculates the unload location for the carried resource. Then AGV drives to that calculated unload location, performs unload and continues driving to next mission.

Load buffer

Load buffer is a feature that allows AGV to load the last resource from a line of resources. When AGV is inside the buffer area, it uses sensor information to detect where the last resource is on the line and calculates load location to be able to pick the resource. There are two sensor options: 1. Laser scanner to detect where the last resource is on the buffer area or 2. Load sensor information to know when the forks are under a resource to pick it up. Then AGV drives to the calculated load location, performs load and continues to unload location.

Requirements

  • Pallet detection license

  • Navitrol 6.28 (6.32 for docking)

  • Laser scanner to detect the object on the buffer area.

  • Navithor 2.3.0.2

Buffer lane feature

This Chapter explains buffer lane load and unload features with more detail and Navitrol parameters that affects to the performance.

Unload buffer

Laser scanner for object detection:

  • Must see the resource when AGV is driving on buffer area

  • Must see a cluster of scanner measurement points

  • Full pallet detection is not needed

Cluster parameters:

  • pallet_det_min_points_close_to_first_point defines how many scanner points are required for cluster

  • pallet_det_2_max_dist_to_first_point defines distance between consecutive cluster points.

AGV distance to detected object:

  • buffer_stop_dist_from_object_when_unloading parameter defines the distance from detected object where to perform the unload.

Search area:

  • pallet_model_width_y[0] parameter defines the search area, where the scanner points are searched for. See Figure 2 below.

Figure 2: Unload search area

Load buffer

Load buffer has three different modes:

  1. Object detected with scanner

  2. Pallet detected with scanner

  3. Load sensor is triggered.

Figure 3: Load buffer search area

Mode 1: Object detection with scanner

This is the same functionality as on the unload. This means that the scanner needs only few scanner points close to each other to detect an object on the route buffer (See above what parameters affects to the clusters).

  • buffer_stop_dist_from_object_when_loading defines the stopping point from the detected object and the distance is calculated from navigation point to the object.

The downside with this mode is that it might detect anything on the route, so the accuracy might vary.

Mode 2: Pallet detection with scanner

This mode uses full pallet detection and also has this object detection feature (same as mode 1) as a safety.

  • buffer_stop_dist_from_object_when_loading defines the stopping point and the distance is calculated from navigation point to the pallet's front line.

  • buffer_stop_distance_from_unwanted_object defines the distance from detected object to stop the AGV if pallet is not detected.

  • buffer_max_dist_from_route_to_target defines maximum allowed sideways distance that the pallet can have from the route. Error is set if the pallet is further.

Mode 3: Load sensor

Load sensor needs to give Navitrol information when the AGV has driven under the pallet and is ready for performing the load. The AGV is driving on the route and waiting this load sensor to trigger, otherwise it will just drive to the end symbolic point.

  • buffer_stop_dist_from_object_when_loading defines the distance how far the AGV can still drive after the load sensor is triggered. In many cases, this can be small number e.g., 0.05, the sign depends on the driving direction.

Docking

Docking is released on 6.32 release. It means that AGV can correct its position sideways on the buffer area. This Chapter explains only the basic idea of Docking. More info can be found from Navitrol Pallet Detection Instructions document

These parameters have to be set to enable docking:

  • docking_to_target_enabled 1 (omni or mechanum) or 2 (steer or differential drive AGV)

  • Load_buffer_mode 2

  • Docking_stop_distance replaces the buffer_stop_dist_from_object_when_loading when docking is used.

NOTE! The buffer_check_start_dist_offset_m should have large enough value to allow some space for the docking. If this parameter is zero or too small, the pallet detection starts when the AGV is inside the buffer area. This can be too late to start docking if the buffer is full and the pallet is very close to the buffer start.

Docking requires pallet detection tag to be enabled on Tools, otherwise the AGV will drive only on the route as in normal buffer lane.

Figure 4: Docking requires pallet detection tag for the Symbolic point on Tools.

The docking has two extra start conditions for load buffer. See Figure 5 and Figure 6.

  • The calculated stop point has to be closer to the route than the buffer_max_dist_from_route_to_target parameter.

  • The calculated stop point cannot be further away from the Symbolic point (behind the SP) than the docking_max_dist_error_from_end_point parameter. This replaces the normal docking start condition that check only the target distance to the SP.

Figure 5: First start condition: Distance to route cannot be too high. It is calculated sideways (see the red arrow).

Figure 6: Second start condition: Stop point cannot be too far behind the Symbolic point.

Other start conditions and more information about the docking can be found from the Navitrol Pallet Detection Instructions document.

Creating Buffer Lanes

Creating a buffer lane for a Load or Unload point is done by setting a buffer distance and enabling the buffer. This can only be done for symbolic points with the type Load or Unload. The size of the lane is visualized in magenta. The UI is displayed in Figure 5.

As a limitation buffer lane cannot currently span across multiple links. Additionally, the load or unload point must only have a single link connected thus it needs to be at the end of a link.

NOTE: buffer_check_start_dist_offset_m, 2.0 by default**,** parameter is offset value that is added to the buffer lane start point. If the buffer lane is 10m on the Tools and this parameter is 1.0 m, it means that the buffer is actually 11.0 m long.

Figure 7. Creating Buffer Lanes. 1: Symbolic point type has to be Load or Unload or both. 2: Enable Buffer Lane feature. 3: Set Buffer area distance, illustrated in magenta on the route.

Fleet control settings

Using buffer buffer lanes in production requires following TCParameters to be set:

  • ResourceManager_ResourceContainerType -- Single

  • ResourceManager_ConstainerStackType -- CombineSameType

Optionally:

  • ProductionManager_UnloadLocationAssignMode -- buffer_balance

  • SymbolicPoint_BUFFER_FULL_DISTANCE_REMAINING -- any value

Unload location assign mode buffer_balance prioritizes unload point with most space left in the buffer. Navithor updates the space remaining in a buffer every time a resource is unloaded to it. The buffer is full if the symbolic point resource count is full or if there is no space on the buffer area to unload anymore pallets. The resource length is taken from the machine type parameter xml file. If the point is set empty, the space left in buffer is also reset.

Buffer full distance remaining sets when we consider the buffer to be full. The buffer is considered full when Navithor believes that the space left in buffer is lower than this value.

Grouping symbolic points

If there are multiple buffer lanes on the production area, the symbolic points can be grouped. Then the production orders can be set to the whole group and Navithor chooses the target buffer based on the UnloadLocationAssignMode parameter. When one buffer becomes full, the order is automatically switched to the next buffer area on that group.

Example edge cases:

  • You have a buffer that can fit 4 resources and 3 resources are already unloaded to the buffer. 1 resource is taken manually away from the buffer. Now Navithor still has info that there are 3 resources, even though 1 is carried away. Then Navithor will only deliver one resource to the buffer and set the buffer as full, even though in reality there would be space for another resource.

  • Resources are cleared on the buffer symbolic point, even though the area is actually full. Navithor creates order to take pallet to the buffer. When AGV comes to the beginning of the buffer it detects that the area is actually full and send the status to Navithor. Then Navithor changes the status to full, abort the drive to this buffer and select another available buffer if it is allowed. If selecting another buffer is not possible for example if the symbolic points are not Grouped, the AGV will just wait on that location until the buffer is cleared manually.

Navitrol Monitor buffer visualization

The load buffer with pallet detection (mode 2) draws normal pallet based on the pallet model parameters to the location where the pallet is found.

Figure 8: Normal pallet with load buffer mode 2.

The unload buffer and load buffer mode 1 doesn't use full pallet detection so they don't provide enough data to draw the full pallet. Instead, they will draw a green circle to the location, where the closest cluster is found, see Figure 9. This green circle is also used on the load buffer mode 2 if there is some object ahead and the pallet is not detected. The green circle is added to the 6.30.00 release, but versions before that draws the pallet to the location where the object is found. In some cases, with the old versions, the pallet might be drawn with weird angle, because of the missing data.

Figure 9: The green object detection circle.

Instructions how to set Navitrol parameters

Required parameters

I,target_detection_type_selection, 3 # Enables ref docking or pallet detection, 0 = disabled, 1 = refl docking, 2 = pallet detection, 3 = pallet detection ver 2 (allows buffer detection)

I,target_detection_scan_selection, 3 # Defines which scanners are used for target detection: 1 = rear scanner only, 2 = front scanner only, 3 = both scanners (supported only in refl docking and pallet detection ver 2)

Pallet model should be set into the parameters with array index of 0. Important parameters for buffers are:

I,pallet_model_enabled[0], 1 # 1 = pallet model enabled

F,pallet_model_width_y[0], 0.80 # Used for determining width of the buffer to check if it is free or not Parameters that can be added to params.txt to enable this buffer feature, change how close to the object the AGV stops in the buffer zone and how early it starts checking, if the buffer is free or not:

I,buffer_lanes_enabled, 1 # 0 = disable buffer lane feature, 1 = enable.

F,buffer_stop_dist_from_object_when_unloading, -2.0 # Stopping distance (m) from the closest object, when unloading in a buffer. Calculated from navigation point to the first scanner measurements seen on the buffer zone.

F,buffer_check_start_dist_offset_m, 1.0 # The minimum distance from navigation point to the buffer zone, when the AGV starts checking if the unload buffer is free or not

F, buffer_stop_dist_from_object_when_loading, -0.05 # Stopping offset (m) for load buffer. Calculated from navigation point. Depends on the sensor, if this parameter needs to be set. If pallet is detected really early it might be useful to have some value to make sure that the pallet is actually loaded.

I, load_buffer_mode, 2 # 0 = none, 1 = detect any objects based on scanner measurements, 2 = detect a pallet, 3 = external sensor (Load Detected bit on Supervisor status or CAN)

I, unload_buffer_mode, 1 # 0 = none, 1 = detect any objects based on scanner measurements

Increasing speed on buffer lanes

Navitrol has implementation, that disables the safety scanner field based on distance from a detected object. This is useful if the AGV has safety scanner installed statically to the body of the AGV, so the scanner doesn't move with the fork.

The main goal for this implementation is to drive faster out from an unload buffer and faster in to a load buffer. If the scanner is safety scanner and its safety has to be disabled when the fork is down, because otherwise it will trigger safety stop. On the buffer lanes, the safety is disabled only when the AGV is close to the load or unload, so the AGV can drive faster and safer further away on the buffer lane.

Driving faster on buffer lanes with this kind of fork setup, requires Navitrol to handle the disable safety message more efficiently based on the distance to the pallet. This means:

On load buffer:

  • The route has a fork height above scanner, so the scanner can see where the pallet is on the buffer.

  • The route speed can be set to normal driving speed.

  • First, the scanner detects the pallet on the route.

  • The AGV starts slowing down to disable_safety_limit_speed when it reaches the load_buffer_slow_down_distance from the detected pallet.

  • When AGV reaches the distance of disable_safety_distance_on_buffer to the pallet, the safety is requested to be disabled (supervisor status section 11 Disable safety) and the fork is decreased to actuator_min_val.

    • Note! If pallet detection scanner can continue detecting pallet when the fork is on the floor, set this parameter to 1: buffer_allow_drive_end_update_when_safety_is_disabled

  • AGV drives under the pallet and picks it up.

  • Continues to unload location.

On Unload buffer:

  • The route has a fork height above scanner, so the scanner can see where the last unloaded pallet is on the buffer.

  • The route speed can be set to normal driving speed.

  • First, the scanner detects the pallet on the route.

  • The AGV starts slowing down to disable_safety_limit_speed when it reaches the unload_buffer_slow_down_distance from the detected pallet.

  • When AGV reaches the distance of disable_safety_distance_on_buffer to the pallet, the safety is requested to be disabled (supervisor status section 11 Disable safety).

  • The AGV drives to Unload location and unloads the pallet.

  • When AGV start driving to next location, it keeps the fork at actuator_min_val for the docking_limit_leave_speed_and_actuator_height_dist distance from the last unload location.

  • The speed is limited to docking_limit_leave_speed until the AGV is further away than this distance parameter or until the fork is above the actuator_disable_safety_max_value_mm.

  • The safety is requested to be disabled until the AGV reaches the disable_safety_distance_on_buffer distance from the last unload location.

  • When AGV is not anymore on this docking_limit distance, the speed and actuator height is taken from the route.

There is new supervisor section message to send the PLC information when Navitrol want to disable the safety on the scanner that is below the fork. The cases when Navitrol will send this message are:

  • When fork is decreased too low (the height can be set with parameter)

  • When the AGV is close to the load or unload location (the distance can be set with parameter). Note: the distance is calculated between the AGV and the detected pallet on buffer lane, not the symbolic point.

Setting up disable safety feature

  • When setting up the disable safety feature, the disable_safety parameter needs to be set to 1. If this parameter is 0, the supervisor message is not sent.

  • Then the disable_safety_distance_on_buffer parameter needs to be set to value, where the safety is disabled. This distance is calculated from AGV navigation point to the unload or load location (location where the navigation point is when the load or unload is done). This parameter should be larger than the safety fields on the safety scanner and it is used to disable the safety just before we arrive to load or unload point.

  • The actuator_disable_safety_max_value_mm parameter should have a value where the fork is just above the safety field and does not trigger the warning zones.

  • If the AGV has some limited speed when the safety is disabled, disable_safety_limit_speed parameter can be set to make sure that the AGV doesn't drive too fast during the limited safety.

Disable safety supervisor message

This message is sent from Navitrol to supervisor on the supervisor status field. This section (ID 11) needs to be requested by the supervisor. See Ethernet Communication specification between Navitrol and AGV supervisor_v4 document, how to request a message from Navitrol.

Disable safety section

Data fieldTypeLength (bytes)Comment
Section ID = 11Unsigned Short2
Section lengthUnsigned Integer4Length of the section
including all data fields of the section
Disable safetyByte10 = Enable safety
1 = Disable safety

Full parameter list

Target detection parameters

TypeNameMinDefaultMaxDescription
Inttarget_detection_type_selection033Enables ref docking or pallet detection, 0 = disabled, 1 = refl docking, 2 = pallet detection, 3 = pallet detection ver 2 (allows buffer detection)
Inttarget_detection_scan_selection033Defines which scanners are used for target detection: 1 = rear scanner only, 2 = front scanner only, 3 = both scanners (supported only in refl docking and pallet detection ver 2)
Inttarget_max_n_times_missing300Defines when the last target is reset. If the target is not found for this amount, the target data is cleared. Recommended value is 300 or smaller on buffer lanes.

Pallet model parameters

TypeNameMinDefaultMaxDescription
Intpallet_model_enabled[0]11 = pallet model enabled, 0 = disabled
