Floatpallet_model_width[0]0.8Used for determining width of the buffer to check if it is free or not

Buffer lane parameters

TypeNameMinDefaultMaxDescription
Floatbuffer_stop_dist_from_object_when_unloading-2.0Stopping distance (m) from the closest object, when unloading in a buffer. Calculated from navigation point to the scanner measurements seen on the buffer zone.
Intbuffer_lanes_enabled0010 = disable buffer lane feature, 1 = enable.
Intload_buffer_mode0230 = none, 1 = detect any objects based on scanner measurements, 2 = detect a pallet, 3 = external sensor (Load Detected bit on Supervisor status or CAN)
Intunload_buffer_mode0110 = none, 1 = detect any objects based on scanner measurements
Floatbuffer_check_start_dist_offset_m-5.02.05.0Higher the value, earlier the machine starts checking, if the buffer is free for unloading
Floatbuffer_stop_dist_from_object_when_loading-5.00.05.0Stopping offset (m) for load buffer. Calculated from navigation point to the target. If load sensor is used, this is just offset for the load sensor.
Floatbuffer_max_dist_from_route_to_target0.00.22.0Maximum transverse distance where the target can be from the route. If target is further away than this parameter, AGV is stopped. Also used as docking start condition (if it is enabled)
Intbuffer_stop_AGV_when_decreasing_fork_before_load0110 = Allow AGV drive while decreasing the fork, 1 = stop the AGV until the fork is decreased to the floor level. Used only if disable_safety_distance_on_buffer is used.
Floatbuffer_stop_distance_from_unwanted_object-1.01.05.0Distance to stop the AGV in front of object if using pallet detection. The distance is calculated from AGV frame. The AGV should continue driving when object is removed. Negative value stops the AGV immediately.
Floatload_buffer_slow_down_distance-1.0-1.020.0Distance to start slow down before target in m. Uses the disable_safety_limit_speed. Negative not used
Floatunload_buffer_slow_down_distance-1.0-1.020.0Distance to start slow down before target in m. Uses the disable_safety_limit_speed. Negative not used
Intunload_buffer_error_when_lane_full001Trigger fatal error if unload buffer lane is detected to be full when bringing a load.

Disable safety parameters

TypeNameMinDefaultMaxDescription
Intdisable_safety001Disable safety message is send to supervisor. 0 = not used, 1 = used
Intactuator_disable_safety_max_value_mm003000Disable safety if actuator is lower than this value, 0 = not used
Floatdisable_safety_distance_on_buffer-1.0-1.020.0Disable safety if driving closer than this distance to target in load or unload buffer, Negative or zero not used
Floatdisable_safety_limit_speed0.00.21.0Limit speed when safety is disabled, if disable_safety_distance_to_load_or_unload > 0. If it is 0, speed is not limited.
Floatdocking_limit_leave_speed_and_actuator_height_dist-2.0-1.020.0Distance from the unload location, where the speed and fork height is limited to the actuator_min_val. If negative, they are not limited. If enabled, had to be smaller than docking_mode_to_fleet_control_dist parameter.
Floatdocking_limit_leave_speed0.00.21.0Limit speed while driving out from unload location, if docking_limit_leave_speed_and_actuator_height_dist > 0. If it is below 0, speed is not limited.
Intbuffer_allow_drive_end_update_when_safety_is_disabled001If new drive order is received to the same destination when fork is set to floor level: 0 = keep the previous drive end, 1 = allows to update drive end point. Related to parameter disable_safety_distance_on_buffer. If AGV has pallet detection scanner that can be used when fork is at floor level, set this to 1, otherwise 0

Stack Loading Guide

Updated 13.09.2024

Introduction

Stackloading is a feature to pick up pallet from the top of the pallet stack.

Requirements

  • Sensor to detect the pockets of the pallet
    • Scanner attached to the fork (See Figure 1 for sensor location). Required to scan the whole stack while increasing the fork.
    • Possible to use any kind of sensor with external target detection
  • Possible safety sensors on the tip of the fork to stop the AGV if it is pushing something while driving in to the pocket.

Figure 1: Example picture

Specification

This chapter describes the steps that AGV performs when doing the stackloading feature. This can be used as help to check what happens or what might go wrong. See also the end of this document about the pictures of the sequence.

  • AGV drives towards the Pickup symbolic point where StackLoading is enabled

  • When the undermost pallet in the closest stack to AGV is detected, the stackloading sequence starts and the AGV drives with the forks at route height towards the pallet. At defined distance, the AGV is stopped for scanning the stack and warning WARNING_CHANGING_LOAD_OR_UNLOAD_HEIGHT is shown.

  • AGV starts scanning the stack of pallets by increasing the fork height. This step and the next step are skipped with stack_loading_stop_increase 5. Then fork is only increased to the estimated height given with the drive order from Navithor and AGV waits for a response from external target detection before it can continue driving.

  • AGV stop increasing the fork based on what method is used

    • Occupancy check: If the scanner doesn't see enough points on the area where the first pallet was detected, stop increasing the fork.

    • Leg detection: Stop increase if legs are not detected for a while.

    • Leg detection v2: Stop increase if legs are not detected for a certain height.

  • AGV starts decreasing the fork to the top pallet pocket. The pocket positions and sizes are stored to the system while doing the increase. There is also parameter to define how much the fork can be decreased from this height. If the target pocket height is too low, error is set.

  • If the top pocket is not large enough for the fork to drive in, the next suitable pocket will be chosen. The pocket min and max size can be set with parameters.

  • When the fork height is set to pocket level, the AGV starts driving to the pallet and performs pickup.

  • While lifting the pallet up, the load sensor can be used to check if the pallet is correctly placed on the fork.

  • The assumption is that the pallets on the stack are aligned same way as the bottom pallet.

  • After the load is complete, the AGV will start driving out from the stack.

  • When it reaches the same position, where it was increasing the fork, it will decrease the fork to the route level.

  • AGV continues driving to the unload symbolic point.

This warning is used when the scanning is active: WARNING_CHANGING_LOAD_OR_UNLOAD_HEIGHT.

It is enabled when the fork is started to increase for scanning the pallets and reset after the fork is moved to the pocket height and the AGV is ready for driving in to the pocket.

Limitations

  • Stackloading feature depends a lot on the leg detection part of the pallet detection algorithm. Note that pallet detection includes linear model detection (straight line that has the same width as the pallet) and leg detection. If linear model is found, then leg detection is not done. This linear model detection can be used to filter out false positives on leg detection as leg detection might detect straight lines as legs. If the leg detection can't detect the legs properly, it will affect to the stackloading success rate. Exception is the external target detection, where Navitrol only relies on external sensor input and does not do the leg detection.

  • At the moment, there is no proper way in Navitrol to detect if the AGV pushes the pallet while driving in to the pocket. This would require additional sensor (e.g., ultrasonic or laser) to detect if the pallet moves while driving in. However, it is possible to install some sensor to the tip of the fork and stop the AGV with an emergency stop on the PLC or with some other way without Navitrol.

  • If the top pallet's heading differs too much from the bottom pallet, it would be hard to pick it up, with the steer or differential AGVs. These types of AGVs requires much space for adjusting the forks to correct position in sideways, so the fork would hit the pallet leg. However, the stackloading algorithm will try to load the pallet if it can detect the pallet properly.

Setup

Navithor Tools

Stackloading feature uses virtual tag on the symbolic point (and load detection). These features need to be set in Navithor Tools when creating the environment for the AGV.

There are two options to setup the Stackloading:

  • Regular symbolic point without buffer lane. Requires load detection tag.
  • Load buffer. No load detection tag required, but buffer area tag and buffer distance are required.

Note: Stackloading tag is not needed if Navithor can give the stacking command (see Navithor document Using Buffer Lanes). Then the stacking can be decided based on each drive order.

Figure 2: Setting up stackloading: 1. Select Pickup type. 2. Enable load detection (not necessary with buffer lanes if docking not needed). 3. Open Edit Tags window. 4. Enable StackLoading tag. 5. Enable buffer lane. 6. Set Buffer lane distance.

Navitrol Parameters

TypeNameMinDefaultMaxDescription
Istack_loading_enabled0011 = Enable stackloading feature. 0 = disabled
Istack_loading_step_mm115000How much (in mm) the lift reference is changed in each step when scanning the stack. Recommended 20 or higher. Too low value might cause actuator to slow down and then speed up multiple times when it reaches close to the current target and before it has received the next reference.
Itarget_detection_actuator_offset_to_scanner_mm-3000300Scanner height offset relative to the actuator. Negative means that scanner is below the actuator. With this offset the fork should be at the correct height for loading.
Istack_loading_occupancy_min_hits001000 = disable occupancy check. Defines the minimum hits allowed on the occupancy check area. If the area has more scanner points than this parameter value the fork starts increasing and scanning for the stack until there are less points. Not used anymore as the occupancy zone is not needed anymore, the occup_check_min_hits parameter is used instead to check scanner points at the stack location.
Istack_loading_min_hits_top_legs0230How many times the legs are required to detect before stopping at the top pallet level. Used only if stack_loading_stop_increase is 1 or 2.
Istack_loading_min_hits_false0730How many false detections are required before stopping increasing the fork.
Istack_loading_stop_increase035What method is used for stopping increase and defining the stack height.
0 = none
1 = leg detection. The top of the stack is found when the legs are not detected for stack_loading_min_hits_false amount.
2 = line model and leg detection. The top of the stack is found when the legs or the linear model is not detected for stack_loading_min_hits_false amount.
3 = occupancy check. The top of the stack is found when scanner points are seen less than occup_check_min_hits inside the area of the first detected pallet.
4 = 3D camera. The top of the stack is found when point density is less than obj_reg_3d_empty_space_max_cluster_density inside the detected volume at stack location.
5 = fork is moved to estimated height. E.g. external target detection can be used to detect the pallet and give final docking height after the fork is increase to estimated height
Fstack_loading_max_dist_to_pallet_m0.01.010.0Discard found pallets if they are further than this value. Calculated from the scanner to the pallet front side. Used only with target_detection_type_selection = 2
Fstack_loading_dist_to_start_increase_m0.01.010.0Distance from navigation point to target stopping point to start increasing the fork
Istack_loading_min_pocket_size_mm010500Minimum vertical pocket height in mm. If pocket is smaller, choose the next pocket. This parameter and the next one is used to avoid the AGV to drive to the pocket that is broken or not detected correctly. Ensures that the pocket size is large enough for the fork.
Istack_loading_max_pocket_size_mm0150500Maximum vertical pocket height to allow docking, in mm. If pocket is higher, choose the next pocket
Istack_loading_min_false_hits_legs0230How many times the legs are required to false detect before detecting it as a false.
Istack_loading_enable_soft_stop0010 = Softstop is used only when increasing the fork to the top pallet level, 1 = Enable softstop also when decreasing the fork back to route level after driving out
Istack_loading_max_height_mm0300010000The maximum fork height for the scan. If the fork is still increased when reached this value, error is set.
Istack_loading_max_height_raises_error011If the fork height goes over the maximum allowed height 0 = stop increasing the fork and decrease to found pocket, 1 = set error.
Istack_loading_max_height_to_load_from_floor_mm0200010000The maximum fork height after scan is ready where the fork can still decrease to floor. If the fork is higher than this value and the pocket is found on the floor, error is set. Used to avoid picking multiple pallets.
Istack_loading_stop_increase_height_mm0010000Additional method for the stopping the increase. If this is 0, the stack_loading_min_hits_false is used to define when the increase is stopped. If this has some value, the increase is stopped when the legs are not detected while the fork is increased to the defined height. Every time the legs are detected, the target height is increased by this parameter.
Istack_loading_max_decrease_val_after_scan_mm0010000Maximum allowed decrease when the scan is done. Used to avoid selecting pocket from too low height. Recommended value is the maximum pallet height + some error. 0 not used
Istack_loading_max_retry_if_scanning_fails005Maximum number of retries if scanning doesn't find the pocket.
Fstack_loading_dist_from_stack_to_move_actuator0.01.55.0Distance from navigation point to the detected pallet front line where actuator can be controlled safely without hitting the stack.
Fblock_stacking_reset_distance_from_increase_location0.00.510.0Distance to reset the state machine if AGV is far enough from the location where the increase starts.

Example set of Navitrol parameters

Stackloading requires that pallet detection is enabled. If occupancy check is used as the increase method, then pallet detection is still used to define the stopping distance before starting to increase the fork. It is recommended to check first that the pallet can be detected before trying stackloading.

Pallet detection parameters

This chapter describes the required pallet detection and docking parameters. The pallet model parameters are based on EUR-pallet and the detection is to be done to the side defined with pallet_model_width_y parameter.

I,target_detection_type_selection,                                 3
I,target_detection_scan_selection,                                 1
I,docking_to_target_enabled,                                       1
F,docking_max_start_distance,                                   3.00
F,docking_stop_distance,                                        0.19
F,docking_approach_dist,                                        1.25
I,pallet_model_enabled[0],                                         1
F,pallet_model_width_y[0],                                      0.80
F,pallet_model_length_x[0],                                     1.25
I,pallet_model_n_legs_x[0],                                        3
I,pallet_model_n_legs_y[0],                                        3
F,pallet_model_mid_leg_width_y[0],                             0.075
F,pallet_model_mid_leg_length_x[0],                             0.19
F,pallet_model_side_leg_width_y[0],                             0.09
F,pallet_model_side_leg_length_x[0],                           0.165

Stackloading parameters

Stackloading parameters for a fork that provides scanner data to Navitrol. Scanner is used for detection. 

I,stack_loading_enabled,                                           1 
I,stack_loading_step_mm,                                          20 
I,stack_loading_min_hits_top_legs,                                 2 
I,stack_loading_min_hits_false,                                   30 
I,stack_loading_stop_increase,                                     3 
F,stack_loading_dist_to_start_increase_m,                   2.000000 
I,stack_loading_min_pocket_size_mm,                               10 
I,stack_loading_max_pocket_size_mm,                              150 
I,stack_loading_min_false_hits_legs,                               2 
I,stack_loading_max_height_mm,                                  3000 
I,stack_loading_max_height_raises_error,                           1 
I,stack_loading_max_height_to_load_from_floor_mm,               2000 
I,stack_loading_stop_increase_height_mm,                        1000
F,stack_loading_dist_from_stack_to_move_actuator,                3.7
I,occup_check_min_hits,                                            1

Additional information of parameters

stack_loading_min_hits_top_legs 0

How many times the pallet legs are required to detect before the leg bottom height is stored. The idea is that the leg bottom and top height are stored and the fork is controlled between those. Increasing this value decreases the possibility of false detection. The detection count can be something between 2 and 20 with one pallet and this depends on the detection angle and distance, lifting speed and scanner measurement speed.

stack_loading_stop_increase 3

3 = occupancy check. Check area is square with side length of pallet_model_width_y located on the center of the detected target front line.

stack_loading_max_dist_to_pallet_m 2.0

Discards detected pallets if they are further than this value from the scanner. Used to avoid detecting pallets too far away. Calculated from the scanner to the pallet front side (in meters). Used only if target_detection_type_selection is 2.

stack_loading_max_retry_if_scanning_fails 0

Defines how many times the scanning can be retried if suitable pocket is not found. The suitable pocket is checked each time when the fork is increased and the scanning is ready. If there is no suitable pocket, the fork is decreased back to the route level and then the increase and scanning is done again. Then this is repeated by the amount of this parameter. If the retry succeeds and there is a valid pocket, the fork is decreased to the pocket level. If all the retries are done without any suitable pocket, fatal error is set.

User notes

  • Pallet detection is used with stackloading, so it is recommended to test first. There are few pallet detection parameters listed on the Example set, but it is not full list. However, using those parameters would be enough in most cases to get started.

  • Stackloading feature needs Navithor to properly perform the loading sequence. Without Navithor, e.g. with Monitor drive orders, the stackloading can be run until it drives under the pallet, but it cannot load the pallet automatically. However, there is Load button on Client and on Monitor Actuator Control that can be used to Load the pallet.

  • NavitrolMonitor is good tool when the parameters are adjusted at the first time. It is easier to adjust the parameters with Monitor to get the fork to correct level.

  • When starting the production with Navithor, the resource is needed on the symbolic point and the stackloading feature is automatically started when the AGV drives close enough to the detected target.

  • Before starting stackloading, test first with Monitor that the pallet can be detected by setting the target_detection_always_enabled to 1.

  • If the stack is high, it might be possible that the drive is aborted by Navithor while increasing the fork. Then this Navithor parameter TrafficController_ABORT_WAIT_TIME_SECONDS should be increased. Generally, the abort shouldn't be happening when the AGV is searching for the top pallet. The parameter should be at least a time how much the AGV is standing still when doing the scan.

  • Searching "StackLoading1" from the log shows the scanning results. The "Legs detected" line shows the height of the actuator when the legs are detected with the scanner. The "Legs false detected" shows where the legs are not detected. This is very useful to see if there are any valid pockets and what are the sizes. See Chapter Pocket found too high as an example.

  • Searching "StackLoading: Pocket height saved" from the log shows what are the heights of stored pockets. The ActVal is actuator height of that detection and level defines if it is the pocket bottom height (1) or top height (2). The pocket height is calculated from those bottom and top values. Even though there might be consecutive bottom heights on the log, they are not used for anything.

Aborting the state machine

If the AGV got stuck and customer wants to abort the mission and try again, the sequence can be aborted by driving AGV far enough from the stack. If the state machine is active it can be seen from terminal with logging "STACK_LOADING_STATE_". If there is no logging, the state machine is not active.

The state machine is aborted if

  • AGV has already started the scanning phase, but hasn't picked the pallet up and new drive order is given to route or symbolic point without Stack loading tag. Actuator is controlled automatically to the route height when AGV has driven stack_loading_dist_from_stack_to_move_actuator distance away from the stack.

  • AGV has already started the scanning phase and AGV is driven (manually or with drive order) further away from the stack front than stack_loading_dist_from_stack_to_move_actuator + block_stacking_reset_distance_from_increase_location. For example, taking the AGV into Manual mode with Monitor keyboard command and drive few meters backwards. The actuator should be controlled automatically to the route height as soon as AGV has received new drive order, if it isn't controlled manually.

  • AGV hasn't started the scanning phase yet and it is outside the load buffer area and docking is not active. For example, driving AGV with drive order out from the buffer area. Actuator is already at route height when this happens.

Laser scanner view

Figure 4: Laser scanner view of the stack

If the last found pocket is too small or too large, error is set. The size of the pocket can be set with parameters. Also, if the actuator reaches the maximum allowed height, error is set.

The scan is always done to the top of the stack and the assumption is that the pallets are quite well aligned to the same location. The general stackloading idea is to just set the fork to the highest legs that are detected, so Navitrol doesn't know anything about the independent pallet heights on the stack beforehand or how many pallets there are on the stack. If there is only one pallet, the scanning is still done.

Errors

ERROR_STACKLOADING_POCKET_FOUND_TOO_LOW

Triggered if pocket height is below stack_loading_max_decrease_val_after_scan_mm from the current actuator height.

ERROR_PALLET_POCKET_NOT_FOUND

Triggered if there is no valid pocket and actuator height is higher than stack_loading_max_height_to_load_from_floor_mm.

ERROR_STACKLOADING_TARGET_TOO_HIGH

Triggered if the actuator reaches the stack_loading_max_height_mm while scanning the stack (stack_loading_max_height_raises_error has to be 1).

Example sequence with pictures

These following figures shows the basic sequence when the stackloading is used on load buffer.

Troubleshooting

AGV found pocket too high

The StackLoading1 logging will show the actuator heights where the scanner is detecting legs of the pallet that are defined as the pocket (Legs detected) or something else (Legs false detected) that is usually the stringer board or some noise. On this case the issue was that after the last pocket, the scanner points are scattered and that caused the system to find legs -> this will cause the system to find small pocket at the very top of the stack. When the scanner scans the stack from bottom to top, the pockets are usually seen really well and the usual pocket height for normal pallet is something between 85-115mm.

  • The stack_loading_min_pocket_size_mm is used to discard pockets that are too small after all pockets have been found.
  • The stack_loading_min_hits_top_legs parameter is used to store pocket low heights to the system when the pocket is seen this parameter amount in consecutive cycles.
  • The stack_loading_min_false_hits_legs parameter is used to store pocket high heights to the system when the pocket is not seen this parameter amount in consecutive cycles.

On this example, the stack_loading_min_pocket_size_mm was on default value 10. stack_loading_min_hits_top_legs and stack_loading_min_false_hits_legs was 2.

12453.5109 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs false detected (top line): 0, actval: 86
12453.5748 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs false detected (top line): 1, actval: 86
12453.6419 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs false detected (top line): 0, actval: 86

12460.9130 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs detected: 1, actval: 510
12460.9745 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs detected: 0, actval: 516
12461.0431 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs false detected (no pallet): 1, actval: 523
12461.1116 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs false detected (top line): 0, actval: 529    -> Eight pocket high height is 523. Two consecutive false leg detections.
12461.1746 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs detected: 1, actval: 534
12461.2422 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs detected: 0, actval: 541                     -> Ninth pocket low height is 534. Two consecutive leg detections.
12461.3134 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs detected: 1, actval: 547
12461.3741 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs false detected (no pallet): 1, actval: 560
12461.4418 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs false detected (no pallet): 0, actval: 565   -> Ninth pocket high height is 560. Two consecutive false leg detections.
12461.5137 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs false detected (no pallet): 1, actval: 573
12461.5742 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs false detected (no pallet): 0, actval: 578
12461.6415 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs false detected (no pallet): 1, actval: 586
12461.7125 [03:6] StackLoading1: Legs false detected (no pallet): 0, actval: 591

From this case the pockets are stored like this (from bottom to top):

  1. Low height 103, high height 104 -> pocket size 1. Noise
  2. Low height 107, high height 109 -> pocket size 2. Noise
  3. Low height 112, high height 116 -> pocket size 4. Noise
  4. The fourth pocket didn't have high value, because there was only one high measurement and two was required by parameter stack_loading_min_false_hits_legs. Pocket is not stored.
  5. Low height 129, high height 236 -> pocket size 107. Real pocket
  6. Low height 254, high height 267 -> pocket size 13. Noise
  7. Low height 280, high height 378 -> pocket size 98. Real pocket
  8. Low height 409, high height 523 -> pocket size 114. Real pocket
  9. Low height 534, high height 560 -> pocket size 26. This was noise from top of the stack.

After the scan there are 9 pockets (number four not valid) and the system will select the top-most pocket that's height is between the stack_loading_min_pocket_size_mm and stack_loading_max_pocket_size_mm. Here the top-most pocket is the 9th pocket that's low height is 534 and high height is 560 -> pocket height is 560-534=26mm. If the stack_loading_min_pocket_size_mm would have been larger than this 26, then the second top-most pocket would have been selected (that is the correct pocket in this case) and that is 409 and 523 -> pocket height 523-409=114mm.

Fork is always too high or too low when driving in to the pallet after scanning the stack

The target_detection_actuator_offset_to_scanner_mm parameter is wrong. This parameter defines how much the fork height needs to be changed from the detected pocket height. If the forklift cannot drive under the pallet, when the final height is set, this parameter should be adjusted. The positive value increases the fork and negative one decreases.

Block Stacking Instructions

Updated 09.09.2024

Introduction

Block stacking is a feature that means unloading on top of another pallet. This is very specific feature and can only be used with a certain type of forklifts, because the unloading height on top of a pallet needs to be detected with sensor. Basically, the idea is that when driving on the buffer area (purple area on the Figure 5) the AGV start detecting pallet with the laser scanner on front of the route. When it detects the pallet, it stops and starts increasing the fork. Using sensor information, the increase is stopped when the sensor detects the top level of the pallet. This height can be searched with laser scanner or with sensors on the fork tip. Then AGV continue the drive on top of that pallet. When reached to the correct unload location, AGV performs the unload. The drive is finished and AGV start driving to the next location while keeping the height at the same level where it was after the unload. When the AGV has driven far away from the unload place, the fork is decreased to the floor level.

ATTENTION! Before setting up block stacking, unload buffer feature should be tested first. Check Figure 1 and Figure 2 for the difference between unload buffer feature and block stacking feature. The unload buffer means feature where the AGV searches the next pallet ahead on the route with the laser scanner and unload on the floor level in specified distance from that pallet. Block stacking can then be enabled to unload pallets on top of each other.

ATTENTION! The fork tip sensor can be used only with custom CAN interface at the moment.

Figure 1: Unload buffer example

Figure 2: Block stacking example

Requirements

Block stacking requires sensor that is used to find the correct unloading height. Fork sensors, for example ultrasonic sensor, on the front of the fork or scanner that is attached to the lifting part of the fork. If the scanner is used, it needs to see the pallet on front even though the forks have the pallet onboard. The sensor is used to detect the height of the pallet and to unload the carried pallet to the correct level. See the Figure 3 and Figure 4 for illustrations about different options for sensor placements.

There are two options for the sensor placements:

Figure 3: Laser distance sensor and laser scanner placement.

or

Figure 4: Laser scanner placement. The scanner should be able to see past the carried pallet.

Specification

This chapter describes the steps that AGV performs with the blockstacking feature. This can be used to check that blockstacking works as it should.

  • AGV drives inside unload buffer

  • Drive is stopped in front of the pallet based on scanner detecting the pallet on the route or fork tip sensors.

  • AGV starts lifting the fork to search where the pallet top level is.

  • The lifting is stopped on the top pallet based on the fork sensor or scanner measurements. The lifting is also stopped if fork reaches maximum height. If this maximum height is reached, the pallet is unloaded to the floor level, if AGV is on the buffer area, or the state is aborted. If the state is aborted, then AGV waits for fleet control to give new drive order to buffer that has space.

  • If the top height is detected correctly, fork is still lifted by load aboard offset so the AGV can drive on top of the pallet without fork hitting to the pallet.

  • AGV continues driving until the carried pallet is on top of the other pallet

  • AGV unloads the carried pallet.

  • AGV drives out of the pallet and keeps the fork height where it is to avoid hitting the pallet.

  • Load sensor can be checked when we have driven a certain distance out from the unload location. This can be used to make sure that the pallet is not anymore on the fork, before driving too far.

  • When the AGV has driven to the same location where it was increasing the fork, it will lower the fork to the route value.

Pyramid stacking

Pyramid stacking allows the unloading point to be altered lenghtwise from the target. The lengthwise offset is obtained either via fleet control or parameter block_stacking_pyramid_length_offset_mm. The aforementioned offset is only applied when unloading to a stack.

Pyramid stacking allows for altering the unload point lengthwise

The process is otherwise the same as for normal blockstacking.

Limitations

  • This feature is only for a certain type of fork AGVs. It is required that the AGV can see the pallet ahead with some sensor while increasing the fork.

  • The pallet detection scanner is required to see the pallet on front when the AGV is carrying a pallet if the pallet detection is used on the block stacking. This means that the scanner needs to be below the fork.

  • The final height depends on the sensor and the surface of the pallet's top. If there is plastic on the top or the top is uneven, the result might vary, and it can affect the safety.

  • When using fork sensor, for example ultrasonic sensor on the tip of the fork, there has to be also scanner that can detect the pallet on the floor so the AGV can calculate stopping point in front of that pallet early enough. The fork sensors have limited distance to detect objects on front so they are required to trigger close to this calculated stopping point. If the fork sensors are not triggered when the AGV has driven past this stopping point, AGV just unloads the pallet to the floor to avoid pushing other pallets.

Setting up

Recommended software:

  • Navithor 2.8.1.0

  • Navitrol 6.26.00

  • Navithor Tools 3.09.10

Navithor Tools

Block stacking needs to be enabled on each symbolic point, where it is used. It can be setup by adding a tag on the symbolic point.

NOTE! Tools version must be higher than 3.09.10!

  1. Create symbolic point and change it to unload type.

  2. Edit virtual tag on the symbolic points menu. New window should open.

  3. Add new tag by pressing Add tag button. Select NavitrolFeature for the tag type.

  4. Select BlockStacking tag from the right-side menu. Exit the window from upper right corner.

  5. Select unload buffer feature tag by enabling the Load Unload Buffer

  6. Adjust the distance for the buffer lane. The purple line indicates the area where the pallets can be unloaded.

  7. Next thing is to add estimate for the number of pallets for the lane. This can be set on the Edit Destinations and Resources menu on the Edit Allowed Resources. The quantity number should be quite close to the maximum number of pallets.

Figure 5: Setting up the blockstacking feature on Tools.

Parameters

Notes of Navitrol parameters

  • First, select the mode with the block_stacking_mode.

    • The mode 1 is occupancy check, so basically it means that when searching for the top of the stack, the AGV uses laser scanner to detect when the pallet's top is reached by checking how many scanner points are found on the area where the pallet's front line is.
    • The mode 3 uses fork sensor information to define when the fork has reached the top of the pallet.
    • The mode 4 is 3D camera that has interface to Navitrol
    • The mode 5 is not dependent to any sensor. In this mode, the target is first detected on the ground and then the fork is moved to the estimated height given with the drive order from Navithor. Then AGV waits for a response from external target detection before it can continue driving.

  • Occupancy check will use scanner that is attached to the increasing part of the fork. The requirement is that when the fork increases, this scanner can see when the fork has reached to the level of the top pallet.

  • Fork sensor uses ultrasonic or laser sensor to detect when there is pallet on front. In general, this kind of sensor is at the end of the fork and will be used for safety as well.

  • The block_stacking_offset_mm parameter defines the distance from the level where we detect the top pallet level to the safe driving level. Depending where the sensor is installed, but in general the AGV can't drive over another pallet when the sensor detects the top of the pallet.

  • Reference step is added to fork height reference on each code cycle, meaning something like 20ms. This reference will increase fast in order to create smooth increase for the fork. Depending the fork control, this value can be 1 or 2. Sometimes, the fork is so fast that it reaches the target before it is increased to next step, so it the fork seems to decelerate and accelerate every now and then. Then this parameter should be increased. It is also safe to add large value, something like 500, if the AGV fork controller can control the fork smoothly to high values.

  • Occupancy min hits is used on occupancy check to define how many scanner points we can have at minimum on the target area. If there are less scanner point on that area, the area is defined as empty. The target area is calculated as a square from the pallet's front. The side of this square is the width of the pallet.

  • Use scanner to check safety - parameter is used in cases, when there is a static scanner that can see on top of another pallet if it has already pallet on top. Should be used only if stacks have two pallets. If there could be more pallets, pallets could have different heights or there is no static scanner that could see to the stack drop-off location, this parameter should be set to 0. If this scanner detects something on the stack drop-off location, block stacking sequence is not started and normal unload is done to the floor in front of the stack. See figures below.

Use scanner to check safety - Drop-off to stack allowed. 1. Scanner that is used to scan the stacking height. 2. E.g. navigation scanner. 3. Stacking drop-off area that is empty. In this case, the scanner 1 is first used to detect the pallet on the floor and to define the location of the possible drop-off area to the stack (3). Then the scanner 2 can be used to check if there is already something on that drop-off area. If there is nothing, then AGV will drive closer and use the scanner 1 to scan the height of the pallet to drop-off on top of it.

Use scanner to check safety - Drop-off to stack not allowed. 1. Scanner that is used to scan the stacking height. 2. E.g. navigation scanner. 3. Stacking drop-off area already has a pallet. In this case, the scanner 1 is first used to detect the pallet on the floor and to define the location of the possible drop-off area to the stack (3). Then the scanner 2 can be used to check if there is already something on that drop-off area. If there is something, then AGV will drive closer and drop-off to the floor in front of the stack without scanning the stack.

  • Max diff on target pos - parameter is a safety check that the pallet detection doesn't change the target too much.

  • Dist to check load sensor - parameter is used to check if the unload is correctly done after we have driven away for this value. This safety check uses load sensor to check if the load is still on board.

  • Dist to unload - parameter defines the distance from the point where we are lifting the fork to the point where the unload can be done.

  • Max diff from route - parameter is a safety check for the pallet that is already on the unload location. If this pallet is too far from the route, block stacking is not started for safety reasons. In block stacking, the assumption is that the pallets are always quite straight on the route. Recommended value for this parameter is 0.15 (cm)

  • Min actuator val after ready - parameter is used to release the AGV for driving after the fork has decreased until this level. This is used after the unload is done and the fork is decreasing to normal route level.

  • Max heading diff - parameter is safety check for the pallet's heading. If the pallet angle is too high related to the AGV's heading, the block stacking is not started.

  • Block stacking max height - parameter is used on the increase phase to define what is the maximum level for block stacking. If the fork is increased to this max level and the occupancy check or fork sensor does not detect the top of the pallet, normal unload is done on that position.

  • Max dist to target - parameter is meant to be used for fork sensor. It was designed to ignore false fork sensor detections before the AGV is close enough to actual the pallet. This parameter can be used also generally to define the distance where the block stacking is started, when using occupancy check.

  • Max extend drive - parameter is used with fork sensors. When driving to unload buffer, AGV will first calculate the stopping distance in front of the pallet. When AGV has reached this position and fork sensor is not triggered yet, it can drive the distance of this parameter to test if the sensor is triggered. If the sensor is triggered, it will start block stacking, otherwise normal unload is done.

  • Verify unload height - parameter requires a load sensor that is high when the pallet is on the fork and low when the pallet is not touching the fork level. So, the sensor should inform when the pallet is on the fork when doing the unload and inform when the pallet is placed on top of the other pallet (There is some space between the fork and the pallet). See additional information (Figure 2) at the end of this document.

  • Disable fork sensor dist - parameter is used to avoid doing unload when the AGV is driving normally on top of the pallet and there is another pallet behind. This parameter should be at least the distance between pallets on the row. See Figure 2 at the end of the document.

List of Navitrol Parameters

TypeNameMinDefaultMaxInformation
Intblock_stacking_mode005Mode for detecting the top pallet.
0 = Disabled
1 = Occupancy check
2 = Pallet detection
3 = Fork sensor
4 = 3D camera
5 = Fork is moved to estimated height
Intblock_stacking_offset_mm-200002000Offset (in mm) from the height where the top level is detected to the safe unload height
Intblock_stacking_reference_step_mm125000Increase value added to the current height on each step in mm
Intblock_stacking_max_detection_wait_time_ms030000100000Max wait time in ms for target detection in front of the stack. Used in both dropoff and pickup and with 3D camera and external target detection.
Intoccup_check_min_hits1How many scanner points are allowed on the occupancy area
Intblock_stacking_use_scanner_to_check_safety002Use scanner to check if block stacking is safe to start. Checks occupancy on top of the pallet where the block stacking should be done. If there is already something, block stacking is not started
1 = rear
2 = front scanner
Floatblock_stacking_dist_to_check_load_sensor-1.0-1.05.0This distance is used to check if the unload is actually done when driving out from the unload location using load sensor. The AGV is stopped if it tries to move and the load is still detected. Negative = not used
Floatblock_stacking_dist_to_unload-10-2.010Distance from detected target to the unload location. Calculated from target's front line to the navigation point.
Floatblock_stacking_target_max_diff_from_route0.00.12.0How far the target can be from the route. If the target is too far, normal unload is done
Intblock_stacking_min_actuator_val_after_ready_mm02001000> 0 Use softstop to move the fork to this parameter value when driving away from stack. 0 = move the fork while driving
Floatblock_stacking_target_max_heading_diff_deg0.015.0360.0The maximum angle difference between target and the AGV for starting the sequence (in degrees)
Intblock_stacking_max_height_mm015006000Max allowed height for the block stacking (in mm). Required to be smaller than actuator_max_val
Floatblock_stacking_max_dist_to_target0.02.010.0Max allowed distance (in m) from navigation point to target to start block stacking. If distance to the target is higher when block stacking is triggered, pause mode is enabled.
Floatblock_stacking_max_extend_drive0.00.21.0Max allowed distance (in m) to extend the drive after stopped with unload buffer if fork sensor is not triggered
Intblock_stacking_verify_unload_height_mm005000 = not used. Verify unload with external sensor, by decreasing the actuator for value of this parameter and checking the sensor status. If sensor detects the pallet when decreased this amount, warning is triggered. If the sensor doesn't detect the pallet during the decrease, unload is considered to be ready.
Floatblock_stacking_disable_fork_sensor_dist0.01.25.0Distance from unload location to navigation point to disable fork sensor triggering unload to the route level after the stack height is detected and when AGV has started to drive on top of the stack. This parameter should have a value that is close to the fork length. Used only if block_stacking_mode is 3. Idea is that fork sensors are used to trigger unload if they detect something ahead, but they should be disabled as soon as the fork is on top of the stack.
Intblock_stacking_verify_unload_height_sensor_offset_mm-50005000 = not used. Offset value for the unload height when the actuator is stopped using the load sensor.
Floatblock_stacking_reset_distance_from_increase_location0.00.510.0Distance to reset the state machine if AGV is far enough from the location where the increase starts.
Floatblock_stacking_max_unload_error_behind_SP0.00.051.0Tolerance for calculated unload point behind symbolic point. If it is more than this parameter, stacking is not done and unload will be done in front of the pallet.
Intblock_stacking_pyramid_length_offset_mm-500005000The length offset for pyramid stacking. Only enabled if the pyramid stacking flag is received from Fleet Control.
Floatblock_stacking_dist_from_stack_to_move_actuator0.00.05.0Distance [m] from navigation point to the detected pallet front line to stop AGV for increasing the actuator. 0 = Stopping point for actuator increase is defined by parameter buffer_stop_dist_from_object_when_unloading.

Example sets of Navitrol parameters

AGV with scanner moving with the fork

This set of parameters is from the fork that has scanner moving with the fork. This one scanner is used to scan the stacking height.

I,block_stacking_mode, 1
I,block_stacking_offset_mm, 54
I,block_stacking_reference_step_mm, 2
I,block_stacking_use_scanner_to_check_safety, 0
F,block_stacking_dist_to_unload, -0.62
F,block_stacking_target_max_diff_from_route, 0.15
F,block_stacking_target_max_heading_diff_deg, 35.0
I,block_stacking_max_height_mm, 1500
F,block_stacking_max_dist_to_target, 2.0

AGV with two static scanners and fork tip sensor to scan the stacking height

This set of parameters is from the fork that has fork sensor at the tip of the fork. It has safety scanner below the fork that is used for detecting the pallet before lifting. There is also one scanner on top of the fork that can see on top of the pallet where we are unloading. On that project, block stacking is used to unload two pallets on top of each other and this scanner on top is used to check if the area on top of one pallet is free.

I,block_stacking_mode, 3
I,block_stacking_offset_mm, 54
I,block_stacking_reference_step_mm, 2
I,block_stacking_use_scanner_to_check_safety, 2
F,block_stacking_dist_to_unload, -0.62
F,block_stacking_target_max_diff_from_route, 0.15
F,block_stacking_target_max_heading_diff_deg, 35.0
I,block_stacking_max_height_mm, 1500
F,block_stacking_max_dist_to_target, 2.0
F,block_stacking_max_extend_drive, 0.2

Notes for Customer

For safety reasons, the AGV should reserve the route all the way until the end symbolic point when driving to unload buffer. Otherwise, the unload buffer area is not checked correctly. This route reservation can be checked with Monitor by checking how far ahead the purple part of the route is. If it doesn't reach the symbolic point when the AGV is at the beginning of the buffer area, increase Navithor parameter TrafficController_LIMIT_FOR_WP_LOCK_SECONDS.

If block stacking is aborted by Navithor while increasing the fork, increase Navithor parameter TrafficController_ABORT_WAIT_TIME_SECONDS. Generally, the abort shouldn't be happening when the AGV is searching for the top pallet. Changing the block_stacking_max_height - parameter increases the search time if not found the top pallet, so this abort parameter should be larger than the time that it takes to lift the actuator to this max parameter and back to the floor.

If the fork is stopping or slowing down while trying to increase, check these parameters:

  • actuator_inner_tolerance_mm

  • actuator_outer_tolerance_mm

  • actuator_inner_tolerance_timer_ms

  • block_stacking_reference_step_mm

If the reference step is too slow, the fork might reach the tolerance too fast and stop the control for a while before the reference start increasing again. Increasing the inner tolerance timer might help but it always depends on how fast is the fork actuator control.

If the pallet top is not static or the pallet top is hard to find with fork sensors due to an object on top, try setting block_stacking_verify_unload_height_mm parameter to for example 0.2 m. See Figure 6 as an example when there is something on top of the pallet. This parameter requires a load sensor that can detect when the pallet is not anymore on the fork when decreasing it to the other pallet. The idea with this parameter is that the fork is decreased this parameter amount from the calculated unload height and stopped if the load sensor doesn't detect the pallet anymore or if the fork reaches this new target height.

Figure 6: Detecting wrong height due to some object is on top of the pallet.

The red object on top of the pallet is the plastic or some other light thing that causes the block stacking to go too high, because we can't detect the static top of the pallet. This object should be so light that the pallet can be unloaded on top of it. The red dashed line is the error height, that should be the set to this verify_unload_height - parameter. Without this new sensor check, the block stacking would do the unload based on the height of the object and then the pallet would not touch the static pallet top when trying to unload resulting the AGV to carry the pallet away.

Figure 7: Minimum value for disabling fork sensor and the normal unload to the route level.

When the AGV is approaching to the pallet, the AGV can perform unload to the ground if the fork sensors are triggered. This might be caused by humans walking in front of the AGV and triggering the block stacking sequence too early. Then the height is detected to wrong height. But in normal case, this shouldn't be triggered and that's why the disable fork sensor dist - parameter should be at least the distance between the pallets.

If something goes wrong and blockstacking cannot be completed, its state machine can be reset by driving away from the location where the increase phase was done. The AGV has to drive block_stacking_reset_distance_from_increase_location amount away from the increase location, 0.5m by default, to reset the state machine. Then the blockstacking can be tried again. This figure down below shows the location where the state is reset. The sate is reset even though AGV is driven manually away, because it only checks that navigation point is far enough from the precalculated unload location.

Figure 8: Location where the state machine is reset if something goes wrong. Defined with block_stacking_reset_distance_from_increase_location.

Navitrol will remember the distance to the stack, when the AGV starts to increase the fork when driving towards the stack. Then when AGV is driving away after it has unloaded the pallet, this same distance is used to let the fork to be controlled to the route height. One exception is the case, when AGV is driving to empty buffer lane. Then the distance is the difference between these parameters: buffer_stop_dist_from_object_when_unloading - block_stacking_dist_to_unload.

Troubleshooting

AGV does drop-off in front of stack without scanning

Stacking tag missing or stacking not allowed

  • Check that symbolic point is Buffer lane and has Blockstacking tag or that Navithor has sent stacking allowed with the drive order.
    • This kind of log line shows Navithor stack data: "ParseDriveCommandV2 received Buffer data. Stack 1, estimated height 0, max height 0"
    • Navithor can order stacking without Blockstacking tag.

Scanner sees something on top of the stack

  • block_stacking_use_scanner_to_check_safety is nonzero and defined scanner sees something on top of the stack.
  • This kind of log line: "BlockStacking: Sequence couldn't be started. PauseOk 1, unloadAreaOk 0, targetDistOk 1, targetAngleOk 1, targetFound 1, distOk 1, Drive end (44.32, 11.99)"

Pallet not detected

  • Pallet is required to be detected to start the stacking sequence
  • This kind of log line: "BlockStacking: Sequence couldn't be started. PauseOk 1, unloadAreaOk 1, targetDistOk 0, targetAngleOk 0, targetFound 0, distOk 1, Drive end (44.32, 11.99)"

Pallet too far from route

  • block_stacking_target_max_diff_from_route is too small or pallet is too far to the side from the route.
  • This kind of log line: "BlockStacking: Sequence couldn't be started. PauseOk 1, unloadAreaOk 1, targetDistOk 0, targetAngleOk 1, targetFound 1, distOk 1, Drive end (44.32, 11.99)"

Pallet angle difference relative to the route is too high

  • block_stacking_target_max_heading_diff_deg is too small or pallet angle is too high relative to the route.
  • This kind of log line: "BlockStacking: Sequence couldn't be started. PauseOk 1, unloadAreaOk 1, targetDistOk 1, targetAngleOk 0, targetFound 1, distOk 1, Drive end (44.32, 11.99)"

Stacking drop-off point too far from symbolic point

  • block_stacking_max_unload_error_behind_SP is too small or pallet detected on the floor is too far behind symbolic point
  • This kind of log line: "BlockStacking: Target found, but couldn't start increase. Increase 1, isStackinUnloadPointValid 0, distToStartIncrease 0.5, Drive end (44.32, 11.99)"

AGV does drop-off too high in stack

Detected stack height is too high. If this happens multiple times, decrease block_stacking_offset_mm.

AGV drives too much in to the stack

AGV stops too late when doing drop-off to the stack. If this happens multiple times, modify block_stacking_dist_to_unload closer to 0.

AGV does drop-off too early on the stack

AGV stops too early when doing drop-off to the stack. If this happens multiple times, change block_stacking_dist_to_unload higher.

AGV does drop-off in front of stack after scanning

The fork reached the maximum height while scanning the stack height. See block_stacking_max_height_mm parameter.

  • There is also possibility to get this maximum height from Navithor with Drive order. If Navithor sends 0, then this parameter is used instead.
  • This kind of log line: "ParseDriveCommandV2 received Buffer data. Stack 0, estimated height 0, max height 2000"

Distance to target

Updated 26.01.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
NavitrolNavigation software for an individual vehicle.
NavitrolMonitorMonitoring software for the Navitrol positioning software running on the individual vehicle.
Navigation pointCentre point of the vehicle's coordinate system which is used as a reference for all other dimensions.
Fork pointCentre point of the fork which is used for distance calculation.
Look section 2.2 to see how the fork point is defined.
Unload pallet pointPredicted position of the pallet after unload
Look section 5.2 to see how the unload point is defined

Introduction

Distance to target is a Navitrol feature unlockable by parameters. Distance to target contains two following features:

  1. Distance from AGV to the pallet.

When AGV is docking to a pallet, Navitrol calculates the perpendicular distance between the fork point and the closest corner of the pallet. The calculation is performed only when the pallet is not turned too much in respect to the AGV.

  1. Distance from AGV to unload point.

When AGV is going to unload the pallet, Navitrol calculates the perpendicular distance between the fork point and predicted unload point. The calculation is performed only when the AGV is not turned too much and not too far away from the unload point.

Requirements

To use this feature AGV should be the forklift type. Additionally, the pallet model should be specified in parameters and the pallet detection feature should be enabled in parameters. Please, see the pallet detection feature instructions for additional description.

Sequence of operation

Distance from AGV to the pallet:

  • AGV is approaching the load symbolic point without any resource on board.

  • AGV detects the pallet (using pallet detection feature).

  • AGV checks if the pallet is not turned too much i.e. AGV is almost perpendicular to the pallet.

  • Calculation activates. Navitrol calculates the perpendicular distance between the fork point and the closest corner of the pallet.

  • Navitrol starts sending data to the CAN and to the NavitrolMonitor.

  • Calculation ends when AGV is loaded or AGV cannot find the pallet for 1.5 seconds.

Distance from AGV to unload point:

  • AGV is approaching the unload point with a resource on board.

  • AGV checks if it is not turned too much from the unload point (i.e. it is really going to unload the resource).

  • Navitrol checks if AGV is close enough to the unload point to start the calculation.

  • Navitrol calculates the perpendicular distance between the fork point and predicted unload point (taking into account the offset between the fork and the pallet).

  • Navitrol starts sending to the CAN and to the NavitrolMonitor.

  • Calculation ends when AGV is unloaded.

Setting up

Required software:

  • Official release version 6.30.00 or later

  • Navithor Tools 3.03.05 or later

Navithor Tools

Pallet detection needs to be enabled on each symbolic point, where distance to pallet feature is used. It can be done in the following way:

  • Create an environment and a route

  • Create a symbolic point and change it to load type

  • Enable pallet detection

  • Limit the resources of the current symbolic point (if needed).

  • Create a symbolic point and change it to unload type.

  • Upload the project to Navitrol and to the Database.

Notes of Navitrol parameters

  • First, enable the calculation. Parameter dist_to_target_enabled should be set to 1 in order to perform the calculation.

  • The calculation is not performed when the pallet is turned too much. Parameter dist_to_target_angle_tolerance_deg should be set to the maximum allowed angle.

  • The distance is calculated from the fork point. The fork point should be defined in parameters. There are two parameters: fork_pos_x and fork_pos_y that describes fork position with respect to the AGV navigation point shown in Figure 1.

Note: Parameters can be either positive or negative. Sign is explained in Paragraph 5.2.

  • The distance calculation to the unload point should be started only when AGV is close enough to the unload point. The maximum distance when calculation should start is defined by the parameter dist_to_target_max_calc_dist.

Using the feature in NavitrolMonitor

After connecting to the AGV in NavitrolMonitor, the feature can be enabled as it is shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2. Distance To Target in NavitrolMonitor

When AGV is approaching the target, the results of distance calculation are shown by the line drawn from the fork point to the target position as shown in the picture below.

Figure 3. Examples of distance calculation from AGV to the pallet

Additionally to the graphic representation, in the left top corner of NavitrolMonitor distance is shown in text format:

Figure 4. Distance displaying

List of Navitrol Parameters

TypeNameMinDefaultMaxInformation
Intdist_to_target_enabled001Distance calculation from AGV to target.
Calculates distance from AGV to pallet when AGV is docking, and distance from AGV to unload point when AGV is driving to unload point with a pallet
Floatdist_to_target_angle_tolerance_deg0.030.0045.00Allowed rotation angle of the pallet with respect to the AGV when distance calculation is enabled
Floatfork_pos_x-0.0-Fork coordinate X with respect to the AGV navigation point.
Floatfork_pos_y-0.0-Fork coordinate Y with respect to the AGV navigation point.
Floatdist_to_target_max_calc_dist0.04.015.0Maximum distance from agv to unloading point when calculation starts

Example set of Navitrol parameters

Illustration of operation

Distance from AGV to pallet

Navitrol performs perpendicular distance calculation between the fork point and closest pallet corner.

Figure 5: Illustration to distance to pallet feature

Note! The calculation is performed only when the pallet is close to the perpendicular to AGV. The maximum allowed angle between AGV and pallet is defined by the parameter dist_to_target_angle_tolerance_deg and cannot exceed 45.0 degrees. The parameter is defined as follows:

Figure 6: Angle calculation

The fork point position is continuously calculated in relation to the AGV position, i.e. navigation point position. Parameters fork_pos_y and fork_pos_x should be correctly measured and set to Navitrol parameter file in order to have an accurate fork point position.

The closest pallet corner position is calculated in relation to the AGV position and the pallet position, which is received from the pallet detection feature.

Note! The calculation is performed only when the pallet has been recognized, and it is dependent on the pallet detection feature.

Distance from AGV to unload point

Navitrol performs calculation of the perpendicular distance between the fork point and the unload pallet point.

Figure 7: Illustration of distance to unload point feature

The fork point position is continuously calculated in relation to the AGV position, i.e. navigation point position. Parameters fork_pos_y and fork_pos_x should be correctly measured and set to Navitrol in order to have an accurate fork point position.

The unload pallet point is the predicted position of the end of the pallet after unloading. When calculating the unload pallet point Navitrol takes into account:

  • Position of unload symbolic point (Which was set in NavithorTools)

  • Length of the pallet. During docking, when the pallet is recognized, the pallet length is stored in memory. This pallet length cannot be measured by scanners and it is taken from the parameters. Thus, for the correct operation of the feature, pallet dimensions should be correctly defined in parameters.

  • Correction for fork position (for the cases where fork point differs from navigation point)

  • Correction for an offset between pallet and fork. This offset happens when there is some gap between the pallet and fork as it is shown in Figure 8. This gap is measured by Navitrol during docking.

Figure 8: Offset between fork and pallet

The following example is provided in order to illustrate how the unload pallet point is defined by Navitrol. In this example:

  • Fork parameters:

    • fork_pos_ x -0.20 (negative sign signals that fork is closer to the back of the AGV then navigation point) as shown in the illustration.

Figure 9: Sign of fork parameters

  • fork_pos_ y 0.00

  • Pallet parameters:

    • pallet_model_length_x[0] 0.45

  • Offset between the pallet and the fork: 0.10 (measured during docking)

The unload pallet point is calculated as it is shown on the figure:

Figure 10: Illustration of unload pallet point calculation

CAN message description

The results of distance calculation are sent through CAN interface. Information about the CAN customer specific message is shown in the table below.

Table 1. CAN message description

CAN Message 0x60B: Navitrol -> PLC: 20ms.
Information for Proximity Based Safety - 20 ms cycle

NameByteBitTypeCalibrationDescription
Distance To Target0-Real-Distance to target in meters
Distance To Target1-Real-Distance to target in meters
Distance To Target2-Real-Distance to target in meters
Distance To Target3-Real-Distance to target in meters
-40--
-41--
-42---
Pick Active43Bit-1 for when Pick is active
Place Active44Bit-1 for when Place is active
-45--
Calculation activated46Bit-1 for when the calculation is activated
Toggle Bit47Bit-Toggle for every message sent

Advice for user

  • Pallet dimensions cannot be measured by Navitrol, but those data are used in distance calculation. So, it is recommended to set the pallet parameters as accurately as possible.

  • Distance calculation highly depends on pallet detection. For best results pallet detection should be properly tuned.

  • In the calculations, it is assumed that AGV stops on the symbolic point. In case if AGV constantly does not stop on the symbolic point, please, contact the Navitec support team. Support team will help you to tune the parameters.

  • In some situations (e.g. in case of wheel slipping) it may occur that AGV is crossing the unload point i.e. distance to the unload point calculated according to the above-mentioned methods is less than the minimum distance. In such unpredictable cases, Navitrol will send (through the CAN and to the NavitrolMonitor) minimal possible distance. Minimal possible distance is the sum of offset between pallet and fork + pallet length.

  • In cases when AGV drives over the symbolic point too much (more, than it is defined in parameter pc_max_dist_err), Navitrol detects some unpredicted behavior of the AGV (which can be caused by brake failure, for instance). In such cases, the distance calculation is impossible to perform, so the calculation is deactivated and the minimum distance will be sent to the CAN interface.

  • If you feel that the calculation is not working or working incorrectly, please, set the parameter log_pallet_detection to value 1 and take logs from the NavitrolMonitor. Please, sent those logs to the Navitec support team for further instructions.

Pallet Detection

Updated 03.07.2024

Pallet detection requirements

Detecting the pallet -- field of view:

At least one of the legs of the pallet is assumed to be in front of the laser scanner within a field of view of 30 degrees

The algorithm assumes the pallet will be located directly in front of the laser scanner.

Field of view explained.

Detecting the pallet -- maximum error:

  • The angle of the pallet relative to the laser scanner must be less than 20 degrees.

  • The maximum error for the pallet's nominal location is about +-15 cm (depending on the pallet dimensions).

    • In good circumstances the pallet can be correctly detected even if the displacement is larger, but it can't be always guaranteed.

  • The space between the pallets next to each other should differ from the distance between the legs of the pallet.

Distance between pallets.

Detecting from stringer board

  • The pallet can be also detected based on the top part of a pallet called stringer board. If the pallet is detected from the stringer board, the pallets must be separated from each other at least by 10 cm.

Using pallet detection

Pallet detection can be used to drive the AGV accurately under a pallet, even if the pallet is not perfectly on the location defined as a symbolic point in Navithor Tools. Pallet detection detects the target and corrects the AGVs driving according to it.

Using pallet detection requires Navitrol license which includes the feature, otherwise Navitrol will stop in an error, if the pallet detection is activated without the proper license.

Pallet detection can be used in combination with 'Load' or 'Load, Unload' symbolic point. If pallet detection is enabled for such a location and the AGV is heading towards the location, Navitrol activates pallet detection and tries to find the target. If the target is found and certain restrictions are met, the AGV starts a docking procedure and corrects the trajectory to drive precisely under the pallet. For more information on docking, see Docking.

Pallet detection can be enabled with a quick selection in Navithor Tools under the Symbolic Points tool -> Edit Symbolic Points -> 'Enable pallet detection':

Enabling pallet detection in Navithor Tools

If pallet detection is not enabled with this checkbox, AGV will drive to the location blindly.

There are several warnings, that can show up, if something goes wrong with pallet detection. If detecting the target fails, Navitrol will show up target detection error. If pallet is found, but the restrictions for starting the docking are not met, Navitrol shows instead a target approach error. If docking is started, but the error is too big to correct when AGV is closer to the pallet, Navitrol will show up the same warning. More detailed explanation about these errors are given in Chapter 8.2. The exact warnings are following:

612, WARNING_TARGET_NOT_DETECTED, "Target for docking not detected"

613, WARNING_TARGET_APPROACH_ERROR, "Target location differs too much from expected"

Some parameters, which are discussed later in this document, need to be also changed in Navitrol to activate pallet detection.

Mounting laser scanner for pallet detection

Scanner angle related to the floor is important to consider when the scanner is mounted to the AGV. In ideal case, the scanner can see the legs of the pallet from the distance and also on close range.

Generic options for mounting laser scanner for pallet detection.

Calibrating laser scanner for pallet detection

NOTE! If the pallet detection scanner is used only for detecting pallets and not for localization, this method should be used to calibrate the scanner. If it is used also on localization, then it should be calibrated in normal way.

The angle of the pallet detection scanner (scan_rear_sen_ang or scan_front_sen_ang depending which scanner is used) plays a key role in the pallet detection accuracy. A clear sign of wrong scanner angle is a sidewise drifting pallet position during the approaching drive.

A good method to calibrate the scanner is to do it in a controlled pallet detection drive as follows:

  • Plan a straight route of approximately 4 meters in an environment with good positioning confidence. Mark a symbolic point with pallet detection tag at the end of the route.

  • Set the pallet detection parameters so that the pallet detection is active during the entire route (target_detection_type_selection = 3, target_detection_always_enabled = 1) and disable the docking to keep the AGV on the route (docking_to_target_enabled = 0).

  • Place a pallet accurately on the AGV fork and give the AGV a drive order to the symbolic point so that it unloads the pallet accurately at the symbolic point location. The idea is just to have the pallet on the symbolic point.

  • Give the AGV a drive order to the other end of the route.

  • Give the AGV a drive order to the symbolic point where the pallet is and verify that the pallet detection is active during the drive.

  • When the drive is ready, disconnect the Monitor from the navigation so that the drive can be analyzed by sliding back and forth with the progress bar (see below)

Monitor Progress bar.

  • Slide backwards until the first pallet detection visualizations in the beginning of the drive (green pallet square on the map) and freeze the view as shown in the figure below.

Frozen initial pallet position at start of drive.

  • Slide forwards again until the AGV reaches the pallet and monitor how the pallet position is drifting while the AGV approaches the pallet.

  • If the pallet position is constantly drifting sideways in one direction, this is caused by an error in the scanner angle, see the second figure below.

  • Adjust the scanner angle in the parameter file, unfreeze the Monitor view, reconnect the Monitor and request Navitrol to update the parameters.

  • Repeat the pallet detection drive, analyzing the pallet drift during the drive and adjusting the scanner angle until the drift is small and randomly to both sides of the route.

  • Now the scanner angle should be accurately calibrated.

Frozen pallet position and current pallet position mismatch.

Required Navitrol parameters

Following parameters have to be always set to use pallet detection:

I,target_detection_type_selection, 3

# Enables reflector-based docking or pallet detection, 0 = disabled, 1 = reflector docking, 2 = pallet detection, 3 = pallet detection v2, 4 = external target detection, 5 = supervisor controlled;

NOTE! There are two pallet detection versions, but version 2 (target_detection_type_selection = 3) should be used from now on. The first version of pallet detection (parameter value 2) should not be used anymore. Navitec Systems have not updated this version anymore since 2018.

Main difference is that version 2 supports using more than 1 scanner for pallet detection, can detect the pallet in any driving direction and works with all omni headings.

I,target_detection_scan_selection, 1 or 2

# Defines which scanners are used for target detection: 1 = rear scanner only, 2 = front scanner only, 3 = both scanners (supported only in reflector-based detection!), 4 = use scanner in driving direction, 5 = alternate between scanners

NOTE! More than two scanners are supported with target_detection_multi_scan_selection parameter. target_detection_scan_selection has to be 0 to activate that parameter.

I,docking_to_target_enabled, 1

# 1 = Enables docking to target. 2 = docking with custom route. If target_detection_type_selection == 0, won't do anything

F,docking_max_start_distance, 3.5 # Beyond maximum distance docking won't be triggered

Differences between these two docking types are explained in Chapters 8.4 and 8.5.

Pallet models used for the detection has to be defined as Navitrol parameters. They are array parameters and maximum number of models used is 5. The algorithm tries to detect the best match from the different models given. At least one models has to be always defined.

An example of EUR-pallet in Navitrol parameters:

ParameterValue
I,pallet_model_enabled[0],1
S,pallet_model_description[0],"EUR-pallet"
F,pallet_model_width_y[0],0.800
F,pallet_model_length_x[0],1.200
I,pallet_model_n_legs_x[0],3
I,pallet_model_n_legs_y[0],3
F,pallet_model_mid_leg_width_y[0],0.145
F,pallet_model_mid_leg_length_x[0],0.145
F,pallet_model_side_leg_width_y[0],0.100
F,pallet_model_side_leg_length_x[0],0.145

The second model can be given by changing the array index to [1], the third model with [2] and so on. Individual models can be temporarily disabled by changing the pallet_model_enabled to 0, so you don't need to remove the whole model from parameter file to disable it. At least one model has to be enabled all the time.

NOTE! Pallet detection algorithm tries to find the best fitting model from these, but if the models are too similar to each other, false positives can happen.

  • Larger differences between pallet models is always better.

  • Additional models should be avoided, if not necessary

Pallet dimensions

Scanner modes

The target_detection_scan_selection parameter has different options for the scanner use. This parameter is only meant to define what scanner data is used for pallet detection. The scanner has to be enabled with this parameter: scan_rear_front_selection.

  • Mode 1: Uses scanner that is defined with scanner_model_rear parameter.

  • Mode 2: Uses scanner that is defined with scanner_model_front parameter.

  • Mode 3: Uses data from both front and rear scanners. Not supported with target_detection_type_selection = 2, the scanner mode 4 should be used instead.

  • Mode 4: Uses data from scanner based on the driving direction. When driving forward, using front scanner, when driving backwards use the rear scanner. Uses wheel speed to define the driving direction (positive forwards, negative backwards). For example: Steer wheel for steer drive, fastest wheel of diff drive. If the AGV is standing still, using the last scanner.

The target_detection_multi_scan_selection parameter supports more scanners. If the target_detection_scan_selection is 0, this parameter is used instead. This parameter is array parameter and each array index matches to the scanner:

target_detection_multi_scan_selection[0] = Rear scanner

target_detection_multi_scan_selection[1] = Front scanner

target_detection_multi_scan_selection[2] = Measurement 0 scanner

target_detection_multi_scan_selection[3] = Measurement 1 scanner

Then the parameter values define what mode is used.

  • Mode 1: Uses this scanner only. For example, target_detection_multi_scan_selection[2] = 1 uses only measurement 0 scanner for target detection.

  • Mode 2: Uses all defined scanners. For example, target_detection_multi_scan_selection[2] = 2 and target_detection_multi_scan_selection[3] = 2 both measurement 0 and measurement 1 scanners are used for target detection.

  • Mode 3: Alternate primary scanner. The idea is that target detection uses only data from the received scanner (primary or secondary). Mainly used on pattern detection (target_detection_type_selection = 1 and refl_det_version = 2).

  • Mode 4: Alternate secondary scanner.

  • Mode 5: Use this scanner when driving forwards. For example, target_detection_multi_scan_selection[1] = 5. Front scanner is used only when AGV is driving forwards.

  • Mode 6: Use this scanner when driving backwards. For example, target_detection_multi_scan_selection[1] = 6. Front scanner is used only when AGV is driving backwards.

  • Mode 7: Use this scanner when driving sideways to the right (should be used only with omni).

  • Mode 8: Use this scanner when driving sideways to the left (should be used only with omni).

Pallet detection

Search area

The search area is an area that defines what scanner points are included in pallet detection algorithm.

  • For non-buffer lane symbolic points with load detection enabled, the search area is defined first as a circle and then limited based on the pallet width we are searching for (see two figures below). The circle radius comes from pallet model dimension and pallet_det_2_initial_search_model_width_add parameter. If there are multiple pallet models defined, then the pallet model that has the largest dimension is used.

Circle shaped search area around the symbolic point, marked as dashed blue line.

  • For buffer lanes, the circle is not used, but the search area is defined initially based on the first pallet model width defined on params.txt file and the pallet_det_2_initial_search_model_width_add parameter as on the figure below. If there are multiple pallet models, then the search area is first limited based on the first model width and later limited based on the model we are searching for.

Search area based on pallet width. The area between the blue dashed lines is defined from route to the pallet width + pallet_det_2_initial_search_model_width_add.

Start point for clustering

The start point for clustering is usually the closest point in AGV coordinate frame. If this point is not found from the closest legs of the pallet, the detection cannot find the pallet. There are two values that are used to select the start point:

  • Distance from scanner point to AGV navigation pose
  • Scanner point angle relative to the symbolic point. This angle is a difference between line that goes from AGV navigation pose to scanner point, and line that goes from AGV navigation pose to symbolic point

Parameter pallet_det_first_leg_ang_weight can be used to define the weight between these two values. The bigger the parameter value, the more important is the small angle. The smaller the value, the more important is the small distance.

Parameter pallet_det_use_dynamic_search_ang defines how the maximum angle for the start point is calculated.
