  • If pallet_det_use_dynamic_search_ang is 1, then the angle is calculated with distance from AGV to the symbolic point + docking_stop_distance and the half pallet width + pallet_det_2_initial_search_model_width_add. The idea is that the angle is little bit higher than the closest corner of the pallet. See figure below.

Maximum angle for the start point, illustrated as red line. The angle changes dynamically based on the AGV distance to the symbolic point. 1. docking_stop_distance parameter, 2. Pallet half width, 3. pallet_det_2_initial_search_model_width_add parameter, 4. Maximum angle, 5. Distance from AGV to symbolic point.

  • If pallet_det_use_dynamic_search_ang is 0, then pallet_det_limit_initial_search_ang is used to define the max angle. See figure below.

Maximum angle for the start point, illustrated as red line. The angle is static and it does not change based on distance to the symbolic point. 1. Angle is defined only with pallet_det_limit_initial_search_ang parameter.

Linear model

Linear model is a detection feature that matches straight line for the pallet width. The idea is to detect the stringer board of the pallet or the load on the pallet if it has the width of the pallet.

Linear model can be enabled with parameter pallet_det_linear_models_enabled.

The parameter pallet_det_lin_mod_point_threshold define what is the maximum distance between consecutive points to create the straight line.

The parameter pallet_det_linear_model_max_err is maximum error between the model width (pallet_model_width_y paramater) and the detected line.

Example of the linear model. The pallet is detected based on the line width.

Asymmetric pallets

An asymmetric pallet is a pallet that is shaped like an isosceles trapezoid, meaning it is symmetric along one axis and asymmetric along the other. Each pallet is assumed to have four legs, visualized below:

Dimensions of an asymmetric pallet

An asymmetric pallet will create four models, from each possible direction of detection. The models are obtained as 0, 90, 180 and 270 degree rotations of the pallet around its axis.

Models obtained from an asymmetric pallet

The pose estimate (x, y, h) of an asymmetric pallet is obtained as the centre of the facade for the symmetric side or in line with the pallet leg that is nominally closer to the AGV. The side leg angle offset Y is used to compensate the computed heading, visualized in the Figure above. The position of the pallet is visualized as a blue circle in the below Figures


Pose estimation of an asymmetric pallet

For asymmetric pallets a heading distinction of 180 degrees must be made. This is done by the sign of the side leg angle offset Y weighted by parameter pallet_det_fitness_weight[7]. Asymmetric pallet detection logging has prefix Pallet detection: asymmetric that is visible, when parameter log_pallet_detection is set to 1.

Locking the target

The target is locked (meaning its position is not updated anymore) after the distance to target is close enough.

  • If target_detection_type_selection = 2, the distance parameter is pallet_det_min_dist_from_scanner.

  • If target_detection_type_selection = 3, the distance parameter is pallet_det_2_min_dist_from_nav_point_to_traj_end.

There is also model-based parameter pallet_model_min_dist_from_nav_point_to_traj_end[model index] that is used if the target should be locked in different distance for different pallet models.

Locking the model

This can be used if there are different pallet models. If the target is found multiple times in a row the algorithm can be locked to search only that specific model by setting the parameter pallet_det_2_lock_model_if_found_number_of_times to some reasonable value (e.g. 10 times). However, it is important to check if the old target is reset between different symbolic points. This can be tested by driving between two pallet detection points that has different pallet models and see which model is locked. If the last pallet model seems to be detected also on the next location, it indicates that the model is not reset between those locations. The old result is reset after there is no detection in number of times set by this parameter: target_max_n_times_missing (e.g. start with 100 times missing and decrease if still detect the model from the last symbolic point).

Wall check

Wall check example shows where the holes and walls are checked.

ParameterValuesDescription
I,pallet_det_wall_check[0],0to 2
I,pallet_det_wall_check[1],0 or 1
I,pallet_det_wall_check_points,3How many points at maximum from the leg are checked in the wall checks, before a decision is made that if there is empty space or not
F,pallet_det_wall_point_dist_threshold,0.01, 0.05, 0.20Maximum distance (meters) between points, that they are estimated to be linked together in the wall checks

There are three modes on the wall check:

Mode 1: pallet_det_wall_check[0] = 1

Check that there is empty space between the legs. If the space is not empty, solution is discarded.

Mode 2: pallet_det_wall_check[0] = 2

Check if there is a wall next to the legs. If found wall, discard the solution.

Mode 3: pallet_det_wall_check[1] = 1

Additional check that if there are pallets next to each other and the pallet detected is actually bigger model than should be (outer legs detected instead of the inner ones)

Example of wall check. The points circled with red are considered as leg and blue ones are included to the wall check. Here the pallet_det_wall_check_points is 6 and it means that if there are 6 scanner points next to the leg, the wall check will discard that result. The pallet_det_wall_point_dist_threshold is 0.05 so the purple point is too far from the blue points, so it is not included and then the blue ones below doesn't have enough points to be considered as wall.

Search only front legs

If the rear legs are not visible with the scanner or if they don't match with the pallet model parameters (e.g. the leg shape is not rectangle), it is possible to use only front legs for the detection. There might be also something else on the rear that doesn't give any reasonable results for the algorithm. For example, on the figure down below, the rear legs are different size than the front legs so it does not make sense to try to detect the rear legs.

Example of poor pallet detection scanner data on the rear legs.

If pallet_det_2_detect_only_front_legs is set to 1, the algorithm detects only front legs.

Object detection

Object detection is a sub feature of pallet detection in which instead of a pallet any group of scanner points that are close to each other and within the search area can be detected as the target. If several groups are found, the closest one is selected as the target.

The downsides of the object detection is that it can detect anything on the route, so the accuracy might vary and that it does not provide the angle of the target. The downsides makes object detection only compatible with docking methods, that do not use the target angle, such as docking with only distance control.

NameTypeRequired valueDescription
pallet_det_object_det_enabledInt1Enables object detection so that instead of pallets any cluster of scanner points inside the search area is detected as a target. target_detection_type_selection must have value 3 for this parameter to have an effect.

As a sub feature of pallet detection many of the parameters affecting pallet detection affect object detection as well with some differences. For example, pallet_model_width_y[0] is used to visualize the width of the found target.

Related parameters that can be adjusted:

  • target_detection_min_search_radius
  • target_detection_type_selection
  • pallet_det_min_points_close_to_first_point
  • pallet_det_2_max_dist_to_first_point
  • pallet_det_use_dynamic_search_ang
  • pallet_det_limit_initial_search_ang
  • target_detection_max_dist_to_symbolic_point

Unwanted cluster between legs

The unwanted cluster is a feature that tries to find object between the two-legged pallet on the first row. The main idea is to add cost to model that has something between its legs or to discard that model. On the picture down below is an example case where there are two small pallets next to each other and larger model (the green box) is detected instead. This has been created mainly to avoid detecting large two-legged models, if there are also smaller models. For example, if the picture down below would have large model (the green box) that would fit to the outer legs, but we want to detect only the smaller one this would be useful.

The parameter pallet_det_2_fitness_cost_percentage_for_unwanted_cluster defines if the fitness of that result is only decreased by some percentage value or if the model is discarded (negative value) when unwanted cluster is found between the legs.

The parameter pallet_det_2_min_points_to_create_unwanted_cluster define how many points is needed between the legs to create cluster. On the figure down below, the unwanted cluster is circled with red.

The parameter pallet_det_2_max_point_diff_for_unwanted_cluster define the point difference related to the side legs. The idea is to detect only similar size clusters as the outer legs.

Unwanted cluster example. The pallet has unwanted cluster (the red circle), between the front legs. Depending on the case, the result can be discarded or the fitness value can be decreased to add more weight to other results.

Target filtering

Target detection results are filtered, before they are given for route planner to calculate a docking path.

Target detection filtering parameters:

F,target_detection_results_dampening, (0.30 by default)

Dampening value for the results; min = 0.0, max = 1

Filters as a low pass filter, so bigger value means that location is updated faster, lower means more filtering is done

I, target_min_n_times_detected, (20 by default)

Minimum number of times target must be detected successfully before target is approved as found.

I, target_max_n_times_missing, (300 by default)

Maximum number of times last known location of target is given if no target detected

This means that, if the target was detected successfully target_min_n_times_detected -times, the algorithm still uses the last known location for route planning, even if the target is not detected in less than target_max_n_times_missing -cycles. If target is not detected for larger amount of cycles, it is considered lost.

Navitrol Monitor Pallet Detection form

Navitrol Pallet Detection form can be opened in Navitrol Monitor from the menu Navitrol -> Pallet Detection Form, when the Monitor is connected to an AGV. It can be used for testing and debugging the pallet detection and the docking procedure it should execute.

The pallet detection form in Navitrol Monitor

All the Navitrol parameters shown on the form can be changed to Navitrol params.txt by changing the value on the field manually and pressing the button 'Upload & Save parameters'. It saves the new parameters and reloads them into use. If the checkbox 'Save new params to file' is unchecked, parameters are only loaded into use for current run, but are not saved to the params.txt. 'Reload current parameters' can be then used to use again the parameters on the params.txt.

Short explanations for the fields shown on the form:

Driving to location with pallet det enabled

When the end location of the current driving order has the pallet detection enabled from Navithor Tools, this box turns green and shows 1. Otherwise it is red and 0 and the docking procedure will never start.

Pallet detection algorithm started

If pallet detection is activated in Navitrol parameters, the AGV is driving into a location with pallet detection enabled and we are close enough to the symbolic point (on default 6 meters), the AGV starts to search for the pallet and this box turns green and shows 1. The algorithm can be also always activated with Navitrol parameters, but that should be usually used only for debugging purposes.

Target found

This box turns green and shows 1, when the target is found.

Target detected n times

Shows how many times in a row the target is properly seen. There is a parameter to limit for how many times the target has to be first send, before the target is locked and docking can be started.

The parameter is shown on the right side: target_min_n_times_detected

Target missing n times

If the target is already locked (the target is seen enough, so that the limit above is fulfilled), the old location for the target is used even if the algorithm doesn't detect the pallet every calculation round. Only after the target is missing for too long time, the docking procedure is cancelled. The parameter for how many times the target can be missing is shown on the right side: target_max_n_times_missing

Distance from scanner to the target

Minimum distance from the scanner to the calculated stopping point for the target location to be updated. Scanners usually have more error in close ranges, so this parameter can be used to just use the last known location for the target, after it is closer than the distance specified in pallet_det_min_dist_from_scanner.

NOTE: If target_detection_type_selection is 3, pallet_det_2_min_dist_from_nav_point_to_traj_end is used instead for the same purpose.

Docking started

The box will stay red until all the 5 restrictions below are met and the docking can be started. After that the box will turn green.

Limits for starting the docking procedure

Distance from navigation point to the target stopping point

Parameter to change: docking_max_start_distance

Angle difference between symbolic point heading and angle from navigation point to the symbolic point

Parameter to change: docking_max_start_angle

Angle difference between symbolic point's and AGV's headings

Parameter to change: docking_max_start_heading

Angle difference between target angle and symbolic point's heading

Parameter to change: docking_max_target_angle

Distance error between symbolic point and the calculated target stopping point (stopping offset included)

Parameter to change: docking_max_dist_error_from_end_point

Other Navitrol parameters shown on the form:

docking_stop_distance

docking_y_offset

pallet_det_heading_offset (used only with target_detection_type_selection = 2)

docking_dist_gain

docking_heading_gain

Below is shown two example screenshots, how the Pallet Detection Form looks like in Navitrol Monitor and how the target is visualized. In the first screenshot the target is found, but all restrictions for starting the docking procedure are not yet met, so the AGV is not yet correcting its path according to the target found.

On the second screenshot docking is started. The new stopping point is visualized with a blue arrow and the green arrow shows the trajectory, where the AGV is currently trying to correct its path.

Target is detection, but docking is not yet started, because the distance to target is too high, the heading is not within allowed limits and start angle is not within limits.

Docking procedure started when the start conditions are met.

Troubleshoot

This chapter introduces some issues that customer might face with pallet detection or docking and how to resolve them.

Pallet detection is not started when driving to symbolic point

When driving to Symbolic point, there is no green box on the Monitor or Client that indicates that pallet has been found. There might be several reasons, but here are the most common ones.

Tag missing

Problem: In this case, there is no warning or error, because the pallet detection or docking is not activated.

What to do: Check that the symbolic point has pallet detection tag on Tools.

Pallet detection tag for symbolic point on Tools.

Target detection not enabled

Problem: On this case, there is no error or warning, because the feature is not enabled. Even if there is the pallet detection tag.

What to do: Check that target_detection_type_selection has 2 or 3.

Closest point not found

Problem: The AGV stops with TARGET_APPROACH_ERROR and on the log just before this error there is a line "Pallet detection ERROR: Closest point for lin mod" or "Pallet det: Closest point for legs not found."

What to do:

  • If pallet_det_use_dynamic_search_ang is set to 1, check that pallet_det_2_initial_search_model_width_add has large enough value. It is used to calculate the search area for the closest point.

Dynamic search angle calculation for two-legged and three-legged pallet. It is calculated based on distance to target and model width + pallet_det_2_initial_search_model_width_add parameter.

  • If pallet_det_use_dynamic_search_ang is set to 0, check that pallet_det_limit_initial_search_ang has large enough search angle.

  • Check that pallet_det_min_points_close_to_first_point has smaller value than scanner points in the smallest cluster on the front row.

The middle leg has only two scanner points and the value for the pallet_det_min_points_close_to_first_point parameter was 2. Meaning that there should be total of three points in a distance of pallet_det_2_max_dist_to_first_point.

Scanner points are discarded

Problem: If target_detection_type_selection is 3, the parameter pallet_det_min_dist_from_scanner is used to discard scanner points that are too close to the scanner. One indication for this case is on the log print where the pallet detection is started. If there is this kind of log print: "Starting pallet det v2 algorithm, pointsnbr 0", it means that there are no scanner points for the algorithm.

What to do: Set this pallet_det_min_dist_from_scanner parameter to small value, so it doesn't discard points in too far distance.

Pallet model parameters are incorrect

Problem: The model is not found, because the width and length are incorrect or the number of legs is not correct. In many cases it is better to verify the actual leg size and pallet width from Monitor (using the Measurement tape button on the top bar), because the sizes depend on the scanner resolution and the distance. The longer the distance to the target, the less accurate scanner data is, because of the scanner resolution.

The pallet_model_width_y parameters is always the front side where the AGV is approaching to the pallet and pallet_model_length_x is the side. For example, when picking the EUR-pallet from normal direction, the width is 0.8 m and the length is 1.2 m. If this same EUR-pallet can be picked up from the side (approaching from the 1.2 m side), then there has to be other model that defines its dimensions. Then that model width is 1.2 m and length is 0.8 m. Also, the leg dimensions have to be set accordingly.

Here the pallet dimensions are same, but there has to be different model based on approaching direction.

What to do: Check Chapter 5 to verify that the model parameters are okay in general.

Pallet detected in wrong location

Pallet is too much on the side

Problem: There are several pallets next to each other. The pallet is found too much to the side, based on the pallet next to the desired one.

Pallet detected on side. The desired result is the two-legged one close to the symbolic point.

What to do: Decrease pallet_det_2_initial_search_model_width_add to decrease the search area or decrease pallet_det_2_max_dist_to_route to discard pallets that are found too far from the route.

Pallet angle changes during drive

Problem: AGV drives towards the pallet, but the target angle changes suddenly. This causes AGV to turn off the route, because it will try to reach the changed target. On the three example pictures down below, the scanner sees first the stringer board, then some part between the legs and the stringer board and finally the legs of the pallet. The main problem here is that the scanner is lifted during the docking procedure. In general, during the pallet detection, the scanner should only see points that can be detected as a pallet (for example not the floor in front of the pallet).

Pallet is seen from the stringer board. Docking is not started yet.

Pallet is seen a bit below the stringer board or the scanner sees something below the pallet. This part of the pallet is not very reasonable for the detection and causes wrong angle. The docking is started based on this detection.

Pallet is seen from the legs.

What to do:

  • Change the docking_start_distance so the docking starts only after the pallet is detected correctly.

  • Check tilt of the scanner. The scanner should see only the legs or the stringer board of the pallet.

  • Decrease pallet_det_2_max_pallet_angle_error to discard pallets that have too high angle error.

Most common parameters

This list includes most commonly used parameters that are often changed in normal use. On this list there are three values for each parameter: min, default and max. If there is only one value, that is the default value. If the parameter is not set on the params.txt file, the default value is used. The first letter states the type of the parameter (I = Integer, F = Float, S = String).

Target detection parameters

ParameterDescription
I,target_detection_type_selection, 0, 0, 5Enables reflector-based docking or pallet detection, 0 = disabled, 1 = reflector docking, 2 = pallet detection, 3 = pallet detection v2, 4 = external target detection, 5 = supervisor controlled;
I,target_detection_scan_selection, 0, 1, 5Defines which scanners are used for target detection: 0 = enable target_detection_multi_scan_selection, 1 = rear scanner only, 2 = front scanner only, 3 = both scanners (supported only in reflector-based detection!), 4 = use scanner in driving direction, 5 = alternate between scanners target_detection_multi_scan_selection is used only when target_detection_scan_selection is 0!
I,target_detection_multi_scan_selection[Indexes 0-3], 0, 0, 8Indexes: 0=rear, 1=front, 2=meas0, 3=meas1. 1 = use as only scanner, 2 = together with others (all at once), 3 = alternating with other as primary, 4 = alternating with other as secondary, 5 = use when driving forwards, 6 = use when driving backwards, 7 = use when driving transversal right, 8 = use when driving transversal left
I,target_detection_always_enabled, 0, 0, 11 = Enables target detection algorithm always. Note! Should be used only for initial test or calibration and disabled after that! 0 = detect target only when close to target detection tagged symbolic point.
F,target_detection_max_dist_to_symbolic_point, 6.0Max distance to the end point to start the algorithm
F,target_detection_maximum_iterations, 1, 10, 50The maximum number of target detection iterations before responding to target detection query
F,target_detection_min_search_radius, 0, 0, 100Defines the minimum search radius around the expected target location, such as symbolic point, from which the target is searched.
For pallet detection see also model widths and pallet_det_2_initial_search_model_width_add parameter.
For reflector detection see also docking_max_dist_error_from_end_point.

Docking parameters

ParameterDescription
I,docking_to_target_enabled, 0, 0, 21 = Enables docking to target. 2 = docking with custom route. If target_detection_type_selection == 0, won't do anything
F,docking_max_start_distance, 3.5Beyond maximum distance docking won't be triggered
F,docking_max_start_angle, 15.0Max angle difference from navigation point to the target compared to trajectory's end point's heading, when starting to dock [-degrees fov]
F,docking_max_start_heading, 5.0Max angle diff for vehicle heading and trajectory's end point heading, when starting to dock [+-degrees fov]
F,docking_max_dist_error_from_end_point, 0.5Maximum distance difference for the stopping point compared to the symbolic point
F,docking_max_target_angle, 15.0Maximum difference between target and end point's headings
F,docking_stop_distance, 0.50Defines how close to the target vehicle tries to drive (calculated from navigation point to target)
F,docking_y_offset, 0.0Offset in y-coordinate for docking (in machine coordinates)
F,docking_approach_dist, 1.25When approaching target closer than this distance, vehicle stops if the approach error is too big
F,docking_dist_gain, 1.0Dist gain while docking, 0 = use pc_pid_dist_p
F,docking_heading_gain, 1.0Heading gain while docking, 0 = use pc_pid_heading_p
I,docking_ref_v_source, 0, 0, 2Speed source when doing docking, 0 = calculated from distance to target, 1 = using route velocity value, 2 = use fixed parameter docking_speed
F, docking_speed, 0.3Speed while docking, if docking_ref_v_source == 2. If it is 0, this is minimum starting speed for the docking drive.
I,docking_leave_unload_loc_straight, 0Limit curvature after unload if set to 1
F,docking_leave_unload_loc_straight_dist, 1.0Limit curvature after unload if set to 1

// Docking with custom route. docking_to_target_enabled = 2

ParameterDescription
F,docking_control_point_1_dist_from_machine, 0.0, 0.20, 10.0Minimum distance for the node straight to the AGV heading.
F,docking_control_point_2_dist_from_target, 0.0, 0.80, 10.0Distance for the node to create straight route before target.
I,docking_allow_custom_route_update, 0, 0, 10 = custom route is locked after it is created, 1 = custom route is updated if the target changes.
F,docking_custom_route_min_xy_diff, -1.0, 0.02, 0.50Minimum distance difference (in meters) between the old pallet and the new to update the last part of the custom route. If set to positive, custom route is updated. Also uses target_detection_max_diff_in_xy_results to check that the difference is not too large.
F,docking_custom_route_min_angle_diff, -1.0, 2.0, 20.0Minimum angle difference (in degrees) between the old pallet and the new to update the last part of the custom route. If set to positive, custom route is updated. Also uses target_detection_max_diff_in_angle_results to check that the difference is not too large.
F,docking_custom_route_max_allowed_xy_diff_for_target, 0.0, 0.2, 1.0Maximum limit (in meters) for the custom route update related to the initial target. The custom route is not updated if the new target is further away than this parameter from the initial target (target location when the custom route is created for the first time).

Pallet model parameters

These parameters define the pallet model we are searching for. These are array parameters and the maximum number of models is 5 (indexes from 0 to 4). Example set for EUR-pallet can be found from Chapter 5

ParameterDescription
I,pallet_model_enabled[index], -10 = pallet model is currently not used for detection, 1 = model enabled
S,pallet_model_description[index], ""Description of the pallet (for example 'EUR-pallet')
F,pallet_model_width_y[index], 0.0Total width of the pallet (measured from stringer board)
F,pallet_model_length_x[index], 0.0Total length of the pallet
I,pallet_model_n_legs_x[index], 0Number of legs (2 or 3) in X-direction (lengthwise)
I,pallet_model_n_legs_y[index], 0Number of legs (2 or 3) in Y-direction (widthwise)
F,pallet_model_mid_leg_width_y[index], 0.0Width (y-dimension) of the legs in middle column
F,pallet_model_mid_leg_length_x[index], 0.0Length (x-dimension) of the legs in middle column
F,pallet_model_side_leg_width_y[index], 0.0Width (y-dimension) of the legs on both side columns
F,pallet_model_side_leg_length_x[index], 0.0Length (x-dimension) of the legs on both side columns

Pallet detection parameters

ParameterDescription
I,pallet_det_linear_models_enabled, 0, 1, 1Enables pallet detection from stringer board (top part of the pallet), which can be seen as a line
I,pallet_det_min_points_in_cluster[index from 0 to 1], 5Minimum num of meas points in leg, second limit for a smaller leg, recommended values 5 for first and 4 for second
F,pallet_det_linear_model_max_err, 0.001, 0.07, 0.25Maximum difference (in meters) between the found line model and width of the pallet model for solution to be accepted
F,pallet_det_min_dist_from_scanner, 0.00, 0.20, 5.00Minimum distance from scanner to pallet that pallet position is updated (on ver2, the scanner points that are closer than this parameter are discarded)
F,pallet_det_2_min_dist_from_nav_point_to_traj_end, 0.00, 0.50, 25.0Minimum distance from navigation point to trajectory end that pallet position is still updated. This parameter is ignored, if model specific distances are defined.
F,pallet_det_2_initial_search_model_width_add, -0.50, 0.50, 2.00Increase the search area by adding this value to the model width.
I,pallet_det_2_detect_only_front_legs, 0, 0, 1If set to 1, algorithm detects only first legs and calculates target position based on this. Sometimes increases accuracy, because front legs are seen most accurately.
F,pallet_det_2_max_dist_to_route, 0.0, 0.2, 2.0Maximum distance to the route (line that is aligned to the route heading). Calculated from the pallet center. If the pallet is found further that this parameter, that result is discarded.
F,pallet_det_maximum_target_pose_error, 0.05, 0.2, 3.0Maximum target distance deviation between estimated centre point and target. Applicable to supervisor target detection.

Advanced parameters

This list includes more advanced parameters that are not necessarily needed in normal use.

NOTE! If need to change some of these parameters, make sure to understand what these parameters do or contact Navitec for more information.

On this list there are three values for each parameter: min, default and max. If there is only one value, that is the default value. If the parameter is not set on the params.txt file, the default value is used. The first letter states the type of the parameter (I = Integer, F = Float, S = String).

Target detection parameters

ParameterDescription
F,target_detection_results_dampening, 0.0, 0.3, 1.0Dampening value for the results
F,target_detection_max_diff_in_xy_results, 0.20How much difference (meters) is allowed in xy-location before the new result is updated without dampening
F,target_detection_max_diff_in_angle_results, 5.0How much difference (degrees) is allowed in angle before the new result is updated without dampening
I,target_min_n_times_detected, 20Minimum number of times target must be detected before giving results
I,target_max_n_times_missing, 300Max num of times last known location for target is given if no target detected; min = 0
I,target_detection_supervisor_update_message_enabled, 0, 1, 20 = Disabled, 1 = Use message 4101, 2 = Use message 4104 (contains more info)

Docking parameters

ParameterDescription
F,docking_approach_max_dist_err, 0.10If distance between reference and navigation point is bigger than this in approach area, vehicle stops
F,docking_approach_max_h_err, 5.0If heading error between reference and AGV heading is bigger than this (degrees) in approach area, vehicle stops
F,docking_limit_curv_on_leave, 0.05Limit curvature on leave (approach distance)
F,docking_small_gains_dist, 0.50The distance to limit curvature on approach
F,docking_limit_corr_dist, 0.50The distance before stopping which is driven only with odometry (docking_max_xy_corr and docking_max_h_corr used instead of normal gains)
I,docking_small_gains, 1Limit curvature on approach
F,docking_max_xy_corr, 0.0001Max loc xy corr while approaching target
F,docking_max_h_corr, 0.003Max loc h corr while approaching target
F,docking_limit_curv_on_approach, 0.1Limit curvature on approach after small gains dist
F,docking_limit_leave_speed, 0.0, 0.2, 1.0Limit speed while driving out from docking location, if docking_limit_leave_speed_and_actuator_height_dist > 0. If it is below 0, speed is not limited.
F,docking_limit_leave_speed_and_actuator_height_dist, -2.0, -1.0, 20.0Distance from the unload location, where the speed and fork height is limited to the actuator_min_val. If negative, they are not limited. If enabled, had to be smaller than docking_mode_to_fleet_control_dist parameter.
F,docking_mode_to_fleet_control_dist, 2.5Inform fleet control of docking mode after leaving the location
F,docking_notify_approach_dist, 0.50Distance from docking target when a notification is sent to the AGV control
I,docking_stopping_point_offset_mode, 0, 0, 10 = Use general stopping offsets, 1 = offsets are defined individually for each pallet model with parameters
I,docking_follow_route_properties, 0, 1, 1Use defined properties on the route while docking to target
F,docking_refpoint_max_err, -1.0, -0.5, 10.0Max error (in m) for the docking point after started docking. Indicate pushing pallet. If negative, not used.

// P-controller These are array parameters with indexes from 0 to 2.

ParameterDescription
F,pc_pid_docking_dist_limit[index], 0.0Change PID settings after the distance to docking target is smaller than given here (0.0 == disabled)
F,pc_pid_docking_dist_p[index], 0.0, 0.0, 100.0distance gain
F,pc_pid_docking_heading_p[index], 0.0, 0.0, 100.0heading gain

Pallet model parameters

These parameters define the pallet model we are searching for. These are array parameters and the maximum number of models is 5 (indexes from 0 to 4). Example set for EUR-pallet can be found from Chapter 5

ParameterDescription
F,pallet_model_y_offset[index], 0.0Offset in y-coordinate for docking (in machine coordinates)
F,pallet_model_stop_distance[index], 0.0Defines how close to the target vehicle tries to drive (calculated from navigation point to target)
F,pallet_model_min_dist_from_nav_point_to_traj_end[index], -1.0Model specific minimum distance from navigation point to trajectory end that pallet position is still updated. -1.0 = disabled and the generic parameter pallet_det_2_min_dist_from_nav_point_to_traj_end is used instead.
I,pallet_model_discard_outlier_points[index], 0, 0, 1Discard outlier points on leg cluster. Uses average distance on cluster to detect outliers. Might be useful if the leg length is small and there are no points to see on the side.

Pallet detection parameters

ParameterDescription
F,pallet_det_lin_mod_point_threshold, 0.01, 0.07, 0.20Max distance between points (meters), when detecting a pallet from stringer board
F,pallet_det_limit_initial_search_ang, 5.0, 20.0, 135.0Limits the search field of view in front of the scanner for the first leg (+-degrees)
I,pallet_det_use_dynamic_search_ang, 0, 1, 1If set to 1, algorithm dynamically makes the search fov bigger, if the target to be detected is closer and vice versa.
F,pallet_det_limit_search_space, 0.30, 3.00, 10.0Limits the searching space in front of the laser scanner. Maximum distance (meters) sideways for points to be considered for pallet.
F,pallet_det_first_leg_ang_weight, 0.10, 0.75, 5.00The two factors deciding the location for the first leg of the pallet we try to detect are angle and distance compared to the expected location. If parameter is bigger, having small angle errors is more important than distance error.
F,pallet_det_point_filter_dist, 0.02, 0.10, 0.30Filters all the points away from calculations, which don't have any close neighbors within this (meters)
F,pallet_det_leg_dist_err, 0.2, 0.5, 2.0Scales how much error is allowed for the points in the side legs (measured from the supposed center points). Allowed distance error is this parameter multiplied with pallet leg width, so the dimensions of the model also affect the result.
F,pallet_det_leg_dist_err_back, 0.01, 0.07, 0.15How much distance error (meters) is allowed for points in clusters behind the first row
F,pallet_det_leg_ang_err, 1.0, 7.0, 15.0How many degrees of error is allowed for individual points in the first row of legs
F,pallet_det_leg_ang_err_back, 0.5, 2.5, 10.0After detecting the legs and correcting the cluster locations, how many degrees of errors is allowed for the cluster location compared to expected for the legs behind the first row to be valid.
F,pallet_det_max_leg_dist_err, 0.01, 0.07, 0.20How many meters of distance error is allowed for the cluster locations compared to expected in the first row of legs for the whole solution to be valid. If error is bigger, solution is not accepted at all.
F,pallet_det_max_leg_ang_err, 1.0, 7.0, 15.0How many degrees of error is allowed for the cluster locations compared to expected in the first row of legs for the whole solution to be valid. If error is bigger, solution is not accepted at all.
I,pallet_det_wall_check[index from 0 to 1], 0Enable wall checks, can be 0, 1 or 2, recommended values 1 for first and 0 for second. Depending on the mode, the algorithm discards the solution, if between the legs the holes are not seen, or if on the sides of the legs it looks like there is a wall instead of empty space.
I,pallet_det_wall_check_points, 1, 6, 100Affects how many points at maximum from the leg are checked in the wall checks, before a decision is made that if there is empty space or not
F,pallet_det_wall_point_dist_threshold, 0.01, 0.05, 0.20Maximum distance (meters) between points, that they are estimated to be linked together in the wall checks
I,pallet_det_new_validity_check, 0, 1, 1New check for pallet validity. Pallet model is discarded if at least validity_check_discard_ratio of points is further away than pallet_det_wall_point_dist_threshold * 10
F,pallet_det_new_validity_check_min_discard_ratio, 0.0, 0.3, 1.0How many outlier points are required before pallet model is discarded
I,pallet_det_correction_recursion_enabled, 0, 1, 1If set to 1, if cluster correction algorithm doesn't find points that could be used for correcting the location, the function can be called recursively (for max 10 times) with a wider search angle. If 0, the search angles are always fixed and wider.
F,pallet_det_cluster_correction_angle_offset, -45.0, 0.0, 45.0On default no offset given, but if the shape of the leg requires this (some non-standard non-square shape). Changing off the offset requires in most case testing with different values to see how it exactly behaves, so no clear instructions can't be given for how to use it.
I,pallet_det_cluster_corr_mode, 0, 0, 1On default setting of 0 tries to correct X- and Y- directions independently. On 1, tries to check point's only on the nearest corner to the scanner and corrects both directions based on this.
F,pallet_det_y_corr_threshold_ang, 0.0, 4.0, 15.0If the angle difference from laser to the leg compared to leg heading is really small (smaller than this parameter), we don't really see either side of the leg so it's better to just calculate an average of the Y-direction.
I,pallet_det_cluster_corr_min_points, 1, 1, 20Minimum number of points used when correcting pallet legs. If 0 points found, making a correction is not possible. If there is a lot of variance and noise in individual points, should be set higher than 1.
F,pallet_det_cluster_dist[index from 0 to 2], 0.90Distance check multiplier for leg points in first row of legs
F,pallet_det_front_row_weight, 0.5, 3.0, 15.0How much weight is given for the front row of legs compared to other legs, when calculating the final result of XYH for pallet. Front row is usually seen more accurately, so on default it has more weight.
F,pallet_det_fitness_weight[index from 0 to 7], 1.0Array to change weight of the different parts for how good a solution is considered to be, if several are found (bigger scale means bigger weight).
Fit0 is the first found leg on the middle? fit1 how many legs found in the first row? fit2 number of legs in the back rows, solutions with more found legs are preferred. fit3 the difference between center of the pallet compared to the expected location. fit4 angle of the target compared to the expected (symbolic point heading basically). fit5 cluster width compared to model leg width. fit6 cluster outer distance compared to model width. fit7 is for determining the heading ambiguity of asymmetric pallets.
I,pallet_det_allow_only_middle_leg, 0, 0, 1If set to 1, accept only solutions for 3-leg pallets, where the closest leg to a line drawn from the navigation point towards the direction of the scanner (straight fw or bw) is the middle leg instead of a side leg
F,pallet_det_split_threshold, 0.02, 0.06, 0.50Used for deciding, if one cluster should be splitted into separate clusters. A line is calculated between start and end point and then the distance of cluster points is compared to this line. If there is a point with longer distance from the line defined by this parameter (in meters), cluster is splitted.
I,pallet_det_min_points_close_to_first_point, 1, 3, 50Min number of points next to the first point we are searching for.
F,pallet_det_heading_offset, -45.0, 0.0, 45.0Heading offset in degrees added to the target angle. Used only with target_detection_type_selection = 2.
F,pallet_det_2_max_dist_to_first_point, 0.01, 0.05, 0.30Max difference between consecutive closest points.
I,pallet_det_2_cluster_only_based_on_distance_and_index, 0, 0, 1,Create clusters based on distance between points (pallet_det_lin_mod_point_threshold) and index.
F,pallet_det_2_min_leg_cluster_coverage, 0.0, 0.7, 1.0Minimum average percentage for legs to cover the cluster. If the percentage is lower, that model is discarded. Uses fit5 value as the percentage. Used only if pallet_det_2_cluster_only_based_on_distance_and_index is set to 1
F,pallet_det_2_max_pallet_width_error, 0.0, 0.2, 5.0Maximum error between pallet width compared to side legs outer distance (in meters). If the error is higher, that model is discarded. Uses fit6 value as the error. Used only if pallet_det_2_cluster_only_based_on_distance_and_index is set to 1
F,pallet_det_2_fitness_cost_percentage_for_unwanted_cluster, -1.0, 0.8, 1.0Percentage cost for the total fitness if found cluster between the side legs. Used only with two-legged pallets and only on the front row. If set to negative, discards the model.
I,pallet_det_2_min_points_to_create_unwanted_cluster, 0, 4, 30How many scanner points are required between the side legs to try creating unwanted cluster.
I,pallet_det_2_max_point_diff_for_unwanted_cluster, 0, 4, 30How many points less are needed on the cluster on the middle related to the amount on the side legs. Used to find only similar size cluster as the side legs.
F,pallet_det_2_max_pallet_angle_error, 0.00, 30.00, 360.00Maximum angle (in degrees) for the pallet related to the symbolic point heading.
F,pallet_det_2_max_error_for_outlier_point, 0.0, 1.4, 5.0Maximum error allowed for outlier points. Used to discard points from cluster if pallet_model_discard_outlier_points is enabled.
I,pallet_det_2_lock_model_if_found_enough_times, 0, 10, 1000How many times same model is required to detect in a row before searching only that model. Cause issues if last pallet model is not reset between consecutive pallet detections (if target_max_n_times_missing is too high, the last pallet is not reset)

3D Load detection

Updated 15.07.2024

Overview

Introduction

The feature performs load detection with a 3D camera, enabling a better overall view of the load. The 3D load detection estimates object pose by matching 3D sensor data with CAD models. The feature allows for accurate pose estimation of single as well as several stacked objects. The feature can also be used for empty space detection, which means searching for an empty space in a rack or ground for unloading. A license is required for this feature.

Requirements

  • A 3D camera providing XYZI values
  • The pose of the camera w.r.t. the navigation point is known (x,y,z,roll,pitch,yaw)
  • Third party licenses installed
  • Load CAD file (.stl) -- Z-axis is pointing upwards
  • Debian Buster or Bullseye

Limitations

  • The computing time differs on the scene, the 3D camera, and how many objects of interest are stacked but the detection takes approximately 200 to 350 milliseconds, including data acquisition.
  • The field-of-view of a 3D camera is limited in comparison to 2D range scanners, normally 40-60 deg
  • Incompatible with 2D load detection
  • Maximum of three different pallet models supported at the same system. See ModelIndex.
  • Maximum of four different 3D sensors supported at the same system. See SensorIndex.

Setup

Quick start

The symbolic point is defined as load or unload, with option Enable load detection in Tools.

Transfer the third party libraries folder dependencies.7z to the IPC. Unzip the folder.
cd dependencies
dpkg -i *
apt-get install xvfb

Add to the startNavitrol.sh to the end of the file, the following line to create a virtual screen to allow rendering the partial views
nano startNavitrol.sh in /home/navitec
copy-paste in:
Xvfb :99 -screen 0 1024x768x24 > /dev/null 2>&1 &

Set the required parameters prior to generating partial views. Uploading the CAD file creates offline a database of 2.5D rendered partial views. The generated files are saved as .ply and .txt in folder /home/navitec/poses, and .bin and .idx in folder /home/navitec. Upload the CAD file to the IPC by pressing Upload to Navitrol in Navitrol Monitor

Required parameters

ModelIndex should be between [0..2].

NameTypeRequired valueDescription
target_detection_type_selectionI4Defines the source of load detection output
obj_reg_3d_enabledI13D load detection enabled
obj_reg_3d_model_name[ModelIndex]SModel name is the CAD file excl. the file extension
obj_reg_3d_object_length[ModelIndex]F0.0Length of the model in meters
obj_reg_3d_object_width[ModelIndex]F0.0Width of the model in meters
obj_reg_3d_object_height[ModelIndex]F0.0Height of the model in meters

Optional parameters

SensorIndex should be between [0..3].

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
obj_reg_3d_sensor_fov_vertical_deg[SensorIndex]F0.0The sensor's vertical field of view [deg]. Used for empty space detection and pose verification. By default 45.0 for O3D, 60.0 for Visionary. Depends on roll angle.
obj_reg_3d_sensor_fov_horizontal_deg[SensorIndex]F0.0The sensor's horizontal field of view [deg]. Used for empty space detection and pose verification. By default 60.0 for O3D, 70.0 for Visionary. Depends on roll angle.
obj_reg_3d_sensor_translation_x[SensorIndex]F0.0The x offset of the 3D camera from navigation point in meters
obj_reg_3d_sensor_translation_y[SensorIndex]F0.0The y offset of the 3D camera from navigation point in meters
obj_reg_3d_sensor_translation_z[SensorIndex]F0.0The z offset of the 3D camera from fork centre point in meters, or floor if obj_reg_3d_sensor_height_fixed is 1
obj_reg_3d_sensor_internal_rotation_roll_deg[SensorIndex]F0.0The roll angle offset of the 3D camera w.r.t. its own X-axis
obj_reg_3d_sensor_internal_rotation_pitch_deg[SensorIndex]F0.0The pitch angle offset of the 3D camera w.r.t. its own Y-axis
obj_reg_3d_sensor_internal_rotation_yaw_deg[SensorIndex]F0.0Sensor calibration yaw. Sensor's internal coordinate frame.
obj_reg_3d_sensor_model[SensorIndex]I0Sensor model
0 -- disabled
1 -- IFM O3D
2 -- SICK Visionary-T Mini
3 -- DDS pointcloud topic
obj_reg_3d_sensor_external_rotation_yaw_deg[SensorIndex]F0.0The angular deviation between the transformed 3d sensor's X and AGV's X in machine coordinate frame (heading).
dds_pointcloud2_topic_name[SensorIndex]SThe topic name for the pointcloud2 message.
obj_reg_3d_sensor_ip[SensorIndex]SThe IP address of the 3D camera
obj_reg_3d_sensor_height_fixed[SensorIndex]I0The camera is mounted statically and is independent of the actuator
obj_reg_3d_pointcloud_loggingI0Enable pointcloud logging - 0 -- disabled, 1 -- enabled
obj_reg_3d_number_of_pointcloud_logsI0The maximum number of pointcloud logs saved to folder
obj_reg_3d_region_of_interest_min_xF1.0Bounding box, all points outside limit w.r.t. camera's local coordinate frame will be filtered out
obj_reg_3d_region_of_interest_max_xF5.0Bounding box, all points outside limit w.r.t. camera's local coordinate frame will be filtered out
obj_reg_3d_region_of_interest_min_zF0.0Bounding box, all points outside limit w.r.t. camera's local coordinate frame will be filtered out
obj_reg_3d_region_of_interest_max_zF0.6Bounding box, all points outside limit w.r.t. camera's local coordinate frame will be filtered out
obj_reg_3d_intensity_filter_scaleF0.85Points with lower intensity than nominal for distance will be filtered. Larger value is stricter
obj_reg_3d_cluster_tolerance_distF0.096Distance tolerance for clustering two points together
obj_reg_3d_cluster_min_sizeI40Minimum number of points in cluster to be regarded
obj_reg_3d_minimum_model_inlierF0.25Percentage of inliers for accepting a model, the higher the value the stricter
obj_reg_3d_distance_between_pallet_legs[ModelIndex]F0.0Distance between two pallet legs, to minimize false positives. Required for stacked objects. 0.0 -- not used for discrimination
obj_reg_3d_min_rack_beam_widthF1.5The minimum width of a rack beam to be detected. Recommended to be larger than the largest model width or length. 0.0 -- not used
obj_reg_3d_stop_for_target_detection_distF2.0Maximum distance from the object before AGV stops and tries detection on standstill. Distance from AGV:s navigation point to the detected object
obj_reg_3d_target_min_n_times_validated_consecutivelyI2Minimum number of times target must be validated consecutively before giving results
obj_reg_3d_target_max_n_times_measured_while_stoppedI15The maximum detection attempts at standstill until driving closer to target.
obj_reg_3d_max_diff_in_xy_results,F0.03The maximum deviation of the pose in x,y,z between pose estimates to be considered conforming
obj_reg_3d_max_diff_in_angle_results_degF2.5The maximum heading deviation between pose estimates to be considered conforming
obj_reg_3d_empty_space_width_marginF0.1Margin added to the empty space width when creating the bounding box
obj_reg_3d_empty_space_length_marginF0.1Margin added to the empty space length when creating the bounding box
obj_reg_3d_empty_space_height_marginF0.1Margin added to the empty space height when creating the bounding box
obj_reg_3d_empty_space_max_cluster_densityI50Maximum number of allowed measurement points per cubic meter inside empty space
obj_reg_3d_view_blocked_by_load_aboardI0The empty space detection is omitted as the 3D camera is blocked by the load. 0 -- empty space enabled, 1 -- disabled
obj_reg_3d_empty_space_min_material_widthF0.3Minimum solid material width beneath empty space
target_detection_max_dist_to_symbolic_pointF6.0Distance to start detection from symbolic point. Calculated along trajectory
buffer_check_start_dist_offset_mF2.0Distance before buffer area to start detection

How to use

Limitations

  • The height of the object is assumed to be known, the object is assumed to be within starting height obj_reg_3d_region_of_interest_min_z and parameter obj_reg_3d_object_height.
  • The bottom-most object in a cluster is assumed to be the object of interest, if a match is not found from the bottom-most subcluster the feature will evaluate the next cluster (to optimize the search)
  • Parameter obj_reg_3d_distance_between_pallet_legs is used to avoid false positives, it is based on the assumption that the object has 3 legs and between these legs a space between. This allows to differentiate between boxes of similar size and pallets. The matching can be done without the parameter but is then only based on how well the sensor view fits the CAD model, which may be noisy.
  • Stacked objects are assumed to be in similar pose and if the pose deviates too much the algorithm will not be able to find the stacked objects.
  • The load detection tracks the object to some extent and updates, however, if the object is completely removed from the scene the AGV will drive to last estimated pose. The pose is not cleared during docking if it does not see it any longer, as the field-of-view of the sensor is limited, and it may not see the object during docking.

Creating training database of a CAD model

Accessible from Navitrol Monitor, under Navitrol Generate Partial Views from CAD Form - 3D sensor. The scale factor is for transforming the CAD file from millimeters to meters or from inches to meters. The CAD rendering options is for determining how many partial views will be generated. The Normal-option generates 18 partial views that correspond the most likely sensor point clouds. Generating partial views from CAD file is performed offline and takes a while, thus requires that the AGV is in STANDBY mode when uploading to Navitrol. Generating partial views takes a while and is therefore not safe to run in normal operation, as the thread is frozen. The partial views will be generated from the CAD file selected in Browse.

The message from Monitor is logged as
MONITOR STL PACKET -- filename
A pop-up message will appear in Monitor depicting the status of the partial view generation, an example is visualized in the Figure below.

The statuses include:

  • Invalid filename
  • Error occurred during rendering - try again
  • Invalid scale factor
  • Successful

The partial view files (.bin, .idx, .ply, .txt) are parsed at startup and when a new model is generated.

The Figure below visualizes a subset of the generated partial views for a eur-pallet.

3D camera setup

IFM O3D

If the used 3D camera is the IFM O3D303 or O3DP03 the configuration of the camera must be uploaded to the camera. In the IPC write the following commands, by replacing the below IP with the IP of the camera. The configuration file must only be uploaded once for the O3D303 and after each reboot for the O3DP03. Follow the steps below to modify the IFM parameters:

  1. Upload the provided configurationFileIFM script to the IPC.
  2. Give script permission - chmod +x configurationFileIFM
  3. ./configurationFileIFM IP-ADDRESS
  4. Verify that the configuration file was successfully updated from console
DDS

Set parameter dds_pointcloud2_topic_name[] and dds_enabled to 1, and obj_reg_3d_sensor_model[] to 3.

IFM O3R:

The sensor provides Z-buffer data, i.e. Z is by default pointing "forward"

  1. docker load < ifm3d_ros_driver.tar.gz
  2. Run script: ./start_ifm_ros2_driver.sh
  3. cd colcon_ws
  4. source install/setup.bash
  5. cd src/ifm3d-ros2/launch/examples

If the IP address of the VPU has been changed the following modifications need to be performed before launching the script.

  1. apt install nano
  2. nano /home/ifm/colcon_ws/install/ifm3d_ros2/share/ifm3d_ros2/config/examples/o3r_3d.yaml
  3. Modify ip: to the desired IP address
  4. nano /home/ifm/colcon_ws/install/ifm3d_ros2/share/ifm3d_ros2/config/examples/o3r_2d.yaml
  5. Modify ip: to the desired IP address

Launch script: ros2 launch example_o3r_2d_and_3d.launch.py

The topic name is by default rt/ifm3d/camera_3d/cloud for the O3R-driver.

Coordinate frame

The sensor pointcloud is transformed according to the above parameters to obtain the object pose in map coordinates. The translation components x and y are the deviations from the navigation point in the AGV's coordinate frame. The translation z component is defined with respect to the fork centre height or w.r.t. the floor if obj_reg_3d_sensor_height_fixed is set to 1.

The left-most sensor shows the "raw" internal sensor coordinate frame and the right-most the transformed coordinate frame. The below example sensor provides Z-buffer data, which means that "forward" would be Z, instead of X. The detection algorithm assumes an X-buffer, so the sensor's internal rotation must be changed. In the below case the obj_reg_3d_sensor_internal_rotation_roll_deg would be 90 degrees and obj_reg_3d_sensor_internal_rotation_yaw_deg would be -90 degrees.

Sensor's internal rotation

The roll, pitch and yaw angles are defined as the rotation along the x, y and z-axes of the sensor, respectively, as shown in the Figure below. The obj_reg_3d_sensor_external_rotation_yaw_deg angle is defined with respect to the AGV coordinate frame, the external yaw of the 3d sensor in the Figure below would be either 180 or -180 degrees.

The sensor is rendered in Monitor based on parameters: obj_reg_3d_sensor_translation_x, obj_reg_3d_sensor_translation_y and obj_reg_3d_sensor_external_rotation_yaw_deg. The triangle inside the square represents the viewing direction of the sensor, as visualized in the Figure below

Filtering & Clustering

The search space can be minimized, to make processing faster and to avoid possible false positives, via parameters with prefix obj_reg_3d_region_of_interest_. The region of interest is described in the sensor's local coordinate frame.

The intensity is quadratically dependent on the distance to the 3D camera. The intensity of points is also dependent on the material, and the default value is based on wood. The strictness of the intensity filter can be scaled by parameter. The higher the value the more strict the filtering. F, obj_reg_3d_intensity_filter_scale, # Range [0.0, 1.0]

Objects far from the 3D camera may have sparsely distributed points, meaning a small value for obj_reg_3d_cluster_tolerance_dist might not be able to cluster the entire object, and too large values might result in adjacent objects being clustered together.

Detection and pose estimation

The detection is started when

  • AGV is in Auto state
  • AGV heading is within +-45 degrees from the end symbolic point. This takes frame heading into account
  • The distance is ok. This is calculated in two ways:
    • AGV is inside target buffer area + buffer_check_start_dist_offset_m parameter or
    • AGV is within target_detection_max_dist_to_symbolic_point from the end symbolic point

The detection is based on matching the sensor pointcloud to the partial views of several CAD files of different models, until a match returning the smallest error and largest number of inliers is found.

In the case the object of interest has three legs on both the shorter and longer side, such as a eur-pallet, the parameter obj_reg_3d_distance_between_pallet_legs is defined as the distance between the shorter side's legs, for each model. The Figure below depicts the parameter selection for a eur-pallet, for which the value would be 0.35. This minimizes the risk of false positives for solid facades of similar dimensions.

The number of inliers between the CAD partial view and the sensor pointclouds is used for rejecting false-positive estimations, and can be tuned by obj_reg_3d_minimum_model_inlier. The higher the value the smaller the risk of false positive matches, but also the risk of rejecting true positives increases. The inlier fraction is logged in the console after a successful registration as: Object registration - registration successful. Inlier fraction(s):

The obj_reg_3d_minimum_model_inlier can be increased to a higher value if the inlier fraction is noticed to be higher during a successful match. Depending on the quality of the data and the model, the inlier fraction can be between 0.4 to 0.6.

The returned pose is the centre point of the model facade and is computed from the length and width of the model. The acquired pose is transformed to map coordinates and given as x, y, z, heading. An initial docking target is found after obtaining obj_reg_3d_target_min_n_times_validated_consecutively consecutive conforming poses. For more information on docking, see Docking. The pose is continuously updated if the new pose estimates conform with previous estimations. The allowed deviation between poses is determined by parameters obj_reg_3d_max_diff_in_xy_results and obj_reg_3d_max_diff_in_angle_results_deg. The smaller the value the stricter the estimation will be, but may result in false negatives. In case several similar objects are stacked the pose closest to the target actuator height is returned.

The status of the detection is logged with the prefix
Object registration -

The pose of the object is logged as
Object registration pose [map coord] : (x, y, z, h)

Empty space detection

The empty space detection is used for unloading AGVs. The exact unload position is assumed to be known in x, y and heading.

An empty space is defined as a volume of object dimension, plus margins, with less points than a threshold. The maximum number of points allowed within the entire volume is defined by obj_reg_3d_empty_space_min_cluster. The object dimensions are obtained from parameters obj_reg_3d_object_length/width/height.

If obj_reg_3d_view_blocked_by_load_aboard is 1, the empty space will always return true and the AGV will unload blindly to the unload symbolic point, without verifying if an empty space is found.

If the volume is larger than the field of view of the sensor from current distance to the unload point, an error message is logged. An empty space is only valid if there is solid material underneath, width defined by obj_reg_3d_empty_space_min_material_width. This is to prevent empty spaces being found mid-air.

The empty space detection returns a height for which an empty volume that meets the above requirements. The status of the empty space detection is logged with the prefix: Empty space -

The detection is initiated if the symbolic point is unload, there is a load aboard and obj_reg_3d_view_blocked_by_load_aboard is set to 0. The status of the detection initiation can be seen from Empty space status -

Buffer lane detection

Blockstacking, meaning the detection of stacks for loading and unloading, requires buffer lane enabled in Tools and the correct parameter set-up. See document Navitrol - Buffer lanes for more information.

All objects in a stack are assumed to be of same model and in similar orientation.

The detection for loading from a stack is performed by finding the bottom-most object closest to the AGV in the buffer lane, and raising the forks until the top of the stack is found. The top of the stack is found by finding an empty space with less points than obj_reg_3d_empty_space_min_cluster above the current top-most object. After the empty space is found, the AGV will load the top-most object from the stack.See document Navitrol - Stackloading for more information.
The current top-most pallet in the stack is logged as: Object registration - buffer area current top-most pallet (x,y,z,h)

Unloading to a buffer stack is done by detecting the bottom-most object and increasing until finding a height where there is less points than obj_reg_3d_empty_space_min_cluster. If the bottom-most object is not found in the stack or stacking is not allowed, the AGV will unload in front of the obstacle in the buffer lane, based on the closest point in the obstacle. The closest obstacle in the buffer lane, in map coordinates, can be seen in the log as Buffer lane obstacle closest position (x, y). See document Navitrol - Blockstacking for more information.

Stopping while executing 3d object registration

During 3D object registration it is possible to stop the AGV and give more time for the feature to detect the target. Stopping will occur when the AGV is closer than obj_reg_3d_stop_for_target_detection_dist distance to unrecognized object or a cluster. Stopping will not occur if object is validated and detected correctly already further away.

Workflow for the detection sequence while being stopped is the following:

  1. Stop the AGV when object is obj_reg_3d_stop_for_target_detection_dist distance away from the AGV
  2. Detect and validate the target obj_reg_3d_target_min_n_times_validated_consecutively times in a row
  3. After obj_reg_3d_target_max_n_times_measured_while_stopped detection attempts, continue moving towards the target again
  4. If detection successful, start docking

Troubleshooting

Partial views

Invalid scale factor of partial view

  • The dimension of the partial view is incorrect. Verify that the scale factor for the CAD file is correct

Upload to Navitrol causes Navitrol to crash and lose connection to AGV. The following line is logged in the console

  • vtkXOpenGLRenderWindow (0x7f5c3c01f0c0): bad X server connection. DISPLAY=:99. Aborting. -- Verify that Xvfb is installed from which Xvfb. If not, apt-get install xvfb. Otherwise, try restarting the virtual screen manually by Xvfb :99 -screen 0 1024x768x24 \> /dev/null 2\>&1 &

Invalid filename of partial view

  • Verify that the Monitor package, logged as MONITOR STL PACKET -- filename has been received and parsed correctly and that the filename matches the CAD file name excluding the file extension (.stl), and that the provided .stl file is not corrupted and has more than 4 points

Load detection 3d form

Load detection 3d form

A green color indicates the requirements are met, red means they are not.

AGV distance within detection range

  • The AGV's distance to the symbolic point along trajectory is more than target_detection_max_dist_to_symbolic_point.

AGV heading within detection range

  • The AGV's heading is more than +-45 degrees from the symbolic point heading.

Symbolic point has load detection enabled

  • Enable load detection in Navithor Tools for the symbolic point.

Partial views ok

  • The model name in parameter obj_reg_3d_model_name[] is not correct or no CAD file (.stl) has been uploaded via the Generate partial views from CAD form - 3D sensor.

Load detection status

  • "Region of interest too small for model" - The parameters obj_reg_3d_region_of_interest_min/max_z are too strict. Check the validity of parameters obj_reg_3d_region_of_interest_min/max_z and/or obj_reg_3d_object_height.

  • "Intensity filter failed" - Parameter value obj_reg_3d_intensity_filter_scale_factor is too high and no points have intensity above threshold.

  • "Passthrough filter (x, y) failed" - Verify that parameters obj_reg_3d_sensor_translation_x/y and obj_reg_3d_region_of_interest_min/max_x are valid.

  • "Passthrough filter z failed" - Verify obj_reg_3d_sensor_translation_z and obj_reg_3d_sensor_rotation_pitch_deg, or all obj_reg_3d_sensor_rotation-prefixed parameters if sensor provides Z-buffer pointcloud.

  • "Euclidean segmentation failed" - The parameter obj_reg_3d_cluster_min_size is too high or obj_reg_3d_cluster_tolerance_dist is too small.

  • "No match found - model file corrupted" - Reupload the partial views for CAD file(s). The log line with prefix "2.5D rendered model" will inform the index of the corrupted model file.

  • "No match found - model not found" - A model giving a larger inlier fraction than obj_reg_3d_minimum_model_inlier is not found, or a subcluster of model height with more points than obj_reg_3d_cluster_min_size is not found.

  • "No match found - fitness value too high" - The error of the fine tuned pose is too high.

  • "No match found - pose invalid" - The computed pose doesn't have any neighbouring points in the sensor pointcloud.

  • "No match found - pocket detection failed" - Pockets have not been detected for the model, defined based on: obj_reg_3d_distance_between_pallet_legs

  • "Detection ok" - The detection was successful, a pose estimate was obtained.

Target found

  • Two consecutive pose estimates deviating less than obj_reg_3d_max_diff_in_xy_results and obj_reg_3d_max_diff_in_angle_results_deg has not been obtained.

The dimensions of the load are ok

  • An object has been loaded

Empty space detection status

  • "The sensor field of views are smaller than the object or object is not in the sensor field of view." - Based on the current distance to query point, the sensor transformation and parameters obj_reg_3d_sensor_fov_vertical_deg and obj_reg_3d_sensor_fov_horizontal_deg.

  • "The empty space was found on floor level" - An empty space around the query point on floor level was found. No solid material required to be seen.

  • "The empty space detection failed - space occupied." - The empty space around the query points has more points than obj_reg_3d_empty_space_max_cluster_density multiplied by the volume of the empty space (length * width * height) with margins.

  • "The empty space detection failed - no rack found." - No solid material of minimum width obj_reg_3d_empty_space_min_material_width found below the empty space, the empty space is invalidated.

  • "The empty space was found" - The empty space was found around the query point. Unloading will commence.

The unload query point in map coordinates (x, y, z, h)

  • The centre point (x, y) of the volume used for empty space detection

The dimensions of the load, incl. margins (L, W, H)

  • The length, width and height of the volume and margins, obj_reg_3d_empty_space_length_margin, obj_reg_3d_empty_space_width_margin, and obj_reg_3d_empty_space_height_margin, used for empty space detection.

Errors and warnings

562 - ERROR_3D_PARTIAL_VIEWS_INVALID

  • The partial views for 3d detection are invalid and parsing was unsuccessful. Verify that the obj_reg_3d_model_name corresponds to the name of the CAD file and that the files exist in /home/navitec/ and /home/navitec/poses/ and are not corrupted.

563 - ERROR_3D_PREREQUISITES_NOT_FOUND

  • The required 3rd party libraries could not be found. Verify that all the packages in the dependencies.7z have been installed.

665 - WARNING_3D_SENSOR_DATA_NOT_RECEIVED

  • A sensor pointcloud is not received, verify network settings and ip address. Check obj_reg_3d_sensor_model and obj_reg_3d_sensor_ip or dds_pointcloud2_topic_name

Advanced troubleshooting

Pointcloud logs

  • If pointcloud logging is enabled, pointclouds will be saved to /home/navitec/pointcloud_logs/ folder. The pointcloud logs are saved as pointcloud_error_log_n.ply. The newest file is the 0th, and the oldest logs are deleted after reaching obj_reg_3d_number_of_pointcloud_logs. The pointclouds are saved to .ply format and can be viewed in e.g. Meshlab, which is a free software.
  • The Navitrol timestamp of the pointcloud is visible as a comment in the .ply file, the files are written in ASCII format. The width of the pointcloud is also written as a comment to the .ply file.

Unsuccessful parsing of partial views

  • In the log there is visible the following line: Could not open file:. The number of partial views parsed can be deduced from log lines Could not open file: ./poses/modelname_poses_3.txt for reading
    Could not open file: ./poses/modelname_cluster_3.ply for reading.
    In the above example only 3 partial views were parsed for modelname. If the number is 0 for either .txt or .ply, no file matching the filename could be found in the required folder. To check for file corruption search in the log for prefix Partial view parsing -

Pattern Detection

Updated 04.06.2024

Pattern detection versions

This document describes the interface between Navitrol and an AGV controller in the special application of reflector target detection. It is designed for measuring the position and angle of a target marked with reflectors or the relative position between two AGVs. The measuring is based on reflectors mounted in a known configuration on a station, carrier or AGV, which are detected with one or two scanners on the controlled AGV.

The measuring is based on reflectors mounted in a known configuration on a station, carrier or AGV, which are detected with one or two scanners on the controlled AGV. The position, angle and height of the marked target can be used for docking to stations or another AGV, picking an object or driving AGV's in synchronized motion (coupled drive).

Version 1 of the system is using two or preferably four reflectors on the target and one scanner on the measuring AGV. It assumes full visibility between the AGV and the target at all times, i.e. all target reflectors need to be detected every time. If the line of sight is broken the measurement is not giving any result.

The reflectors are positioned in a simple pattern defined by two distances A and B. The reflectors also must have a defined width Rw.

Version 2 of the target detection is based on a more complex reflector pattern enabling detection also when only a part of the reflectors are detected. In this version up to 8 reflectors can be used. All reflectors must have the same width Rw and the distances between all reflectors must differ from each other with at least 70 mm. A pattern example is shown below.

Version 2 also supports detection with two scanners. In case the line of sight is obstructed, each scanner can give a separate result if at least 3 reflectors are detected, but the detections can also be combined from both scanners to give a common solution.

Version 3 of the target detection is a combination of pattern detection for position determination with an addition of one angled reflector used for height detection. The angled reflector is added into the middle of the pattern of vertical reflectors to form a gap between two opposite triangles. Due to the angle, this reflector is detected in a different location relative to the vertical reflectors depending on the height position of the laser field. Since there are two different measurements within one pattern, all reflectors need to be detected every time, else the detection is undefined. The pattern is shown below.

As in the other detection versions, the distances A,B,C,.. between reflectors and their widths Rw must be defined. The distances between vertical reflectors may differ from each other, but the angled reflector must be symmetrically positioned between its neighbouring vertical reflectors. Also, the width of the angled reflector shall be calculated to give a similar detection width as the vertical reflectors, and therefore it must be somewhat narrower. Define its widt by calculating Rwa = Rw*cos(ang) where ang is its angle CCW from vertical. The height of the reflectors must also be defined as it defines the available height detection range.

The height detection requires some additional scanner position and reflector position parameters in order to give a defined position from ground or relative position to a moving target with variable height. In case of a fixed target with constant height, the height of the vehicle reference point (in this case the platform height) is defined as in the figure below:

If the target is another vehicle with variable height, the parameters can be defined as in the figure below. By giving a negative height for the Pattern offset (Platform down to pattern base), the offset calculation results in the height difference between the reference levels on the machines (in this case the platform surfaces). Adding half the Range to the Pattern offset moves the zero point to the middle of the reflector target, giving a +/- value range to the height difference.

If both Pattern offset and Scanner offset are set to zero, the raw Height detection value is reported and can be used as a relative measurement without binding to the platform dimensions.

Parameters

General parameters

NameTypeDefault value (suggestion for v2)Description
target_detection_type_selectionI0 (1)Enables reflector docking or pallet detection 0 = disabled 1 = reflector docking 2 = pallet detection
target_detection_always_enabledI00 = detect target only when docking 1 = enables target detection algorithm always (AGV to AGV positioning)
target_detection_scan_selectionI0 (any selection except for 3)Defines which scanners are used for target detection:
1 = rear scanner only
2 = front scanner only
3 = both scanners simultaneously
4 = use scanner in driving direction
5 = both scanners alternately (only version 2 reflector detection) Note! selection 3 does not work with V2 and V3 detection.
target_detection_results_dampeningF0.3Dampening value for the results; min = 0, max = 1
target_detection_max_diff_in_xy_resultsF0.2How big difference is allowed in xy-location (metres) before the new result is updated without dampening
target_detection_max_diff_in_angle_resultsF5.0How big difference is allowed in angle (degrees) before the new result is updated without dampening
target_min_n_times_detectedI20Minimum number of times target must be detected before giving results
target_max_n_times_missingI300Max number of times the last known target location is given if no target is detected; min = 0

Reflector detection parameters

NameTypeDefault value (version note)Description
refl_det_versionI01 - reflector detection ver 1
2 - reflector pattern for ver 2
3 - reflector pattern with height detection
refl_det_refl_widthF0.15Width of the reflectors used for docking purposes (in metres)
refl_det_refl_dist_AF0.55 (ver 1 only)The distance between the reflectors in the middle (in metres, from centre point to centre point) (in metres)
refl_det_refl_dist_BF0.65 (ver 1 only)The distance between the reflectors on the sides (not used with 2 refs, with 4 refs left and right pair) (in metres)
refl_det_num_of_reflectorsI4 (ver 1 only)Number of reflectors used for detection.
Version 1: 2 or 4
Version 2: not needed
Version 3: not needed
refl_det_refl_dist_pattern[7]F0.0 (ver 2, 3)max 7 distance values (m) for max eight reflectors. The distance is measured from center to center of the reflectors. The parameters should contain distances from leftmost [0] to rightmost [6] (the first zero distance cuts the pattern). The distances on each side of the angled height reflector are equal and half of the distance between the neighbouring vertical refelectors.
refl_det_refl_dist_max_errorF0.06Maximum allowed error for the distance between reflectors (in metres)
refl_det_refl_width_max_errorF0.05Maximum allowed error for the width of the reflector (in metres)
refl_max_dist_from_lineF0.1 (ver 2, 3)Maximum deviation from reflector line for discarding a reflector detection from the reflector pattern
refl_discard_undersizedI0 (ver 2, 3)1 to discard undersized reflector detections from the reflector pattern
scanner_heading_offset_gainF0.02 (ver 2 only)Heading auto correction gain for right scanner when using two scanners for reflector pattern detection
scanner_pos_x_offset_gainF0.02 (ver 2 only)Scanner x-position auto correction gain for right scanner when using two scanners for reflector pattern detection
scanner_pos_y_offset_gainF0.02 (ver 2 only)Scanner y-position auto correction gain for right scanner when using two scanners for reflector pattern detection
refl_det_min_points_in_clusterI5Minimum number of measurement points in reflector clusters, recommended value 5

Reflector detection height parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
refl_height_detection_gap_reflector_angle_degF45.0The angle of the gap reflector CCW from vertical
refl_height_detection_gap_reflector_widthF0.05The width Rw [m] of the vertical reflectors and the gap angle ang from vertical, gives the gap reflector width Rwa = Rw * cos(ang)
refl_height_detection_gap_reflector_indexI2Index of the gap reflector in the reflector pattern (indexes start with 0)
refl_height_detection_reflector_heightF0.4The height of the vertical reflectors and the vertical height of the gap angle reflector. Gives the range of use in height detection. The height detection zero point is in the low end of the reflectors.
refl_height_detection_pattern_height_offsetF0.0The height offset between the low end of the reflector pattern and the ground for fixed objects or a reference plane on a vehicle. Positive distance when pattern above the reference level, else negative.
refl_height_detection_scanner_height_offsetF0.0The height offset between the scanner and the reference plane on the vehicle. Positive if the scanner is above the reference plane.
target_detection_height_result_dampeningF0.3Low pass filtering gain to dampen the variation of the output value of the target height detection: minimum = 0 (using old value), maximum = 1 (using new value).
target_detection_max_diff_in_height_resultsF0.15How much difference [m] is allowed in height before the new result is updated without dampening.

General parameters to Calibrate

See initial calibration guide on how to configure scanners correctly.

Calibrating the continuous output version 2 system

Manual calibration of the scanner positions and headings so that both units give the same result from the same reflector target is very difficult. Therefore the target detection calculation has an automatic calibration function, which is continuously calculating offsets between the results of the scanners.
