Machine types: Vehicles with PLC checking the safety scanners

Error reason: PLC reports safety stop

How to recover: Remove the obstacles from the scanner view either by moving them or vehicle

909 WARNING_PLC_SOFT_STOP

Description: Soft stop activated on PLC

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Vehicles with PLC

Error reason: PLC reports soft stop

How to recover: Check the soft stop reason from PLC

910 WARNING_PLC_SLOW_DOWN

Description: PLC slowing down due to obstacle

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Vehicles with PLC

Error reason: PLC reports slow down

How to recover: Recovers automatically when obstacle is not visible anymore

911 WARNING_DEAD_RECK_HIGH_RATE

Description: excessive movement rate detected

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Vehicles with PLC

Error reason: PLC reports too fast movement

How to recover: Take a log and contact Navitec

912 WARNING_ETH_MANUAL_MODE

Description: AGV on manual mode

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Vehicles with Ethernet interface

Error reason: AGV controller reports that vehicle is in manual mode

How to recover: Switch to automatic mode

913 WARNING_AGV_EM_STOP

Description: Emergency stop on AGV

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason: AGV is in emergency stop

How to recover: Release emergency stop on AGV

914 WARNING_AGV_CONTROLLER

Description: AGV controller warning

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason: AGV controller reports warning

How to recover: Check the controller for the reason

915 WARNING_DYN_MAP_SERVER_NOT_CONNECTED

Description: No connection to dynamic mapping server

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason: Navitrol cannot connect to dynamic mapping server

How to recover: Check that dynamic map server is running. Take a log and contact Navitec.

916 WARNING_DYN_MAP_SERVER_MAP_MISMATCH

Description: Dynamic mapping server map doesn't match Navitrol map

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason: Dynamic mapping server noticed that Navitrol map is not matching the version on dynamic mapping

How to recover: Recovers automatically

917 WARNING_DYN_MAP_SERVER_STORAGE_ERROR

Description: Dynamic mapping server storage read/write error

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason: Dynamic mapping server reported error

How to recover: Contact Navitec

918 WARNING_RLS_SENSOR

Description: RLS sensor warning

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Vehicles with RLS sensor

Error reason: RLS sensor reports warning

How to recover: Fix the sensor

919 WARNING_NO_SUPERVISOR_COMS

Description: No communication to Supervisor

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason: No communication to supervisor

How to recover: Make sure that supervisor is connected to Navitrol, Take a log and contact Navitec

920 WARNING_UI_PARSING_ERROR

Description: UI data parsing failed

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason: UI does not match with Navitrol

How to recover: Take a log and contact Navitec

921 WARNING_EXT_BATTERY

See feature documentation for Charge and Battery management.

922 WARNING_PLC

Description: PLC Warning received

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason:

How to recover:

923 WARNING_CAN2_FAILURE

Description: CAN secondary bus, hw or driver error

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason: Error reasons and things to check are identical to those described in case of error 709 ERROR_CAN_FAILURE

How to recover:

924 WARNING_IMU_FAILURE

Description: IMU (Inertial Measurement Unit) error or no connection

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason: Wrong parameters, connection lost, IMU HW error

How to recover: Check the IMU connection and related parameters (imu_type, imu_serial_port, imu_id).

925 WARNING_NO_SUPERVISOR_SEC_COMS

Description: Secondary supervisor is not connected and cannot communicate with Navitrol.

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason: No communication to supervisor

How to recover: Make sure that supervisor is connected to Navitrol, that the ip and the port are correct and the parameters are set correctly. If not possible to resolve, Take a log and contact Navitec

926 WARNING_FSTOP_FLEET_CONTROL

Description: AGV stopped by Fleet control

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason:

How to recover: Release FSTOP from Fleet control

927 WARNING_DRIVE_MOTOR_CONTROL_LIMIT

Description: Motor controller operation - acceleration/deceleration/speed is limited

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason: Motor controller specific

How to recover: Motor controller specific -- if you don't know what is the reason behind, take a log and contact Navitec.

928 WARNING_ETHERNET_FEEDBACK_EXCEEDING_LIMIT

Description: A warning is displayed if speed or angle feedback values exceed limits with 5-20% in the Ethernet control interface. In auto mode 20% causes an error, but in manual mode any value is a warning.

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Ethernet controlled vehicles

Error reason: In auto mode, the speed/angle sensor calibration or control action should be checked. In manual mode some values may be intentionally exceed on the users' responsibility.

How to recover: verify calibrations and whether the limits may be safely exceeded. Limit control.

929 WARNING_SLOWED_DOWN_ULTRASONIC_SENSORS

Description: A warning is displayed, if AGV is slowing down, because of ultrasonic sensors are reporting that something is too close to the AGV.

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles using ultrasonic sensors, that are communicating with Navitrol

Error reason: Slow down triggered by ultrasonic sensors

How to recover: If ultrasonic sensors are reporting false positive, they might need to be physically adjusted. Navitrol array parameters uss_sensor_zone3_dist_slow and uss_sensor_zone3_dist_fast decide, what is the maximum distance to trigger the slowdown. Ask Navitec for more details, if necessary.

931 WARNING_OMNI_STEER_LIMIT_ADJUSTING_WHEELS

Description: A warning is displayed, when omni steer limit feature is enabled and at least one of the omni wheels has reached the defined steer limit. The AGV will perform soft stop and rotate the wheel until it is in the middle area of the defined angle range. When the adjusting is done the warning will be removed automatically.

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Those omni drives where Navitrol have control over every limited omni wheel.

Error reason: Defined omni steer limit reached.

How to recover: Navitrol will automatically reset the error when the wheel adjustment is ready. If the warning stays on and the Navitrol is not controlling the wheels anymore please take a log and contact Navitec.

932 WARNING_LIMITED_STEERING_ACTIVE

Description: The warning is displayed, when steer limit feature is enabled and at least one of the limited wheels has reached the defined steer limit.

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Steer and omni drives with defined steering limits

Error reason: Defined steer limit reached.

How to recover: The warning is automatically reset when the references are back within the limits. This can be done for example giving straight drive order.

933 WARNING_CONFLICTING_MOTOR_CONTROLLER_TYPES

Description: Feedback sensor type defined by parameter conflicts with the one coming from the controller.

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Any vehicle communicating with Roboteq motor controller via CAN bus.

Error reason: Wrong or missing script in Roboteq controller. Note: Prior to Navitrol 6.44 this warning can be unavoidable if several Roboteq controllers with different feedback sensor types are used.

How to recover: Check that Roboteq script is latest available. Check that sensor type parameter roboteq_angle_sensor_type has right value. In Navitrol 6.44 or later, parameter array roboteq_angle_sensor_type_arr is available if multiple controllers with different feedback sensor types are used. If problem is not solved, take a log and contact Navitec.

934 WARNING_NO_GPS_FIX

Description: The long since the last GPS fix, driving without it.

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All

Error reason: GPS receiver is not providing data that is "RTK fixed".

How to recover: Check that the antennas have a clear view of the sky, there is no interference such as metal objects nearby. Make sure that the base station is connected properly. Check that auxiliary antenna is also receiving good signal quality.

935 WARNING_CAN_ENCODER

Description: This warning is displayed when CAN encoder has some issues with initialization by Navigation SW.

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Can vehicles

Error reason: There are some problems either with encoder parameters or with the CAN bus.

How to recover: Check the CAN bus, contact Navitec.

937 WARNING_OBST_AV_V2_PATH_REJECTED_DUE_FRAME_HEADING

See feature documentation for Obstacle avoidance V2

938 WARNING_UNABLE_TO_BYPASS_OBSTACLE

See feature documentation for Obstacle avoidance V2

941 WARNING_CODE_READER_NO_COMMS

Description: Optical code reader communication is not working

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All

Error reason: There are problems with code reader communication parameters, IPC Ethernet settings or connection to the code reader.

How to recover: Check the connections, IPC and reader IP settings and related Navigation SW parameters.

942 WARNING_CODE_READER_STATUS_NOT_OK

Description: Optical code reader reports an issue.

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All

Error reason: There are some problems with code reader.

How to recover: Refer to device specific documentation or contact Navitec support.

943 WARNING_NO_PROFINET_COMMS

Description: No communication to Profinet Supervisor. Error level: Warning Machine types: All Error reason & How to recover: See 850 ERROR_PROFINET_CONFIG

944 WARNING_TEST_VERSION

Description: Test version in use. NOT FOR USE IN PRODUCTION. Error level: Warning Machine types: All Error reason: Test version in use (Navitrol .99 version installed) How to recover: Install a non-test version and restart Navitrol

945 WARNING_INITIALIZING_3D_POSITION

Description: 3D position initialization is currently in progress.

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Any

Error reason: 3D position system tries actively to find a valid 3D pose for the AGV.

How to recover: If the 3D position initialization process appears to take too long (over 15 seconds), try setting initial pose again. Error ERROR_3D_POSITION_NOT_INITIALIZED is always active along this warning.

946 WARNING_3D_POSITIONING

Description: The 3D positioning software is having an active warning.

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Any

Error reason: The 3D positioning software is having an active warning.

How to recover: A device error will occur, providing a more detailed error explanation. If the issue persists, take a log and contact Navitec.

User Guide Logging

Updated 18.07.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
NavitrolLinux program for navigation and positioning of an AGV
Navitrol MonitorWindows program for observing and controlling a single Navitrol
Navithor ServerWindows program for automatically controlling a fleet of AGVs
Navithor ClientWindows program to observe and command a fleet of AGVs
Text logA log file ending with ".txt", these can be read by humans
Binary logA log file ending with ".gz". These can be opened in Navitrol Monitor for visual playback
"The log folder"Folder on the IPC running Navitrol where the logs are stored. By default: "/home/navitec/logs"
Supervisor interfaceEthernet communication interface between Navitrol and supervisor -- typically a PLC.

Overview

What is a log?

A Navitrol log is a file containing the history of most important data processed by Navitrol.

The purpose of a log is to store data so that possible issues can be easily located and solved.

Typically, logs are taken by the user when a problem is detected and sent to Navitec for further inspection to locate and solve the problem. However, advanced users can utilize the logs by themselves to solve simple problems.

What data a log contains?

With default settings a log contains around one minute's worth of history data -- the oldest data is constantly overwritten.

Logged data can be adjusted with Navitrol parameters, see section How to adjust logging -- parameters

Examples of data logged by Navitrol:

  • Position of the AGV

  • Inputs from and outputs to connected devices and software, such as

    • Scanners

    • Motor controllers and encoders

    • Supervisor / PLC

    • Fleet control

  • The state of Navitrol and its threads

  • Errors and warnings

Where are the logs stored?

By default, the logs are stored into "/home/navitec/logs"-folder of the IPC that is running Navitrol.

File system of the IPC can be accessed from Windows with programs, such as Samba or WinSCP, see section How to retrieve a log from the IPC.

The logs can also be downloaded when taking them using Navitrol Monitor or Navithor Client.

Log types

An overview to log types is given in this section. For instructions on how to a take log, see section.

There are two main log types: text logs and binary logs.

Text logs

There are three different types of text logs:

  • Basic Log

  • Start Log

Basic log - log.txt

A text log contains the basic runtime data as described in section What data a log contains?.

It is used in problem solving to see minor details about inner functions of Navitrol.

The data is readable by humans -- written in English.

The text log file names end with ".txt" and can be opened with any text editor, such as notepad++.

"log.txt" is included in most binary log packages excluding Continuous and Monitor's visual logs. Optionally it can be taken separately using Linux console commands.

Start log -- startlog.txt

A start log contains the same data as the basic log but is saved automatically to the log folder on the IPC after 5 seconds of Navitrol start.

A start log can be used to identify start up issues, such as invalid parameters in parameter file, and to see initialization data.

It is always named "startlog.txt" and previous start log will be overwritten when the program is started again.

Long log -- longlog.txt

A text log containing only data logged as high priority, such as position of an AGV and active errors. The log covers a longer period of time compared to the basic log but is much less detailed.

A long log can be used to see issues over long period of time. However, in most cases it does not contain enough details to solve those issues. Long logs are named "longlogXX.txt" where XX is running number: 01, 02.....

Binary logs

Navitrol binary logs contain data that go through the positioning and navigation, including laser scanner measurements and the environment (also known as map).

They can be used to see an overview of problematic situation, such as an area with low position confidence.

Binary logs are in binary format which means that they can be opened with Navitrol Monitor for a log playback by dragging and dropping a zipped file into Monitor window.

Zipped binary log file names end with ".gz".

Naming

  • Log name explained

    • log_<type><number/index>_<year.month.day>_<hour.minute.second>_<AGV position x coordinate>_<AGV position y coordinate>_<Navitrol version>.gz

    • Note that AGV position coordinates are only added when they are available.

  • Examples

    • log_remote_mon0091_2020.10.15_13.36.36_1.0_6.0_6.29.45.gz

    • log_con0075_2020.10.13_09.14.55_6.29.43.gz

    • log_cont_2020.10.21_10.51.22_192.168.56.101_-2,9_6,0.gz

Note: Binary logs are zipped packages that contain basic log and start log text logs. The text logs can be extracted by unzipping the ".gz"-file twice.

Monitor log -- log_remote_mon

A binary log taken using Navitrol Monitor.

Example:

log_remote_mon0091_2020.10.15_13.36.36_1.0_6.0_6.29.45.gz

Console log -- log_con/log_cons

A binary log taken using Linux console commands.

Example:

log_con0075_2020.10.13_09.14.55_6.29.43.gz (Navitrol version < 6.34)

log_cons0075_2020.10.13_09.14.55_6.29.43.gz (Navitrol versions 6.34 and later)

External log - log_ext

A binary log taken using external command, such as Supervisor interface

To adjust see the related parameters.

Example:

log_ext0001_2020.10.15_17.36.02_1.0_6.0_6.29.45.gz

Error log -- log_err

A binary log is taken automatically when an error is activated.

By default, only predefined errors are logged automatically. However, automatic logging for other general errors can be enabled with parameters.

Error logs are stored to separate error log folders under the log folder.

To adjust see the related parameters.

Example:

log_err_401_ERROR_VEH_INTE_HIGH_DT_1143_2020.10.15_11.56.29_-2.7_6.0_6.29.45.gz

Continuous / Long visual log -- log_cont

Continuous logs can be taken with Navitrol Monitor and depending on the selection they are saved either to Navitrol PC or to PC running the Navitrol Monitor application (see section Advanced Monitor logging).

Continuous logging to PC running Navitrol Monitor must be separately started from "Save and download logs"-window of Navitrol Monitor.

These logs can be activated to capture problems that happen rarely, and user cannot react in time to take a regular log that includes the incident.

To adjust logs saved to Navitrol PC, see the related parameters.

Note: does not include text logs.

Example:

log_cont_2020.10.21_10.51.22_192.168.56.101_-2,9_6,0.gz

Monitor's visual log -- log_monitor

This log can be saved with Navitrol Monitor and contains the currently saved binary log data in Navitrol Monitor's memory that can be played back (see more in section Advanced Monitor logging).

Hence, this log can be saved even if the connection to the AGV is lost.

Note: does not include text logs.

Example:

log_monitor0001_2023.10.20_15.05.08.47_6.49.02.gz

Thread monitor log -- log_mon

A binary log taken in case of an automatic restart.

Thread monitor is a part of Navitrol that restarts Navitrol in case of an unexpected shutdown.

To adjust see the related parameters.

Example:

log_mon0037_2020.05.14_12.39.47_0.0_0.0_6.27.25.gz

FSTOP log -- log_fstop

A binary log automatically taken in case of state change triggered to FSTOP for any reason.

This feature can be enabled with the parameter log_dump_on_fstop_max_files (max number of logs stored; defaults to 0).

Example:

log_fstop0007_2020.05.14_12.39.47_0.0_0.0_6.27.25.gz

FSTOP on ESTOP log -- log_estop

A binary log automatically taken in case of state change triggered to FSTOP on ESTOP.

This feature can be enabled with the parameter log_dump_on_estop_max_files (max number of logs stored; defaults to 0). If FSTOP logging using parameter log_dump_on_fstop_max_files is enabled then this log is not stored.

Also parameter pc_fstop_on_estop should be set (defaults to 1).

Example:

log_estop0007_2020.05.14_12.39.47_0.0_0.0_6.27.25.gz

Other

Navigation log -- navigationlog.txt

A separate text log named "navigationlog.txt" containing only times and related positions.

Compatible only with "positioning only"-AGVs. (Navitrol does not control the AGV).

Can be enabled with the parameter log_to_navigationlog Misc parameters.

Battery log -- battery_log.txt

A separate text log named "battery_log.txt" containing only battery related information.

It can be enabled and adjusted with parameters.

Core dump -- core

A separate log named "core" that can be included in the zipped Thread monitor log. If you encounter this log type, please forward it to the Navitec support.

How to take a log

Navitrol Monitor

Step by step instructions

  1. Start Navitrol Monitor by running NavitrolMonitor.exe

  1. Log in by entering the password (default: ntnavitec)

  2. Connect to Navitrol running on the AGV

  • Select an AGV and IP from the dropdown list in top left corner.
    • If the dropdown list is empty. Click "Edit"-button next to it and add new machine name and IP-address.
  • Click "Connect"-button
  1. Click "Save Logs"-button to open "Save and download logs"-window.

  1. Take a log by pressing "Save Log" button.

  1. Wait for the "Download Log Files" view and "Last saved: " text to be updated.

The log is now saved to the IPC and it can be downloaded using the "Download" button.

Advanced Navitrol Monitor logging

For advanced options click the "Advanced" field.

This expands the view of the form for additional logging options.

  1. Additional logs
    • Tick the checkbox for saving long visual logs (only binary) in Navitrol PC. When taking the logs with "Save log" button, log_cont*.gz logs (one or more) will be saved along with the regular log_remote_mon*.gz log. This can be useful when the log could not be saved immediately after the incident.
    • Tick the checkbox for saving Monitor's visual logs (only binary) in the PC running the Navitrol Monitor application. Click the "Browse.." button before saving the log with the "Save log" button to determine the location to store the log_monitor*.gz log. This log can be saved even if the connection to the AGV is already lost.
  2. Continuous logs
    • Tick the checkbox for saving continuosly long visual logs (only binary) to a folder the user can define clicking the "Browse.." button. This can be useful when the issue happens rarely. Remember to untick the checkbox before trying to playback the log_cont*.gz logs. Note also that Navitrol Monitor needs to be all the time connected to the AGV for saving the logs continuously.
  3. SSH Credentials
    • Click the "SSH Credentials.." button to determine the username and password for Navitrol PC connection. The credentials are needed for downloading / deleting the logs from the Navitrol PC.

Linux console

Instructions:

  1. Open Linux console on the AGV running Navitrol -Usually done using PuTTY connection - Default user: "root" and password: "navitrol"

    • Another option is to directly connect a screen and keyboard to the IPC

  2. Select log type to dump

  • Binary log
    • Log command: ./Navitrol dump
  • Text log
    • Log command: ./Navitrol dumpf

  1. Type the log command of selected log type and press enter

    • See previous step for available commands.
    • Example:

  2. Wait for the line telling that logging is finished.

The log is now saved to the IPC and can be downloaded using the "Download" button

Advanced console logging:

It is possible to filter the data written to the log file and filter and print log lines to the console while Navitrol is running. For further instructions, see section Advanced logging.

Supervisor interface

If supervisor interface is used, external-log---log_ext can be taken by sending message 1007. See "Ethernet Communication specification between Navitrol and AGV supervisor_v4.docx"-doument for details.

Navithor client

When taking a log with Navitrol client it is possible to include binary logs (monitor-log-log_remote_mon) from individual AGVs. Further instructions can be found from Navithor documents.

Basic steps:

  1. Open Navithor client

  2. Click "Save logs"-button on lower left corner to open "Log saver"-window.

  1. Select the AGV (or AGVs) from upper left section. (Navitrol logs are included only for selected AGVs)

  1. Click "Save the log files"-button in the bottom of the window.

  2. Wait for pop-up window informing that saving the log was successful. The log is now saved to the Windows system into the folder shown in the pop up window.

Note: By default, the log is saved to the Navithor Server's folder, but the pop-up window gives an option to download the files to the computer running Navithor client. See document "Navithor System - overview and Client user instructions " for further details.

Automatic logging

Log typeMore information
Start logSee Start log -- startlog.txt
Error logSee Error log -- log_err
FSTOPSee FSTOP log -- log_fstop
FSTOP on ESTOPSee FSTOP on ESTOP log -- log_estop
Thread monitor logSee Thread monitor log -- log_mon
Core dumpSee Core dump -- core

How to retrieve a log from the IPC

The log files can be retrieved from the IPC running Navitrol in multiple different ways. This section describes the most common ones.

WinSCP

  1. Open WinSCP
  2. Connect to the AGV
  3. Navigate to the log folder
  4. Copy or move the files where wanted

Navitrol Monitor

  1. Open the "Save and download logs"-window from the Navitrol Monitor clicking "Save Logs" button.

  2. Click the "Refresh"-button located in lower left corner.

  1. Select the logs you want to download and click the "Download"-button

  1. Select the file location by following the instructions of the opened pop-up window.

File explorer / samba

  1. Open Windows file explorer
  2. Type the AGVs IP to the top bar: <IP>/home/Navitec
  3. Copy or move the files where wanted

Note: Some Windows settings and versions may prevent remote access using this method.

How to read a log

Reading a text log

A text log can be opened with text editors, such as notepad++.

What you can do with a text log:

  1. See the main operations and diagnostics of the AGV over a longer period of time (compared to binary logs)
  2. See XY coordinates and heading value
  3. See Received and performed drive orders
  4. See errors and warnings that are active or have been set / reset
  5. Analyze and troubleshoot low level information, such as:
  • Received and sent data values between Navitrol and other systems or sensors
  • Communication intervals
  • Values and information from active Navitrol features and functions

Structure of the text log -- Start of the file:

  1. When the log was taken
    • Date and time
  2. Navitrol build information
    • Navitrol version
    • Build time
    • Machine type
  3. Kernel version
  4. Enabled license options
  5. Parameters from the params.txt
    • Data type, name, value # comment
  6. Parameters from the memory (not in the image)
    • Located just after "Parameters from the params.txt"-section

Structure of the text log -- A log line:

  1. "Time"
    • Counted from the start of Navitrol
  2. "Thread : level"
    • Thread
      • From which thread the log line is coming from
      • See List of log threads
    • Level
      • Priority of the information
      • The smaller the number the higher the priority
  3. "Logged data"
    • Typically starts with a description and ends with a list of values

Binary log playback

Binary logs can be played back using Navitrol Monitor.

Note: Versions of Navitrol and Navitrol Monitor must match.

How to start playback:

  1. Start Navitrol Monitor
  2. Make sure that you are not connected to any AGV
    • To disconnect from an AGV press "Disconnect" button located next to "Save Logs" button.
  3. Open a zipped binary log file
    • Option 1 - Drag and drop the file to the map section of Monitor window
      • "The map section" is the grid with coordinates on the sides
    • Option 2 - Select file to open
      • Open "File"-menu from top left corner.
      • Select "Open log"-option
      • Follow the pop-ups

What can you do with playback:

  1. Review localization performance
    • Graphs and visualization of scanner measurements, environment points and reflectors
    • Ability to match scanner measurements to the environment points and reflectors
    • Amount of performed correction
  2. Review driving performance
    • Graphs and visualization of the position and heading of the AGV
    • Measured position and heading compared to the route and the stopping points
    • Measured speed values compared to the target values
  3. Review the quality of the environment
    • Position confidence graph values
    • Amount of visible environment points

How to use:

  1. Charts and data can be viewed as if an AGV was connected

  2. Log time can be scrolled by

    • Dragging the blue slider in the bottom middle
    • Or with arrow keys

  3. A time interval can be pinpointed by

    • Dragging the ends of the time slider

Helpful information that can be seen with the log playback:

  1. How well the scanner measurements match the environment
  2. Position confidence
  3. Warnings and errors
  4. Graphs of given references and received measurements

Tip: If Navitrol Monitor has been connected to an AGV and then disconnected, the last moments can be played back as it were a binary log.

How to adjust logging - Parameters

Logging can be adjusted with Navitrol parameters by modifying params.txt file and reloading the parameters. Most of these parameters are optional, which means that if they are not defined in the params.txt their default values are used. From Navitrol version 6.30.00 forward all logging parameters have default value of 0 and are all optional.

Note: Most of these parameters affect only the text logging as data of binary logging cannot be adjusted by the user.

Note: When changing parameters, check if the parameter is already defined before adding one. If a parameter is defined twice, the Navitrol gets parse error and will not work.

File handling

This section lists parameters that define log sizes and how many logs of certain type can be stored.

General

Parameter nameTypeDefault valueDescription
log_vehicle_stopped_speedFloat0.05Stops continuous logging and increases startinfo update interval when AGV's speed is less than the given value (m/s)
Startinfo.bin is a binary file storing data from previous Navitrol run. It is used for example when initializing the AGV to last know coordinates.
min_free_disk_space_mbInt1000Minimum available disk space required when dumping log files or writing teach data (Mb)
logging_rate_warning_limitInt800000Amount of characters per second for high logging rate warning to be triggered
log_trigger_pass_to_supervisorInt0If set to 1, when Navitrol receives a log trigger from fleet control or monitor the trigger is redirected to Supervisor interface (message 4100) and Navitrol will not take a log.

Binary log length

These parameters can be used to increase or decrease the size of the binary logs. The log_loc_log_size alone determines the length of visual playback. However, if there is less position control data than localization data (timewise) only localization data will be visualized in the beginning of the log.

Note: For visual playback, a binary log must always have localization data, but position control data is optional.

Parameter nameTypeDefault valueDescription
log_loc_log_sizeInt30Size of localization binary log buffer (Mb)
Affects the amount of localization data, such as scanner measurements and odometry, in log_dynamic.ntl file inside the zipped binary log.
About 7 seconds per Mb
log_pos_cont_log_sizeInt30Size of position controller binary log buffer (Mb)
Affects the amount of position control data, such as wheel references, in log_poscont.ntl file inside the zipped binary log.
dyn_map_pt_min_weight_loggedFloat0.05Limit amount of dynamic points written to log. SSet minimum map weigh for point to be included in the log.Recommended 0.0 - 0.2
For systems with dynamic mapping this parameter limits amount of logged dynamic mapping data greatly increasing the length of the log.

Error log

Parameter nameTypeDefault valueDescription
log_err_txt_log_dump_sizeInt10Size of text log to dump on error (Mb)
log_dump_on_error_cooldown_secsInt15Minimum cooldown before taking new automatic error log (in seconds)
log_dump_on_error_max_filesInt20Maximum number of error log files to keep on disk -- from predefined errors.
Default changed 50 ->20 starting from Navitrol version 6.34
log_dump_on_any_error_max_filesInt0Maximum number of error log files to keep on disk -- from general errors.
log_dump_on_specific_errors_only_arr[]Int0Can be used to define any specific errors/warnings to trigger automatic logs. Any valid error/warning number can be used. If defined, automatic log taking is not triggered by any other error/warning.

Thread monitor log

Parameter nameTypeDefault valueDescription
log_dump_thrmon_txt_log_sizeInt10Size of text log to dump on thread monitoring error (Mb)
log_dump_thrmon_max_filesInt20Maximum number of thread monitoring log files to keep on disk.

Continuous log (long visual)

Parameter nameTypeDefault valueDescription
log_cont_log_chunk_sizeInt30Size of continuous log chunk (Mb)
log_cont_log_chunksInt10Number of continuous log chunks
log_cont_log_when_moving_onlyInt1Record continuous log data only when moving. Enabled = 1, Disabled = 0
log_cont_log_stopped_timerInt5Time to keep logging after stopping in seconds

Battery log

Parameter nameTypeDefault valueDescription
battery_log_modeInt00 = disabled,
1 = voltage and driveWheelV,
2 = percentage and driveWheelV,
3 = percentage, wheelV, current, state of health and status

Note: creates separate text log file: battery_log.txt
log_battery_file_size_mbInt20Maximum battery log file size
log_battery_update_interval_msInt50Interval in milliseconds for writing a new line to battery log

Misc

Parameter nameTypeDefault valueDescription
log_dump_external_max_filesInt10Maximum number of log files from external trigger to keep on disk.
Supervisor logging uses this parameter.
log_to_navigationlogInt0Log position to separate navigation log text file: navigationlog.txt
log_dump_vdma_max_filesInt20Maximum number of log files triggered by VDMA to keep on disk.
log_dump_thrmon_max_filesInt20Maximum number of log files triggered by thread monitoring to keep on disk.
log_dump_remote_mon_max_filesInt20Maximum number of log files triggered from Monitor/Fleet control to keep on disk.
log_dump_on_fstop_max_filesInt0Maximum number of log files triggered by any FSTOP to keep on disk.
log_dump_on_estop_max_filesInt0Maximum number of log files triggered by FSTOP on ESTOP to keep on disk.
log_sys_resoures_interval_sInt10Time interval [s] to log resources of the operating system: 0 = disable. This can be helpful if there is reason to suspect that the IPC is running out of resources. The related lines can be found from the log by searching "systeminfo:"

Amount of logging

Amount of logging to text files can be adjusted with parameters. Each logging parameter adjusts the logging of a single Navitrol feature.

Effects of high and low logging rates explained:

AttributeLowHighComment
Time period savedLongShortThe longer period of time the log covers, the easier it is to catch information about an issue into it, because the user has more time to take the log.
In worst cases the logs are filled in less than 5 seconds making it almost impossible to capture an error.
Amount of detailsLowHighThe higher the amount of logged details, the easier it is to solve an issue.
Solving some issues might be impossible to solve with minimal logging.
Very high logging rates can also cause data to be lost because of hardware limits.

As a rule of thumb, the amount of logging should be kept low unless there is reason to suspect problems with a certain feature. For example, supervisor logging should be increased when taking new messages to use and decreased when they are tested and working.

With logging parameters value 0 means that logging is disabled. Values above that increase the amount of logging step by step until the parameter specific max value is reached.

From Navitrol version 6.30.00 forward, all logging parameters are optional, and they are disabled by default.

All logging parameters of integer type can be set in params.txt followingly:

I,parameter_name, value

Example: I,log_veh_inte_eth, 1

While logging parameters of unsinged integer type should start with U:

Example: U, log_ext_target_det, 1

Note: If some feature is not used, changing its logging level will not have any effect.

Connected devices

Parameter nameTypeMax levelDescription
log_scannerInt5Log scanner data details.
log_sensorsInt1Log sensor data
log_bmsInt1Log external battery management system communication.
log_motor_controllersInt2Log motor controller details
log_imuInt2Log IMU details:
1 - parsed data
2 - raw data
log_gpsInt3Log GPS localization details:
0 = disable,
1 = log outputs,
2 = log antenna points,
3 = log messages.
log_pointcloud_interfaceInt2Log pointcloud interface:
0 = No,
1 = Basic,
2 = Detailed
log_actuatorsInt1Log actuator control details: 0 = general, 1 = detailed.

Control interfaces

Parameter nameTypeMax levelDescription
log_veh_inte_ethInt4Log ethernet supervisor messages:
1 - message info
4 - all bytes
log_canInt1Log primary CAN details, including all messages byte by byte
log_can2Int1Log secondary CAN details, including all messages byte by byte
log_can_msgsInt1Log parsed and built can messages.
log_can_summaryInt1Log CAN msg summary
0 - on ERR condition only
1 -- periodically
log_keyb_ctrl_ioInt1Log keyboard controls from Navitrol Monitor
log_modbusInt1Log parsed and built modbus message data
log_ethercatInt3Log EtherCAT communication details.
log_profinetInt2Log profinet interface details:
0 = general,
1 = detailed,
2 = log binary data.

Position control

Parameter nameTypeMax levelDescription
log_speed_limitInt1Enable detailed logging for active speed limitations
log_segparsingInt1Log segment parsing details
log_get_trajInt3Log trajectory generation
log_omni_controlInt3Log omni control details.
1 - log drive time
2 - route filtering
3 - speed limits
log_rtr_generationInt1Enables logging of return to route generation.

Localization

Parameter nameTypeMax levelDescription
log_correlationInt5Log various correlation calculations used for localisation.
log_positioningInt5Log various calculations related to poses and positioning
log_deadrecInt5Log dead reckoning calculations.
log_reflector_posInt5Log the reflector positions.
Warning: high levels can cause very high logging rate.
log_thrd_localizeInt1Log state and events of localize thread
log_ext_locInt3Log external localization:
0 = disable,
1 = enable,
values 2...3 for more detailed logging with some sensors.

Target detection

Parameter nameTypeMax levelDescription
log_pallet_detectionInt1Log pallet detection calculation details
log_pattern_detectionInt1Log pattern detection details
Note: very detailed and should be enabled only when testing.
log_ext_target_detUint1Log external target detection data
log_table_detectionInt1Log table detection details: 0 = general, 1 = detailed.
log_target_detectionInt1Log target detection calculation details: 0 = general, 1 = detailed.

Misc features

Parameter nameTypeMax levelDescription
log_pos_ini_reflInt1Log reflector-based position initialisation
log_rackingInt1Log warehouse racking details
log_driving_with_stop_ptsInt1Log driving with stop points details.
log_ext_fleet_controlInt2Log external fleet control
log_sensor_fusionInt3Detailed logging for sensor fusion
1 - location estimates
2 - location and velocity
3 - max
log_trailer_transportInt1Enables logging of trailer transport details.
log_coupled_driveInt2Log coupled drive control details.
log_obst_detectionInt3Log obstacle detection:
0 = none,
1 = result line counts,
2 = detailed logging,
3 = log all lines.
log_rosInt2Log ros specific details:
0 = disable,
1 = enable,
2 = log detailed path information

Misc internal

Parameter nameTypeMax levelDescription
log_eventsInt1Log all internal events between different Navitrol threads.
log_timer_threadInt1Log internal timers.

Trouble shooting

WARNING_HIGH_LOGGING_RATE

WARNING_HIGH_LOGGING_RATE is a warning activated when logging rate of the text.log exceeds characters per second rate defined by the parameter logging_rate_warning_limit.

Too high logging rate can cause logged data to be lost or corrupted. It might also decrease the overall performance of the Navitrol.

It is recommended to fix this warning by how-to-adjust-logging---parameters.

Other option is to increase the value of the parameter. However, this approach only hides the problem instead of solving it.

Navitrol Monitor gives an error when opening binary log

Make sure that the Monitor version matches the version of the Navitrol which was running when the log was taken.

Navitrol Monitor does not accept a log file

Make sure that the file type is ".gz" in lower case. For example, "LOG_BIN.GZ" will not open but "LOG_BIN.gz" will.

Other problems

If you are facing a logging related problem and you cannot find an answer from this document, please contact Navitec support.

Advanced

Filtered console logging

It is possible to use filtered text logging with Linux console commands. The list of commands that can be used in order to write specific log messages to files and/or view them in real time are presented below. Amount of log lines and the threads of interest can be specified manually.

If [n] is 0 when using dumps or dumpl, log lines are displayed in real time as they are output by '.'.

Note: All available Navitrol console commands can be seen with ./Navitrol help -- Linux console command.

To the console screen

Dumping filtered data to console screen in `real time` can be helpful when running tests as often user is interested only in certain log lines and seeing them from the console screen is faster than taking a log and opening it separately.

Related commands:

'./Navitrol dumps' - echo last 100 lines of log on screen.
'./Navitrol dumps [n]' - echo last [n] lines of log on screen.
'./Navitrol dumps [n] [t]' - echo last [n] lines of log from thread [t] on screen.
'./Navitrol dumps [n] [t1] [t2]' - echo last [n] lines of log from threads [t1] and [t2] on screen.
'./Navitrol dumpl [n] "[string1]" "[string2]" "[...]"' - dump last n lines of log that contain any of the specified strings.
'./Navitrol dumpt [start] [end]' - dump lines between timestamps [start] and [end].

To a text log

Dumping filtered data to a text log is rarely useful as user can dump whole log and filter it with text editor.

Related commands:

'./Navitrol dumpf' - dump whole log to ./logs/log.txt.
'./Navitrol dumpf [n]' - dump last [n] lines of log to ./logs/log.txt.
'./Navitrol dumpf [n] [t]' - dump last [n] lines of log from thread [t] to ./logs/log.txt.
'./Navitrol dumpf [n] [t1] [t2]' - dump last [n] lines of log from threads [t1] and [t2] to ./logs/log.txt.

List of log threads

Log threads tell the user from which part of the code a log line has been written. See Reading a text log.

Up to date list of threads can be seen with Linux console command ./Navitrol help

Example list of available threads:

log_dump: -2
main: -1
veh_inte: 0
scanner_rear: 1
scanner_front: 2
localize: 3
lift_ctrl: 4
ui: 5
io: 6
remote_mon: 7
can_inte_primary: 8
veh_inte_supervisor: 9
dyn_map_server: 10
route_driver: 11
safety_scanner0: 12
safety_scanner1: 13
safety_scanner2: 14
safety_scanner3: 15
pilz_inte: 16
charger_inte: 17
log_handler: 18
ext_loc_sensor0: 19
ext_loc_sensor1: 20
ext_loc_sensor2: 21
ext_loc_sensor3: 22
traj_man: 23
can_inte_secondary: 24
imu_inte: 25
tools_inte: 26
file_io_handler: 27
pos_cont: 28
mcs_inte: 29

Obsolete log types

Here is a list log files that have been in use but are no longer available. If you see any of these in IPC they can be deleted or ignored.

Log typeName exampleComment
Real time loglog_realtime1.txtRemoved because of too excessive disk writes causing potential Navitrol performance and disk reliability issues.
Leuze scanner logLeuze_udp_trace.txtRemoved

Linux image installation

Updated 26.01.2024

  • Clonezilla
  • CAN drivers
  • Debian Buster
  • Debian Bullseye

CAN interface and CAN drivers

Updated 26.01.2024

Overview

Traditional "old style" CAN drivers for Linux are based on the model of character devices and provide comparatively little functionality. Typically, these drivers are manufacturer specific and therefore tied to a specific hardware. Exchanging the CAN controller or even the manufacturer of the hardware requires employment of another device driver and often the need for adaption of the application to the new driver's API.

SocketCAN was designed to overcome the limitations of dedicated character device drivers. SocketCAN is part of standard Linux kernel distribution and since Debian 9 (Stretch) was released, SocketCAN has been the preferred CAN interface to be use with Navitrol.

SocketCAN

SocketCAN basics

SocketCAN is a set of open-source CAN drivers and a networking stack contributed by Volkswagen Research to the Linux kernel. SocketCAN concept extends the Berkeley sockets API in Linux by introducing a new protocol family, PF_CAN, that coexists with other protocol families, such as PF_INET for the Internet Protocol. The communication with the CAN bus is therefore done analogously to the use of the Internet Protocol via sockets.

Fundamental components of SocketCAN are the network device drivers for different CAN controllers and the implementation of the CAN protocol family. SocketCAN supports natively many commonly used CAN controllers. For example, Kvaser and Peak (Navitec standard offering) CAN cards are supported natively. There is no need to install any additional drivers.

There are also CAN controllers/cards that are not natively supported but come with SocketCAN compatible network device drivers. Additional driver for the CAN hardware should be installed only in this case.

SocketCAN benefits

SocketCAN provides multiple benefits over manufacturer specific character device drivers:

  • SocketCAN is the "official" CAN API of the Linux kernel and is included in standard Linux.
  • Linux comes with device drivers for all major CAN controllers used in various architectures and bus types.
  • Because of wide use and acceptance, manufacturers of non-natively supported hardware typically provide SocketCAN compatible network device drivers.
  • Applications, like Navitrol, have standardized communication API that works with any hardware having native support or compatible drivers. Changing CAN hardware provider does not require any modifications to the application. See figure below.
  • As the SocketCAN concept uses the model of network devices, multiple SocketCAN user space applications are allowed to access one CAN device simultaneously. This makes it possible to use different kind of utilities to interact with the CAN bus. Most commonly used utility pack, can-utils, includes several tools to send/receive/dump/monitor CAN messages in any system. One can for example monitor CAN traffic from a Linux console using candump utility while Navitrol is running.

SocketCAN device availability and testing

Simple test to check availability of SocketCAN devices is to write command "ip a" on the Linux console. Detected SocketCAN devices should appear on the list of available network interfaces as shown below; having device names like can0, can1,...

    4: can0: <NOARP,ECHO> mtu 16 qdisc noop state DOWN group default qlen 10
    link/can
    5: can1: <NOARP,ECHO> mtu 16 qdisc noop state DOWN group default qlen 10
    link/can

At startup, SocketCAN devices are in "link down" state. If CAN interface is connected to working CAN bus having messaging on the bus, then for testing purposes one can configure and "activate" SocketCAN devices writing commands:

    sudo ip link set can0 type can bitrate 250000
    sudo ip link set can0 up
    candump can0

Utility candump (part of can-utils package) will then dump all messages on the bus to the console as shown below.

    navitec@debian11:~$ candump can0
    can0  041   [4]  00 00 00 00
    can0  7B8   [1]  01
    can0  0F9   [1]  02
    can0  7AE   [0]
    can0  669   [8]  04 00 00 00 00 00 00 00
    can0  11C   [1]  05
    can0  5A6   [1]  06
    can0  0FE   [1]  07
    can0  12F   [3]  08 00 00
    can0  140   [7]  09 00 00 00 00 00 00
    can0  220   [2]  0A 00
    can0  5DF   [4]  0B 00 00 00
    can0  714   [8]  0C 00 00 00 00 00 00 00
    can0  79D   [6]  0D 00 00 00 00 00
    can0  70B   [2]  0E 00
    can0  3B1   [5]  0F 00 00 00 00

Another option is to use Navitrol for testing that CAN interface works as expected. Typically, these simple console commands are however a faster way to get assurance of a working interface.

Navitec Systems Linux images and CAN support

Debian 7, Debian 8 and Debian 9

Older Navitec Systems Linux images, based on Debian 7 (Wheezy) and 8 (Jessie), had two character device CAN drivers pre-installed. Those drivers provided support for CAN card offering from Kvaser and Peak.

SocketCAN has been the default and recommended interface for Navitrol since Debian 9 (Stretch). Manufacturer specific character device drivers have not been installed in Linux images based on Debian 9 or later by Navitec Systems.

NOTE: Debian 7, Debian 8 and Debian 9 are supported by Navitrol versions up to 6.42.xx only.

Debian 10 or later

Support for Debian versions older than Debian 10 (Buster) is dropped by Navitrol version 6.44, released March 2023. At the same time SocketCAN becomes the only supported CAN interface. Therefore, Kvaser and Peak dedicated character device drivers can't be used anymore.

Debian 10 or later - character device driver for CAN installed

Navitec Systems has instructed not to install Kvaser and Peak character device drivers to new Linux systems. Installing Kvaser or Peak character device driver to Linux not only installs that dedicated driver, but also effectively removes SocketCAN from use by "blacklisting" it. This blacklisting typically involves only the specific hardware the character device driver has been installed for. For example, Kvaser character device driver installation blacklists SocketCAN for Kvaser interfaces and outputs to console this for each supported interface type

Checking for loaded SocketCAN driver for Kvaser USB devices.
Unloading SocketCAN driver...
Blacklisting SocketCAN Kvaser USB driver to prevent it from auto-loading.

So, if Kvaser or Peak dedicated character device driver has been installed, SocketCAN can't be used with that hardware unless that driver is uninstalled first and SocketCAN "re-activated". In such a case, some extra work is needed prior to updating to Navitrol 6.44.xx or later. This means

  • Uninstalling character device driver in question.
  • Removing the SocketCAN driver from blacklisted drivers.

Instructions for this procedure are presented in the following. Fortunately both Kvaser and Peak latest driver packages manage these both operations gracefully.

Uninstalling Kvaser or Peak dedicated character device driver

Uninstalling Kvaser CANlib character device driver

NOTE: Some older Kvaser CANlib packages did not handle uninstall at all, so you can get this response: 

root@navitrol:/home/navitec/linuxcan# sudo make uninstall
make: *** No rule to make target 'uninstall'.  Stop.

So, if you have issues with uninstalling the driver or package is not available anymore, download the latest linuxcan driver package (linuxcan.tar.gz) from Kvaser web-site: http://www.kvaser.com/. Sample outputs below are from Bullseye Linux with Kvaser driver version 5.40.102 (which was the latest one at the time of writing this).

If linuxcan driver package is not available anymore at target IPC (or you wish to use the latest driver for uninstalling), you need to do the following steps prior to actual uninstall:

  • Copy linuxcan.tar.gz to your target system
  • Extract linuxcan: "tar xvzf linuxcan.tar.gz"
  • Change directory: "cd linuxcan"
  • Inside of the linuxcan directory, run "make" to build everything which is required before you can uninstall

To uninstall the driver

  • Run: "sudo make uninstall". Output of this is shown below. As the output shows, SocketCAN Kvaser drivers are also removed from blacklist.

  • Reboot IPC to finalize and verify correct operation using SocketCAN.

      navitec@debian11:~/linuxcan$ sudo make uninstall
  Uninstalling pciefd
  Remove SocketCAN Kvaser PCI driver from blacklist.
  Uninstalling pcican2
  Remove SocketCAN Kvaser PCI driver from blacklist.
  Uninstalling pcican
  Remove SocketCAN Kvaser PCI driver from blacklist.
  Uninstalling virtualcan
  Uninstalling usbcanII
  Remove SocketCAN Kvaser USB driver from blacklist.
  Uninstalling mhydra
  Remove SocketCAN Kvaser USB driver from blacklist.
  Uninstalling leaf
  *************************************************************************
  WARNING: leaf could not be removed! Either unplug USB device and
          remove leaf manually after uninstallation or do a reboot.
  *************************************************************************
  Remove SocketCAN Kvaser USB driver from blacklist.
  Uninstalling common
  *************************************************************************
  WARNING: kvcommon could not be removed! Either unplug USB device and
          remove kvcommon manually after uninstallation or do a reboot.
  *************************************************************************
  make -C canlib uninstall
  make[1]: Entering directory '/home/navitec/linuxcan/canlib'
  make[1]: Warning: File '../make/pkgconfig.mk' has modification time 2789510 s in the future
  rm -f /usr/lib/pkgconfig/canlib.pc
  make -C examples uninstall
  make[2]: Entering directory '/home/navitec/linuxcan/canlib/examples'
  make[2]: Warning: File '../../make/gflags.mk' has modification time 2789510 s in the future
  rm -rf /usr/doc/canlib/examples
  make[2]: warning:  Clock skew detected.  Your build may be incomplete.
  make[2]: Leaving directory '/home/navitec/linuxcan/canlib/examples'
  rm -f /usr/lib/libcanlib.so   \
      /usr/lib/libcanlib.so.1    \
      /usr/lib/libcanlib.so.1.10.1   \
      /usr/include/canlib.h \
      /usr/include/canstat.h \
      /usr/include/obsolete.h
  /sbin/ldconfig
  rm -rf /usr/doc/canlib
  make[1]: warning:  Clock skew detected.  Your build may be incomplete.
  make[1]: Leaving directory '/home/navitec/linuxcan/canlib'
  make -C linlib uninstall
  make[1]: Entering directory '/home/navitec/linuxcan/linlib'
  make[1]: Warning: File '../make/pkgconfig.mk' has modification time 2789510 s in the future
  rm -f /usr/lib/pkgconfig/linlib.pc
  rm -f /usr/lib/liblinlib.so   \
      /usr/lib/liblinlib.so.1    \
      /usr/lib/liblinlib.so.1.6.6   \
      /usr/include/linlib.h
  make[1]: warning:  Clock skew detected.  Your build may be incomplete.
  make[1]: Leaving directory '/home/navitec/linuxcan/linlib'
  rm -f /etc/udev/rules.d/10-kvaser.rules
  rm -f /etc/modules-load.d/kvaser.conf

Uninstalling Peak character device driver

If you have issues with uninstalling the driver or package is not available anymore, download the latest driver package (peak-linux-driver-X.Y.Z.tar.gz) from Peak web-site: https://www.peak-system.com. Bullseye Linux with driver version 8.15.2 (which was the latest one at the time of writing this) has been used to verify correct operation.

If Peak driver package is not available anymore at target IPC (or you wish to use the latest driver for uninstalling), you need to do the following steps prior to uninstall:

  • Copy peak-linux-driver-X.Y.Z.tar.gz to your target system
  • Extract driver package: "tar -xzf peak-linux-driver-X.Y.Z.tar.gz"

To uninstall the driver

  • Change directory: "cd peak-linux-driver-X.Y.Z"
  • Run "sudo make uninstall". Output of this is shown below.
  • Optionally result can be pre-checked before rebooting by "sudo dmesg | grep pcan". See example output below.
  • Reboot IPC to finalize and verify correct operation using SocketCAN.

Output for command "sudo make uninstall":

    navitec@debian11:~/peak-linux-driver-8.15.2$ sudo make uninstall
    make[1]: Entering directory '/home/navitec/peak-linux-driver-8.15.2/driver'
    rmmod pcan 2> /dev/null || true
    if [ -f /lib/modules/5.10.0-19-rt-amd64/misc/pcan.ko ]; then\
            rm -f /lib/modules/5.10.0-19-rt-amd64/misc/pcan.ko;\
            depmod 5.10.0-19-rt-amd64;\
    fi
    [ ! -d /var/lib/dkms/peak-linux-driver ] || \
            /usr/sbin/dkms remove peak-linux-driver/8.15.2 --all || true
    rm -f   /usr/src/peak-linux-driver-8.15.2 \
            /tmp/peak-linux-driver-8.15.2-dkms.stderr
    rm -rf /var/lib/dkms/peak-linux-driver
    rm -f   /usr/include/pcan.h \
            /usr/include/pcanfd.h \
            /usr/local/bin/pcan_make_devices \
            /usr/local/bin/lspcan \
            /usr/local/bin/pcanosdiag.sh \
            /etc/udev/rules.d/45-pcan.rules \
            /usr/local/bin/pcan_usb_minor_check.bash \
            /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist-peak.conf \
            /etc/modprobe.d/pcan.conf

    make[1]: Entering directory '/home/navitec/peak-linux-driver-8.15.2/lib'

        /usr/include/libpcanfd.h
    for f in libpcan.so libpcan.so.6 libpcanfd.so libpcanfd.so.8 libpcanfd.a; do \
            rm -f /usr/lib/$f; \
            rm -f /usr/lib32/$f; \
    done
    /sbin/ldconfig
    make[1]: Leaving directory '/home/navitec/peak-linux-driver-8.15.2/lib'

navitec@debian11:~/peak-linux-driver-8.15.2$ sudo dmesg | grep pcan
