[    4.609183] pcan: major 245.
[  331.784590] usbcore: deregistering interface driver pcan
[  331.784759] pcan: removed.

Clonezilla Installation Instructions

Updated 26.01.2024

Installation

Debian 10.* Buster Installation

Updated 26.01.2024

Installation:

Debian version used: 10.* stable release

  • Esc while booting to boot to BIOS

  • SCU Enable USB boot

  • Boot manager USB stick

  • Debian installation:

    • Language = ???

    • Country = ???

    • Locale

    • Keyboard = ???

    • Network = ???

    • Host name = Navitec

    • Domain name = ---

    • Root password = navitrol

    • User account = navitec

    • Username = navitec

    • User password = navitrol

    • Force UEFI installation = no

    • Partitioning method = Guided -- use entire disk

    • Disk partition = hard drive

    • Partition scheme = Separate /home partition

      • Make sure root (/) partition has at least 16 GB, needed for RT kernel installation

    • Finish partitioning and write changes to disk

    • Write changes to disk

    • Debian archive mirror country = ???

    • HTTP proxy = ---

    • Participate in the package usage survey = no

    • Software selection = SSH server & Standard system utilities

    • Install GRUB boot loader = yes

    • Device for boot loader installation = /dev/sda

Updating to real time kernel:

apt-get update
apt-get install linux-image-4.9.0.9-rt-amd64 # Use uname -a to check the kernel version before this step, installed kernel has to match with standard kernel version

  • updated to kernel 4.9.0-9-rt-amd64

  • Double check that systems has preempt_rt kernel installed and in use before proceeding to following steps, by running uname -a And checking that the running kernel is actually real time patched.

Packages installed

  1. apt-get update

  2. apt-get dist-upgrade

  3. apt-get install linux-headers-4.9.0-9-rt-amd64

  4. apt-get install make

  5. apt-get install gcc

  6. apt-get install valgrind

  7. apt-get install aptitude

  8. aptitude install cpufrequtils

  9. aptitude install sysfsutils

  10. apt-get install screen

  11. apt-get install build-essential

  12. apt-get install libpopt-dev

  13. apt-get install insserv

  14. apt install tcpdump # For recording tcp communication

  15. apt install can-utils

  16. apt install net-tools # ifconfig tool installed

  17. apt install acpid # power button handling

Setting CPU frequency to performance

cd /etc/default
cat > cpufrequtils

#*Input the following*
GOVERNOR="performance"
#*save*

Ignition pin configuration

Optional step to make IPC shutdown with IGN pin with systems having hardware support for that:

nano /etc/acpi/events/power

Write to the file:

event=button/power
action=/sbin/shutdown now

Setting up Samba

apt-get install samba
nano /etc/samba/smb.conf

change the following settings

Under [global]

min protocol = SMB2
max protocol = SMB3
client min protocol = SMB2
client max protocol = SMB3
client ipc min protocol = SMB2
client ipc max protocol = SMB3
server min protocol = SMB2
server max protocol = SMB3

Under [homes]

read only = no

save

service smbd restart # To apply changes without restart

Add password for user navitec for Samba

smbpasswd -a navitec
password: navitrol

Ethernet configurations

This step is not necessary for Navitrol to run. Performing this step affects only the naming of the network interfaces not the functionality.

ip a

If ethernet interface name are not classic eth0, eth1, etc., for example:

2: eno0 3: eno1 4: eno2 5: can0

...perform following steps:

nano /etc/default/grub

enter the following to the file

GRUB\_CMDLINE\_LINUX=\"net.ifnames=0 biosdevname=0\" > grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg

reboot
ip a

2: eth0 3: eth1 4: eth2 5: can0

nano /etc/network/interfaces

example below for the Navitec default settings

# The primary network interface
allow-hotplug eth0
iface eth0 inet static
address 10.10.6.100
netmask 255.255.255.0

allow-hotplug eth1
iface eth1 inet dhcp

#auto wlan0
#iface wlan0 inet static
#address x.x.x.x
#netmask x.x.x.x
#gateway x.x.x.x
#wpa-ssid xxxxxxxxxxxxxx
#wpa-psk xxxxxxxxxxxxxx

Booting to /home/navitec

nano /etc/passwd

change the following settings

root:x:0:0:root:/home/navitec:/bin/bash

Remote Control Support (web interface)

apt-get install lighttpd
apt-get install libfcgi0ldbl

Lighttpd configuration

Default configuration

Edit /etc/lighttpd/lighttpd.conf to following. Please note that different versions of lighttpd require bit different configurations. Best approach is to add missing configurations (leave include_shell as they are) to existing file, instead of replacing the file completely.

server.modules = (
  "mod_access",
  "mod_alias",
  "mod_compress",
  "mod_redirect",
  "mod_fastcgi",
  "mod_auth",
)

server.document-root = "/var/www/html"
server.upload-dirs = ( "/var/cache/lighttpd/uploads" )
server.errorlog = "/var/log/lighttpd/error.log"
server.pid-file = "/var/run/lighttpd.pid"
server.username = "www-data"
server.groupname = "www-data"
server.port = 80

index-file.names = ( "index.php", "index.html", "index.lighttpd.html" )
url.access-deny = ( "~", ".inc" )
static-file.exclude-extensions = ( ".php", ".pl", ".fcgi" )
compress.cache-dir = "/var/cache/lighttpd/compress/"
compress.filetype = ( "application/javascript", "text/css", "text/html", "text/plain" )

# default listening port for IPv6 falls back to the IPv4 port
include_shell "/usr/share/lighttpd/use-ipv6.pl " + server.port
include_shell "/usr/share/lighttpd/create-mime.conf.pl"
include_shell "/usr/share/lighttpd/include-conf-enabled.pl"

fastcgi.server += (
  "remote_control" => (
  "remote_control.fcgi.handler" => (
    "socket" => "/tmp/remote_control.fcgi.socket",
    "check-local" => "disable",
    "bin-path" => "/home/navitec/remote_control.fcgi",
    "max-procs" => 1
  ))
)

Enable authentication

This step is optional.

Create file /home/navitec/.lighttpdpassword and to that file add line with desired password and username separated with column (:):

username:password(MD5 hashed)

Add following lines to /etc/lighttpd/lighttpd.conf:

auth.backend = "htpasswd"

auth.backend.htpasswd.userfile = "/home/navitec/.lighttpdpassword"

auth.require = ( "/" =>
  (
  "method" => "basic",
  "realm" => "Password protected area",
  "require" => "valid-user"
  )
)

Enable HTTPS

This step is optiona.

  1. Run: mkdir /etc/lighttpd/certs/

  2. Add your certificate file (.pem) to just created location. If using self-signed cert, run following commands in created directory:

openssl req -new -x509 -keyout lighttpd.pem -out lighttpd.pem -days 358000 -nodes

Note:

  • Days can be adjusted

  • Using self-signed certificate requires user to manually trust the certificate

  1. Add following lines to the end of /etc/lighttpd/lighttpd.conf file:
$SERVER["socket"] == ":443" {
  protocoll = "https://"
  ssl.engine = "enable"
  ssl.pemfile = "/etc/lighttpd/certs/lighttpd.pem"

} else $HTTP["scheme"] == "http" {
  # In case of unsecure connection, redirect to secure*
  $HTTP["host"] =~ ".*" {
    # redirect to https, port 443:
    url.redirect = (".*" => "https://%0$0")
  }
}

Allow Root access through SSH

nano /etc/ssh/sshd_config

edit the following lines

#PermitRootLogin without-password

# to

PermitRootLogin yes

Restart ssh server: /etc/init.d/ssh restart

Disabling suspend and problematic services

Run as root. If services do not exist (possibly installed as a part of graphical desktop, and installation of the desktop should be avoided):

systemctl disable NetworkManager.service

systemctl disable ModemManager.service*

Run as root. Disable all suspends and sleeps:

systemctl mask sleep.target suspend.target hibernate.target hybrid-sleep.target

Navitrol UI support (touchpad interface)

apt-get install qt5
apt-get install libqt5multimedia5
apt-get install devilspie2

NavitrolUI.desktop /etc/xdg/autostart

Change from Wayland to X11 when logging in and enable automatic login: nano /etc/gdm3/daemon.conf

WaylandEnable = false

AutomaticLoginEnable = true
AutomaticLogin = navitec

Setting NavitrolUI to run fullscreen:

nano /home/navitec/.config/devilspie2/maxim.lua

add the following into the file

If(get\_window\_name()=="NavitrolUI") then\
set\_window\_fullscreen(true);\
end

Setting the correct resolution on boot:

touch .xprofile nano .xprofile

Add the following into the file

xrandr \--newmode "1280X960 60.00" 101.25 1280 1360 1488 1696
960963967996\
xrandr \--addmode eDP-1 "1280X960 60.00"

chmod -x .xprofile

Set screen to not turn off or be dimmed when idle:

gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.screensaver lock-enabled false
gsettings set org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.power idle-dim false
gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.session idle-delay 0

Hide cursor on boot:

`apt-get install unclutter`

`nano /etc/xdg/autostart/unclutter.desktop`

*Creates a new file, add the following in*

`unclutter -idle 0`

Debian 11 Bullseye Installation

Updated 14.02.2024

Overview

Debian Bullseye is a Linux distribution that can be used on the AGV:s computer (eg. VBOX) to run Navitrol and other related software. This document guides you throuh the process of installing Bullseye using our custom installer. This customized installer makes it easier to set up a correct running environment for Navitrol. There are also a couple of things that you may want to customize after the installation that are also mentioned here.

Introduction

Debian Bullseye was released August 14 2021 and will be supported by the Debian Long Term Support team and Debian Security Team for 5 years. In December 2022 Navitec has made available the customized installer for Bullseye that creates a suitable running environment for Navitrol using a streamlined installation process. Almost all the configuration that was done manually to the previous versions and delivered in a CloneZilla image is now part of the installer itself.

What's new in this version of Debian image?

  • This image includes Docker, which should allow running containerized applications on the AGV. For example ROS based applications can be installed this way.
  • The image also includes 'sudo' which can be used to become root when needed.
  • Web interface uses SSL by default. It also has password protection enabled by default. The username and password are the same as you would use to login through SSH.
  • The release notes for Debian Bullseye are found at https://www.debian.org/releases/bullseye/amd64/release-notes/
  • The kernel version that is installed by the installer is 5.10.0-19-rt. The kernel includes support for CAN devices through SocketCAN and shouldn't require any extra drivers to be installed.

Requirements

  • A computer that can boot from USB and has a hard-drive that will be used for installation. To run the installer, there should be at least a keyboard and monitor connected to the computer. You may also prefer to have a mouse for navigating the installer.
  • An installation medium, typically a USB stick that has at least 2Gb of space. If you prepare the installation media yourself, you also need the ISO image and a computer running the suitable software (eg. Rufus) to make a bootable USB stick from the ISO file.
    • Rufus is available at https://rufus.ie/en/
    • The ISO file can be downloaded from https://www.dropbox.com/s/e11v2ynzt0g88eh/bullseye-installer.iso?dl=0
  • The computer used should satisfy hardware requirements for Navitrol. The Debian installation itself isn't a limiting factor from hardware point of view.

Limitations

  • The installer doesn't install packages for supporting Touch UI. If that feature is required the support packages will have to be manually installed.
  • The installer doesn't install packages for supporting 3D object detection. If that feature is required the support packages will have to be manually installed.
  • To make the setup easier, most of the decisions you normally make when installing Debian have been made for you. This means that:
    • It will pick the installation drive automatically. Do not connect other drives during installation.
    • It will partition disk automatically, so you can't customize that.
    • locale will be en_US.UTF-8

Dependencies

  • Navitrol installer (.deb package) supports installing on Debian Bullseye starting from version 6.42

Set up

Making a bootable media

Take the ISO image and burn it to DVD or USB stick. On Windows, software called Rufus can be used for this task. Select the DD mode and not the ISO mode when writing to USB.

  1. Plug in your USB stick
  2. Start Rufus
  3. Windows will give you a dialog where you should select "Allow this program to make modifications"
  4. Select your USB stick as the "Device"
  5. Select the ISO image by clicking the "SELECT" button under "Boot selection"
  6. The rest of the options can stay at their defaults:
    • Partition scheme: MBR
    • Target system: BIOS or UEFI
    • File system: FAT32
  7. Click "START"
  8. It shows a dialog titled "ISOHybrid image detected" with options "Write in ISO image mode (recommended)" and "Write in DD Image mode". Select "Write in DD Image mode" and press OK
  9. Wait for it to finish before removing the USB stick

Installation

These installation instructions are tested on VBOX, but the installation should be similar on other PCs as well. The specific keys and boot menu may of course be different.

  1. Plug the USB stick to USB2 port on the back of VBOX (the black one, not one of the blue ones). If you use a blue port, the installer will start, but will run into problems in the middle of the installation.
  2. Enter the BIOS on machine startup by pressing the ESC key (may be different on other machines), select the USB stick as the boot device
    • Use arrow keys to browse to the 'boot' tab
    • Select Boot option #1 using the arrow keys
    • Press Enter and select the USB key using arrow keys, press Enter again
    • Press F4 to "Save and exit"
  3. Boot the machine
  4. The installer should start and ask for keyboard layout, select the desired layout.
  5. The installer should ask for the name of the host. Enter desired name for your AGV.
  6. Installer now runs for a while, but should ask no further questions.
  7. In the end, the installer will warn you that the computer is going to restart. Remove USB stick and press ok.

Fine tuning

Network configuration

To view current network interfaces and their status ip a

Network configuration can be changed with. sudo nano /etc/network/interfaces.d/navitec

The example below are the Navitec default settings. These settings are active if you don't configure anything else.

# The primary network interface
allow-hotplug enp1s0
iface enp1s0 inet static
address 10.10.6.100
netmask 255.255.255.0

allow-hotplug enp2s0
iface enp2s0 inet dhcp

You can also configure a wlan network if needed. This can be in the same file or under a different file, eg. in /etc/network/interfaces.d/wlan

auto wlp3s0
iface wlp3s0 inet static
address x.x.x.x
netmask x.x.x.x
gateway x.x.x.x
wpa-ssid xxxxxxxxxxxxxx
wpa-psk xxxxxxxxxxxxxx

Newer versions of the Bullseye installer provided by Navitec (V3 and up) uses the new Debian naming convention for network interfaces. The new naming convention binds the network names with physical PCI lanes which makes the interface name to physical port correspondence more consistent. With the new interface names you would typically have enp1s0, enp2s0 and wlp3s0 instead of eth0, eth1 and wlan0. To revert the interface names to the old naming style, follow these steps:

  1. Open the following file with a text editor, for example nano /etc/default/grub
  2. Locate the line withGRUB_CMDLINE_LINUXand addnet.ifnames=0 biosdevname=0. The line should look like this after modifying GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX="net.ifnames=0 biosdevname=0"
  3. Update GRUB to use the new configuration update-grub2
  4. Reboot the machine sudo reboot
  5. Now you can check the interface names with ip a

Now you have to change the network interfaces file to correspond with the old names

# The primary network interface 
allow-hotplug eth0
iface eth0 inet static
address 10.10.6.100
netmask 255.255.255.0

allow-hotplug eth1
iface eth1 inet dhcp

You can also configure a wlan network if needed. This can be in the same file or under a different file, eg. in /etc/network/interfaces.d/wlan

auto wlan0
iface wlan0 inet static
address x.x.x.x
netmask x.x.x.x
gateway x.x.x.x
wpa-ssid xxxxxxxxxxxxxx
wpa-psk xxxxxxxxxxxxxx

Setting the time zone

To get the list of time zones give the following command over SSH

timedatectl list-timezones

and then you can select your timezone using this command:

sudo timedatectl set-timezone <your_time_zone>

Lighttpd configuration

The Lighttpd server is configured correctly by default. SSL and password authentication are enabled by default.

Disable authentication

The authentication can be disabled by removing the file /etc/lighttpd/conf-enabled/require_password.conf.

Change the password

Edit file /etc/lighttpd/nt_password. That file should have a line with desired password and username separated with column (:): username:password(MD5 hashed) It is using htpasswd as the backend, so you should create the hash accordingly.

Disable SSL (HTTPS)

You can disable the SSL by removing /etc/lighttpd/conf-enabled/enable-ssl.conf.

How to use

User accounts (SSH)

The installed system will have a user called navitec with the customary default password. The system will allow logins through SSH and will have the default network settings described above. You can use eg. PuTTY to connect to the computer running Debian from a Windows computer, or just ssh from terminal if you are connecting form Linux or MacOS. You can transfer files to and from the computer using SFTP.

Navitrol Updater

Navitrol Updater is a separate piece of software that can be used to install Navitrol on the Debian. It can also be used to send other files. For more information, see Navitrol User Instructions.

Troubleshooting

Installer is not starting at all

  • Ensure that the USB stick is selected as a boot device from the BIOS

Installer encounters a problem (can't find installation media)

  • Ensure that the USB stick was made using DD mode and not ISO mode
  • Ensure that you are using USB2 port to install, the USB3 ports may not work with all firmware

Parameter zones

Updated 26.01.2024

Overview

Navitrol parameter zones can be used to change active parameters of the AGV on the fly based on the AGV's position.

The parameter zones can be used for example to define separate position confidence limits for different areas on the map.

Important note: Before taking this feature into use contact Navitec support to discuss what you are planning to do. This is required because changing some parameters at runtime might cause unwanted side effects and some might not do anything as they are only updated at Navitrol startup.

How to use

Preconditions

  • Minimum software version requirements
    • Navitrol 6.42.00
    • Navithor Tools 5.0.0.0
  • Discuss with Navitec support that this feature will work as intended for your use case.

Basics

Parameter set

  • A set of parameters that will replace the normal ones defined in params.txt
  • Defined using params_zoneX.txt files that must be located in the same folder as Navitrol executable
    • "X" refers to the index of the parameter set. Valid values are 0, 1, 2 and 3.
    • For example "params_zone2.txt"
  • The parameters defined in the parameter sets will override the ones defined in the params.txt
    • This means that only the ones that you want to change should be defined in the params_zoneX.txt
    • Does not alter params.txt file
  • Parameter sets of different indexes do not affect each other in any way

Parameter zone

  • Defines an environment zone and a related parameter set index.
  • Related parameters are taken into use when the AGV enters a zone
    • AGV is considered to enter a zone when its navigation point has been within it for 200ms
  • When the AGV leaves a zone the parameters from params.txt are taken back into use
  • There can be any number of parameter zones

Set up

Define parameter zones

  • Open the Navithor Tools project
  • Select "Zones"-tab from the menu on the left
    • The tab is located near the bottom of the menu
  • From "Zone type"-dropdown menu select "ParameterZone"-option
    • If the option cannot be found, update the software
  • Click on the map to define corners of the desired area for a parameter set
  • From "Zone options"-dropdown menu select the desired parameter set for the created zone
  • For more zones, repeat the previous three steps

Define parameter sets

  • Create a new text file params_zoneX.txt
    • Parameter set indexes does not have to be defined in order. For example, you can have only parameter set of index 2 without defining indexes 0 and 1.
  • Add the parameters that should be changed within zones using that parameter set
    • Uses same format as params.txt
    • Tip: You can copy the parameters you want to change from the params.txt and change their values

Additional info

  • If parameter zone is defined but corresponding params_zoneX.txt file is missing, WARNING_PARAMETER_ZONE_PARAMETERS_NOT_FOUND is set and the parameters from params.txt will be used.
    • In practice this means that the zone has no effect
  • The defined zones can overlap. In case of overlapping zones Navitrol will use the zone with lowest ID defined in tools. see Figure 1
    • NOTE : Zone ID is different than parameter set index (for example ParameterSet_0)

Figure 1: In case of overlapping zones, Navitrol uses lowest zone ID.

  • If parameter set (params_zoneX.txt) is defined but corresponding parameter zone is missing, parameter set is parsed in but never used.

Related features

Parameter set override through supervisor interface

Starting with Navitrol version 6.50 the parameter set can also be selected through supervisor interface message 1035. That selection takes precedence over the parameter zones.

Troubleshooting

I defined the parameters zones but now Navitrol does not start

  1. Check that minimum software version defined in Preconditions section is fulfilled.

AGV enters a parameter zone but nothing seems to happen

  1. Check if WARNING_PARAMETER_ZONE_PARAMETERS_NOT_FOUND is active. If it is, the params_zoneX.txt with the index X that matches the parameter set index of the entered zone (defined in Navithor Tools) is missing. Create the file, save it and reload parameters (or restart Navitrol).

  2. Check that parameter zones are correctly defined in the Navitrol's map file by enabling Navitrol monitor zone visualization:

    • Open Navitrol monitor
    • Connect to the AGV
    • From the top bar select "View"-menu to open a dropdown menu
    • From the dropdown menu select "Visualization Options"-option
    • From "Zone visualization"-box check "Parameter zones"-option
      • If the "Parameter zones"-option is disabled or there is no zones visible when it is checked.
        • Check that the Tools project was correctly modified and successfully uploaded to Navitrol
      • If parameter zones option does not exist
        • Check that minimum software version defined in Preconditions section is fulfilled.

  3. Check that you are trying to change parameters that can be changed on the fly. If you have not contacted Navitec support to discuss your use case, do it now.

Navitrol behavior changes in an unintended manner when entering a parameter zone

  1. Check that you are trying to change parameters that can be changed on the fly. If you have not contacted Navitec support to discuss your use case, do it now.

I have any other issue or the troubleshooting tips did not work for me

  1. Take a log covering the problem situation.
  2. Contact Navitec support and provide the log for further analyzation.

Reflectors

Updated 26.01.2024

Overview

This document includes generic information about using reflectors with Navitrol. Feature specific detailed information is found in documentation for each feature.

Requirements

In order to use reflectors for any purpose, the scanner(s) used obviously need to support reflector detection, see "Scanners reflector detection" below.

Why/when to use reflectors

Navitrol basic positioning and most additional features have been designed to work without added infrastructure. There are however cases that benefit from use of reflectors, while some special features even require use of reflectors.

Positioning

Navitrol positioning is designed to work using natural features only, i.e. infrastructure free. Guidelines for good environment can be found in Environment Guidelines.

Sometimes visible static features are just not enough or out of reach for reliable positioning of the AGV. In such a case the options are

  • Adding artificial static objects/features to the environment
  • Adding reflectors to the environment
  • Using additional sensors, like IMU unit and sensor fusion
  • Using Dynamic mapping feature

Reflectors can be added to only problematic areas or distributed all over the production area. Navitrol can then use either static environment or reflectors or both in combination for positioning. When using reflectors together with natural features, even a single reflector can help with positioning. If reflectors are used alone, then a minimum of two reflectors are needed to be visible at the same time.

Use of reflectors typically does not result in better positioning accuracy, but rather improved reliability where static features are not enough or do not exist at all. Additionally,

  • Reflectors can be seen further away than natural features, which makes them a viable option in large open areas.
  • Reflectors can be distinguished from the other objects which again means more reliable positioning.
  • Reflectors do not take much space and can be easily added to the environment.

Precision positioning

Sometimes higher positioning accuracy is needed in specific areas, like loading/docking points. One option then to improve accuracy in such limited sized areas is to use precision positioning, with or without reflectors. This feature is documented in Precision Positioning.

Position initialization

Position initialization is done on request (like by fleet control or supervisor) or automatically. Automatic position initialization can be done

  • At startup based on last stored position and scanner views (stored in startInfo.bin).
  • At any time based on reflectors, as documented in Reflector Based Position Initialization.

Load and target detection

These features are typically implemented using 2D or 3D data without reflectors. Some special cases use reflectors for detecting load or some other target.

Detection of target, other than load, can be used for example to docking to target or just measuring relative position and angle to the target. One example is to use special reflector patterns mounted in a known configuration on a station, carrier or another AGV. This feature is documented in Pattern Detection.

Scanners reflector detection

The method by which reflectors are detected with different laser scanners can be classified into three categories as follows

  • Reflector detection by scanner itself. In this case the scanner provides information for each measurement point whether it is hitting a reflector or not. Navitrol parameters have therefore no effect on this detection. Scanner models providing this information are
    • Sick microScan/nanoScan
    • Sick S300 Expert
    • Keyence SZ-V 32N
  • Reflector detection by Navitrol based on signal strength or return intensity (RSSI) reported by the scanner. Scanner models in this category are
    • Pepperl+Fuchs R2000
    • Sick Tim/LMS (Tim5xx, Tim571, Tim781S, LMS1xx, LMS5xx)
    • Leuze RSL400
    • Omron OS32C
    • Hokuyo scanners (SCIP: UAM-05LP, UST-10LX-H02 & UAM-05LP native)
  • Reflectors not detected at all. Scanner models in this category are
    • Sick S300 other than Expert
    • Quanergy M1 Core/Plus/Ultra (NOTE: M1E has optional support)

Reflector detection based on return intensity

This option is used with scanners that do not provide reflector detection information, but do provide return intensity (RSSI) for each measurement point. In this case nominal RSSI values for diamond grade reflector are tested by Navitec and defined as a look-up table in Navitrol code. This means that scanner models in this category can be used for reflector detection only if tested by Navitec.

The look-up table in Navitrol defines optimal RSSI values for different distances. Optimal values are though not always realistic in real life. Therefore, Navitrol uses a lower relative threshold level for the decision whether a measured point is a reflector or not. This threshold level is defined by parameter reflector_rssi_min_ratio as the ratio (0.0 - 1.0) used for reflector detection. The picture below shows an example of such a look-up table, the blue line being the look-up table RSSI value as a function of detection distance (X-axis). The red line shows the threshold level used with parameter setting reflector_rssi_min_ratio = 0.75.

How to use

Reflector material

Diamond grade reflector material shall be used for reflectors. The reflector material recommended is 3M Diamond Grade DG Reflective Sheeting 4090 White. It is important that the microstructure/grooves are vertical; if not, the reflector will not work optimally. This material has proved to work well with all scanner types. One can also refer to scanner manufacturers recommendation for more details.

Reflector types supported

Navitrol supports two types of reflectors, round and flat. Triangle (two flat reflectors together) shaped reflectors are not supported.

For positioning purposes round and flat reflectors can be mixed. When a reflector can be seen only from a single direction, the flat shape is preferred. When a reflector is seen from different directions when the AGV is driving around, the round shape gives better results.

Reflector size

The recommended diameter/width of the reflector depends on many aspects, like scanner model used and maximum distances to reflectors. The generic recommendation is 5 - 10 cm. A quite common width used in low/mid-distance ranges is 5 cm.

Another important measure is the vertical length of the reflectors used. Tilting of the AGV results in scanner beams hitting the target at different heights. This height difference from the scanners mounting height depends on floor/AGV tilt angles and maximum distances from scanner to reflector.

Reflector mounting

Even on quite even floors some AGVs tend to swing noticeably while driving. If the reflectors are too short or mounted at a wrong height, the set of visible reflectors can change frequently while driving. This can have a negative impact on positioning performance.

With a top mounted scanner, reflectors should obviously be mounted so that the vertical mid-point of the reflector is on the same height as the scanner. With a scanner mounted very low, like a safety scanner, there is obviously no such option.

Reflectors for positioning

There are some aspects to consider when deciding the number and locations of reflectors used for positioning or position initialization. Some general things to take into account are:

  • Consider if reflectors are truly needed. Add reflectors only to areas where they are needed and provide additional value.
  • Reflectors should not be mounted too close to each other. Having reflectors too close to each other causes potential problems rather than solves them. The minimum recommended distance between two reflectors is 50 cm, preferably more.
  • Optimally at least 3 reflectors are seen at the same time. Less than 3 at a time can be used by Navitrol for positioning though.
  • More is not always better - use a reasonable number, well planned and well matching reflectors.
    • Pay attention to achievable geometries and distances between reflectors rather than just number of reflectors seen.
    • Make sure that reflectors on the map match with static features seen at the same time. If this is the case, the reflectors are presumably improving positioning performance. If the match is not good, the reflectors potentially disturb the positioning in certain areas.
  • Good geometry of the reflectors seen by the scanner(s) is the key to a solid performance. The geometry is good if the scanner sees reflectors in multiple directions, the angles between these directions being quite evenly distributed. For example, reflectors seen in one direction or in opposite directions only, do not provide a good geometry for positioning purposes. See Environment Guidelines for more information.

Reflector locations are added to the map as part of the map making process. Navithor Tools has the capability to automatically detect and add reflectors to the map. As mentioned, for optimal performance one should check that the reflector detections truly match with the static environment in the final map.

Generic parameters

There are plenty of feature specific parameters when it comes to using reflectors. The following includes only parameters common to all features.

NameData TypeDefault ValueComments
reflector_rssi_min_ratioFloat0.85Required RSSI value for reflector detection, when compared to optimal lookup table value.
Recommended initial values for different scanner models can be found in Scanner Configurations
scan_halo_angFloat1.5 deg m/sHalo angle in degrees around reflectors.
All measurements within this halo are effectively disabled.

Troubleshooting

Some generic issues related to reflector detection are listed below. In order to do successful troubleshooting, it is important to understand the way the scanner(s) in use detect reflectors (see "Scanners reflector detection").

Most common issues

Reflectors are not detected at all

  • Check if the scanner in use supports reflector detection.
  • Try detection with a reflector close to the scanner. Make sure that the scanner beam hits the reflector.
  • Check the reflector material in use, and it's orientation relative to the scanner.
  • If the detection is based on the RSSI value, check the value of parameter reflector_rssi_min_ratio. Try a smaller value.
  • Clean the scanner lens.

Reflectors are not detected reliably

  • Check the things mentioned in the previous checklist.
  • Check the mounting of the scanner and verify that it sees the reflectors - check that the scanner beam truly hits the reflector at all times. With a scanner mounted low, like a safety scanner, the scanner beam might occasionally hit the floor whenever the AGV is tilting and/or distances are large.
  • Check the length of the reflectors as well as their mounting height. Uneven floors cause tilting of the AVG, which may occasionally direct the scanner beam over or under the reflector. This can be improved by making the reflector long enough and mounted at the correct height.

Reflectors are not detected at larger distances

  • Check the things mentioned in previous checklists.
  • Try if wider reflectors would work better.
  • Try better scanner angular resolution when possible (Pepperl+Fuchs R2000).

Non-reflective targets are detected as reflectors

  • If detection is based on RSSI value, check the value of parameter reflector_rssi_min_ratio. Try larger value.

SSL/TLS connection setup and certificate creation

Updated 26.01.2024

Glossary

TermDescription
MMCMicrosoft management console
CNCommon Name
.crtCertificate file appendix
.csrCertificate signing request file appendix
.keyCertificate private key appendix
.pfxPersonal exchange format file appendix. Combination of private key (.key) and certificate file (.crt)

Overview

SSL support is currently implemented in Navitrol-Monitor, Navitrol-Navithor and Navithor-MES communication interfaces. It requires the support to be enabled by parameter on each end and the correct certificates to be installed. If only one end is configured to use encryption, connection can't be made.

The use of SSL aims at both encrypting the communications, so that it can not be eavesdropped, and identifying the communicating parties, so that unauthorized parties can not give commands or feed false information into the system. For this purpose, both ends are using certificates, signed by a common trusted root certificate. The different parties have a different common name in the certificate, which prevents stolen certificate from being used to communicate in another role in the system (eg. Navitrol certificate can't be used as Navithor).

This document gives instructions on how to create a root certificate and use that to sign the per-role certificates. It also explains how to install the certificate in windows (where it has to be done system-wide) and Linux (where it is local for only Navitrol). Relevant parameters are listed and some tips are given for debugging issues.

Create Root CA (Done once)

Create Root Key

Attention:this is the key used to sign the certificate requests, anyone holding this can sign certificates on your behalf. So keep it in a safe place!

openssl genrsa -out rootCA.key 4096

Create and self sign the Root Certificate

openssl req -x509 -new -nodes -key rootCA.key -sha256 -days 5024 -out rootCA.crt

Create a certificate

This procedure needs to be followed for each server/appliance that needs a trusted certificate from our CA

Create the certificate key

openssl genrsa -out example\_cert.key 2048

Create the signing request (csr)

The certificate signing request is where you specify the details for the certificate you want to generate. This request will be processed by the owner of the Root key (you in this case since you create it earlier) to generate the certificate.

Important: Please mind that while creating the signing request it is important to specify the Common Name providing the name for the service, otherwise the certificate cannot be verified. Navitrol server Common Name (CN) default is "Navitrol"

Openssl will ask you questions about the certificate to generate like the organization details and the Common Name(CN) that is normally the web address you are creating the certificate for. Navitrol instead uses the role of the machine as the common name.

openssl req -new -key example\_cert.key -out example\_cert.csr

Verify the csr's content

openssl req -in example\_cert.csr -noout -text

Generate the certificate using theexample_certcsr and key along with the CA Root key

openssl x509 -req -in example\_cert.csr -CA rootCA.crt -CAkey rootCA.key -CAcreateserial -out example\_cert.crt -days 5000 -sha256

Verify the certificate's content

openssl x509 -in example\_cert.crt -text -noout

Quick guide for creating root, client and server cert for Navitrol --- NavitrolMonitor communication

Create a folder /home/navitec/openSSLCerts in Debian.

Go inside this folder and follow the commands below.

  1. Create root key:
    openssl genrsa -out NavitecCA.key 4096

  2. Create and self sign root cert:
    openssl req -x509 -new -nodes -key NavitecCA.key -sha256 -days 5024 -out NavitecCA.crt

  3. Create the certificate private key for Navitrol:
    openssl genrsa -out agv.key 2048

  4. Create the signing csr for Navitrol:
    openssl req -new -sha256 -key agv.key -out agv.csr

  5. Verify the csr's content:
    openssl req -in agv.csr -noout -text

  6. Generate the Navitrol certificate by using csr and private key:
    openssl x509 -req -in agv.csr -CA NavitecCA.crt -CAkey NavitecCA.key -CAcreateserial -out agv.crt -days 5024 -sha256

  7. Verify Navitrol cert content:
    openssl x509 -in agv.crt -text -noout

  8. Create the certificate private key for NavitrolMonitor:
    openssl genrsa -out monitor.key 2048

  9. Create the signing csr for NavitrolMonitor:
    openssl req -new -sha256 -key monitor.key -out monitor.csr

  10. Verify the csr's content:
    openssl req -in monitor.csr -noout -text

  11. Generate the NavitrolMonitor certificate by using csr and private key:
    openssl x509 -req -in monitor.csr -CA NavitecCA.crt -CAkey NavitecCA.key -CAcreateserial -out monitor.crt -days 5024 -sha256

  12. Verify NavitrolMonitor cert content:
    openssl x509 -in monitor.crt -text -noout

  13. Change Navitrolmonitor key + cert .pfx file
    openssl pkcs12 -export -out monitor.pfx -inkey monitor.key -in monitor.crt

  14. Copy root cert and monitor cert (monitor.pfx) to Windows mmc

    1. add root cert (example NavitecCA.crt) under MMC Certificates/Trusted Root Certification Authorities/
    2. add monitor pfx cert (example monitor.pfx) under MMC Certificates/Personal/

Setting up SSL in Navitrol

1. Default setup

If you use the following names for the certificate files and don't set passwords for them, the setup is just these three steps:

  1. Set the ssl_enabled parameter to 1
  2. Copy the certificate and key with "Navitrol" common name on the AGV
  3. Copy the root certificate (but not the key) on the AGV
FileName
Navitrol certificate/home/navitec/agv_certs/agv.crt
Navitrol key/home/navitec/agv_certs/agv.key
The root certificate (that was used to sign the other keys)/home/navitec/agv_certs/root.crt

2. Extra steps if you don't use the default places for files

  1. Set the ssl_agv_certificate_file to the certificate file path
  2. Set the ssl_agv_key_file parameter to the key file path
  3. Set the ssl_ca_file parameter to point to the trusted root certificate

3. Other options

  1. If the key requires a password, set the password in ssl_pem_password parameter

SSL parameters in Navitrol

ParameterDescriptionDefault value
ssl_enabledWhether to use SSL to encrypt connections0
ssl_verify_server_certWhether to verify the certificate when Navitrol is connecting as a client1
ssl_verify_client_certWhether to verify the certificate when Navitrol is acting as a server0
ssl_agv_certificate_fileThe certificate the AGV uses to communicate
ssl_agv_key_fileThe key the AGV uses to communicate
ssl_pem_passwordPassword needed to unlock the key (if any)
ssl_ca_fileThe root certificate filename
ssl_cipher_listList of accepted cipher suites in preference orderLong list of defaults
ssl_dh_param_fileDiffie-Helman parameter file needed by some cipher suites. Needs to be pre-generated if those ciphers are used./home/navitec/dh_param_2048.pem

Example parameters:

## Secure communication parameters: Navitrol <-> NavitrolMonitor
I,ssl_enabled, 1
I,ssl_verify_server_cert, 1
I,ssl_verify_client_cert, 0
S,ssl_agv_certificate_file, /home/navitec/agv_certs/agv.crt #Navitrol private certificate
S,ssl_agv_key_file, /home/navitec/agv_certs/agv.key # certificate private key
S,ssl_ca_file, /home/navitec/agv_certs/NavitrolCA.crt # root cert
S,ssl_pem_password, navitrol # agv_certificate_file password

Common names CN for various roles

RoleCommon name
Fleet controlMCSServer
MonitorRemoteMonClient
AGVNavitrol
MESNavithorMES

Setting up SSL in Windows

Add root cert

Navitrol root certificate (NavitrolCA.crt) must be added to MMC so that SSL communication works between Navitec products.

  1. Open MMC

  2. Click File Add/Remove Snap-in...

  3. Choose certificates and then click Add

  4. Select "Computer account" and click Next

  5. Select Local computer and click Finish

  6. Press Ok to close "Add or Remove Snap-ins" pop-up window

  7. Now in your MMC view you should have a Certificates section. Navigate to Certificates/Trusted Root Certification Authorities/Certificates

  8. Click More Actions -> All tasks import

  9. Add root Cert (example NavitrolCA.crt)

I. Browse the Correct cert

II. Choose "Place all certificates in the following store"

III. Click finish

Adding a certificate

If two-way authentication is needed/wanted, a client-side certificate is needed also. This is the certificate for NavitrolMonitor or Navithor. MES interface does not require a client certificate to be sent. The certificate needs to be added under MMC Certificates/Personal/. In this example the client-side certificate is named monitor.pfx

  1. Open MMC

  2. Add Certificates Snap-in as Computer account local computer as done in Chapter 1.

  3. Navigate to Certificates/Personal/Certificates

  4. Import new certificate

  5. Browse and choose the .pfx file

  6. Type the certificate password if it had one

Server and Client certificate Common Names (CN)

By default, Navitrol/Server certificate (agvcrt) Common Name is Navitrol and Monitor certificate (monitor.pfx) CommonName is RemoteMonClient.

If these must be changed, do the following:

  1. Go to the folder where you have NavitrolMonitor

  2. Open Parameters.xml

  3. Search <ServerCommonName> and change the Server common name to match the server certificate common name (agv.crt Common name)

  4. Search <ClientCommonName> and change the Client common name to match the client certificate common name (monitor.pfx common name)

ParameterDescriptionDefault value
ServerCommonNameNavitrol certificate common name (must match to it, example agv.crt)Navitrol
ClientCommonNameMonitor side certificate common Name (Must match to it, example monitor.pfx)RemoteMonClient

Enabling SSL on NavitrolMonitor

Open NavitrolMonitor and click "SSL comms" to enable SSL. Make sure that Navitrol has SSL enabled as well and SSL certificates configured according to the image below

Enabling SSL on Navithor

Open settings in Navithor Client and set the following parameters in NavithorServer.exe.config to configure the wanted common names of the certificates. Certicates with the names must be placed into the certificate storage as described earlier in section 8. This must be done before server startup.

ParameterDescriptionDefault Value
secureSocketCertCommonNameCommon name of the certificate used by Navithor. Both when acting as server for MES or when connecting as a client to NavitrolMCSServer
secureSocketNavitrolCertNameCommon name of the certificate received from NavitrolNavitrol

Now that the common names are configured, you can choose to enable SSL communications from Navithor Client under TC parameters.

ParameterDescriptionDefault Value
Machine_CommunicationEncryptedEnables SSL in Navitrol-Navithor communication.false
MES_CommunicationEncryptedEnables SSL in Navithor-MES Interface communication.false

Troubleshooting

Navitrol SSL initialization

  • Check that you have root certificate, Navitrol certificate (agv.crt) and Navitrol certificate private key (agv.key). Also check that the paths of these are set correctly in params.txt. Check that SSL is enabled in parameters.

  • In addition to following log messages, errors originating from SSL library are logged as messages starting with CCSSL_LogError

Log messageCauseNote
OpenSSL initializedSSL library initialization was successfulContains the SSL library version, sometimes useful for debugging
Log messageCauseParameters
Client context created
Server context created		SSL is enabled and SSL certificates & ciphers were successfully set upssl_enabled
Log messageCauseParameters

Navitrol SSL connecting

  • When connecting with Monitor or fleet control, Navitrol acts as the server

  • Navitrol verifies the client certificate

  • Check that both ends have SSL enabled

  • In addition to following log messages, errors originating from SSL library are logged as messages starting with CCSSL_LogError

Log messageCauseParameters
SSL connection accepted using "SOME_CIPHER_NAME" cipherConnection was successfully established and the negotiated cipher was selectedssl_cipher_list
Log messageCause
Certificate name 'some_name' matchesThe client provided a certificate with the correct name

Navitrol Monitor SSL Authentication failed

  • If NavitrolMonitor is using SSL, but SSL is not enabled on Navitrol enable ssl_enabled parameter on Navitrol

Battery overtemperature actions

Updated 26.01.2024

Overview

Battery overtemperature actions can be used to perform an emergency unload followed by an emergency drive of predefined length straight forward in case battery overtemperature is detected when the AGV has load aboard. These emergency actions cannot be aborted as long as the battery overtemperature is active.

Figure 1: Overview of the battery overtemperature actions.

One might want to use this feature to move the AGV from under the load it carries to provide easier access to the overheated battery.

Important note: For this feature to function, the AGV must be operational regardless of the battery overtemperature.

How to use

Preconditions

  • Minimum software version requirements
    • Navitrol 6.38.00
  • A source, such as BMS or supervisor interface, for reporting battery overtemperature and/or battery temperature.
  • AGV that can drive straight forward after unloading a resource without colliding into it.
  • A safety system that stops the AGV, if the it would collide during the emergency drive.

Basics

Use case example:

  1. AGV is driving with a load when a battery management system (BMS) reports battery overtemperature.
  2. Navitrol stops the AGV
  3. Navitrol commands emergency unload to be performed
  4. Navitrol drives straight forward for a predefined distance
    • The drive distance and maximum speed can be configured with parameters
  5. Emergency persons can now access the battery department of the AGV

Set up

Add following parameters to desired values to the params.txt file
F,battery_overtemperature_drive_dist, 1.0 # Defines the overtemperature emergency drive distance. 0 = disabled
F,battery_overtemperature_drive_max_v, 0.4 # The maximum drive speed when driving forward from the resource after the unload

If one would use the temperature measurement from battery instead or in addition to overtemperature signal add following parameter
I,battery_high_temperature_error_limit_C, 100 # If battery temperature (Celsius) increases over the limit an error set. 0 = disabled, 127 = max

Troubleshooting

I defined the parameters but now Navitrol does not start

  1. Check that minimum software version defined in the "Preconditions"-section is fulfilled.

I have any other issue or the troubleshooting tips did not work for me

  1. Take a log covering the problem situation.
  2. Contact Navitec support and provide the log for further analyzation.

Charging and battery management

Updated 26.01.2024

Overview

This document explains charging logic and battery related information. Battery management systems (BMS) are also covered.

Introduction

Navitrol can monitor, log, relay and visualize battery information and perform opportunity charging. Navitrol can communicate with Battery Management Systems via Supervisor interface or via model specific CAN interface. Navitrol can receive charging commands from Navithor or Supervisor interface.

If searching for the battery overtemperature actions see Battery Overtemperature Actions document.

Requirements

  • Battery
  • Interface to send Navitrol the battery data

Dependencies

  • Charge type symbolic point, if charging is required.

Setup

Quick start

Set charge command source

Set the charging_cmd_source to value where the charging command should come. This means that what source is used to give the start charge action. The options are:

  1. Fleet control (Navithor or VDA5050)
  2. Oportunity Charging: Start charging whenever AGV is stopped at Charge type symbolic point
  3. BMS will give the command.

Set interface for communicating data to/from Navitrol

Set the extbatt_if_type parameter to correct value depending what interface is used to send battery data to Navitrol. The options are:

  1. Motor controller. Set extbatt_if_type parameter to -1. More information could be found from each motor controller manual. Supported motor controllers to sent battery data:
    • Schwarzmueller
    • Roboteq
    • Curtis. See Curtis document.
    • MiControl
    • Oriental
    • Ethercat Synapticon
  2. Supervisor interface. Can be used as a general communication protocol without committing to any BMS model. Set extbatt_if_type parameter to 5. With this setup, customer would need a PLC that communicates with the BMS or battery and sends the data to Navitrol via the supervisor interface. See Battery section 8 on the supervisor status message 3002 for more information: Supervisor Interface.
  3. BMS CAN interface for specific models. Ask Navitec about the CAN specification. The description of the extbatt_if_type parameter has list of what models Navitrol supports and what is the related value for this parameter. If Navitrol does not already have the interface for some model, that would require then custom development.
  4. Custom CAN interface. Set extbatt_if_type to -1. Some custom interfaces will send Navitrol the battery percentage or voltage or both. Contact Navitec if not sure if this applies to your project.

Navithor Tools

Add Charge type symbolic point to the route.

Charge symbolic point type on Navithor Tools.

Navithor

If using Navithor see the Managing Battery Levels chapter in Navithor document. Navithor can for example, give drive orders to Charge if battery level goes too low or it can keep always some amount of AGV in a Charge point.

Required parameters

NameTypeRecommended valueDescription
charging_cmd_sourceInt10 = disabled, 1 = fleet control (Navithor or VDA5050), 2 = opportunity charging (Start charging whenever AGV is inside Charge type symbolic point), 3 = external source (Supervisor or other BMS, see extbatt_if_type parameter), 4 = project specific (Customer specific CAN interface)
charging_prevents_drivingInt1When charging is active: 0 = driving allowed, 1 = driving preventented with soft stop
battery_level_knownInt11 to read battery percentage from external device (motor controller or bms), 0 to calculate it from battery voltage based on battery_voltage and battery_percentage parameters

Fine-tuning

Battery alert parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
battery_alert_fromInt0-1 no alert, 0 to alert from low voltage, 1 to alert from low battery percentage
battery_alert_percentageFloat5.0Percentage lower than this value will set alert
battery_alert_voltageFloat29.5Voltage lower than this value will set alert
battery_high_temperature_warning_limit_CInt0If battery temperature (Celcius) increases over the limit a warning set. 0 = disabled, 127 = max
battery_high_temperature_error_limit_CInt0If battery temperature (Celcius) increases over the limit an error set. 0 = disabled, 127 = max

General voltage parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
battery_voltage_gainFloat0.01Gain for updating the voltage. 1.0 = new voltage value is used without gain. Increase this parameter if voltage is updated too slow. Used like this: voltage = voltage + gain * (newVoltage - voltage)
battery_voltage_input_scaleFloat0.0Scale battery voltage input by multiplying with this value, 0.0 = do not scale.

Calculating percentage from voltage

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
battery_empty_voltageFloat24.0Limit to set percentage to 0. Used also to calculate new percentage value. Used only if battery_level_known is 0.
battery_voltage1Float25.4Voltage limit used to calculate percentage between battery_empty_voltage and this value. Used only if battery_level_known is 0.
battery_percentage1Float5.0Percentage value used to calculate percentage from voltage below battery_voltage1. Used only if battery_level_known is 0.
battery_voltage2Float26.85Voltage limit used to calculate percentage between battery_voltage2 and battery_full_voltage. Used only if battery_level_known is 0.
battery_percentage2Float60.0Percentage value used to calculate percentage from voltage above battery_voltage2. Used only if battery_level_known is 0.
battery_full_voltageFloat29.1Voltage limit to consider battery percentage to be 100%. Used only if battery_level_known is 0.

battery_log.txt related parameters

See Battery log chapter and parameters on the Logging document.

External Battery Management System parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
extbatt_if_typeInt-1External battery interface type: -1 = disabled, 0 = MasterVolt, 1 = SL BMS, 2 = Jungheinrich, 3 = RoboteQ, 4 = Voltabox, 5 = Ethernet Supervisor (message ID 3002 section 8), 6 = MEB battery, 7 = JLN, 8 = Wiferion
can_extbatt_if_node_idInt0Can node id for external battery interface
extbatt_if_max_interval_msInt10000Maximum update interval (ms)
can_extbatt_if_secondary_busInt00 = Primary CAN Bus, 1 = Secondary CAN Bus
log_bmsInt00 = no bms logging, 1 = Log external battery management system communication.

Opportunity charging parameters

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
charging_opp_min_at_charger_timer_msInt3000Timer for opportunity charging which defines how long vehicle has to stay in charging station before charging is requested

Customer specific parameters

These parameters are related only to customer specific interfaces. Ask Navitec if these are related to your project.

NameTypeDefault valueDescription
charge_request_interval_msInt1000Charger request interval in msecs
battery_update_interval_msInt1000Battery value update interval in msecs
charging_collector_arm_extend_optionInt0Onboard charger collector arm extend options. 0 = extend one side only, 1 = extend two sides separately

How to use

Sending only battery data to Navitrol without charging

Set these parameters:

  • charging_cmd_source to 0
  • extbatt_if_type to value where the data is sent to Navitrol. Use -1 if value is read directly from motor controller.
  • battery_level_known to 1

Check the Monitor main screen bottom to see if the values are received correctly to Navitrol.

Reading percentage values from voltage without charging

Set these parameters:

  • charging_cmd_source to 0
  • extbatt_if_type to value where the data is sent to Navitrol. Use -1 if value is read directly from motor controller.
  • battery_level_known to 0

Example charging sequence with Navithor and BMS connected to Navitrol via supervisor interface.

Set these parameters:

  • charging_cmd_source to 1
  • extbatt_if_type to 5
  • charging_prevents_driving to 1
  • battery_level_known to 1

  1. BMS send battery percentage to PLC.
  2. PLC send the percentage to Navitrol via supervisor interface.
  3. Battery percentage is sent to Navithor.
  4. Navithor will give drive order for the AGV to Charge symbolic point when battery percentage is too low.
  5. AGV will drive to the Charge symbolic point and Navitrol reports that AGV is at Charge symbolic point.
  6. Navithor request charging.
  7. Navitrol -> PLC: Charging required set to 1.
  8. PLC -> BMS: Charge start command sent.
  9. BMS -> PLC: Charge started.
  10. PLC -> Navitrol: Charging 1 (the AGV is charging). At this point, WARNING_CHARGING_ACTIVE is set.
  11. Navitrol -> PLC: Charging required 1, charging 1 (it still needs to charge and is charging).
  12. Navithor stops charge and want AGV to run production or battery status is full enough.
  13. Navitrol -> PLC: Charging required 0 while charging still 1.
  14. PLC -> BMS: Stop charging.
  15. BMS -> PLC: Charging stopped.
  16. PLC -> Navitrol: Charging 0. At this point, WARNING_CHARGING_ACTIVE is reset.
  17. Navitrol -> PLC: Charging 0.
  18. Navitrol -> Navithor: Charging stopped, Navithor can give drive order to the AGV.

Opportunity charging

AGV start charging whenever is at Charge type symbolic point. Can be enabled with charging_cmd_source as 2. AGV will start charging whenever it is

  • in Standby state
  • closer than symbol_point_enter_dist parameter from the Charge type symbolic point.
  • Has been in Standby for charging_opp_min_at_charger_timer_ms time.

Charging is active only if AGV has stayed at the Charge symbolic point and has been in Standby for this time period. If the state changes to Auto or Manual while AGV is charging, the charge is stopped and the charge is started again when the start conditions are met.

Monitor

Battery Manager Overview

Battery Manager Overview is a form in Monitor that shows Battery and Charging related data that Navitrol receives from the BMS. It is a useful tool for checking what is the status of battery or charging. By default, all the data is 0, but it should be updated once Navitrol receives the data from BMS.

Battery manager overview form.

Battery Manager Overview shows the following data:

  • Battery percentage
  • Battery voltage
  • Battery status in numerical and in text form
  • Battery errors in numerical and in text form
  • State of health in percentages
  • Current draw in Ampers
  • Charger voltage
  • Time left before battery is full in minutes
  • Voltage of the minimum cell
  • Battery temperature in Celsius degrees
  • Load cycles. How many times battery has loaded
  • Operating hours. How many hours the battery has run
  • Remaining capacity. How much Amper Hours the battery has.

Battery percentage and voltage

Battery percentage and voltage can be seen on the bottom of the Monitor main screen.

Troubleshooting

Most common issues

WARNING_AGV_LOW_BATTERY is active even though percentage is high enough

  • Check the percentage and voltage that they are shown correctly on bottom of the Monitor main screen. See chapter Monitor.
  • Check parameter battery_alert_from to see if the warning is set based on percentage or voltage.
  • Check parameter battery_level_known to see if Navitrol calculates the percentage or if it is received from external source.

Errors and warnings

639 - WARNING_CHARGING_ACTIVE

Description: Vehicle is stopped due to charging

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Navitrol with driving

Error reason: Vehicle is stopped with softstop because of charging. Set only if charging_prevents_driving is set to 1 and charging is active.

How to recover: Reset automatically when charging is finished. If stopping is undesired, check sensor status for charging.

520 - ERROR_BATTERY_HIGH_TEMPERATURE

Description: Battery temperature has exceeded the error limit

Error level: Error

Machine types: Navitrol with driving

Error reason: Battery temperature reported by battery management system (BMS) has exceeded the limit defined with a parameter battery_high_temperature_error_limit_C

How to recover: Let the battery cool down or modify the limit

601 - WARNING_AGV_LOW_BATTERY

Description: AGV battery level low

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Navitrol with driving

Error reason: Battery level is too low.

  • If battery_alert_from is 0, battery voltage is lower than battery_alert_voltage.
  • If battery_alert_from is 1, battery percentage is lower than battery_alert_percentage.

How to recover: Charge the battery

611 - WARNING_AGV_NO_BATTERY_LEVEL

Description: AGV battery level unknown

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Navitrol with driving

Error reason: Navitrol cannot read battery level. Two reasons:

  1. External bms initialization failed
    • CAN interface error. Check that node IDs are correct if using CAN interface. Check that extbatt_if_type is on correct value.
    • Check if there is this kind of log line: "ExtBattCanInit CanRegisterMsgDefs for node id". It will show what node ID has been failed to register.
  2. Timeout.
    • Data not received within extbatt_if_max_interval_ms time.

How to recover: Reset when data received within time or when initialization is successful. If it does not reset take a log and contact Navitec

635 - WARNING_BATTERY_FULL_CHARGE_NEEDED

Description: Battery needs a full (reference) charge

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Vehicles with external battery interface

Error reason: Too many load cycles without full charge. Related to Voltabox BMS only, see extbatt_if_type. Reference charge might be necessary, if battery has not been fully charged for a long time (30 load cycles).

How to recover: Battery charge to full capacity. Warning is reset when the status is cleared from Voltabox side. Check Voltabox specification for more information.

636 - WARNING_BATTERY_ERROR_OR_WARNING_ACTIVE

Description: Battery management has active error or warning

Error level: Warning

Machine types: Vehicles with external battery interface

Error reason: Used battery management system has an error

How to recover: Resolve error in battery management system

646 - WARNING_BATTERY_HIGH_TEMPERATURE

Description: Battery temperature has exceeded the warning limit.

Error level: warning

Machine types: Navitrol with driving

Error reason: Battery temperature reported by battery management system (BMS) has exceeded the limit defined with a parameter battery_high_temperature_warning_limit_C

How to recover: Let the battery cool down or modify the limit

921 - WARNING_EXT_BATTERY

Description: BatteryFaults bit received from customer CAN interface. Contact Navitec for more information.

Error level: Warning

Machine types: All vehicles

Error reason: Communication failure with external battery management system

How to recover: Reset when BatteryFaults bit is not received anymore.

Advanced troubleshooting

Here are some useful log lines related to battery and BMS:

"ExtBattData read, V 24.1 SoC 10.000 extraData 0"

  • External battery voltage and percentage. extraData tells if extra info is received.

"ExtBattData"

  • All external battery logging.

"Updated battery"

  • Current battery voltage and percentage in the system. Input values that Navitrol receives are in parenthesis. Useful logging if Navitrol should calculate the battery percentage from voltage (battery_level_known parameter 0).

"veh_inte_ethernet: Parse battery section"

  • Data that Navitrol receives from supervisor battery section. Logged only if log_veh_inte_eth is greater than 0.

"veh_inte_ethernet: Battery, pct: 50.0 current 24.0"

  • Percentage and current in Amperes that Navitrol sends to supervisor via battery secion.

Hardware requirements

Updated 13.03.2024

Overview

Navitrol IPC hardware requirements can be divided into two categories:

  • Generic requirements imposed by working environment and electrical and mechanical constraints.
  • Requirements imposed by Navitrol software - this means mainly resources needed by Navitrol (CPU, RAM, mass storage, connections) for robust operation and good performance.

Generic hardware requirements

Suitability for mobile use is the key for reliable operation. As working environments and target machines have huge variation, generic hardware requirements discussed in this section are rather things to take into consideration than detailed requirements.

Working environment

Working environments can be very different in different cases. Some things to consider and check when estimating suitability of the IPC are:

  • Working environment ambient temperatures.
  • Working environment ambient humidity levels.
  • Working environment dust levels and possible water or other liquid sprays.
  • Vibrations and shocks while driving.

If the IPC is supposed to withstand excessive dust levels or liquid sprays, then the enclosure of the IPC should be IP rated correspondingly. Another option is to mount IPC inside a protective enclosure, which may affect the cooling (see below).

Vibrations and shocks of some magnitude are unavoidable in mobile robots. Therefore, one generic requirement is that IPC should not have moving parts, like HDD's or fans. Additionally, all connectors used should have some form of locking mechanism.

Cooling

The IPC selected should have passive cooling like heat sinks and cooling through natural convection instead of fans. This approach mitigates potential issues caused by dust, vibrations, and maintenance complexities, ensuring consistent and efficient performance. Failure to cool down the CPU to acceptable temperature levels can in worst case result in CPU to shut down.

Mounting place of the IPC has significant impact on cooling. IPC should not be mounted next to excessive heat generating objects. Special attention should be paid also to cases where IPC is mounted inside a separate protective enclosure. In such a case the ventilation and cooling of this enclosure must be effective enough for the IPC cooling to work as expected.

Mounting - electrical/mechanical aspects

IPC form factor, mounting options and especially mounting place are something that require attention. Poorly selected mounting place introduces risks for

  • Inadequate cooling.
  • Extra vibrations that can result in premature malfunction of the IPC. IPC should always be mounted on a rigid body part of the machine. It is also important to assure enough free space for all connectors and cables.
  • Physical damage to IPC or connectors caused by collisions or people using IPC as a step when working on the machine.
  • Problems for maintenance if IPC itself and connectors are not easily accessible.

Input voltage range of the IPC, and it's compatibility with the machine's power system is one thing to check. For flexibility the IPC should have broad input voltage range, like 9 - 36V or 18 - 36V. If the IPC requires a regulated voltage source, that may require additional hardware to be installed.

Hardware requirements imposed by Navitrol

Additional notes about requirements imposed by Navitrol

Application

Navitrol IPC hardware requirements for CPU, RAM and mass storage capacity depend very much on the overall system in use as well as environmental factors.

When it comes to CPU, RAM and mass storage capacity, significant factors are for example the following:

  • Is Navitrol used for position only or controlling AGV.
  • What sensors are used. Especially the model and number of laser scanners used for positioning is significant factor.
  • Which Navitrol features are used. CPU intensive features matter the most. Features listed below are considered CPU intensive:
    • Dynamic mapping
    • 3D load detection
    • Obstacle avoidance V2
  • Linux installation details, especially whether graphical User Interface is installed and running (affects amount of RAM required).

CPU

Because the GHz value of a CPU doesn't describe the performance very well, CPU requirements are defined using specific Intel processor models as an example. These processors are the ones that have been used in Navitec standard IPC offering. When evaluating an IPC with some other CPU, and comparing those to ones used as examples, one can refer Passmark software CPU benchmarking on the web at https://www.cpubenchmark.net/. The key figure is then the Single thread rating that should match or exceed the ratings of the example CPUs. See table below:

CPUSpeedSingle thread ratingCPU Mark
Intel Celeron 2980U1.6 GHz9291056
Intel i3-6100U2.3 GHz13342639
Intel i5-6300U2.4 GHz16693240
Intel i3-1115G4E2.2 GHz26345912

Recommended single thread rating is higher than 1800 units and minimum clock speed is 2.2 GHz.

Mass storage

Solid State Drive (SSD) should always be used as a mass storage device for faster data access and more robust operation in mobile robots.

Scanners

Regarding scanners, requirements below use the following classification:

  • Low/medium resolution scanners scanners with angular resolution of 0.2 degrees or more.
  • High resolution scanners scanners with angular resolution smaller than 0.2 degrees.

Hardware Requirements - Navitrol positioning only

Minimum

  • Conditions - low/medium resolution scanners, max. Production area 200mx200m
  • CPU: 2 core Intel Celeron 2980U, 1.6 GHz
  • RAM: 4 GB
  • SSD: 16 GB, industrial grade

Recommended

  • Conditions - high resolution scanners
  • CPU: 2 core Intel i3-6100U, 2.3 GHz
  • RAM: 4 GB
  • SSD: 16 GB, industrial grade

Hardware Requirements - Navitrol controlling AGV

Minimum

  • Conditions - low/medium resolution scanners, no CPU intensive features used, max. Production area 100mx50m
  • CPU: 2 core Intel i3-6100, 2.3 GHz
  • RAM: 4 GB
  • SSD: 32 GB, industrial grade

Recommended

  • Conditions - high resolution scanners, any CPU intensive features used
  • CPU: 2 core Intel i3-1115G4E, 2.2 GHz
  • RAM: 16 GB
  • SSD: 128 GB, industrial grade

Connectivity

Basic connections needed in the IPC are

  • Gigabit Ethernet port(s) - preferably two or more.
  • Wi-Fi for remote connectivity.
  • SocketCAN compatible CAN interface if Navitrol should communicate via CAN to other devices. CAN interface is typically a separate add-on card mounted into IPC (see Expansion slots below).
  • Serial ports (RS232/RS422) on need basis serial communication has been used with some motor controllers, IMU units and scanners. RS232 serial communication is very prone to disturbances and cant be recommended for any device communication.
  • Expansion slots (1 or 2 PCIe slots) inside the IPC may be needed for potential hardware upgrades or additional functionalities. Most commonly used expansion card is CAN communication interface.

Running other SW in same IPC with Navitrol

It is recommended NOT to run additional customer SW in Navitrol IPC, as that can have negative impact on performance of positioning and control of the AGV.

In some cases, however, it may be necessary and justified to do so. If such additional SW is very "light-weight" when it comes to using resources, like CPU/RAM/Communication/Disk I/O, then it might be safe to run it without extra precaution. Responsibility on such a decision is obviously on end-user side.

General guidelines for running any additional SW in the Navitrol IPC along with Navitrol are:

CPU

  • CPU should have minimum 2 cores dedicated for Navitrol use only - basically this means CPU with 4 cores or more.
    • If several CPU intensive features are used, then 2 cores is not enough for Navitrol.
  • Single thread rating shall still match the basic requirements.
  • Additional SW shall be run in dedicated and pre-specified core. That core shall not be used by Navitrol (this can be excluded using Navitrol parameter cpu_core_exclusion_mask, see below).

RAM

  • RAM requirements by additional SW shall be added to basic requirements.

SSD / Disk I/O

  • Additional SW shall avoid or minimize reading/writing disk at run time.
  • SSD size requirements are affected only if additional SW uses extensive amount of disk space (several GB).

Communication by additional SW

  • WLAN/WiFi data throughput shall be minimal or not existing at all.
  • Wired Ethernet data throughput shall not be extensive.
  • Transmitting messages over CAN bus is not allowed without consulting Navitec. Poor CAN data object design may result in dramatic performance loss or even malfunction. NOTE: This applies also to CAN devices that are not used for positioning or control purposes.
  • Use of any other additional communication shall be consulted with Navitec.

If these guidelines are not followed, normal Navitrol operation and performance is compromized. In worst case, some of the following issues can happen:

  • Delayed processing or event handling in Navitrol can generate an ERROR, which results in stopping the AGV.
  • Communication slowed down or even communication breaks, causing sluggish operation of User Interfaces.
  • Filesystem corruption when power is switched off.
  • Navitrol running out of memory, which can result in Navitrol shutdown and restart.

How to control CPU cores used by Navitrol

Parameter cpu_core_exclusion_mask can be used to control which CPU cores Navitrol is using. This parameter, as the name implies, is an exclusion mask - any bit set means that corresponding CPU core shall not be used by Navitrol. For example, binary exclusion mask value 11b (decimal value 3), means that Navitrol will not use CPU cores 0 and 1.

U,cpu_core_exclusion_mask, 3

By default Navitrol allocates all available cores in use. Consult Navitec in case of any doubts how to set this in appropriate way.
